summary: Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) is an ambitious young jazz drummer, in pursuit of rising to the top of his elite music conservatory. Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), an instructor known for his terrifying teaching methods, discovers Andrew and transfers the aspiring drummer into the top jazz ensemble, forever changing the young man's life. But Andrew's passion to achieve perfection quickly spirals into obsession, as his ruthless teacher pushes him to the brink of his ability and his sanity.

reviews.content: Everything is perfect, but I highlight the sound mix, when the protagonist plays the drums and gets hurt, you feel it through your own veins! WOW!

The music, the script, and acting all phenomenal. Another iconic score. Truly and iconic and mesmerizing film. Damien Chazelle is just brilliant. Why did it take me so long to watch this. I literally don't know how to operate after watching this.

I reviewed the movie Whiplash. This is a movie starring J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller. The movie is about Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) who is an ambitious young jazz drummer, in pursuit of rising to the top of his elite music conservatory. Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), an instructor known for his terrifying teaching methods, discovers Andrew and transfers the aspiring drummer into the top jazz ensemble, forever changing the young man's life. But Andrew's passion to achieve perfection quickly spirals into obsession, as his ruthless teacher pushes him to the brink of his ability and his sanity. And as Andrew keeps pushing and pushing himself, he finally snaps. He charges at Fletcher and starts attacking him which leads to Fletcher getting fired from charges that students said about him. The students were saying he caused them harm physically and mentally. The story concludes with Andrew walking down the street when he sees a jazz club and looks at the sign they have posted by the door and it says Fletcher is performing. Andrew walks into the club where he meets Fletcher after his performance and Fletcher tells him he is starting a new jazz band and that they need a drummer that can play the collage notes he learned back when he was playing with Fletcher but when Andrew goes to perform fletcher deceives him and the band starts playing music that Andrew doesn't know so  Andrew finally snaps and takes over and the band starts playing the music Andrew was brought in to play. Andrew drums his heart out and that's when Andrew realized he finally became the drummer he was destined to be. Whiplash got a 94% on rotten tomatoes and got a 94%on what the audience thought this movie won five Oscars in 2015 for best sound mixing, best-supporting Actor, best film Editing, best-adapted Screenplay, and finally best picture. My thoughts of this movie were it was  phenomenal best acting I've ever seen. It truly tells a story. Miles Teller did a great job portraying Andrew. J.K. was one of the most menacing villains I've seen in a long time. And I'm surprised this didn't win best cinematography. The cinematography in this picture was outstanding, especially Andrew when he was practicing the drums, just seeing the sweat coming off the drums and his hands starting to bleed onto the drums just how they shot that scene was outstanding. In my opinion, I would give this movie a 9.9 out of 10.
One of the greatest films I have ever seen. Enjoyed this one ALOT. Coming from an up-coming drummer.
Everything about this movie is simply perfect. The acting is phenomenal and the story is brilliant. This seemingly simple drama constantly keeps you on your toes.

"Whiplash" is a gripping and intense film that leaves its audience on the edge of their seats from start to finish. Directed by Damien Chazelle, this critically acclaimed movie was released in 2014 and has since become a modern masterpiece.

The story centers around a young jazz drummer named Andrew Neiman, played brilliantly by Miles Teller, who is determined to become one of the greatest jazz musicians of his generation. Andrew is accepted into the prestigious Shaffer Conservatory, where he meets the enigmatic and ruthless jazz instructor Terence Fletcher, portrayed by J.K. Simmons in an Oscar-winning performance. Fletcher's teaching methods are harsh and unorthodox, as he pushes Andrew to his limits, demanding nothing short of perfection.

One of the standout features of "Whiplash" is the electrifying and soul-stirring jazz music that serves as the heartbeat of the film. The film's soundtrack, composed by Justin Hurwitz, is a masterpiece in itself, perfectly capturing the essence and intensity of jazz music. The music is flawlessly integrated into the narrative, adding depth and emotion to every scene, and elevating the film to a whole new level.

The performances in "Whiplash" are nothing short of extraordinary. Miles Teller delivers a career-defining performance as Andrew, portraying the character's unwavering determination and internal struggles with incredible authenticity. J.K. Simmons is a force to be reckoned with as Fletcher, exuding an imposing presence and an air of unpredictability that keeps the audience on their toes.

The screenplay of "Whiplash" is sharp and tightly woven, with a perfect balance between drama and suspense. The film delves into the toxic relationship between student and teacher, exploring themes of ambition, obsession, and sacrifice. It raises thought-provoking questions about the price of greatness and the lengths one is willing to go to achieve it.

The direction by Damien Chazelle is masterful, creating a palpable tension throughout the film that is both exhilarating and nerve-wracking. The camera work is dynamic and immersive, capturing the rhythm and intensity of the jazz performances with precision. Chazelle's meticulous attention to detail is evident in every frame, making "Whiplash" a visual and auditory feast for the senses.

In addition to its technical excellence, "Whiplash" is also a thought-provoking exploration of the human psyche, examining the dark and often destructive side of ambition and the pursuit of excellence. It's a film that lingers in the mind long after the credits roll, sparking conversations and reflections on the nature of art, mentorship, and the sacrifices we make in pursuit of our dreams.

Not a jazz aficionado. But love music and this has plenty of toe tapping rhythm. JK Simmons is a favorite of mine. There is truth to trauma creating great art and neuropathways. I felt one thing was missing from this movie was a scene to really hit home how wrong the "monster" was. A simple meeting with the school where they informed him that they hired him to teach the students without emotionally damaging them and if he wanted to "mold" and manipulate the next best jazz great he could do it on his own time and with his own liability. telling him teaching does not require "belittling" a student to greatness so he can stroke his ego. Just a little more of that would have helped the audience understand how big this monster was and the ending would of been that much more satisfying

Great movie!  Very compelling.  I applaud the creators for making something that is riveting and suspenseful while at the same time is down to earth without a large budget or special effects, etc.  We all have that teacher in our past that everyone was afraid of and graded hard, and this touches that nerve.  Additionally, with the short burst practice and yelling sessions, the audience gets instant feedback into 'is the drumming good or not?' without really knowing anything (or in my case, even caring) about music.  The movie isn't about music.  It is about driving to greatness and what you have to sacrifice for that.
On the down side, I don't know how that guy ever had a teaching job.  And the ending was sloppy.  Why did Nieman agree to do it?  Why didn't they ever even have one practice?  Why didn't the band revolt?
Solid movie. Not spectacular but worth watching. Worth your time.

During my examination days, I once said while carrying my failed literature test,  "Art is subjective, literature is too, there's no standard answer to a piece of creativity." While most movies have their assumed ending, Whiplash is the only movie I've seen that gave two perspectives that actually makes a lot of sense. 

The obsession for greatness, and Happiness, are the two polar opposites shown in this movie, and one's values will deeply affect how one sees this movie in a motivational film or a tragedy film. 

As a motivational film, Whiplash has everything a great motivational film needs; intense, emotional scenes, impressive editing, and strong dialogue between two characters who strive for excellence. Nearly everything Andrew Neiman did in the film since his arrival at Fletcher's Studio band has the intention to be the best, trying to meet Fletcher's standards, but was constantly beaten down. In the end, even facing a career-ending performance that was set up by Fletcher, Andrew returned, and did not just perform, he impressed the one man who is his greatest hindrance and reached excellence. Truly an awesome motivational film.  From a perspective like this, one will see that a man can reach greatness with an immense work ethic and extremely strong resilience. 

But on the other hand, some people view Whiplash's ending tragically. In the end, Andrew is under the spell of Fletcher, as he finally becomes the "Charlie Parker" Fletcher longed for.  

Before Fletcher, Andrew is already obsessed with his drumming, he stated he doesn't need friends, and he quickly discharged his thought on dating Nicole once he realized he need to practice more and he will stay up all night with messed up bloody hands just to get his part on "Caravan", but when even he was broken by Terence Fletcher, it is shown how Fletcher is as a person, he broke the mind of the obsessed and he has no intention of positivity for Andrew until Andrew proved himself. While Andrew himself tried to return to his normal life by calling Nicole, returning to his home and failed, only had one way out, proving himself on the big stage with his music career on the line. But in the end, Andrew still proved himself, he chose greatness over his humanity, and that is a choice. Something with no right answer. 

 The clear cue is shown already early in the dinner table scene, when Andrew states "I rather die drunk, broke and die in 34 and have people at the dinner table to talk about him than be rich, sober at 90 and nobody remembers who I was." 

And to me, Whiplash is a motivational film, I am moved by the amazing editing and the interaction between Andrew and Fletcher, they are both striving for excellence, and obsessed with music. The jazz pieces are amazing and the ending scene is one of the greatest redemption scenes I have ever seen. 

But only one's values decide what Whiplash wanted to present.

I am out of words and I haven't even spoken yet. In terms of genre its the best of its kind no doubt about it. In terms of acting I see pure gold. JK Simmons just delivered the best piece of acting I have probably ever seen no doubt about it. This character was scary and unphased but just when you believe this character isn't All that. The soft cloudy image you may have of him becomes a dark poisoned fog. The Best thing about the character wasn't even how scary he can be its the fact that what he says is the straight up truth, he understands how the world works far beyond other which is what makes him great. The fact that he doesn't get recognized for the work he puts backstage alone represents how people truly just look at the presentation rather than the story of the presenter. The main character himself was deceived by him throughout the Film. Lets talk about the ending, that is some of the best music I have heard and it was just a joy to watch. A phenomenon! The only Criticism I have is the undeveloped story of Nicole. I love how She was there mainly to represents the main characters confidence level throughout the movie as when he got into fletchers band he asked her out and when he became core member he became too cocky even so in the end but that's where it hit him that others have a life too and its not revolved around just him. Although these are all positives the fact that the members of the family has as little role as that is where I hoped for more. Two NFL 3rd league players who are always talked positively about versus a talented hardworking drummer who is always criticised. Would've been great to show who's on top but at the same time the ending was too perfect and there was no room for that. 9.9/10 overall

As it relates to reviews on Rotten Tomatoes, I have seen consensus that Whiplash is one of the greatest films, of which I agree. However, I have seen other reviews of the film on the internet, saying that the film is nothing more than a bullying teacher and a talented drummer. I am here to explain my thoughts on why that is incorrect and to hopefully persuade one viewer who may have read those reviews and has or has not seen the film but in any case agrees with those standings. Whiplash, starring Miles Teller as Andrew Neiman and J.K. Simmons starring as Terrence Fletcher is a film about being the greatest by whatever means possible, and a teacher wanting to develop the greatest musician to ever be. The part of the film I believe most people have a problem with is all the violence and "unrealistic" anger of Fletcher onto Neiman. These scenes in the film, however, may not be the most realistic but do set the stage for Neiman to want to become the greatest drummer of all time. The film takes you through the struggles on that journey and what one must give up to be the greatest, and what a teacher must do and put his students through to eventually create and curate the greatest musician to have ever lived. While the film may be a hard watch for those who do not believe what musicians will go through to be the best, any person who knows music and a person who can appreciate what it takes to be the best knows that the film creates a feeling of greatness through impeccable acting, incredible drumming, and immersive atmosphere through the short one hour twenty minute "epoch" of Andrew Neiman aspiring to be the best drummer to ever live. Whiplash earns itself a first and solid 100% from me. I urge each person to watch this film, and experience all it has to offer, which is a lot.

I considered myself a Damien Chazelle fan after only seeing La La Land. I knew I needed to see Whiplash at some point, and I have both a snow day from Northwest ISD and a 30-day free trial of Showtime to thank for introducing me to one of my new favorite movies ever. The story was so incredibly gripping thanks to amazing performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. Simmons in particular was masterful; I don't think I've ever been more fearful of a character than I was of Terence Fletcher, and maybe that's because I'm a music student and I'm scarred in my own special ways, but I don't care. I was on the edge of my seat from start to finish, and the last 20 minutes put my jaw on the floor. Chazelle depicts the descent into madness so well, both with his cinematography and the dialogue. The soundtrack was so well-tailored to this movie, and I was very pleased to discover that Justin Hurwitz wrote the score. He was great in La La Land (Mia and Sebastian's Theme, anyone?), so I was happy to learn that he and Chazelle are all buddy-buddy. While I still favor La La Land by a hair, Whiplash is incredible. I love Damien Chazelle, and I'm ready for Babylon, no matter what the critics say.

Massive bullying and abuse that was nauseating. My wife and I both couldn't bear it- we had to stop watching after 20 minutes. There is no room for this type of behaviour in modern society. American cinema must stop its love affair with bullying. Bullying is a frequent theme and trope in American movies and TV. 85% of high school shooters suffered severe bullying, so it's time to root bullying out of film and television (other than to rightly demonise it). To glorify abuse and bullying in this manner is unacceptable. It's not a sign of genius, it's a sign of an incomplete life.

It has an element of mystery and allows you to fill in your own lines with certain things and it has such a rich soundtrack and tells a sad and wonderfully beautiful story that many might be able to relate to. It personally helped me appreciate my place in life a lot more than i did going into it. Its a very easily accessible movie as well, as you can watch it for free right now on Youtube. Some other things that are worth bringing up is the character of Fletcher and the actor J.K. Simmons as well as Miles Teller and his character of Andrew. The two main characters. Miles Teller actually performs most of the drumming in the movie himself, he was the perfect choice to play the role of Andrew, and the character Fletcher is easily one of my favorite villains in cinematic history. Ive watched this movie 3 times in a row and that is because of my fascination with Fletcher. I can't really decide whether to appreciate him for pushing Andrew to the point of absolute success, or hate him for destroying Andrews life in the process. Nevertheless the movie tells a beautiful story about how absolute success requires so much loss, and the question you must ask yourself by the end of the movie is; is it really even worth it?

Jazz may not be for everyone, but god damn this movie will make you love it. Whiplash is a prime example of how a film can be a masterpiece without having the need for hundreds of millions of dollars and 20 different sets. This movie is simple, but is remembered by the performances, J.K. Simmons may easily have played one of the most terrifying villains. His acting is remarkable, as he is able to go from teddy bear nice guy, to in your face drill sergeant in a second which is hard to do for a lot of actors but he does it like its another Tuesday. Miles Teller was also great in this, as he makes you feel for his character throughout the film as he try's to simply get what a lot of real life people want, and that's recognition for commitment. The music, omg THE MUSIC!!! It is easily one of the most enjoyable parts of the film especially when you get to the climax, the final song of the film is perfect, right down to the last note on the page. Overall a masterpiece of a film and kudos to the Academy for rarely making a good decision and giving J.K. Simmons the Oscar he rightfully deserves, 3, 2, 1, lets jam.

The breakout for damien chazelle and a reminder of Simmons' talent. Whiplash is an electric motion picture from one of the most promising filmmakers working today. Whilst the anwsers to the questions the film poses are not the right ones, this is understood by filmmakers and explored in a ferocious and unapologetic means that only heightens the movie's insane energy and tense atmosphere. Whiplash is a simple premise, especially compared to the oversaturation of franchises we face today, yet manages to seem all the more important in today's climate, with it's demand for only the best and most significant art. Whiplash fits that category.

It explores an abusive relationship between mentor and apprentice, and how the abuser tries to justify his behaviour through the failings or victories of his pupil. It also plays with the idea that genious is always permeated with a touch of madness. 

The movie keeps a tension that builds until the last moment and keeps the viewer in the edge of their seat. Some moments were almost unwatchable because they made me so nervous, but I think that's what's so incredible about it.

Ultimately the teacher is a more of a villain than inspirational, but you will feel conflicted by the end of it. If you look at someone like George S Patton the famous American WW2 general, he was an awful person, the ultimate warmonger that saw war as just a sport. 
But he was also a tough bastard that was needed as an inspirational leader for a terrible time in  history - what I'm meaning is he was the right person for the job at the right time. You don't have to like him but he helped in the eventual victory. Likewise Fletcher, as loathsome and abusive as he was you can't deny that he pushed Andrew far beyond what he thought he could do, as demonstrated at the end of the film.

An Insane Up-close and Personal Nerve Rattling Ride. A Chazelle Picture Comes to Life.

Nava Medikonda | 4/5 Rating

Damien Chazelle has created a Jazz movie, one that reflects the struggle for musician's and their livelihood.

Whiplash hinges itself as a love story between Andrew(Miles Teller) and Fletcher(JK Simmons). We are taken through a rough story that only becomes more crazy as time passes, ups and downs, its a perfect ride.

The films opening scene starts with the 2 most important characters of the film, and their perspectives on what a good drummer should be. Fletcher has an interest in meeting Andrew after he catches Andrew practicing the drums. The personality of Fletcher's darker side is already introduced, and Andrew's desire to impress is quickly obvious.

The goal of Miles Teller in the film is to become "one of the greats," and JK Simmons in the film has the goal of "pushing beyond the expected of a musician."

Teller's character is easily a great setup because we understand his desire to become a great drummer, and we know and get snippets from his life, other than his passion for drumming. On the other hand, Simmons's character lacks the story of his own life outside "teaching." This effect puts a viewer to question why Fletcher is so ambitiously bashing of his drummers, and the other musician's in the story. His character comes off as an evil villain trying to push an artist to their fullest potential, even though that may not seem obvious at first.

The art of the "cut" in Whiplash is extraordinarily fast paced, and a tension bringing illusion. The films editing is brilliant, and Tom Cross the film editor makes sure the audience is hooked to the screen.

We are continuously told the same message throughout the story to "not give up." Andrew's luck may or may not be the worst, and his situation may, or may not be fair, but the story strives to tell the message, take chances when given the opportunity. Do not hide behind who you are trying to be, and do what you want to do, how you want to do it.

An astounding performance is given by Teller and Simmons. Teller portrays what it feels like to be an aspiring musician, and Simmons portrays exactly how a demanding abusing mentor would act.

Damien Chazelles film is a film that is rare to come across. Its easily the "one of a kind" like film. The film was shot in 19 days, and a ARRI ALEXA "Digital" Camera was used, alongside a Canon EOS-7D Camera and Angenieux Optimo Zoom Lenses, and a few more unique lenses.

Words aren't the right way to describe Whiplash. Its a cinematic pleasure. The film is impressive, and an audience won't get bored while watching it, the performance, the cutting, the sound, the music, the lighting, and the directional style all contribute to making this fantastic film. It is truly a movie that should be watched in theaters.

As for director Damien Chazelle, Whiplash has become his first film that gas gotten so much recognition, and its extremely understandable why. This film deserves to be called one of the greats, and its storytelling style in screenplay and the motion picture itself has awards coming its way.

The final performance in the film is exactly what the audience wanted to see, something unexpected, something that was impressive. Even after Andrew was thrown out of his music school, Fletcher was too thrown out shortly after. As the two meet up again, Fletcher offers Andrew a favor, playing in front of people who can potentially change his life. Andrew uses this opportunity to show off his skills, and Fletcher knowing Andrew as a great drummer, helps him do that. In the end, we don't see Fletcher as a sabotaging abuser who wants to crush a musicians dream, but someone who was trying to push a musician to greatness, to becoming great.

The films story is strongly a simple one, but the more connections a viewer makes, the more complex and personal it will get. The movie is entertaining, and watching JK, and Miles, for a short 1 hour and 46 minutes, it feel much shorter.

Whiplash is a hidden gem amongst us. Telling the story of a new-coming drummer and an actually scary abusive antagonist. The acting from Miles Teller as well as the revered J.K. Simmons is amazing. While having no exact rhythm or sense made up for it, the color scheme is wildly under-appreciated and is what I think made the movie stand out as much as it did. The soundtrack is also great and is an example for how good a movie can be just based of the soundtrack. The fact that about 40% of the soundtrack is Miles Teller's actual drumming is awesome. Overall, this is a great movie that I can see becoming a classing in the near future.

Whiplash is an intense thriller with brilliant acting from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. The movie tells a profound message about achieving one's goals. However, it is violent and contains several accounts of emotional abuse (-1 stars). 

SPOILERS: In a nutshell, Whiplash explores how far one can go to become "one of the greats," in which the conductor, Terence Fletcher, strongly believes in pushing the musicians as far as possible to find the next "great musician." He verbally attacks the students, hurls objects around the practice room, and breaks several things (which I found distressing). Additionally, the main character Andrew wants to fulfill his dream of becoming "one of the greats" and does whatever it takes to stay in Terence's band. Consequently, he neglects his physical and mental well-being to meet Terence's strict standards. He gives up on romantic relations and dedicates his time to drumming. The movie ends on a cliffhanger, and we cannot see Andrew's success/failure as a drummer. Understandably, this could have been deliberate to make the audience think about the relationship between Andrew and Terence. Even after the conflict between the two characters, Andrew may have finally gotten approval from Terence after his impressive drum performance.

Essentially a conventional plot, but there is so much that sets it apart as one of the best films of its decade. The performances, the script, and the direction are of course essential to its success, as is the economic run-time. But for me what really makes it sing is the way the movie's whole craft - but especially the editing and cinematography - cast it more as an action film than as something more conventional for the plot's structure. Almost everything to do with music in the film is cast with military/action overtones and the result is adrenalised, breathless, and thrilling - with a romantic subplot that's also suffused with heart and soul. All of this means that when a character falls, trips or some other genuine physical incident, it leaps off the screen and grabs the viewer with an intense impact that is missing in many genuine action films. A question at the film's heart  - if the relationship between teacher and pupil is bullying, abusive or inspirational  - is left tantalisingly unresolved, in the care of the viewer meaning this is a film for heart, soul, and mind.

Nominated for five Oscars, and winning three (editing, sound and Best Supporting Actor, with nominations for screenplay and Best picture), 'Whiplash' is positively blistering, with a darker and more realistic view on aspirations and done in a way that's tense and inspirational.

Visually, 'Whiplash' looks great with grittily atmospheric photography with plenty of beautiful, gripping shots (like close-ups of the drum playing) and some of the tightest, cleverest and most audacious editing of any film that year. The sound is also thrilling in its intense authenticity, and really add to the impact of the pulse-racing Jazz soundtrack. There is in particular unbelievable drum playing that serves as a fond reminder of iconic drum players of the classic Jazz Age, the final drum solo is long but exhilaratingly played and a huge part of why the ending sends up a storm as much as it does.

The script is sharp and cutting, sometimes uncompromising and at other points patient. The story is not new, but makes a point of aspirations and talent having its dark and less glamorous side, competitiveness and that there are always obstacles (including dictatorial bullies). While not quite as extreme in life as shown here situations and people like seen in the film exist. The story is at its most successful in its tension between Andrew and Fletcher, which is thrilling and nail-biting, and Andrew's very relatable and inspiring drive and passion, and much of it is very taut and rarely laborious in pace.

Damian Chazelle directs with a clear love for film and the jazz style and passion for the subject. 'Whiplash' has great performances all round. The secondary cast do much with little and Miles Teller more than holds his own in a telling lead performance. This is JK Simmons' film however, proving that his Oscar win was one of that year's most deserved wins. He doesn't just dominate the film with his ruthless manner as a terrifyingly dictatorial character, but actually IS essentially the film, one's terrified of him but also understands his point of view.

'Whiplash' could have been slightly better this said. Most of the supporting cast, especially Andrew's family (the film at least tries to say why the romance was rushed and dropped, in that it didn't mean anything to him like his playing of music did), are severely underwritten and underused. The car crash scene and the aftermath also feels out-of-kilter and even the most committed musician wouldn't be in the right function to do what happens after that scene.

Otherwise, this is a blisteringly great film with a huge amount to recommend. 9/10 Bethany Cox

In the end, "Whiplash" emerges as a one-trick pony, notable for gimmicks more so than depth.

Whiplash (2014) takes a familiar core story, but with its musical elements creates a fascinating story that feels entirely unique as it dives deeper into becoming a musician. The film stars Miles Teller who doesn't have too much development outside of his passion, as it shows that his objective to succeed at drumming has taken over his life, both physically and mentally. He is supported by J.K. Simmons who proves why he deserved that Oscar for this role with such a terrifying performance. At first he appears as a strict teacher with sympathy for new and young students, but as time passes you realise he uses that kindness so that people open up to him, only for him to strike them where they're vulnerable. That switch from insane aggression to a (fake) sympathetic mentor highlights Simmons' fantastic range as when he's at his worst (in a good way) he makes the viewer nervous.

Teller's characters drive to be the best he possibly can be is captivating as you see the lengths he goes to be the best, with physical damage getting involved. The rivalry (of sorts) that Teller and Simmons develop is both tense and thrilling as the outcome could be so unexpected.

While Whiplash (2014) is a fantastic film with a engaging story, the main standout from it is J.K. Simmons performance, which deservedly won him an Oscar.

A tour de force of direction and an outstanding cast make this story of a sadistic music teacher and a driven pupil a "not to be missed" film. Simmons and Teller command the screen as they combat each other, leading to a climactic ending.

There truly are both no words to explain how good this movie is and thousands of words to explain how good this movie is. I'll start with the cast. J.K. Simmons is... holy fuck. His performance is one of the best of his career and of the 2010s. The energy he brings when Fletcher is manic is intense, and the wholesomeness he delivers is phenomenal. The psychology of Fletcher is complex and fascinating. There is no simple term for what he suffers from. Miles Teller performs the best in his current career. We beautifully see his transformation from his anti-social awkwardness and existential crises to his full-on sociopathic dedication to his success and his refusal to want to hate Fletcher and the need for approval from him. This is possibly one of the greatest portrayals of a sociopath in cinema history. For those who aren't fully educated on what a true sociopath is (thanks to our flawed education system), it is most likely not what you are thinking. Sociaptthy has barely any connections to psychopathy. The personality disorder is called ASPD (Anti-social Personality Disorder) and I recommend looking into it further if you are fascinated by Andrew Neiman. Enough with the cast, the pacing in this movie is a masterclass. The 2nd act feels like 4 hours that went by in 20 minutes but was actually 1 hour, probably a very confusing sentence but if you've seen the film you'd understand. The editing is *chef kiss*. The lighting is phenomenal, every scene feels like you are in a world tour jazz competition. The directing is unique and on key and is Damien Chazelle's best writing-directing credit he will most likely ever have. I'll wrap up this review by saying, I was shocked when I saw the Blumhouse intro in the beginning, and at the end, I think I realized why Jason Blum produced this; this is a horror film, the horrors of our real-world; the horrors of emotional abuse and untamed mental health; this film made my brain cry. Watch this film or you will be a potato.

The way this film is so beautiful and breath-taking. It's one of those rare masterpieces, where each scene feels like a work of art in a gallery. J.K. Simmons is so brilliant in this movie, he perfectly captures his character so well. He breathes fire into this film. The final scene may well be the silkiest and most beautiful end to a film ever.

An irrefutable masterpiece — framing the chase of greatness and the travails that triumph necessitates. This film mashes the brutality of competitiveness in ones field and the scrupulosity that takes place in the process of standing out, and performing to virtual perfection. Memorable across the board, viewers will be highly absorbed — beautiful cinematography, a screenplay that's etched itself in cinema rapport and show-stopping acting performances by Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons, has exhibited how the intensity and vigor of ones obsession of perfection is taken to great lengths narratively speaking. Important philosophical themes are piquantly sparked — asking audiences 'What moral boundaries can be crossed in order to achieve success?' and 'Is mental health and emotional relationships an automatic trade-off for the process of chasing greatness?'. This themes are further interpolated amongst the exploration of characters' motives — an uncomplicated concept that further delves interestingly complex ideas and a web of conversation.

Andrew Niemann will do anything to be the greatest jazz drummer in the world. We meet Andrew at the start of the film starting his first year at Shaffer Conservatory of Music, a school which we are told is the best school of music in the United States. Despite not coming from any great artists or creatives, with his father being a moderately successful English teacher and failed writer, Andrew has made it here and is awaiting his moment to push up to the top. That moment comes in the form of the chance meeting with the teacher in charge of the best students at Shaffer Terence Fletcher. After this chance encounter with Fletcher in one of the practice rooms, Andrew is asked to join Fletcher in his studio band as an alternate drummer. After joining Andrew quickly realizes that Fletcher operates with violence and intimidation to push his students to achieve the best possible. Fletcher leaves every student for themselves to fight to the top in a very aggressive and cutthroat classroom and band. Despite all this Andrew takes this opportunity exited to push himself to be the best and achieve his goal. He will have to figure out what he is willing to sacrifice to achieve his goals.

Whiplash is a wonderful depiction of an artist pushing to achieve greatness at any cost. This depiction is done through masterfully crafted cinematography, soundtrack, and the great performances of both Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. To begin with Miles Tellers' performance as Andrew Niemann, a worse actor would have made the mistake of letting Andrew grow to confidant whenever success is achieved Teller, however, holds any sense of complete confidence off until the very conclusion of the move making that climax all the more satisfying. He allows for a small spark of passion to shine through the initial insecurity to give the audience something to take interest in and for Fletcher to feed off of and push. Now onto Simmons as Fletcher, with less dedication and intensity a less skillful actor could have butchered the part. Fletcher needs to be both the god and the devil in the film, he needs to give all the opportunities for Andrew to take advantage of and he needs to be the one to break Andrew down and keep him from falling into complacency. An actor who does not fully commit to being this would lose the interest of the audience early on. Now we can look at how the two actors, and in turn their characters, interact to help create such a good story. Alone Andrew would not be able to push himself to be the best, for better or for worse he needs someone to push him past the point of sanity and normal behavior to become the best in the world. A similar issue applies to Fletcher he himself is in a sense a failure he is not the best in the world nor has he produced his Charlie Parker, he is waiting for someone like Andrew to come by, he is waiting for someone with the right amount of passion to achieve greatness but with the insecurity to be easily manipulated. This is where the greatness of each actor's performance is shown the way each of the actors creates characters that play so well together both pushing to the limit of sanity to achieve their respective goals, Andrew to be the best, and Fletcher to produce the best. The final thing to look at in the things that go together to create this film would be the cinematography and editing and soundtrack. Whiplash creates a certain intimacy with the characters in times of tension with very close angle shots giving the audience nothing to look at and think about but the emotions of the characters. The filming also focuses heavily on putting the audience on stage with the characters you are not viewing the cation from the point of view of the true audience more a fly on the wall in the classroom or on stage. This gives the audience access to a part of the performance that is not usually seen. The editing and soundtrack also play well together with the camera's cutting and panning with the rhythm of the music. 

Every film however is not without its faults and Whiplash is no exception to this. To begin the injuries attained from practicing so hard by Andrew are hard to believe unless he is practicing with very poor technique, why would one of the better drummers at the top music school in the united states have such poor technique. This film is also not the most gentle to watch it earns every inch of its R rating. It makes no attempt to make either Andrew or Fletcher good or compelling in a positive light, there is an understanding that both are selfish and see themselves as better than everyone else. This can be abrasive to some viewers, typical underdog stories will try to make us like the main character to root for them. However, when watching parts of this film it can almost be described as a car crash, with Andrew slowly losing his humanity and sanity to pushing himself to become the best, one watches with almost morbid curiosity. This aggressiveness with which it approaches the subject makes it almost impossible to relate to the characters this to some will remove most interest from the film as it can feel like your watching someone almost fetishize the process of an artist losing their humidity for their work. Another thing that one must really suspend disbelief for when watching this film is the behavior of Fletcher. It can be hard to believe that the best music school in the country would let their top instructor throw chairs and scream slurs at the drop of a coin. It can be even harder to see the students at said school going through all this with such complacency as to not make any form of complaint.

Whiplash is such a rare movie, an impressive technical achievement and a triumph when it comes to direction and acting. The movie follows an aspiring jazz drummer called Andrew, who is finally accepted into a prestigious conservatory. He is given a chance to participate in the conservatory's big jazz band by its BD, Terrence Fletcher. What he does not know is that Fletcher is a dream crushing, abusing, relentless, perfectionist person, willing to get Andrew to great lenghts if that means his band's success in competitions and Andrew's psychological and physical destruction. That leads to a love-hate relationship (mostly hate) between the teacher and the student. 
Starting with the technical aspects of the film, it is hard to finish watching this movie without admiring its wonderful editing, that successfully gives a lot of scenes their tension and terrifying nature. Its sound design is also worthy of praise, considering this is a movie about music. Cinematography is also pretty amazing and the simplicity of the makeup and costumes really fits every scene and situation.
I actually felt really satisfied with the screenplay, as a musician myself. Most movies would have turned such concept/ premise into a joyful, dumb, prodigy-achieves-his-dream musical. But Damien Chazelle showed that the world of music is equally aggressive and relentless as any other working enviroment and that striving for perfection is something you cannot avoid, despite that meaning that the musician should sacrifice his mental and physical health and even put an end to his social life and relationships. My only problem is that, as a musician, I have never come across such authoritarian and evil BDs like Fletcher. It is quite impossible ans wrong, in my opinion, to be such a @sshole to other musicians, when in the end, the joy of playing music is totally gone, and replaced with fear of mistakes and mechanical, scared playing. Not even professional orchestras are that oppressive and terrifying for a musician to work at, let alone a conservatory jazz band. And even if a BD is that much of a perfectionist, that does not mean he should mess with his musicians psychologically and physically, that is a literal felony. That is the only problem I have with the movie, that I don't think an actually conductor would throw a seat at his drummer just because.
Despite that, I will also give lavish praise to the two leads. Miles Teller is a very talented actor, and it shows in this movie. His movements, his actions, his interactions, are totally how a full time musician dedicated to his craft would act everyday. And J.K. Simmons, oh my god... I firmly believe that J,K, Simmons' performance in this film is in my Top 3 of all time. I love him in this movie. Sometimes I just watch the movie for him alone. He is so terrifying inn every scene, even if he is not meant to. His darkly comedic comments on his musicians' "uselessness" never fail to make me laugh, yet quickly shift to terror, simply because of hsi apperance and the fact that he capable of more than we can comprehend. His performance is a very sttrong 10/10 for me.
Overall, I will say that Whiplash, despite some liberties it took and exaggerated, overblown stereotypes about the band, that cannot really exist in real life, Whiplash, is amust watch for its tense direction, fascinating screenplay and premise about the world of music and its performances that will be remembered for years to come. Rushing or dragging?
My favorite movie of all time.

Instantly one of my favorite movies, so interesting and intense and just beautiful to watch. Extraordinarily well written characters, perfect pace and development, and great music too.
Just overwhelming.

A film that continues to escalate. It poses big questions about the sacrifices people make to be great at something, but also what we're willing to put up with from others to pursue our own self-interest.
If some real life conductor was as rude and ----- as the one in this film, how long would it have been this till someone KO's him?

A film about abuse veiled as a necessary tool for perfection. Having experienced abuse at the hands of a conservatory teacher myself, I can understand where this film is coming from, but, the homophobic angle of this film was unnecessary. The drumming scenes were captivating, the acting good, etc... but this comes across to me as yet another film that capitalises on stereotypes of the gay community. Not good.
Amazing story about personal drive regardless of what other think. Incredible, and unrelenting.

Utterly perfect in almost every way, Whiplash is truly something special in the realms of direction, writing and of course acting, and delivers what is to be considered one of the greatest movies of the last decade.
Bomb-ass Movie!!! Top ten movies for me.

After spending a career playing quirky and interesting characters in bit parts, JK Simmons hits his stride as the mercurial and despotic music instructor in Damien Chazelle's Whiplash, the story of dreams and desire and how they manifest themselves.  Miles Teller plays Andrew Neyman, an aspiring drummer attending the best music school in America.  He is recruited into the top jazz band by Terence Fletcher, alternately inspired and destroyed by the maniacal teaching techniques of the instructor.  All of the accolades bestowed on Simmons are warranted as his electric performance has to be seen to be believed.  The dialogue in the film is crisp and insightful, the editing in the final music sequence is brilliant, and the twists at the final performance are inspiring.

Now this is a masterpiece. This was the 4th time I'd seen Whiplash, and I remained stressed and on tenterhooks for the duration. It remains Damien Chazelle's best film, and would have been a much more worthy multiple Oscar winner in my book than his 2016 big winner La La Land. Whiplash follows the trials of Miles Teller (playing Andrew) who didn't get anywhere near enough recognition for his part in this beauty, an aspiring drummer at Shaffer conservatory, desperate to impress the near tyrant like conductor Terence Fletcher (an Oscar winning J.K Simmons). That is pretty much it, but in terms of musical brutality, this will have you wincing at the screen (I've done a lot of wincing at the screen this week it seems) and almost watching through your fingers in your desperation for Andrew to be accepted. The last twenty minutes of the film are as nail biting and astounding as any thriller, turning a piece of music into a scene of torture whilst retaining the beauty of the sound and the visuals in a vortex of utterly brilliant film making. Original, compelling, and wonderfully acted, this is one of the best films of the 10's without any shadow of a doubt. 
Whiplash is curently available on BBC Iplayer.

Damien Chazelle doing what he does best: creating modern classics centering around jazz.

Check out the full review: 

https://neoncamerareviews.blogspot.com/2021/08/whiplash-2014.html?m=1

This film does what all films should do, which is entertain the audience.  Sure, JK Simmons character would not last more than a day at a real school, but he gives a great performance (essentially channeling his Oz character) in this Full Metal Jacket homage.  Great stuff!!!

I think that this would be hard to upstage if tried to make anything like it. There was such a buildup of emotion through out the film that you don't know how to feel or how to read their emotions by the end. It is the edge of insanity through music.
This is why cinephiles watch movies.

Whiplash has everything to be an awesome movie: The story, the direction, the soundtrack and the performances (in the case of J.K Simmons just increddible).
Also, the film doesn't make any mistakes. The only problem that I found was that at the beginning I did not emphatize with the main character.

It's an incredibly well made movie and extremely well acted. There isn't much of anything I can say bad about it. I'm glad I watched it however it wasn't as captivating for me personally as I am sure it is for many others out there. Still something everyone should see once however as a fan of film.
Really good movie but tbh a little too stressful for me. I caved and spoiled it for myself 15 mins form the end cause the anxiety was too much.
This movie is as close to perfection as it can get. Just watch this movie, that's all I can say!
As a drummer, I got a great deal out of seeing this movie. Fantastic filmmaking and acting, well worth seeing, and should be compulsory viewing for anyone who plays drums.

The first time I watched this movie, I thought it was missing something. Either I didn't like the love story, or the colors were off, or maybe it was the long last scene. I originally gave this film a 4.5/5. Now, the things that I thought made the movie bad, might be the things that I love about this movie. Damien Chazelle did amazing with this film. It was a snub that this didn't win (WHY BIRDMAN???) because this is amazing. Miles Teller was scammed of an Oscar nomination (He wouldn't have won because of the amazing performance by Eddie Redmayne in The Theory of Everything, but know I am getting off track), but J.K. Simmons did amazing. His performance is one of, if not the best supporting actor performance in the history of films. Also, I didn't notice until my third watch that Fletcher was saying Andrews last name wrong the whole time! That makes it even better!

This movie is one of the most enjoyable films I have ever seen but it still manages to tackle deep themes. It is a masterpiece in storytelling that keeps you engaged the entire time. This movie is so impactful and emotional throughout that it leaves you thinking about for hours after it's over. It's one of the best films of all time.

My favorite movie of all time. JK Simmons puts on one of the best performances I've ever seen. The way he can intimidate, but also deliver hilarious one liners. I can easily say that the ending of this movie is the most satisfying ending I've ever watched.
The musical is high, the movie is intense. But I didn't find this movie encourage, instead there is full of revenge by the teacher. A setup in order to lose performance in front of the big audience.

I remember the first time I saw Whiplash, I was completely blown away. There were very few films I'd seen beforehand that made me feel that way, and very few since. Every time I watch it, it just seems to get better and better.

Music is one of my biggest passions, both listening and playing, so this film just hits me harder. Director Damien Chazelle is also a musician, having previously had ambitions to become a jazz drummer before pursuing filmmaking. Indeed, his experiences in his high school band directly influenced various aspects of this film. You can definitely feel that individual passion and experience behind this film.

The intricacies of music are shown to great effect via the technical aspects of the film. The editing and sound mixing make you feel every single beat of the drum and every note played by the band. The intensity and passion of the musical pieces just oozes from the screen with every shot. I've never seen music so perfectly portrayed on film before.

JK Simmons is phenomenal and terrifying as Terrence Fletcher, the abusive bandleader whose attempts to push his students to the absolute limits of their abilities pushes the line between inspiration and abuse. I love how nuanced his character is. He could easily be presented as a simple bad guy, but we get to see his point of view and gain an understanding of why he does what he does. It makes you think about the costs of obsession and the things you have to lose in the pursuit of perfection.

Really, I think every aspect of this film is perfect and it will remain my number one recommended film for the foreseeable future. I don't have a negative thing to say about it whatsoever. Please watch it if you haven't yet.
Movies have flaws........this movie does not. Hard to watch at times because of how intense and real the acting felt. Intense is an understatement for this movie.

I love this film and have seen it five or six times now, but it's not perfect and therefore doesn't deserve 5 stars. The plot and characters are well written and believable besides the fact that Fletcher would have never kept his job that long. Miles and Fletcher both made fantastic main characters, although not much was said about the secondary characters. However, there are apparently technical inaccuracies in terms of the music theory/terminology - e.g. asking people to count in BMP makes no sense. That, for me, is a big letdown. Some of the dialogue from the background characters also felt a little unrealistic, but perhaps American university students actually talk about such topics like that. On the other hand, the acting, cinematography, visual effects, editing, and soundtrack are all on point throughout, with the exception of the low budget truck collision CGI. Massive respect for Miles Teller for learning jazz drumming for the role as well. In sum, there are lots of memorable scenes, there's funny dialogue, and the film is unique. It's well worth a watch and a rewatch.
Wow that's intense, insanity, hard works, sweats & bloods, you won't survive a day without determination. Enjoy every minute of it, absolutely brilliant! Muak!
Fantastic. It's a sports movie with a jazz drummer standing in for the QB, PG, boxer, etc. JK Simmons at his best. Efficient plotting and direction.

I am just gonna say that this in my opinion was a masterpiece. I loved every second of the movie, the music fits in perfectly into every scene. Absolutely amazing performance by J.K Simmons and Miles Teller. I am so glad that I watched this movie. My favorite part was the way that they ended the movie, it ended with a bang. It shows all the blood, sweat, and tear that goes into becoming one of the greats. I would recommend everyone to watch it once.

If describing this to someone I would say it's ‘School of Rock' meets ‘Full Metal Jacket.'  Not to be cliche, if for nothing else - the drum solo.  My biggest problem with this is I wish I'd found it first or at least sooner than 2021.

Deep, dark and enjoyable, "Whiplash" offers what most philosophical Hollywood films can't: Enjoyment through raw culture. The sound, the light and J. K's performance are enough to put this film on repeat and just lose the sense of time. You'll be missing out on art if you do not watch this film.

Small note: This is THE greatest movie ending in Hollywood history, bar none.

The character development was phenomenal, acting performance was fantastic, and the detail to the choreography was spotless. Couldn’t have been more intrigued the whole time watching this masterpiece.
This movie has amazing performances. Miles Teller is very overlooked in this movie, he deserves so much more creds.
Despite the outstanding performances, Whiplash drumms on about too much to really appeal to anyone outside of the scene

I am completely speechless.
One of the most incredibly moving movies ever made. The film isn't just about music, but it serves as a powerful message to people that no matter what happens, you can never give up and pursue their dreams.
A gold star for Simmons and Teller's outstanding performances.
Intense, focused on the pressure that Andrew feels and the manipulation Fletcher imposes on him, makes the music really pop out to you.

As a story taking place in the world of music, nothing has struck me as matching the combined realism and drama that Whiplash achieved. I was fairly satisfied with La La Land and slightly bored by First Man, but Chazelle proved himself a great storyteller capable of coaxing the best performances out of talented actors in this one. The freneticism, anxiety, and general madness all comes through to create a truly affecting experience.

Miles Teller does fine, But J.K. Simmons makes the film, for me. He takes a character that could easily have been a one-dimensional villain with a character arc that we have all seen hundreds of times before, but Simmons plays Fletcher with a brilliant nuance and balance that makes you despise him like Andrew whilst respecting him all the same. Not many characters successfully encapsulate this duality.

The story offers few surprises. While the musical sequences are impressive, the ending was a bit oversweet from the tone of the whole piece. Perhaps it is Andrew's imagination or perhaps the world arranged itself to lift him up perfectly, but it seemed weak. In this film, though, you have to search for flaws buried in its strengths, of which there are many.
Intense and powerfully acted by J.K. and Tellers, Damien Chazelle's debut feature setts of an exciting future for the director.
Great Movie! Iconic performance by JK Simmons that earned him a well deserved Best Supporting Actor Oscar.  Even smug face Miles Teller is pretty good in the lead.
Daft and objectionable.  Take-home message is that vile bullying is justified if it brings out transcendent performances.  Oh, and you can tell when a drummer is any good because their hands bleed.
Riveting. Edge of your seat. Heart pounding. Gut wrenching. Brilliance!

A gritty story about a talented percussionist who finds himself pushed to the point of madness by a brutal student mentor. Forced to give up any social life to achieve his dream of becoming the lead drummer in the top ensemble of his college, Andrew finds himself in conflict with a sadistic , perfectionist who pushes his students beyond the limits of their capabilities. This film is so well shot , edited and acted it is easy to see why it was not only nominated but won multiple Awards.

Whiplash is one of the most powerful films that I have seen in a long time. The sheer emotion and power it is able to effectively convey is simply extraordinary. J.K Simmons Performance goes unrivalled by anyone else, and his character is just as well written as it is acted. Miles Teller is also great, and helps to amplify the chemistry between himself and Simmons. Director Damien Chazelle greatly captures the physical and mental toll that Fletcher's psychological ‘torture' begins to show on Andrew, using a variety of film techniques. The brilliant writing is capable of capturing the true extent of Fletcher's evil humour, brilliance and his scarce humanity. Chazelle also demonstrates an exceptional ability to edit and direct the rapid paced and high tension segments of the film, which is able to effectively engage and relate the viewer to Andrew and Fletcher's dysfunctional and at times crazed relationship, maintaining the pacing and never inducing a disinterest or boredom. Also some great visual shots during the the high impact tension scenes, which help ground the audience during these sequences. Also, (to no surprise) no musical choices are phenomenal, from the funky stuff displayed throughout the performance scenes, to the eery and well placed sounds that help amplify an important or tense sequence. All of these significant pieces come together to form a truly well-realised Thriller that will keep you engaged from the opening credits. It may very well be the epitome of an 'edge of your seat' Thriller, one could even describe it as a masterpiece.
10/10
Whiplash has a surprising, but worthwhile intensity thanks to stellar performances by Simmons and Teller.

Simmons

I love music, but I don't take this movie as one about music. I see a kid and a teacher striving to be great and find greatness. We should all have this trait and it has motivated me as well. One of my favorite movies I've ever seen.

Andrew Niemann is a promising young drummer has dreams of becoming a great  jazz musician. So he enrolls and is accepted into the best school for music in the country, Shaffer Conservatory of Music. Entrance into the school also means Andrew has a chance of entering the tutelage of Terrance Fletcher, the studio band teacher and head of the band that represents the school in jazz competitions. Fletcher is highly regarded for his skill in anything jazz and teaching talents, also a man with a ruthless reputation for his certain teaching methods. Fletcher is known to bring the best ability out of his students but that is achieved by the intimidation and belittling of his students as he strives for perfection each and every note no exceptions, this creates a pretty hostile environment that not many can endure. Andrew sticks with this as he has no musical pedigree and he believes this may be his only chance to truly prove his worth. While the tension is always unbearable Andrew will quite literally stop at nothing to achieve his goal, blood, callused hands, & car crashes be damned.  


I was pleasantly surprised the first time i saw this film, an exciting drumming movie!  The on screen connection between Miles Teller & J.K. Simmons is very strong and the movie really sets out to portray a very tense vibe between the two. Very inventive cinematic elements with color and camera work that really gives this film a whole Jazz feel to it. The plot and script leave a little to be desired but the incredibly real drumming talent Miles Teller has makes up for that along with Simmons' very intimidating nature you really focus on those two grippingly. Never before have we seen Jazz on screen with such visceral beauty.
This movie was great! So intense! J.K Simmons gave an incredible performance! Miles Teller too!

This is a pity, since things like these do happen, but the way this movie was made makes it seem a total fairytale. I am genuinely surprised by how well this movie was received and how many people bought the very unbelievable storytelling. Also paints a very odd picture of music studies and weirdly credits the crazy nazi-style teacher in the end. Was deeply disappointed.
well acted and pleasant to watch

Overall, Whiplash is a fantastic story regarding the ambition people have for the dream passions. The performances from Miles Teller and J. K. Simmons encapsulate this premise superbly, they are terrific. Damien Chazelle has fast become one of my favourite directors not just today but ever. La La Land was the film that made me fall in love with movies, but wow Whiplash is absolutely extraordinary! There was simply nothing to dislike about this, it's rightfully on IMDB's Top 250 ever and it's one I'd instantly recommend, go treat yourself!

Quote - "I was there to push people beyond what's expected of them. I believe that's an absolute necessity." - Fletcher

Rating - 5/5

It is one of the worst and most disappointing films I have seen recently. The biggest problem is with the non-existent plot and thin characters. All we see is that foul mouthed teacher and ambitious student at never ending rehearsals. Other band members just turn up, play then leave. It's not really clear why he picks on the drummer(s). Fletcher is just written for the Oscar: he is shouting, swearing, hitting and has the best, clever lines in the film. Writer/director Damien Chazelle adapted this from his own short film and it should have only been a short film. This is because Whiplash doesn't have the right elements to be called an accomplished film. It doesn't explore the character's desire for music. A silly and pointless girlfriend line that never develops. Almost nobody in the band talks, they only stare or only comment, "Don't touch my folder". Either Damien Chazelle doesn't know how to write a proper dialogue apart from swearing or couldn't be bothered to write something with real meaning. In the last 30 minutes of the film we are presented with a storyline about a previous student of Fletcher's who killed himself. From that point nothing in the film makes sense. Characters' choices and the way they act in the final few scenes is really unbelievable and silly.
An inspiring and entertaining music drama with a young director in awe of his craft and wonderful performances in the process, particularly a magnetic one from J.K Simmons

An absolute marvel of a film with J.K Simons and Miles Teller at the helm, putting on their best performances to date. An inspiring tale with a truly jaw-dropping ending that’ll have you at the edge of your seat, biting your nails. A must see film.

The fact that this was low-budget, wasn't originally given funding, and was turned around relatively quickly, is testament to the sheer passion and dedication of the creative team behind it. An incredible achievement

One of the movies that has a strong purely powerful drama full of energy.
As a musician, I was awestruck by this. As a filmmaker, I was in love with this.

Stunningly Breathtaking. The movie is filled with suspense of the best kind, emotional suspense. We feel as we are on a personal journey with Andrew(Miles Teller) as he navigates his way through the tough world of music. It makes the story all the more rewarding. Anybody who wants to see a quality film should definitely watch this movie.

In my opinion a 21st-century masterpiece

While some side-moments could have been better, this intense film is almost a masterpiece. JK Simmons plays an intense Music Professor in one of his best roles ever. Don't get even 1 bpm off with him.

The whole trope of "psycho hard-ass teacher who does nothing but degrade and yell at students" is overdone and unrealistic. I'm not the biggest jazz fan and music doesn't touch me the way others are apparently touched by it. So the music didn't do anything for me. Absolute must see, and always can watch again, beauty of a movie. Wouldn't change a thing and the ending is even better.
This film in many ways defined my experience studying jazz at the university level. If you want a film about jazz that underscores the unrelenting scrutiny of music education, look no further.

The two best things that Whiplash has going for it are the two main characters and the actors playing them (Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons). This film writes its characters so brilliantly in how their motives and personalities work off of each other that it turns the most lackluster concept for a movie into a thrilling roller coaster ride.

It's hard to watch, but something to be experienced and creates great conversations with other adults and older teens about what it takes to be "the best" and if that's something that is both worth it, and ethical.

Loved it! Kept me glued throughout. One of the most intense films I've seen in a long time and will definitely recommend to friends. The fact that there were only really two characters to the whole story, everyone else just merely filing in space, did not detract from the mesmerising story of one young man's dream to be the best drummer, and an older man's passion, albeit brought to us in an unconventional, mean, scary and most of the time, just plain horrible way, to bring out the best in his students. The chemistry and connection between these two characters had me from the start, and I found myself holding my breath and even clenching my fists during the final scene, completely enchanted by the talent and emotion. Beautiful, mesmerising, intense, emotional... a big thumbs up from me. Not giving it five stars only because, as much as I loved it, I'm not sure it's a film I would want to watch over and over again, but I definitely would watch it maybe once more.

Great film. No room for character development outside the protagonist/antagonist dynamic. But that's the point. Nothing else matters except the goal, the dream they share. Everything else - friends, family, fingers - is secondary to the music and the search for greatness. The Teller is great, but the vascular Simmons is awesome. Anyone hoping for a cuddly Juno's dad will be disappointed. Briefly. Then they'll decide that if only they'd had a teacher like Terence Fletcher then they'd probably be the next Charlie Parker.
This film was really intense, don't know what type of genra to put it in 😂
Real good. A must watch.
Whiplash is a perfect movie.  And a perfect storm.

Whiplash is a movie full of suspence, emotions and great music.
Electrifying AF! J.K. Simmons delivers one of all time best supporting performances. WHIPLASH 9.25
A brilliant movie about bringing up the genius within everybody: you will find yourself watching the last 10 minutes over and over again. BTW, the music is otherworldly.
An outrageously extraordinary movie with amazing acting from Miles Teller and J.K Simmons, had a unique story, and had one hell of a finale.

Whiplash is an amazing, thrilling experience that brings to light a dark side of creativity, of art. We always envision art as a beautiful thing that comes out of bright place, and we think of artists as open, interesting people. Damien Chazelle takes that idea and crushes it with a story that is almost the complete opposite.

Whiplash is all about breaking expectations and creating suspense, as well as generating sympathy for the main character, in an environment where we wouldn't expect unforgiveness. Fletcher is ruthless and he's obsessed with perfection. Most artists agree that "perfect" would be nice, but it's ultimately impossible. Damien Chazelle was able to take that idea of such a hyperbole, and he put it on the big screen in a narrative that can't look away from. 

The environment of the film is one of the best aspects of it. The creative choice to have this movie center around the drums speaks volumes not only narratively but cinematically. What better instrument than a literal instrument which so much power and drive and force and VOLUME and impact. It was a brilliant choice and the movie couldn't have better in another environment, especially with the characters that were placed in them.

It is only fitting that Whiplash pits these two powerhouse characters both obsessed with perfection. A student who wants to be the best being worked by a teacher who wants the best. It's a pseudo-Jekyll-and-Hyde foil that only gets stronger and more dangerous even after the climax of the film. 

The very end of the film may be the best part about it, when we get to see the main character finally stand up to Fletcher on the stage. All the power struggles between the two characters leads up to this exciting back-and-forth that Chazelle executes beautifully. The movie definitely could've ended with the ball in either Andrew or Fletcher's court, but it didn't. The choice for them to be in it together was most likely a difficult choice, but it was a very good one.

Whiplash is an amalgamation of this somewhat exaggerated experience of being an artist, and creates a visually pleasing, cinematically captivating, and ultimately breathtaking experience.
But sometimes people need to be scolded these days.
The movie is breathtaking , one of the best movies that deal with artistic ambition ,reaching your potential and craziness.

An incredibly terrifying performance by J.K. Simmons, you will never look at J. Jonah Jameson again after seeing J.K. roar obscenities and throw chairs at his student's head. Incredibly real performances along with a heart dropping twist make this simple movie about drumming feel like a horror film, in the best and most unique way possible.

While utterly ridiculous, Whiplash is an extreme, suffocating film that almost surely  leaves you furious at nearly every character in the film. It manages this on the shoulders of mesmerizing performances from its cast, and intelligent camera work from its crew. JK Simmons earned his Oscar for this role.
A wolf in sheep's clothing.

Whiplash is like a circus sideshow. Its theatrics strive to make it "real"--but fail. Apart from contrived attempts at shocking its audience, the story and plot are boring, redundant and monotonous. I simply could not care about its main characters. The teacher was all about himself. The main drummer was a sucker. He could have changed his school and teacher if he really planned to be a jazz great. The film might have benefited from a dramatic change of pace. Why not show that previous(distraught) student in the act of killing himself? Anyway, the movie did not work for me.

BRILLIANT!!! Whiplash is one of the most artistic films of the 2010s. With great performances, a realistic story and an  
Powerful ending. I 100% RECOMMEND THIS FILM!!!

A powerful, well-crafted, intense, inspiring and thrilling music drama that's a raw and brutal exploration of artistic ambition, psychological and mental abuse, and obsession. It has a dazzling editing, excellent soundtrack, a brilliant and stylish direction from Daniel Chazelle, and career-best performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons.

I love music but have never been a big fan of jazz, so I wasn't sure before sitting down to watch this movie. It's an intense joy of a film and you just want Andrew to absolutely nail it. This movie also looks and sounds utterly stunning, I am now a fan of this musical style which surprises me greatly.
one of my favorites. amazing performances. makes you think!

Occasionally there comes a film that challenges its viewers to delve deeper into the human psyche. Such films are a necessity in today's fast paced society, as they raise philosophical questions and provide valuable insight; items that are integral to our self-development. Whiplash presents several central questions to all who aspire to rise to the top of their passions: How far can an individual push themselves? How much is an individual willing to sacrifice in the pursuit of greatness? The film gives a glimpse into the life of Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller); an aspiring drummer attending an elite music conservatory in the heart of New York City, later gaining the attention of the school's renowned and elite jazz band conductor Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons). Neiman's character is shy, introverted, and seemingly out of place in a school where everyone seems to know each other. This is contrasted by Fletcher's authoritative, demanding, and unrelenting nature. The film dives deep into the relationship between mentor and protégé, as Fletcher pushes Neiman to the limits both physically and psychologically in an attempt to mold the next great jazz drummer. The character arcs are fantastically done, and the storyline is very well paced. The film wastes no time setting the tone, as the opening scene immediately sets a tense aura, as Fletcher's character does a fine job conveying a sense of dominance and ruthlessness, while Neiman's character conveys insignificance and submission. Three main acts are present in the film, each showing where the protagonist is on his quest to be the greatest jazz drummer of all time. Damien Chazelle portrays this journey brilliantly, using clever lighting in crucial scenes and fast-paced camerawork to convey a sense of urgency and chaos. Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons portray their respective characters with vigorous passion, providing life into Neiman and Simmons' relationship. Shots of blood, sweat, and tears remind viewers that greatness comes at a cost, and to persevere requires dedication and courage. Whiplash is an electrifying and captivating piece of satire; a testament to what perseverance and determination can achieve. Terence Fletcher is a personified dramatization of the age-old adage of pushing ourselves beyond what is expected. Whiplash is fundamental viewing for mentors and students alike, as it challenges viewers to relate the messages portrayed in the film to their own pursuits. It is a film that deserves recognition for years to come, as its core message will remain relevant so long as humanity continues to exist.
