A phenomenal film that exposes some wonderfully nuanced layers behind a couple of electrifying performances. To this note, the performances of Teller and Simmons manage to marry two distinct characters, in which polarizing differences unfold into a relationship of shared affinities. The resulting affect is a film that, no matter how uncomfortable it makes us feel (and it brings out some intense emotions), we are left with a profound tension between the positive and negative impact of this relationship, a confusion of where the line (a question that is posed near the end of the film) of right and wrong sits, of what is helpful and harmful. And ultimately it is this dynamic that allows this film's powerful exploration of the cutthroat nature of elite music training/competition to become a commentary on the larger human tendency to struggle with excellence and failure, healthy obsessions with perfection and controlled success. The strongest poetic symbol of this tension comes in Fletcher's (Simmons) insistent declaration that, "The most dangerous two words in the english language are 'Good Job'".
Standing above the marriage of these two performances is a raw and honest film direction that mirrors the frenzied movement of the music itself. The pace and positioning of the camera work uses angles to give us added perception to the dramatic interplay between characters. It interprets a scenes emotions through a mix of close ups (at time allowing the vision of a slight grimace to portray more than words, at others allowing the instrument itself to carry the dialogue). And the back and forth movement between the increasing emotional interplay between student and teacher is captured through camera work that sits almost slightly behind or ahead of the scene itself ("Are you dragging or are you rushing!", as Fletcher would say).
There are so many powerful moments in this film. It tells the story of a young aspiring jazz musician (drummer) attempting to make it in an elite music school. It centres around the relationship that sparks between student and a popular teacher. However, this relationship sheds light on the students (Neyman) own relationship with his past and upbringing, his father and the loss of his mother, his inability to get out of the shadow of the successes of his siblings (and others). There is an absolutely wonderful scene around a supper table in which Neyman is left to defend the sort of subjective nature of success as a musician (to perhaps the more measurable success that comes in other fields). The illumination of this subjective nature only pushes him towards a more concrete notion of his goal, which is expressed so incredibly well in another wonderful scene between him and his girlfriend through which he articulates exactly what success looks like (another transition point in the film).
My personal reaction to this film came with a slew of emotions. The truth is we are left not so much with answers in the end as we are images. We are left carrying a mix of anger and disbelief with feelings of happiness and joy. There is certain wanting for justice that comes out of the journey of this relationship between teacher and student, and yet we are not quite sure what this justice should look like. For me, I had to take a close look at my own relationship with success and failure. I had to examine some of those characters who have existed in my own life (and I think we would all have at least one). I had to deal with those feelings of not quite living up to some measure of success (whatever that might be interpreted as), and also learning how to react to failure. I had to deal with anger as I watched this film, anger over the truth that for however hard we try, there always seems to be someone who is better than you at nearly everything we do. And learning where this leads to defeat and where this leads to motivation to try harder is a tough line to draw, especially when it tends to come with so much personal baggage.
And ultimately it brings up questions about what matters in this world, and why it matters. To what end do our achievements bring worth, and what does it mean to be remembered (and what does it mean to recognize that we will not be remembered, certainly not beyond the immediate relationships we impact in the few years that we have on this earth).
This film is about much more than music. I am not sure how accurately it describes the cutthroat nature of the competitive music scene. But in my own limited experience I would say it likely comes somewhere i the vicinity, and is likely similar as well to what comes out of the professional culinary world as well (of which I observed through my wife's career). This world, careers, relationships, can be cruel things to navigate and to balance. And yet there remains something powerfully important about how we navigate these things, not just in terms of our happiness, but in how we perhaps feed in to and inspire others in their own successes and failures.

29 -year old Damien Chazelle launches what should be a promising career with Whiplash, an intense, emotionally grueling experience with a Rocky-style ending that will absolutely knock viewers out of their seats!

 Miles Teller (The Spectacular Now; Divergent) plays Andrew, a young drummer at an exclusive music school, who is dazzled to be chosen by the most sought after instructor at his conservatory. Fletcher's jazz band is the pinnacle of achievement for any ambitious student. But Andrew soon finds out that Fletcher, played with glorious fire and brimstone by character actor J.K. Simmons (Spider-Man; Juno), is an uncompromising, impossible to satisfy task master of the highest order. His training crosses the line into physical and emotional abuse, and Andrew finds himself all the more eager to please - and best - his mentor. 

Simmons is pure adrenaline giving a performance that has already won him multiple awards and most likely the Oscar next month. He comes on like R. Lee Ermey's drill sergeant in Full Metal Jacket, unrepentant, uncompromising, and unforgiving of even the slightest infraction. Teller, a young actor navigating his way through YA material like the Divergent series and soon to play Mr. Fantastic in the Fantastic Four reboot, gets the role of his life here. 

The finale of this film is so powerful it will have viewers on their feet when the two leads faceoff on stage. Will Fletcher finally crush Andrew's dreams forever and drive him away from music, or will Andrew step up and shatter his tormentor's hateful cynicism. 

Whiplash has received 5 Academy Award nominations including Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Adapted Screenplay. It opens to today in Charleston. It's an unmissable experience.
One of the most intense films I've ever seen, and my favourite for 2014. Incredible performances from both Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons.

A film with the title 'Whiplash' about a instrument you beat, full of confrontational dialogue and aggressive character reactions. And that's just describing it, 'Whiplash' is as ferocious as the title suggests. Taken from a piece of music played in the film it follows 'Andrew' (Miles Teller) a newbie at America's most prestige music school - and his meeting with controversial and testing instructor 'Terence Fletcher' (J.K Simmons).

'Whiplash' is a film I missed when it initially released in cinemas because it wasn't playing where I am. Well for one day it was on and I took my chance. 

I don't know anything at all about the world of big band music, or how they get there. So my view on its accuracy is non-existent. But what I do know is 'Whiplash' is a damn fine movie. The film builds up and becomes more and more frantic the further 'Andrew' gets to his dream - and further from himself (or at least towards his more 'primal' self). 

There's a brief relationship which seems a little of place given how well defined everything else is. 'Andrew' starts off meek and timid never shown more evident then the first time he meets 'Nicole' (Melissa Benoist) and his last meeting. It appears that the aggressive technique works on Andrew. His idea that people need to be pushed further than they're expected to be is an interesting one. 'J.K Simmons' does a fantastic job and I can see the reason for his accolades. He really showcases his character complete indifference to those around him - his only intention being to find the greatest musicians.

It's paced to the beat of a drums tarting with a solid tempo and raising it along with Andrews growing want and need. Equally 'Miles Teller' matches 'J.K Simmons'. Their essentially hate hate relationship only works so well because of each actors commitment - my favourite scene between the two being a shouting match where you can finally see that 'Andrew' is at his level.

Full of award winning performances and excellent pacing. There isn't really much if anything to fault. The relationship between slightly psychotic teacher 'Fletcher' and newcomer 'Andrew' is one of the most interesting Iv'e seen on-screen. The tempo constantly raises as the stakes and hunger of 'Andrew do. It shows the lengths someone will go to for the success they crave. Sabotaging their own happiness mentally and physically - destroying relationships for a persons approval who has the key what they want. (and that goes for both)

Some of the best movies take a relatively simple plot, and floor you with the execution. Young drumming student at a prestigious Jazz school gets a chance at the big time when his talent catches the eye of the schools most discerning instructor. Um, that's it. Is Whiplash an inspirational tale of how persistence and hard work leads to greatness? Far from it. Writer/director Damien Chazelle expanded on a dark chapter from his youth, and spun Whiplash into a sepia-drenched, single-minded thriller dealing with obsession, betrayal, and an instructor whose methods would've raised the eyebrows of the drill sergeant from Full Metal Jacket. In math terms, Whiplash's delivery can be described at y=x; it's an austere and cynical exercise in relentless tension buildup that keeps petty distractions like character development and continuity to an as-needed basis. Whiplash is simplicity personified, augmented with brilliant editing and a honed script that'll suck you in and spit you out in a way few films do these days.
As a drummer, I was really inspired by this film. The performances are great, especially J.K. Simmons.

J.K Simmons is memorizing in a beautifully constructed look at how perfection comes at a cost. Whiplash features an enthralling psychological battle between its lead characters that culminates in an ending so satisfying that it literally had me applauding from my sofa.

Review:
I was really looking forward to watching this film because I have been drumming since I was a little boy and I know that jazz drumming is one of the hardest methods to master. The movie is about an inspiring drummer who tries his utmost to impress the top instructor in his school. After showing him his determination and dedication to his art, he gets promoted to be the head drummer in his orchestra but the teachers ruthless methods and constant search for perfection, takes his toll. The movie is original and entertaining from beginning to end. The drumming from Miles Teller is superb but it's J.K. Simmons nasty methods that impressed me. The storyline is quite basic and it seemed really short, for some unknown reason but it's very entertaining and I'm glad that it got the recognition that it deserved. If your not into drumming or jazz music, the relationship between the teacher and student is worth a watch because it shows how far a person will go to achieve perfection. Enjoyable!

Round-Up:
This is the first major film from Damien Chazelle who also wrote the strange Grand Piano starring Elijah Wood. With such a small budget, he really did get the most out of actors which got J.K. Simmons an Oscar, Bafta and Golden Globe for Best Supporting role. That just proves that audiences always like a good baddie! Anyway, Miles Teller who also starred in Divergent, 21 and Over and Rabbit Hole, hasn't done to bad since he came on the big screen 2010 and he has a major role as Mr. Fantastic in the new Fantastic Four franchise. J.K. Simmons has starred in over 100 movies but he's mostly known for playing J. Jonah Jameson in the Spiderman movies. Anyway, I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and I hope that more people will get to watch it, now that it's on DVD.

Budget: $3million
Worldwide Gross: $14million

This movie is extraordinary. Going in to this movie i wasn't much of a jazz band fan, but it was one of the most intense and engaging movies I have ever seen. Which is quite obviously the point of the movie, Throughout the movie it is made apparent how the art  of jazz has taken a back seat in a world dominated by sports. You can really see the love and care the director, Damien Chazelle, has for the art of jazz. From the shot angles focusing of the instruments to the dull lighting of the picture it made you really focus on the music and the intensity of the performances of miles teller and J.K. Simmons. I loved how the instruments were almost characters themselves. That's not to take away from how good both teller and Simmons were. From the way Simmons could go from the relaxed teacher to the fury filled eye demon he seemed to be. As the picture progressed we learn why he has to be so seemingly cruel, and we see that he is not cruel but just a man who is holding on to the art of jazz and refuses to let it die. It is a gutsy call to action to not accept mediocrity, but to fight for what we love and to fulfill our full potential. Whiplash seems like a simple jazz movie, but is actually one of the most important and really one of the best movies of a year filled with greats but one of the greatest ever and it is the best movie i have ever seen.
Intense and entertaining. Amazing performance by J.K. Simmons and some damn good music too.

Whiplash is true to its title. It throws you around with impunity, yet Chazelle exerts tight, exacting control over his increasingly feverish and often weirdly comic melodrama. Intense, inspiring, and well-acted, Whiplash is a brilliant sophomore effort from director Damien Chazelle and a riveting vehicle for stars J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller. If you can appreciate the sight of two totally dialed-in performers simmering until they boil over, that's enough. Whiplash rises on the strengths of a brilliant, Oscar-winning performance from J.K. Simmons and a great soundtrack to complement it, turning what could have been a rather bland story of a determined drummer into something a little more memorable. In a stunning performance, Teller resists the impulse to sugarcoat Andrew's egocentricity. Simmons is equally impressive, lending Fletcher just enough humanity to render his monstrousness all the more shocking. This is a muscular and accomplished work of kinetic cinema built around two tremendous acting performances, and it's really about teaching and obsession and the complicated question of how to nurture excellence and where the nebulous boundary lies between mentorship and abuse. Sum up the plot and it sounds interminable. Watch the film and it will spit you out elated, exhausted and cheering for an encore.

VERDICT: "Instant Classic" - [Positively Acclaimed Reaction] Usually I give this rating to a movie that I believe is absolutely outstanding and has little to no flaws in it. Audiences, who haven't seen this film, must see it right now! (Films that are rated 4.5 or 5 stars)
amazing its just amazing one of the greatest movies ive watched in my whole life

No one ever said achieving greatness beyond what everyone expects and being immortalized for all time as a bonafide legend would be easy. It has never been an easy path and it is usually riddled with pain, suffering, anguish and personal loss along with potentially losing the love of your profession in the process. The mentor/student relationship has been done before but it reaches an all new level of barbarity and shocking intensity with Whiplash. It throws everything about that tired genre out the window, exploding it beyond recognition while swearing gross obscenities and slurs at it. To say it will leave you breathless is a huge understatement, but it also might make you think about your own potential and how one would reach their own pillar of greatness. That is hopefully without the specific teachings of Terence Fletcher hurling objects and cruel insults at them.
Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller) is a very gifted, young jazz drummer who wants to be seen and respected as one of the greats, willing to do anything to get there. He is enrolled at the Shaffer Conservatory in New York City, the best music school in the country. Andrew trains endlessly to get noticed by Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), a well-known conductor at Shaffer who is looking for a new drummer alternate. Andrew seemingly gets in the good graces of Fletcher and is thought to be liked by him. But that quickly fades away as its revealed that Fletcher is a cruel, sadistic, manipulative teacher who stops at nothing to bring out the best in his students. While he is brilliant and has much standing when it comes to music, he becomes a bitter enemy to Andrew as they butt heads and Andrew lays his claim to be the prominent drummer at Shaffer no matter what Fletcher thinks. Andre gets pushed to the brink of his own sanity and never rests until he gains the respect of Fletcher and achieves the position as one of the greats.
For all the buzz Simmons has received for his performance, it was a long time coming to finally see him on screen. The final product was even better that I ever anticipated and it's truly one of the best performances of the entire year. Simmons basically owns the entire movie and never lets up. He is a literal force of nature, a swirling typhoon of rage; anger and passion that will envelop anyone who dares to challenge him or threatens anyone who would sabotage his band. Never have I seen an actor so magnetic and fervent in the way that Simmons does it. This was basically made for him and I could never envision anyone playing this role or even coming close to his level of intensity. 
He has made a career as a brilliant character actor for decades, but never being the star. He is known for being a scene stealer, whether it's a brutal neo Nazi Vernon Schillinger in Oz or the boisterous, loud mouth publisher of the Daily Bugle J. Jonah Jameson in the Spider-Man trilogy. With his charisma, biting sense of humor and powerful emotive abilities, he rightfully steals many of the scenes in Whiplash. Simmons always excels in any role he is put in and lays claim that he has been unnoticed by many of the populace for too long. With this one role, he quickly rises from being that guy who was in that thing to a sure fire Oscar contender. 
With so many memorable films this year, Terence Fletcher stands out as something bigger and eventually will become more iconic. His look, style and general way of doing things is menacing that is reminiscent of a super villain. Clad in black from head to toe with a chrome dome and an expression on his face that could shatter glass, he has a look that doesn't want to be messed with. But the way that he is presented shows that he isn't outright trying to be an asshole just for the sake of being one and has many layers beneath him that show a method to his twisted madness. He is a very hateful guy who breeds contempt but at the same time, you can't help but somewhat understand him and realize that a teacher who wants to bring out the best has a point. 
Even if it's a rather physically and mentally damaging way of going around it that no normal teacher would use. He is a very complex character that begs to be broken down where you are curious to his upbringing that would cause him to be such a brutal teacher of music. But the best characters don't need a reason or a backstory to reveal why they do certain things which makes him all the more engaging and magnetic. You are immediately drawn to him because there is so much you don't know about him but to reveal anymore would damage the mammoth mystique that was previously built up. At times he is like a Bond villain who controls all that he sees and hears and has his students used as mere pawns in his manipulative game. Fletcher uses whatever you give him to his advantage and breaks you down mentally with that information. 
The way he masterminds his devious plans is downright brilliant where you can't help but marvel at how it went about. I cannot recall a more sick and twisted scholastic professional since Paul Gleason's Richard Vernon from The Breakfast Club. Teller continues to show that he is a great dramatic actor with another stand out role. He brings the needed vulnerability to make Andrew human and relatable but not necessarily someone we root for initially. Andrew screws up a lot which gains a few enemies at Shaffer and the acidic scorn of Fletcher which makes his plight against him all the more complex. If Andrew would have done a few things differently, it may have been an entirely different movie but then again maybe not. Teller goes face to face and toe to toe with Simmons every step of the way to show that he belongs in the band where they bring out the best in each other. 
Their chemistry together is red hot and bristles with tension every time they are on screen together. You wait for something ugly to happen and a potential bomb to blow up, and it doesn't disappoint as the resulting blast is bigger than one expects. It's a great showing of a talented young upstart and a well-respected veteran going off of each other and literally off of each other as they come to some serious blows. It was as much as Simmons making his presence known in a star making performance after so many years as it was Teller staking claim as one of the best young actors today and one to look out for in the future. Teller has already shown his immense talent playing tortured characters in The Spectacular Now and the under seen and underrated Rabbit Hole. 
But he steps up in every way with Whiplash showing immense character development with an intense transformation. You can see him breaking down mentally as well as physically as the movie goes on where Teller shows his impeccable acting and emotive skills by hardly saying anything and lets his body do the talking. The pain and anguish he goes through is even more powerful by the tired and exasperated look on his face that easily speaks volumes. He eventually becomes just as brutally honest as Fletcher to his family, girlfriend Nicole (Melissa Benoist) and fellow students, berating them for not understanding the hard work that comes when being a jazz drummer at an elite school. The way that Teller tells people off doesn't come off as condescending but truthful in many ways and has a natural honesty that comes off the screen. He slowly comes into his own not only as a musician but as a man who quickly takes charge when he needs too and doesn't take a no for an answer. Seeing two freight trains in Simmons and Teller go 200 mph at each other makes for excellent viewing and one of the best 1-2 punches of the entire year.
Damien Chazelle really came out of nowhere with his sophomore feature and immediately places him on the list for the most promising directors and screen writers. He has received much acclaim from his first film, Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench which I have yet to find anywhere on any streaming site. Its one of the best sophomore films in a long while and one that quickly ignited the cinematic landscape. It's a great mix of humorous verbal barbs, musical performances, napalm like rage with a powerful message of following ones dreams. Chazelle crafts an all too real world of a cut throat music school where only the best of the best need apply and only the strong survive. 
It's not a portrayal of all elite schools but it could for many professions where the slightest, most insignificant thing that you would never notice would set off the wrong person who holds your future in the palm of their hand. Since it never really lets up, the pacing is perfectly executed where the tension and the situations are ramped up every time. Andrew goes through more pain and Fletcher gets more vindictive as the movie goes on and you're left hanging on the edge of your seat. Chazelle has a very unrelenting style that doesn't let up and grabs you by the collar in so many ways. If you're not being attacked by Fletcher with a string of gross insults, you're engrossed by the gorgeous music and the amazing accompaniment in the background. 
The music played was on point, sounding spectacular every time even if someone was off key or not in Fletchers time. Everything went so well with one another and much like a band masterminded by Fletcher, it never felt like it was incomplete, rushing or dragging. There were some amazing sequences that were increasingly intense. One scene half way in particular had me yelling obscenities, with my arms thrown up in the air and my mouth aghast to what I had just seen. It's completely visceral and shocking that goes really well with the all-around chaos of the film. The tryouts were brutal as well as Andrews very first day in Fletchers class that will leave you awe struck. 
Andrews practice sessions were like seeing a man literally torture himself, where he bleeds, sweats and generally puts his sanity on the line to impress Fletcher enough to place him in the band as lead drummer. Of course the editing is what makes Whiplash work so impeccably well and without it would not be as lauded as it is. The editing by Tom Cross was absolutely fantastic and mesmerizing. The abrupt and quick cuts made it flow so much easier. It was almost like watching a music video at times as the beat of the music timed with the editing to make a collage of imagery and sound. You see every bit of the band from every corner when they play and the quick cuts allows you to swiftly take it all in with one swoop. The cinematography by Sharone Meir was also excellent and showed the solitude that would follow Andrew. 
For much of the film, he finds himself enclosed within his own prison of being the best and the camera shows that very well. It presented Fletcher as the ultimate head honcho like a god some of the time and it built up their confrontations beautifully. When Fletcher is berating Andrew and the camera gets up close, it feels like a heavy weight fight. I also loved the sound and how it was included. When the other players in the band prepare, you hear all the sheet music being flipped through, instruments being handled and calibrated to their own specific likings to make a gorgeous cornucopia of sound. The exciting and thrilling climax uses all of these elements to create one of the best sequences in a long while. As for the ending, it was brilliant in so many ways that perfectly extenuates all that was preceded before it. There was so much to go over and dive into that it made for excellent viewing. 
The script was full of dark humor as well as some bitter hidden truths to being seen and respected as one of the greatest in ones respected field. There were some of the funniest and cruelest verbal takedowns that I've heard in a long while and the relationship that Fletcher had with his students reminded me of R. Lee Ermey's Gunnery Sergeant Hartman in Full Metal Jacket, where he also took no prisoners, spewing hilarious vitriol at his soldiers and also saw fit that his men were the best of the best. 
While it would have been easy to paint Fletcher as an outright evil villain and to see him that way, that's not how he was presented. Throughout the film he shows some type of compassion for his students and shows that he cares to guide them to greatness. But at the same time doesn't apologize for his actions which are realistically how much of the world works now. It also doesn't paint Andrew as a completely sympathetic character as he knew somewhat what he was getting into and the mistakes that got Fletcher mad at him were his fault. The dichotomy shown has two characters presented one way but shown the opposite later on to create a complex study of both of them.
Fletcher makes an excellent point saying that "There are no two words in the English language more harmful than good job." People become complacent when they are told that what they are doing is only good enough and not terrible or amazing. There can be no improvement if one is simply told that it's good for now. While I don't necessarily agree with all his methods, every teacher should aspire to push their students beyond their limits and make them realize that every little thing counts. In an arena as immaculate as jazz band where everything must be perfect, it shouldn't be out of line to only accept greatness. The legends achieve that status by putting up with everything thrown at them when they think of quitting the most and the future looks as bleak as ever. Whether it includes slaps in the face, thrown chairs and homophobic slurs is anyone's guess. 
You'd be hard-pressed to find another film like Whiplash and another character like Terence Fletcher. Whether you hate him or love him, he leaves an impact and will have you thinking if you have what it takes to put up with anything and everything to be great. Chazelle lays his own claim for greatness with his only second film, his first hardly seen but may garner some more attention now. Unapologetic, intense and bludgeoning, it's the ultimate portrayal of the mentor/student relationship but only way more sick and twisted. Whiplash isn't just the title of the film and one of the songs that Fletcher gets the band to play, but it's also the effect you have when you're done watching the film. It comes out of nowhere to crash right into you, shocking you into submission and leaving you breathless to where you hardly know what hit you and you don't even have any words to what just happened. It's hard to find another film from last year to have as stunning and meaningful an impact where you still think about it days later. Five thrown chairs out of five.

Intense and exhilarating with a truly outstanding cast. JK Simmons and Miles Teller make a great duo, and the direction is phenomenal. Whiplash has the depth and quality of an Oscar-winner while still being approachable to the average movie-goer. It is a truthfully an incredible film.

Whiplash is an embodiment of passion, anger and desperation in young adults. The relationship between Andrew Neyman and Terence Fletcher is complex, unhealthy and yet completely relatable. Despite Fletcher's barbaric methods and intimidating presence, Neyman is keen for his approval and goes to great lengths to prove himself, which doesn't always go in his favour. Whiplash details the dying presence of both Jazz and compassion in today's America. Featuring a brilliant score and innovative cinematography - my favourite shot features Neymen's hand entering a jug of ice water, and the blood slowly begins to engulf  the water and Neyman's arm. Whiplash is inspiring and exhilarating, featuring a satisfying climax that will leave you wanting an encore.

A brilliant, searing film about talent and excellence. One of the best films of 2014 by far & should've have won the Best Picture Oscar. The visceral energy that the film latches on is addicting and the scenes of Miles drumming, especially at the end, are breathtaking.

'Whiplash' is a tightly edited, scripted, and acted affair about a jazz drummer who must face the overwhelming pressures of living up to the expectations of a demanding, to say the least, music teacher (Simmons) who is best described as the Bobby Knight of jazz conductors.  Compelling and myopic, 'Whiplash' has a great undertow--once you understand it is more than a ham-fisted diatribe against a despotic personality.  If you love jazz and/or tense drama, this film should not be overlooked.

Much better than expected, Whiplash, more than anything, is a fun movie to watch, thanks to its fast pace and JK Simmons´ terrifying, yet curiously humorous performance. The one aspect that I did not enjoy was Teller´s performance as an arrogant and self-involved teen; he did not make himself likable, but rather a nuissance throughout the film.

Extraordinary Masterpiece! The film is truly a beautiful drama and I recommend this one to everyone, and for those who have ever been in a band class might be able to relate to some of the things.

Simmons deserved best supporting actor through his performance. One knock I have on the film is the pretentious cinematography. Inspiring, intense, reverent, Damien Chazelle's jazz-infused drama is an incredibly complex character study that has Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons at the top of their game in this brilliant effort. Whilst I was fixated by 'Birdman' and found 'Boyhood' a generally entertaining watch, 'Whiplash' is by far the most riveting and sensational drama I have viewed from 2014. J.K. Simmons stars as antihero Terence Fletcher, a character we look at as the opportunity of Andrew's success, but also we hate for his brutal portrayal. His performance is flawless and breathless, a truly resonant achievement. The final drum solo ends the film on a high note and keep its audience lingering on the edge of their seats, it is powerful, it is intense, it is a near-masterpiece!
Not sure why everyone was nuts about this movie? Jk Simmons kept movie alive and wanting more of him and less of f*cked up kid.

JK Simmons was awesome. This film definitely has a story to tell, and conveys it effectively. The music scenes were a bit drawn out at times, but this is easily forgiven in light of the subject matter. There is effective use of juxtaposing the thrilling heights of success and acceptance with the stinging lows of failure and being torn to shreds.

Loved it, real music!  J.K. Simmons is the music instructor from hell where all the best jazz comes from. The abuse is a bit much I suppose, but I don't think the plot is meant to be taken literally. What it is is a glimpse into how much pain and suffering must go into being truly great at anything at all, a grotesque display of complete dedication beyond mere talent. The last number Caravan, man.... it was admirable.

I guess if drumming or jazz music interest you, you might be able to enjoy this. I really tried to keep an open mind because I enjoy both lead actors, but this movie is nothing but negativity wrapped up in melodrama and I really have better things to do than listen to people scream at each other for nearly two hours. I appreciated a few of the one-liners toward the beginning, but they got old fast and I totally lost interest by halfway through.
Yeah, I was late to the party, but it was an awesome party.

Electrifying and tense, Whiplash's moral ambiguity between teacher and student strikes hard in a film all about goals, and how far people will go to achieve them. Simmons, whose presence keeps you uncomfortably glued to your seat, this film will leave you tapping your fingers, loving jazz, and scared of music teachers for a long, long time.

This movie is as good as I expected it to be, nothing that gave me the wow factor. Then the final scene/climax happened, and I was blown away. The performances by Teller and Simmons made that scene in a way such that I couldn't break my concentration from the screen. The rest of the film is great, don't get me wrong. The film in its entirety relied on cinematography and the acting abilities of Teller and Simmons, and all of those those are right on point to make the film great to watch. Whiplash, Whiplash, Whiplash. You make me ever so happy. It is mind boggling how good this movie is, not was. This was my personal favorite of the year and for good reason. Lets start with performances, J.K. Simmons is well the bright and shining star of this movie. I will have no arguments on that. He gives a Heath Ledger level performance and completely earned his Oscar. Miles Teller gave a perfect performance and was an inspirational lead in an inspirational movie. Next up is directing. Damien Chazelle's direction and writing is flawless to say the least. The smart overhead shots of instruments really show that the actors know how to play them. This movie is a must see for everyone who likes good music, great performances, and great directing. 100% or A+

If you see one movie for the rest of the year, see Whiplash.  Everything that's been pulled from other reviews like Exhilarating and extraordinary and astounding and electrifying...they're all true.  Whiplash will leave you breathless.  It is fast, it is jazzy, it is brilliant.  Miles Teller plays Andrew Neyman and he's a drummer going to the best music school in the United States.  He wants to be the best in the world, he wants to be remembered as a legend, and along comes J.K. Simmons playing Terence Fletcher who proves here that he is so deserving of an Oscar, I'm so happy he won the award, because this performance is a hit out of the ball park.  Teller and Simmons play off of each other so well that every encounter you have no idea how it's going to go down.  Will Neyman break, will Fletcher break?  Are their limits to greatness?  At what cost can we aspire to be great?  This isn't a film about people taking it easy to make their dreams come true and someone just happens to come along and tell them they're cool and give them a bunch of money.  This is a film about practice, about hard work, about sacrifice, about blood, and about what it takes to become the stuff of legend.  It's a fantastic film and that hour and forty six minute run time is going to fly by once you start watching.  Just do yourself a favor and see this movie.

Whiplash is a brilliantly gripping and tense film that shows the struggles and sacrifices Andrew Neimann goes through to become a great drummer. This film had me on the edge of my seat and the way how it's directed gives the film great intensity. The film flew by and I can't believe it's almost 2 hours long. The only thing that stopped me giving the film 5/5 was that I thought the film ended a bit too soon for my liking. It felt like the story was incomplete, hopefully a sequel will be made, every other film seems to get a sequel nowadays!

This movie is incredibly amazing. I've never seen a movie that I got so anxious throughout the whole movie. The performances were brilliant especially J.K. Simmons part. The jazz music was really cool and that pretty much made the whole movie. It's one of my favorite movies of all time.

Whiplash is my personal favorite film of all time. Sure, its a classic formula, similar to that of Rudy for example. However, the directing, J.K. Simmons and Miles Tellers' incredible acting, the cinematography, editing, soundtrack and writing makes for an astonishing film that won't be forgotten by those who see it. The intensity of the film raises as it progresses, and the movie's finale is the most breathtaking and satisfying finale I have ever seen. Whiplash is a very special movie, although it may have some aspects that can be related to earlier films. Not enough words can be said in this review to truly explain my love for the movie, I think everyone should see it, without question. 5 out of 5.

With flawless direction, screenplay, and cast, including an Oscar-winning performance by J.K.Simmons as the merciless instructor Terence Fletcher to Miles Teller's ambitious drummer Andrew Neyman, Whiplash is a film that reflects the side effects of perfection-and what some choose to go through to attain it.

This movie is about as close as you can get to being a flawless film.  The film wasted no time at the beginning inroducing the main character and his drum playing.  The story revolves around Andrew Neyman a young jazz drummer who obviously has talent.  He is enrolled at Schafrer Music School one of the top schools in the country for music.  While there he meets a stern, vulgar, hard nosed teacher who demands absolute perfection.  J.K Simmons plays the teacher Terence Fletcher who has methods that probably aren't acceptable at most schools, though it seems somewhat ok at this prestigous school.  The acting is unbelieveable and Simmons steals the show.  He is spot on and believable in his acting.  The guy kills it with his emotion.  Teller displays good acting chops also.  One thing must be said...the drumming scenes display an intense realism, and the emotional levels of some of the drumming scenes are top notch.  The finale scene is gripping and it reaches a gratifying yet stunning level.  The relationship between teacher and student is the only thing that matters in this movie and it more than delivers.  A must see do to the acting, story, and realism displayed in the film.

While it does get a bit slow in the third act, this is a brilliant film, even more impresing when you consider this is Damien Chazelle debut. Great looking, amazingly acted (J.K. Simmons was born to play this role), filled with beautiful music and an excited story, this movie is a modern classic indeed.

Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) is a first-year jazz student at the prestigious Shaffer Conservatory in New York. He has been playing drums from a young age and aspires to become one of the greats like Buddy Rich. Famed conductor Terence Fletcher (J. K. Simmons) walks in on Andrew practising in the music room late one night and eventually invites him into his studio band as the alternate for core drummer Carl Tanner (Nate Lang). Fletcher is abusive toward his students, mocking and insulting them; when the band rehearses the Hank Levy piece "Whiplash" and Andrew struggles to keep his tempo, Fletcher hurls a chair at him, slaps him, and otherwise humiliates him in front of the class. At a local jazz competition, Andrew accidentally misplaces Carl's sheet music; as Carl cannot play without it, Andrew steps in informing Fletcher that he can perform "Whiplash" from memory. Fletcher promotes him to core drummer. Soon after, Fletcher recruits Ryan Connolly (Austin Stowell), the core drummer from Andrew's former lower-level class. Ryan is clearly a worse drummer, but Fletcher promotes him to core almost immediately, infuriating Andrew. Determined to impress Fletcher, Andrew practices until his hands bleed and breaks up with his girlfriend Nicole (Melissa Benoist), believing she will distract him in his mission to become one of the greatest drummers in the world... 

"Whiplash" premiered in competition in the US Dramatic Category at the 2014 Sundance Film Festival on January 16, 2014, as the festival's opening film. Sony Pictures Worldwide acquired the international distribution rights. At the 87th Academy Awards, Whiplash won Best Film Editing, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Supporting Actor for Simmons, and was nominated for Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Picture. The screenplay for this film was featured in the 2012 Blacklist; a list of the "most liked" unmade scripts of the year. Director Damien Chazelle gives us a intense and inspiring piece of film diving into the world of wanting to achieve musical greatness and its consequences. The movie has a build up almost like a sports movie and the struggle for perfection, the wish for recognition by the antagonist and the love for the instrument. The rhythm, the cinematography and the great performances creates something unique that will stay with you in mind and heart. Miles Teller gives a great performance even if he feels a bit too dazed and zombielike at times while J. K. Simmons is truly an A grade asshole in his role as Fletcher. I believe in pushing people into greatness, but there´s different ways of doing that, and Fletcher´s way is not fully the way in my opinion. He is unlikeable, but he forces the film and the storyline forward and you can´t help wanting to know if he gets what he deserves in the end. But, he is at the same time that force yelling at you when you´re not good enough and taking you to new heights. The movie puts forward the question what is great and what is just good enough. It´s in the eye, or in this case the ear, of the beholder. I love how intense Chazelle has worked with both Teller and Simmons to make the story believable music scene wise. Just the closeups of the drums are pure perfection. Teller is ferocious on the drums and I got really inspired to sit myself behind a drum kit to live out my long time dream of being a drummer. Melissa Benoist is lovely as Nicole, but she got maybe a bit too little screen time in my opinion. My only real critique was the sometimes haphazard editing at times that I felt disrupted the balance and flow. "Whiplash" is nevertheless a fine piece of film.

"There are no two words in the English language more harmful than "good job"" JK Simmons Oscar winning Fletcher tells aspiring drummer Andrew, and it's an opinion which sums up his character better than any other.  This is not the pat-you-on-the-back, "I'm so proud of you" type of mentor you get in your usual rookie rises to the top film.  This is a man who truly believes that in order to achieve your best, you can never be content.  In his search for the next big thing, Fletcher believes that praise is great if you want to make a musician worthy of a Starbuck's jazz CD, but to get the best requires blood, sweat, tears, and a well timed chair (or cymbal) thrown across the room at anybody who may be stopping your band from achieving perfection.
  Whiplash introduces us to Andrew- an aspiring young drummer at the fictional Shaffer Conservatory in New York who gets noticed by Professor Fletcher, the school's most respected mentor and leader of the Studio Band- Shaffer's top jazz ensemble. Andrew comes into the film as a loner with a fierce desire to succeed where his writer-turned-high-school-English-teaching father did not.  Fletcher spots a potential prodigy, or "the next Charlie Parker", as he puts it, and refuses to let him settle for anything less than being the best.
  Writer and Director Damien Chazelle seems to have taken Fletcher's mantra of constant improvement to heart, taking his 2013 short film of the same name and doing far more than just upping the run time.  It's a testament to the quality of the story, the acting, and the direction that the film doesn't feel stretched.  Fletcher remarks at one point that a year can make a huge difference when it comes to a performer's output, and this is certainly apparent in Chazelle's direction here.  His camerawork is sometimes frenetic- music sheets flashing across bright lights and bandstand tunes; sometimes slow- beads of sweat bouncing off cymbals and blood filling an ice bucket.  At other times he's content to sit back and let the drama speak for itself.  Like any good musician he knows when to slow down, when to speed up, when to go all out, and when to fade into the background and let other instruments come to the fore.  The fact that the film won both the Grand Jury prize and the Audience Award at Sundance 2014 (a feat all the more impressive as it's only Chazelle second full-length feature), should be enough to let you know that you are in for something special.  One hopes that Chazelle didn't bleed quite as much as Andrew did in order to get the finished product, though. 
  The relationship between the two main characters is what makes Whiplash tick, and makes the run time fly by, in spite of the fact that most of scenes are low-lit interiors.  Andrew's conflicting love/embarrassment of his father is mirrored perfectly in the hate/admiration he holds for his new teacher.  It's easy to see where both Andrew's hate and admiration for Fletcher come from- every time Simmons is on screen he is both captivating and terrifying.  He sweeps into the room and everything goes quiet until he says otherwise.  In fact, everyone is so scared of him, it becomes apparent that Fletcher's interest in Andrew comes not just from his musical ability, but from his ability to take a licking and keep on ticking.
  JK Simmons is of course the star of the show.  As the man most famous for yelling "PARKER!" in Sam Raimi's Spiderman movies, you may be forgiven for expecting "J Jonah Jameson Goes to Music School."  However, while Simmons in Spiderman played an enjoyable caricature of the angry boss, the Simmons we see in Whiplash takes what undoubtedly the meatiest role of his career and shakes the opportunity firmly by both shoulders.  A bully who fires out hurtful (and hilarious) zingers left and right, Fletcher is not so much a villain as a formidable, believable adversary.  A lot of times in the past, though, acting Oscar nominations have been given to great turns in mediocre films (see Blue Jasmine, Birdman).  This is not the case with Whiplash- though Simmons may be the best part of it, this film is the exceptional sum of exceptional parts.
  Teller faces the unenviable task of both having to act alongside what is clearly an Oscar-worthy performance as well as being the brunt of most of Fletcher's on-screen aggression.  The fact that Teller made it to the end of production shows that he must be possessed of the same determination as his character- that's real sweat and real blood you see pouring off Andrew in the film.  The time Teller put into his drum training is clearly evident on screen too, and as Andrew's obsession with being the best takes him to the brink of a nervous breakdown, we watch the relationship (perhaps "chess game" is closer to the truth) between teacher and student from the edge of our seats.  The tension in Whiplash comes from waiting to see if Andrew will get it right, and what Fletcher's reaction will be if he doesn't.
  Indeed Chazelle makes the interesting choice of making Andrew hard to like for most of the film's running time- an angry young perfectionist who throws away those who can't do anything for him and looks down on those with less talent- and one of the reasons that the movie still works is in emphasising the emotionally-scarring effects that family members and teachers can have on a young impressionable mind.  Andrew is hit repeatedly, but like Jake La Motta in Raging Bull he refuses to go down, and for this alone his character retains our admiration.  Chazelle makes clear the reasons for Andrew's desire for approval in his absentee mother, his exceptionally normal father, and in an interesting dinner scene, where his musically illiterate family downplay Andrew's spectacular achievements to heap praise on his quarterback cousin.  
  JK Simmons actually sustained two cracked ribs in one of the film's more physical scenes, and it's not surprising, as palpable tension drips from every frame.  By the finale- which can only be described as a fierce battle of wills- the tension is so high you may well be as sweaty as Andrew after one of Fletcher's practices.   Justin Herwitz' score deserves all the praise that will undoubtedly be heaped upon it- though, if you're anything like me, you may find yourself unable to enjoy it fully because you're sitting ready to dodge a flying chair form Fletcher that could come at any moment.

This was quite an intense, smart, well-made film; I can see why it got the word-of-mouth success that it did. The movie takes a seemingly simple story - that of the relationship between a young jazz drummer (Miles Teller) and his almost psychotically intense and cruel teacher (J.K. Simmons) - and makes it play like a thriller or action movie. The performances are both excellent; it almost goes without saying, but J.K. Simmons is probably one of the best character actors in the world. This was the movie that finally made everyone know his name, but I've loved Simmons in everything I've seen him in since at least the first Spider-man movie. The editing, which won an Oscar, is kinetic and intense; you have to see it to appreciate just how good it is. I'm certainly never joining a jazz band now.

As a film: Excellent. Great acting, editing, writing, cinematography, etc. Reminds one of Raging Bull and Full Metal Jacket. 
As a portrayal of jazz music/music philosophy in general: Terrible. All the jazz greats from Louis Armstrong to Django Reinhardt would be horrified by the so-called "jazz" world presented in this. Jazz has never been about having machine-like perfection to win competitions. It's about feeling and improvisation and making screw ups sound brilliant. People like Bill Evans or Bird surely would have rather lost tempo than lost the feel.

Tom Cross (Crazy Heart, Deadwood) holds a clinic in film editing. We may never quite be able to articulate the language of jazz, but the highly technical construction of film has evolved into a language unto itself - a syncopation of craft, vision and instinct. 

This film is so seamlessly sliced and diced, pitched so perfectly, tempo and rhythm so finely tuned, that I truly believed the final scene was going to explode in cloud of smoke and disappear - just as the closing credits rolled. 

An unlikely gem, created in the cutting room by Tom Cross and sound editors Craig Mann, Ben Wilkins and Thomas Curley - albeit with the finest of ingredients, not the least of which was the performance of J.K.Simmons.
 
My personal choice for Best Picture of the Year!

Whiplash is for all those underdogs who are out there who had the heart and courage to chase a dream. A lot of us underdogs do not get to realize our dreams, but Whiplash is the story of our collective blood, sweat and tears being reincarnated into one drummer who suffers and sacrifices, but then perseveres and finally stands alone- victorious.
At the Shaffer Conservatory in New York- it begins. Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) is alone setting the tempo of practice making perfect, sweat dripping music playing. Suddenly a man walks in on him practicing, "Why did you stop playing?" the man said. Andrew is quick to pick up his sticks but as soon as he picks his head up the man is gone, only returning briefly for his forgotten jacket.
In that moment, Andrew just gained the attention of Terrence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) the maestro of the school's and possibly one of the country's greatest concert bands. Soon after, Fletcher gives Andrew a shot in his band.
What ensues afterwards is a struggle that almost anyone can relate to, but Andrew has a legitimate shot at realizing his dreams. He suffers for it and sacrifices a lot for this opportunity. Even the smallest mistake could set Fletcher off at any given moment, and his anger (or rather his passion) knows no bounds. 
The road to success can be a rocky one, but it takes a bold spirit and an undeniable hunger to persevere, and not only does Andrew has that hunger, that drive, but he's holding up the middle finger and listening to cool jazz as he does it.

The psychological abuse in the film stretches reality, but not to the point where a deeply intimate and intense portrait of two flawed people plays out in devastating and, surprisingly, redemptive fashion.

I have problems with the no-gray-area notions of excellence that the movie seems to espouse, but I can't deny the visceral power of Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons's master and slave tango. In fact, one of my problems is that Teller didn't get any Best Actor nods for his utterly grotesque, quietly smoldering intensity as a self-torturing artist while Simmons swept the Best Supporting category just for, I suspect, the flashier role. Simmons's acceptance speeches were all class acts, but I found the character to be a flat stereotype of the tyrannical maestro with obvious "pieces of sugar," begetting an average performance with only a handful of notes - well-conducted notes in terms of literal conducting form - but still only a handful nonetheless.

It's unclear whether Terence Fletcher is a revenge-driven bully or a no-nonsense educator who truly believes in his prodigies and elicits the best out of them. It's too easy to say he can be both. He never seems to doubt his extreme methods, covering up his former prodigy's suicide as a car accident and mourning more for the loss of beautiful music than regret at pushing a student to his death. Fletcher starts off as the kind of unsentimental idealist that makes for an interesting character, but the revenge plot is too inorganic and just plain evil, and the chrome-domed, tight-black-t-shirt uniform (while well-worn) makes him too freakily reminiscent of that douchey designer played by Miguel Ferrer on "Will & Grace" who also liked to make people jump through hoops for his own amusement. Did Fletcher suffer some kind of trauma in his past to become the way he is, or did he also endure and conquer a similar drill sergeant music teacher?

And while I'm not a drummer, I like to think of myself as a musician with good rhythm, but I didn't find the tempo exercises to be that clear. WAS Andrew rushing or dragging? I'm still unsure. Furthermore, was Andrew's last drum solo a fuck-you to Fletcher, or was he trying to gain his respect? Are we to admire Andrew's crazed tenacity or feel sorry for his Stockholm Syndrome? Once again, it's too easy to answer C) All of the above. If there were at least one last shot of Andrew's father outside the door looking lost and hopeless, maybe I'd buy the latter. Fletcher's gestures of approval seem to indicate a rapport building, but isn't the whole point of Fletcher's pedagogy to never say "good job"? Andrew ought to never measure up in Fletcher's eyes, but we don't get to see what happens after the movie ends, so it's too cooked of an ending.

I do have one other compliment for Melissa Benoist who plays Andrew's #WCW.  Her girl-next-door affability lights up the screen.

Whiplash is a gripping, powerful film, and Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons gave a fantastic performance in their careers. Andrew (Miles Teller) is a first year in a music conservatory and playing drums hoping to follow his dreams. His music conductor Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) is abusive, and insulting to his students and pushes his students to the edge in playing and getting the right notes to his standards. Andrew is pushed to the limit that will have him focus on the music notes and the pitch at all times, even if it's avoiding his personal life. 

Director Damien Chazelle managed to keep this drama piece entertaining, and jaw dropping. Chazelle kept the movie unsettling at times, and raises the anxiety and the pressure Andrew has to go through in order to achieve his goals. There is a moment when Andrew is drumming until his hands are bloodied. Even during a scene, Andrew was running late and rushes to the competition and getting in a car accident. He runs out of a totaled car and rush to the event. 

Miles Teller gave a great performance, and so far one of his best roles. J.K. Simmons also gave a highlight to his role as Fletcher. Simmons played a great abusive instructor and is by far sinister with his character.  Whiplash is a good drama film that is gripping, intense, and shining through the two main talents.

An amazingly good, engaging, shocking and entertaining movie. The portrayal of the musicians in a music school is quite good, not showing a music collage in the way a lot of films do. There are egos in this film, there are insecurities, and there are people who are taking music so seriously, that they're no longer really enjoying it. 
Whilst some of the movie is a little over the top, it does represent the seriousness of obsession and phycological abuse. However, whilst the film sets up a clear hero and villain, the film also develops these characters well, showing flaws in both but redeeming features in both, even some respect between the two. 
Miles Teller is great as the young, determined and often very egocentric drummer who aims to be the best, at all cost. Here, he shows much more range than many of his other roles, as this film has depth that others such as Divergence does not. 
Academy award winner J.K Simmons is clearly deserving of his statue, electrifying every scene he's in. He doesn't over play the role, despite the violent nature of it, avoiding the pitfalls of becoming a one note yelling machine. His scene in a bar towards the end of the film, where his character discusses his motives, shows great experience and adds further depth to his character.
The music is fantastic. The title song is really funky and features great melodic lines. And if you're not humming Caravan for hours after the film, well, J.K Simmons should come and yell at you!

If I had to make a simple list of words that describe WHIPLASH, the variety would be jarring. Teller and Simmons' unforgettable performances aside, I can't help but feel I would have a difficult time explaining what to expect from Mr. Chazelle's Oscar-winning drama.
 Smart. Charismatic. Dark. Uncomfortable. Nauseating. Thrilling. Heart-breaking. Triumphant. And lastly, perhaps most importantly, ambiguous as all hell.
The film raises the not-so-comforting point that some greatness, despite its ability to bring joy and inspiration to its beholders, spawns from some place of darkness, unjustness, and suffering. While motherly figures the world over will understandably be turned off by the movie's focus on an abused youth in his quest for existential fulfillment, its technical craftsmanship has reminded me why I love music, cinema, and the gorgeous offspring that is their collaboration. 
The vibrant visuals and kinetic editing fetishize the world of artistic commitment, showcasing the beauty of the instruments and their wielders' discipline while unleashing a music student's most deep-seeded nightmares on screen.
I am still buzzed off this picture, which has itself reinvigorated me as an artist, and can't wait to watch it again.
*NOTE TO TEACHERS: this movie will either rub you the wrong way or line up entirely with your own artistic beliefs. in any case, I will use this post as a platform to represent the demographic I have just recently left, and relay the following message:
there's a difference between pushing your pupils and being a dick. so please, in the name of all things educational, no matter how far you feel you have to push those who are learning the ways of the universe from your unique perspective,
DON'T BE A DICK.

How far would you go to be the best? This understated film is about Andrew, an ambitious student drummer who wants to be in the jazz band led by Fletcher, a teacher with incredibly high standards and a short fuse. The poor soul who gets his rhythm wrong and he will douse the victim with foulmouthed verbal abuse that makes waterboarding sound merciful. But Fletcher's intensity only fuels Andrew's resolve, but how far will Andrew go? J.K. Simmons totally deserves his Oscar as Fletcher, and he fuels the film as Fletcher fuels Andrew.

Whiplash is the story Andrew Neiman an aspiring Jazz drummer who studies at the prestigious Shaffer Conservatory in new York who dream to become one of the greatest jazz players to the likes of Buddy Rich. During his experiences at the conservatory Andrew faces the harsh and abusive behavior of Conductor Terrence Fletcher a perfectionist in his craft who expects nothing but the best from his students. Itâ??s a story thatâ??s filled with so much tension, inspiration and harsh realities of life. This has to be JK. Simmons best performance in his career as he dives deep into the psychological mindset of this peculiar character. Terrence is what would be considered the main villain of the film dressed in all black from top to bottom who brings an uncomfortable demeanor presence into the room when he comes in. Heâ??s a like a vampire rather disappearing and reappearing wherever he goes and it always manages to catch you off guard. Terrence craves perfection, he needs it. But the way he goes about on obtain it from his students can start off as a simple correction by saying â??Thatâ??s not my tempoâ??. But after the 2nd and 3rd mistake he does not hesitate to verbally insult your race and gender orientation. He does not hesitate in physical harm by throwing a chair at Andrew or slapping him in front of the whole class humiliating him for not telling the difference of whether he was â??rushing or draggingâ?? in his performance. The way these scenes are performed makes them disturbing and almost unwatchable. Clearly a man capable of such things is nothing short of an asshole right? But yet I canâ??t really say I hate Fletcher. 


There is a philosophical truth behind his beliefs. Like the great filmmakers of history such as Stanley Kubrick and Charlie Chaplin they were perfectionist in their crafts. These were artist who believe that every shot, every frame and every movement on set and camera needed to convey their vision in the most authentic way possible. These men were so caught up in their work that the way they went about it was almost inhuman. Whether if it was the extensive amounts of retakes, performing their own stunts, ideas that were thought unfilmable at the time or something as simple as â??holding a flowerâ??. In the end though itâ??s evident that all their hard work did pay off. Their achievements had earn them a spot on the history of filmmaking and how we see it today. When I see fletcher I donâ??t see much of an abusive deluded man trashing on his students (granted thereâ??s no denying that his attitude is still atrocious) but instead I see the same spark and initiative that drove these men to what no other person wanted to achieve, to break the boundaries, to reach the peak of their abilities. And in Andrew we see that undying determination to gain the respect of this superior to which would be the biggest honor he could have. Itâ??s really a true source of inspiration. Let me clarify however that I do believe that at some point there is a limit to how your work can consume you, maybe to even the brink of insanity. But that strive for perfection is really worthy of admiration. Personally I would consider myself a bit of a perfectionist so it was easy to hear how this film spoke to me in that regard. Because of this I appreciated how the film smartly strays itself apart from musical underdog clichÃ©â??s and give us a more realistic view of the harsh reality of hard work and perseverance. 

Regarding the cinematography and editing the film handles each of its shots in a fast and brisk pacing following the tempo of the Jazz sequences. They illuminate the screen with such careful artistry to the songs that contrast the dark and tension filled moments with Fletcher and Andrew. The music soars and it feels exhilarating. Itâ??s one of those rare times in film that such directing makes you feel that youâ??re there with the characters in every step of the way. Even in the quite moments with Andrew practicing and studying you question whether heâ??s enjoying the moment or is desperately breaking himself emotionally by drumming so much to the point that his hands bleed. 

This is a great film with its profound love for its characters and music.  Filled with bravado, emotion and great direction. Sometimes I feel that we could all use a Terrence Fletcher of our own in our lives.

I know that all the comments offer the image of a tyrant teacher, who has no regard for his students feelings, etc.
I personally love this Man. He is first and foremost an Artist. Not a teacher, an Artist. Art cannot be taught. It can be guided, discovered, not taught. Better said: the talent cannot be taught. The genius.
Or, this Fletcher character may not use the most orthodox methods to push talents to the edge of genius, but most certainly he succeeds in what he's doing. I agree with his ideas: you want to excel in something, work harder and harder, until you bleed. Cry, if you care, cry out loud, but do not give up. The lesson of this film is outstanding: genius can't be coward and a coward can't be genius.

 A child with great talent in music was discovered by Fletcher, trained by him and, after graduation he was recruited by the best Conservatory of USA. After a while he commits suicide. 
Well, Fletcher is devastated and remembers that boy as being a genius and being discovered by him. Now, who can tell that that boy was mentally ill because of Fletcher? Maybe it was a parental situation, a family problem, or genetics to lead him to suicide. But, because the teacher had a reputation, it was easy to put the guilt on him.

Fletcher operates on fear and intimidation, never settling for what he considers less than the best each and every time. Being the best in Fletcher's mind does not only entail playing well, but knowing that you're playing well and if not what you're doing wrong. His modus operandi creates an atmosphere of fear and of every man or woman for him/herself within the band. But this fear is felt by the weak and the ones who don't really truly want to sacrifice everything for Art.

Andrew, the 19 years old drummer seems to be as strong and ruthless as Fletcher. He understands his mentor better than anybody else. Events of life set them in motion to fight and part.
They meet again, by serendipity, both out from the Music school. Fletcher knows that Andrew witnessed against him, and wants revenge. That shows that for him Andrew is not a child: he perceives Andrew as a fellow Artist who "screwed him over".
They are on stage when Fletcher tells Andrew: "-I know it was you!" and opens the concert with another piece, a piece whose sheet Andrew does not have. Well, Fletcher sees him failing and says: " After all, you don't have it in you!". What did he not have? The power of improvising.

Many times Fletcher told his players the story of Charlie Parker and Jo Jones. Without Jones throwing a chair to the head of Parker there would not be THE BIRD.

Also he confessed to Andrew that, actually, he never had a "Parker" to discover and guide.

Then, on stage, all those memories come back to Andrew, and after such humiliation, what does he do? He returns to his kit and interrupts Fletcher's speech, starting to play "Caravan".
Orchestra is watching him, questioning, and he says: "I'll cue you!". Fletcher goes from surprise, to madness, to another amazement ending up CONDUCTING Andrew...He found his Parker! He becomes one with his drummer boy! Everything and everyone is forgotten: "Andrew, what are you doing Man?" asks him with total admiration...and the boy, between sweat and blood: " I'll cue you!"
And he plays, with all his heart, and Fletcher takes off his coat and follows his dream: the eye contact teacher-student speaks volumes. Andrew is waiting for his approval and Fletcher SMILED after ten seconds eye to eye with the young Artist. Then Andrew smiled back and let himself led by the Master to the end...

Fletcher is not a teacher. He is a musician. A real one, not a restaurant entertainer. His ear is born with the 6th sense of perfect music: either he hears it played by a student or not. They are not average students: they are Artists. They should excel, not become Doctors with a  hobby to play an instrument.
Art has not half measure: either you are a genius or a nobody. In music most of all. This film is an wonderful lesson about Art and Kitsch: what's the difference these days?

An Artist should be merciless when it comes to Art. No compromising, no caressing, no sugar-coating wannabes or has-beens. 
It should be zero tolerance for mediocrity. That's why I love this film: it is true!
So, I disagree with bad reviews regarding "Whiplash and its subject", and I admire the very young director Damien Chazelle and both actors: J.K.Simmons and MiIles Teller...And, by the way, the dad of Andrew plays a major role being very supportive, whatever his son decides to do. His love gives his son POWER to fight and this is amazing. Best film about Art I have ever seen...

Both heart wrenchingly inspiring and deeply unsettling, Whiplash leaves you with an uneasiness that can be hard to shake off. I'd whole heartedly recommend watching it. It validates so many of my anxieties while suggesting whole new streams of reassessing my life and the way in which I perceive the journey that is 'following your dreams'. It brought me back to memories of learning ballet from a rather strict Eastern European instructor, and wondering how much more drive he'd had within him before concerned Canadian parents had tempered his style. I'm still looking for answers, but I now have a greater sense that I'll never find them.

"There are no more harmful two words in the English language than GOOD JOB". . . From a motivational standpoint, I have always taken the positive standpoint, but there are some very powerful things going behind this story of an aspiring jazz drummer and his tyrannical mentor (J.K. Simmons in his well earned Oscar winning performance). Almost military-esque, the mentor's technique of breaking his team down in order to fully push them to the limits is astounding. We watch what true painful motivation looks like and the drastic effects it has on pushing its "victims" into a state of sheer craziness and obsession. Shot in a vivid yet shadowy style symbolic of it's jazz settings, the style of this film is on point all the way to a climax that is as flawlessly executed as I have seen in a long while. Dragging, rushing, "Whiplash" is in fine tune for our viewing pleasures. Just to watch J.K. domineer the stage is worth the ticket in itself.

Also, for a movie that's about a competition between musicians, there's no way for the layman to tell that the main character is any better or worse than anybody else as what he does. Director and screenwriter Damien Chazelle has a unique voice that speaks in tempo, which is a strange development in the world of cinema. His past film "Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench" revolved around the romance between two musicians in the form of a musical. While his last film looked at the ardor of the thirties musical scene, this film looks at its raw underbelly. Looking at the abusive, often violent influences of musical instructors at top tier universities and schools, Chazelle has tapped into a reserve of pain and talent that so often isn't seen. The pressure of striving to be the best often ruins people's lives, and yet renders them living legends.

Whiplash is directed by Damien Chazelle and starring Miles Teller as a young drum student and J.K. Simmons as a sadistic music instructor at a prestigious music college.  Simmons is the fire that molds the steel into an instrument of perfection.  His abusive teaching techniques melts away the impWHIPLASH+onesheeturities of the weaker students while forges the determination of the best of the best, but at a cost.  This film makes me ask,  "If it wasn't for the abusive, sadistic role models pushing for greatness, would we be a society of mediocrity? What greats would we have lost if they were told as young students, "Good Job". Am I willing to make the sacrifices to achieve my goals?   What is the price of greatness?"  I thoroughly enjoyed the film and Simmons portrayal of the abusive teacher. Miles does a fantastic job in taking me to the depths of his passion as a drummer.  Definitely see this movie and let me know if you think they did a "Good Job"
