"Whiplash". You could think that this film tells the story of a drummer (the movie poster is a bit of a spoiler when it comes to this) who has suffered this injury by violently playing his instrument. Or he lost control of his car while drumming rhythmically on the steering wheel and crashed into the car driving in front of him. You could link the movie title to these assumptions, because the arrangements that Andrew (Miles Teller) has to play in this masterful and highly rhythmic film may result in a neck injury. And when it comes to losing that control ... well ... then you should go and watch the movie to find out yourself. Anyway, the film title refers to a song written by the American jazz composer Hank Levy. The central theme of the film is about the influence you can have on someone and drive that person to exceed certain inhuman limits of his own ability. Now, for me you're already a top musician when you know the complete arrangement of "Whiplash" and "Caravan" (written by Duke Ellington) by heart. Even if there's a little mistake here and there or you are little bit offbeat, eventually I will have a boundless admiration for the musician after completing such a superhuman performance.

I've never had such a desire to pull someone through the screen and then smack a huge cymbal against his face as now with the presumably extremely talented music teacher Fletcher, brilliantly played by JK Simmons. A man who lives for his music and has a huge passion for it. It's a bit exaggerated that passion though. Exaggerated to such extent that it exceeds the limit of human dignity and by his passion for creating a perfect musician, his way of teaching tends to be sadomasochistic. A kind of militaristic attitude towards his traumatized and frightened students who are wary of any unexpected outburst. A disrespectful howler, suitable as "drill sergeant" in the US Army, and first-class bully, who suddenly swings around music stands, slaps his students in the face and throws out a member of his orchestra, just because he plays a bit out of tune . Afterwards, the accused doesn't appear to be the culprit, but he's just thrown out of the classroom because he didn't know he wasn't the one playing out of tune. A worse stain on the reputation of a professional musician, according to Fletcher.

That's also what Andrew, an ordinary American teenager who studies at the Shaffer conservatory and whose only envisioned aim is to be the best jazz drummer ever, undergoes. The moment he's being asked to join Fletcher's school orchestra, which only consists of a select group of musicians, it becomes the best day of his life. His confidence gets such a boost that he even overcomes his shyness and dares to ask a girl, who works at the cinema, on a date. That it's subsequently leading to a veritable psychological warfare, goes beyond his wildest dream. Gradually the terror policy of Fletcher drives him to the utmost to meet Fletcher's expectations. Even his relationship with Nicole (Melissa Benoist) is terminated abruptly by him. The love for music is displaced by a bloody battle for a wanted spot in the orchestra. The obsessional takes the upper hand, tending towards self-destruction.

I'm not exactly an expert myself when it's about jazz. And I've read reviews where it's suggested that the essence of jazz is completely misrepresented here : "The idea about jazz in this movie is brought in a grotesque way and looks like a ridiculous caricature". The whole history about Charlie Parker and the anecdote Fletcher tells everytime, apparently isn't exactly true at all. Could be, but for me the jazz section wasn't of essence in the story. It's the emotional and physical brutality that Fletcher uses to bring students to a higher level. In this way Fletcher tries to create "HIS Charlie Parker". The whole movie does follow the rhythm of the used music: uplifting, rhythmic and intense. Only the end was predictable and presented us of course the well known rule that the oppressed kicks the oppressor's ass again. Actually I hoped Andrew would put his drumsticks there where the sun doesn't shine at Fletcher.

The performances of Teller and Simmons are obviously extremely stunning. It took me a while before I realized that I've seen Teller in "That awkward moment". A movie I wanted to forget about as soon as possible. Here, however, I thought he was brilliant. And apparently he's an avid drummer and he did all the drumming himself. Hats off and respect ! But the most brilliant achievement was undoubtedly that of Simmons. What a great character sketch with lots of charisma. A character that scares you. Someone you start to hate thoroughly after a while. But in the end I understood a bit what drove him to this behavior. He won an Oscar for this role and in my opinion well deserved. An energetic musical thriller, with a fairly predictable outcome and which is so extremely rhythmic you can't sit still. Highly recommended!

This brilliantly made, constructed, photographed, edited film, fails because the director-writer allows it to depart from any connection to our shared real world. The young orchestra musicians behave like Japanese prisoners of war to J.K. Simmons sadistic camp commander. He yells racist epithets (hymie) as well as expletives and insults, psychological tricks (good guy, bad guy in one), hits the young drummer Neyman repeatedly in the face while screaming at him, tricks him, insults him and finally humiliates him, to which the orchestra of young musicians say nothing, do nothing and no one records the revolting behavior on their smart phones or puts it on the internet, as they most certainly would. All in an attempt to make a  tense drama that fails because I don't believe it, I do not believe Neyman would lose the music folder, I do not believe he would crawl out from under a car accident and run to the music competition bleeding and limping, he would not fall for Fletcher's trick the second time when he befriends him. I saw it all coming as I am sure many others also do. It looks great, the music sounds great even if the jazz is somewhat dated ( hear Harry Connick Jr. band from the early 90s for modern big band jazz), so I think the audience has been mesmerized by cinematic pyrotechnics that would be better placed in a more grounded story. And Fletcher means "arrow maker" while Neyman ( pronounced as the German "niemand") means "nobody". So disappointed after all the hype.

An enthralling story, set against the backdrop of a prestigious music school.  It covers one young man's attempts to reach the top of the musical industry, and the band leader who may be his ticket, or his nemesis.

A deeply psychological drama, it explores issues like ambition, obsession and power.

Has a few interesting twists too, especially towards the end.

Not perfect: some of the twists aren't consistent, character-wise.  The final scene overplays the conclusion and is too neat in some ways.  Despite this, it missed having a final word on one or two of the themes, leaving these as secondary considerations in favour of a more Hollywoodesque ending.

Decent performance by Miles Teller in the lead role.  Superb performance by JK Simmons as Fletcher, the band leader.  He well deserved his Best Supporting Actor Oscar for a performance that is searingly intense and perfect for the character.
It's no new story, but its made, and acted better than all its predecessors.

Never before have I experienced a film with such emotional depth. Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller) is a drummer, driven by the belief that he can become the all-time greats. Though standing is his path to greatness is Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) a hard-nosed instructor that expects more than just greatness from his students, he expects perfection. This leads to the most compelling conflict between two characters I have ever witnessed, and the film's finale will leave you speechless. 5/5 stars.

Touching on aspects of sacrifice, diligence, and integrity, a question that can bother any man; "Greatness, or the girl", is used to help emphasize the importance of ambition and where it can lead. "Whiplash"  on the surface is a tense, complex study of artistic struggle, obsession, and megalomania. I HATED IT. Not because it wasn't well constructed; not because it wasn't well acted; not because it wasn't well directed, it was all these things and more. No, I hated it for it's heart, its misguided insight into what art and beauty are truly about.  It is not lost on me that any discussion or criticism about art could be argued to be completely subjective; I would still say that this movie does not reflect the beauty of art or do credit to the struggle of the artist. Thats not just my opinion either, to me that is a fact. I am not trying to argue an opinion here, I am actually commenting on something that I truly believe. It has been said that "Beauty is Truth and Truth Beauty". I believe in Truth and truth can not be an opinion. "Whiplash" takes a swing at what it believes is necessary to reach that truth and fails completely at capturing what it means to be an artist. This movie would have one believe that suffering, obsession, sacrifice and ugliness are the building blocks that "great art/artist" are founded on. I couldn't disagree more. As an artist myself I understand how all these "negative" motivators can drive an artist to produce art, even to produce great art, yet I feel this movie celebrates them as a necessary right of passage. That in order to be great one has to work harder; it implies that those who are successful are those who have suffered and sacrificed the most, and those who aren't just didn't try hard enough.(How many great artist has history ignored only later to discover their beauty?) Perhaps most disturbingly It implies that one's self worth is dependent upon the reception of their art by an audience or someone outside themselves.  "Enter the EVIL music/art instructor" who's job it is (by this movies logic) to push someone past what they think is possible to open up new untapped potentials hidden away by psychological blocks of complacency and self-pity by employing the tools of cruelty, manipulation and terror. All this hidden behind some BS ideal that their is some great NOBILITY inherent in not depriving the world of a great artist no matter what the cost. GAG!! What overblown melodramatic tripe.  I don't argue that we all couldn't use a swift kick in the pants occasionally in order to rise to our potential,or that honest criticism can be crucial to progressing as an artist but to ruthlessly and doggedly bully and torture someone in the hopes of achieving said effect is where i take offense. Who the hell gave him that cross to bare anyway!? There IS a line. This movie even mentions this "LINE" at one point and comes really close to reaching a redemptive conclusion....then misses the mark entirely and descends into the abyss.  At this point the movie could have had some valid commentary on the consequence of tyranny and obsession and lifted itself to having a message worth sitting through.  I had a glimmer of hope that the movie"s heart was true and had been enact all along. Unfortunately this was not to be.  The scene that twists the knife comes when; after being set up and sabotaged by Fletcher, Andrew rises to the occasion against all odds and puts on the performance of a lifetime. Had he done this despite the villainy of Fletcher and the movie just ended, then  one could have left the movie with a certain ambiguity, open to contemplating the various themes and questions the movie raises about art and the artistic process. However the damning evidence of the movie's actual message comes  during Andrew's  fevered solo when despite everything Fletcher has done to Andrew there is a nod of acknowledgement from Fletcher that conveys the approval that Andrew has been so desperately seeking and the movie ends as if something triumphant and beautiful has been brought into the world. UUNNGHHH!!! Never mind that Andrew is an obsessive with no sense of self (or self worth), never mind that Fletcher is a maniacal, narcissistic power drunk bigot (who may have even played a hand in pushing a young mind to suicide), never mind that there seems to be no consequences for any of these characters in their pursuit of greatness. No at this point the movie decided to celebrate this twisted moment as a triumph of art and truth. As if there being squeezed torturously from a person is how great art is born. No I don't think it is cool to celebrate this message nor do i think it is healthy to celebrate Fletcher's and Andrew's relationship as justified and productive. AS AN ARTIST IT OFFENDS ME WITH ITS CLICHES, I feel it lacks insight, responsibility and any awareness as to the very purpose of art. Art doesn't have to be beautiful, art can be dark. It is both and it is neither. Art is truth and that is all I would ever ask of any form of expression. In "Whiplash" I got pandering, "Top Gun"-esque melodrama  and a self indulgent study in cruelty that pretentiously masquerades as if it knows what it means to be an artist.  (2 stars for the undeniably fine craftsmanship and performances, but on those alone does not a good movie make.)  -SIZER

To describe in one word: Powerful. I enjoyed every second of this film, even the ones where I was painfully nervous for the main character Andrew Neyman. My heart was pounding at points where I simply didn't want Andrew to fail or stumble. That would translate into the bombardment of criticisms from his cruel instructor. This movie tells an incredible story of what people do to push themselves beyond others. How they push themselves to be the very best and what that does to their social life. Miles Teller's character is one wonderful to watch. Although at times, he can come off as a dick, watching this film you grow to care and hope for the character to achieve his dreams. What this movie also does a nice job of is showing how the profession and hobby of musicians are looked at and treated compared to those who focus on sports. Andrew's family does not seem nearly as concerned with his success in the music department than as they do with his cousin who finds success with football. They don't respect the pain Andrew feels and the blood he sheds literally. There are scenes where his hands bleed onto the drum set while he continues to play and even made my hands begin to sting. I'm also glad toward the end they decide to flesh out J.K. Simmons character Terrence Fletcher (the cruel instructor) and let him explain his reasons for insulting and constantly demeaning his players. The end result is most certainly satisfying. This movie ends exactly how it should leaving the audience in awe.

Whiplash Changes Tempo

Whiplash is a film above all about struggle, the struggle within ourselves and the struggle we have with the influences in our life: our family, our mentors and our artistic challengers. Andrew, played by the talented Miles Teller, is a young drumming prodigy, or is he? Is he the next Buddy Rich or Max Roach? 

Andrew admires his mentor, Fletcher, played by J.K. Simmons. Simmons won an Oscar for the playing the megalomaniacal band leader who thinks he has the power to beat greatness into his students through abuse, name-calling, manipulation, lies, whatever it takes to be great. One big question left standing at the end of the movie is whether abusive teaching works for the most talented of artists, if it can make them that much greater?

Whiplash is a more dramatic and less smarmy look at the entertainment industry than Birdman. Whiplash doesn't beg for us to notice how clever it is at every turn, it's not predictable, and while we are not clear where the protagonists will go at the end of the film, it doesn't need to invoke magical realism and mysticism to be a mystery. Other than both being compound nouns with eight letters and about the entertainment industry, the two films are world's apart.

Whiplash is not your typical film about an artist climbing to the top. Few films give so much time to the importance of mentorship in the artists' lives. Few films explore the obsession of the the art itself that leads one to desire to be "one of the greats." And the film isn't talking about the obsession of drugs and alcohol or some abusive family that leads artists to greatness. Like many artist we consider great, his obsession stems from his inner demons of not knowing what else he would do with his life without it and his insecurities in a world where the next guy on drums might be better. If he can't play like Elvin Jones, than what's the point???Unlike most of us who either aren't willing to do what it takes to be great or are content with what talent we do have, artists (athletes, scientists, writers...) who become the best have a different mindset. Whiplash lays that out for us to see in an entertaining form. 

And when you think you caught the beat of Whiplash, it turns on us like modern jazz and ups the tempo. But it never plays down to us. Whiplash surprises with the plot twists and just when you think it goes to far, that it has played out, the key changes and leaves us wondering.

If you want to experience an unremitting cinematic portrayal of mental and emotional abuse and torture this movie may be your cup of tea.  It would have us believe that a valid pathway to inspire and develop any kind of excellence is through fear and bullying, the equivalent of getting information through torture.  I suppose some people will believe this, but what is the point of putting this on the screen unless your ultimate purpose is to come back to reality and show that it actually does NOT work.  This movie never gets to that destination.  An occasional challenge, an isolated blow up in the workplace or in the creative sphere between colleagues can be cathartic and even positive.  But it cannot work as a day-in-day-out, 24-7, psychological warfare strategy to build anything of value let alone run a school or keep and organization intact. It is such a ridiculous premise that is lacks internal consistency (why would anyone who is a teacher of anything constantly undermine their students' and their own personal success) and unbelievable situational circumstances (the car wreck scene).  We don't even get a glimpse into the extreme personality of Terrence Fletcher to help explain why this person exhibits sociopathic or psychotic behavior.  Glad I didn't pay to see this in a theater.  And it sure as hell didn't deserve an Oscar nomination.

"There are no two words in the English language more harmful then good job." That summarizes bandleader Terence Fletcher's pedagogical philosophy. Unfortunately, he is unable to see the potential destructiveness of "never good enough." 

A young student, Andrew Neyman, is at first taken in by Fletcher's powerful persona, then obsessed with meeting his super-human expectations. Neyman knows that Fletcher would see a thousand mediocre lives destroyed to produce one great, and Neyman yearns to be one of the greats, no matter the cost to himself or others. Will Neyman live up to Fletcher's expectations or die trying?

The film is driven by great performances and good music. However, it succeeds a little too well in making the audience feel the protagonist's anxiety, and Fletcher's bigoted obscenity is quite repellent. For me, both of these things at times detracted from my enjoyment of the film. Moreover, one can object that the film's ending actually affirms Fletcher's perverse value system. But a film that can make you entertain questions of ultimate values is necessarily a good one.

Better late than never.  'Whiplash' delivers all the intensity and ferocity of some of the most uptempo action movies to date with its relationship between Miles Teller as the student and JK Simmons, the instructor.  

What an incredible dynamic the two actors had on screen.  Their characters, and the story itself, may have been a bit over the top for Hollywood, but it still gives you great insight into how a musician's greatness is cultivated over time.  Sure it takes a special kind of natural talent and luck of the draw in the gene pool, but even with this resembling the most extreme sides of the business, there feels to be a hint of truth in it.

It's clear why JK Simmons won best supporting actor for his performance.  Method to the madness might be the best way to describe how he walks through life while training these kids.  For Miles Teller, I'm super impressed with his ability to pick up the drums and train the way he did over a couple of months to at least get the jist of those songs down.  While great editing and breaking the songs into chunks to make it appear as if Teller was really tearing it up in one fluid play-through, he still gets a standing ovation.

You can actually see the lightbulb switch on in the final ten minutes when they start Caravan.  Not just for Teller's character finally hitting his full potential, but for Simmons' character coming to terms with his teaching techniques proving him right.  They hit the high hat with this one.

Here's something for those of you interested in watching this movie, but are not as into watching "good" movies like me to keep in mind as I write this review. Starting with Whiplash, I'm going to write movie reviews that take into consideration the art behind movies and I'll judge the movies accordingly. But I am just like anyone else and I will judge this movie based in how entertained I was and how much I genuinely liked the movie. That is what I plan on doing for my movie reviews for the rest of my days of reviewing movies. 1 star or lower is garbage to me and had few or no good qualities. 2 stars is bad but had some good qualities to it. 2 1/2 is half-baked. 3 stars is just mediocre. 3 1/2 is good but could definitely have taken a little more time developing itself. 4 is quite entertaining but not the best that it could have been. 4 1/2 it's pretty good but it's not the best it could have been 5 is the absolute best it could have been. And I will try my best not to deviate from this. This movie has an arbitrary yet free flowing pacing to it. Rhythm and timing were the most CRUCIALLY important parts in a movie such as this. At moments it fails. The editing was perfect, yet the character driven parts of the story which involved Andrew getting to spend time with his dad or his girlfriend those parts felt ignored for most of the movie and were only put in when they needed to add a little something something to spice things up and to make us feel bad for Andrew more than we already did. As I watched I started off feeling bad for Andrew and then I grew to dislike Andrew, but then I started to cheer for him. Because this movie starts off showing us that his dad is an unsuccessful writer who  teaches high school english and actually babies his kid too much for my taste. Then we see Andrew getting chewed up and spit out by his jazz teacher on his first day in the elite jazz team. And Andrew takes some of that anger with him and takes it out on a girl that HE JUST STARTED SEEING and on his own family. That was the moment I saw that he was trying to do the same thing that his teacher was doing and that was to tear apart the people around them. But unlike his teacher he was doing it to motivate them Andrew just did so to be mean. And that makes you dislike Andrew, but then he attacks his teacher and gets kicked out of school and in a way I felt bad, but at the same time I was glad. And at the movies climax, his teacher does one more thing to intentionally discourage him in order to get him off the stage, but then Andrew realizes this is just another one of his tricks and in order to be the best I have to ignore every discouragement he throws at me and start drumming on my own tempo. One of the most memorable parts is while he does this and his teacher tries to discourage him with another threat and as his teacher does so he hits one of the crash cymbals in retaliation to his teachers intimidation. I loved that. One thing I absolutely loved about this movie is how well defined as a character Fletcher was and how well J.K. Simmons played the role. He won an oscar and he earned it. One thing I have to mention is something about this movie that I totally agree with. The the two most dangerous words in the english language are GOOD JOB. I read these words in a book titled I Am Better Than Your Kids by MADDOX. He actually said the exact same thing in his book. And this movie takes what MADDOX said to a different and significantly more intense extreme. And I'm starting to think that ALOT of the inspiration for Terrence Fletchers Character comes from the aforementioned book I am Better Than Your Kids. And as for the rest of the movie I felt this was a very hard movie to sit through. It starts with Andrew playing pretty good. At least better than me that's for sure, but to this teacher even though he's good if he's not the best he can be he's not good enough. And at the final moments of the movie when Andrew is much more sure of himself he realized in that moment his teacher was finally acknowledging that he had skill because you're either out to be the best or you're not worth my time. All in all a very well done movie. Whiplash is very well written, streamline and on time editing, great acting, and just a really good movie.

Whiplash is a film hard to come by; it's brave, nerve wreaking from beginning to end, and showcases two incredible modern actors at their respected high point of their career. Besides who's on the screen, the work put into the production of Whiplash is stunning; a true cinematic pleasure. The theme of abuse is not handled lightly, both the writing and JK Simmons acting styles allow the film to get up in your face, through blood, sweat, and tears. The energetic film ends the second act with an explosion, leaving you wanting more. Nothing can compare to the home stretch of the film, however. In the third act, the energy slowly recharges and sets itself up for, what is, possibly the best movie ending since The Usual Suspects.

Talk about hard to sit through! It shows you how amazing this film is when the big jazz band performances in front of everyone felt more intense than most action scenes. Miles Teller, whom I always saw as that "meh" actor from Divergent, blew me out of the water with his performance as the drummer who's blessed yet also cursed by the talented beats of his drums. But the crown of performances has to go to J.K. Simmons, who quips funny sergeant Hartman-esque jabs but in a way that felt more real like any rude, dominative perfectionist that anyone has had to dealt with in their lives but able to spread incredible amounts of terror and psychological tension. You can just see the misery he inflicts upon his students and even see his attitudes rub off on his students (whom end up paying consequences for that like when Teller's friends, the seldom joys of his character's life, start to take notice and call him out on it). There's also layers to Simmons's character, whom is shown to fake a gentler persona while with friends, debates the cons of not testing one's limits, and sadly is the possibility of a previous cycle of psychological abuse and perfection that got him to where he is today. "Whiplash" not only portrays the depth of passion(the one thing most people feel safe with), but in a way where the thing that the protagonist loves the most is turned against him. It asks if it's worth it to put yourself through living Hell when you should be enjoying what you do in order to achieve perfection. But it also leaves the door open wide enough to interpret the pros of becoming the very best as well, so one could still answer the movie's jarring question (one which is rarely given in movies) with a quite different answer. Finally, this movie has one of the most tense yet meaningful climaxes that I've watched in a long time. Whether you identify yourself with Miles Tellers' character or end up feeling more grateful for your own path of career pursuit, I think many can agree that that they may never be able to listen to drums the same way again. This may not be the "fun" popcorn flick that many look forward to, but it's for sure that in all of the right ways.

One of the best movies I've seen in some time. I'd much rather watch a dark and gritty, yet truthful drama like this than any "inspirational" musician story Hollywood normally hawks our way.    

When critics throw out words like "electrifying" or "exhilarating" to describe a film, they're often accused of hyperbolizing. In this case, however, such words do indeed fit this emotionally pulse-pounding drama. The climax of the film is particularly well-crafted -- one of the most thrilling and crowd-pleasing in recent memory. 

Plenty has been made of J.K. Simmons' performance in this film. Naturally the notices are all accurate and he more than deserves his Oscar. This truly is one of the most pleasantly surprising portrayals of the year. Saying his music teacher character is intense may be an understatement. He's a very complicated, emotional character -- unapologetically hurling a chair at a student one minute, and breaking down in tears in the next. Tour-de-force doesn't begin to describe it.

Miles Teller also does tremendous work here. He's certainly an up-and-comer whose craftsmanship stands out more and more with each performance. I sincerely hope Simmons' brilliant turn hasn't over-shadowed Teller's strong, emotionally vulnerable work here.

The cinematography is terrific. Sharone Meir's work here reminds me a lot of Jeff Cronenweth's work in David Fincher's films. It's beautiful stuff. For a relatively simple, personal character story, he pulls out all the stops visually -- providing a rhythm that compliments the jazz performances and a color pallet that compliments the brassy instruments.

The story of Whiplash is relatable to anyone who struggles to measure up, faces failure, yearns for greatness, or compares themselves to their parents. No matter the craft or career, most people can see themselves in Teller's drummer character. It just so happens that centering this film around the drums (elements of the movie are autobiographical for the director) highlights the almost percussive intensity with which we fight for attention and approval -- through repeated failures and triumphs.

Like some dark cousin of bring-your-daughter-to-work day for would-be over-achievers, "Whiplash" invites the viewer to witness the dark underbelly of exceptional performance.  In the process, and process is what's in focus here-the following questions are broached: How can one motivate another person beyond all rational bounds and constrainsts? Can intermittent fits of passion be leveraged into consistently exceptional performance?  And most importantly, can this be accomplished using conventional means, or must lines be crossed and taboos scorned?  This movie is about steering exceptional ambition, from the inside and out. 

The plot itself doesn't diverge much from the standard hero's journey, but the emphasis does.  The camera directs its focus much less on eventual glory than excruciating process.  Instead of watching a likeable Rocky Balboa's quest for fame and fortune, his already adonic physique attaining ever greater levels of perfection over the course of a 4-minute montage set to inspiring music, we watch probably coddled, definitely socially awkward and painfully self-absorbed Neyman work sores into his hands, hammering at a cymbal in an isolated, sound-proof room.  A cheering crowd, a concept probably too discomfittingly intimate for our hero anyways, is a faraway thought.  He already dismissed the girl to be got without ceremony or any hint of empathy and his interdependent goals -to increase the speed of his 400th notes imperceptably and earn the right to play the song for the next competition- are incremental victories at best; it is difficult to imagine that whatever difference the conductor portends to hear belongs just as much to the world of make believe as actually securing a starting role in the darwinist world of Studio Band.  What percentage of the audience can even identify with the goal of being a background musician in a genre far past its prime?  All interpretation aside, the juice is surely not worth the squeeze in the individual mental calculations of many viewers. 

Yet the whole thing is exhilarating.  In spite of the parade of unflattering qualities exhibited by both, I found myself viscerally pulling not just for the unlikely hero, but also his anti-mentor.  In a billiant illustration of Hegel's thesis-antithesis-synthesis dialectic, beauty was not ultimately achieved by the triumph of one ego over another, but rather as the culmination of the grinding interplay between them; they do eventually harmonize to produce something unique and memorable, but only because they failed to kill each other first. 

That his father was abscent probably helped too.

There is such a myriad of blood, sweat, tears, anxiety, screaming, and terror in "Whiplash" that an outsider might mistake it for a horror show instead of a cursory, superiorly breathtaking thriller of sorts.  I'm not the kind of critic that uses tired phrases like "kept me at the edge of my seat" or "made me sweat bullets" as devices to trickily describe my heart-rate, but during "Whiplash," I experienced both sensations.  Not in the same way I did when Ghostface was chasing around Drew Barrymore with psychotic fascination in "Scream" and not in the same way I did when Marion Crane was getting shower-knifed in "Psycho"; "Whiplash" invents an entirely new kind of thrill, one where an aggressive insult is as excruciating as a punch to the face and a drum solo quivers with the same acrimony of a fist fight where no one wins.
	Miles Teller (who is already becoming one of Hollywood's many underrated young talents) portrays Andrew Neyman, an aspiring drummer who has found a place within the halls of a respected music conservatory on the East Coast.  Though slightly cocky, his talent is undeniable; he aspires to be the next Buddy Rich, and it doesn't seem like all too much of an exaggeration.  Little does he know that he is about to become the punching bag of Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), a sadistic conductor who isn't afraid to hurl verbal and physical assaults on his students in order to achieve a sickened sort of perfection.
	Famously, the American Film Institute compiled a series of Top 100 lists, its subjects being stars, laughs, passions, quotes, and more.  If they were to start again from scratch in the next decade or so, Terence Fletcher would, in no doubt, find his place as one of the Top 50 Villains.  Simmons has made himself a kind presence before ("Juno," all those insurance commercials), but never again will I be able to look at him without a cautious, passing fear.  As terrifying as Darth Vader or Nurse Ratched, Fletcher seems to enjoy inflicting pain onto his students; even scarier is the fact that the film never offers any explanation as to why he feels the need to traumatize the impressionable youths around him.  Most movies would use a dying wife or an abusive childhood as excuses, but not with Fletcher.  He is evil, and he probably doesn't even realize it.  Simmons snarls his way through screaming matches with unbridled ferocity, but more disconcerting is his ability to radiate cruelty even when his manners are at their very best.
	In "Whiplash," we're never quite sure if Fletcher's alarming teaching methods will ultimately guide Andrew in the direction of the greatest drummer alive, or if they will send him over the edge.  Teller, a brilliant and intuitive actor, is aware that Andrew isn't always likable but makes up for it with fierce determination.  As he practices unbelievable amounts of time to polish a certain section of a particular piece of music, blood rips through his hands like a geyser, sweat pours down his face like a waterfall.  But will he give up? The lethal rapport between Teller and Simmons is morbid enough to keep us guessing.
	Mention must also be made for Tom Cross' magnificent editing.  The way he pieces together Fletcher's attacks on Andrew are inflamed in peril, flickering with rough movement that matches Fletcher's unpredictable mood changes; most impressive is the climax (which is basically a long, extremely intense drum solo), which captures every single detail imaginable, ensnaring any drip of sweat or instrumental spasm of the performance.
	When the closing credits finally popped up, I noticed that, in all my leg-shaking and shortages of breath, I was drenched in sweat.  "Whiplash" doesn't allow for a smoke break or a second to get your bearings straight - the continuance of high tension makes it the most thrilling film of 2014.

Yes, this movie is well filmed and directed. Unfortunately, as a current jazz major, it poorly reflects anything vaguely real. This isn't even a dramatic representation of what school for jazz musicians is like, ESPECIALLY in high school. It's farfetched, and has put yet another nail in the genre's coffin. If all people know about jazz is from this movie, we are all doomed. None of the stuff in this movie has ever happened or will ever happen, and any teacher of music that hinted at intense irrational behavior like this would be fired immediately. Also, the tasks that the "all star drummer" has to accomplish are extremely novice, and most average high school musicians could play at this level very easily. On top of this, it promotes the idea that jazz is about competition, which is a sad diminishing of music and makes it look like evil glee.

"Whiplash" is intense, but it's this kind of emotional intensity that leaves you drained by the end of it. That is the brilliance of the film, because it's in these electrifying sequences of dialogue between the two leads that you become the most invested in the story. J.K. Simmons' role seems specifically tailor-made for him, and he delivers it with the perfect amount of sadism and humanity. He really is an extraordinary character actor, and his performance here is equally extraordinary. Miles Teller is not talked about as much, but he definitely holds his own against Simmons in these engrossing sequences. Ultimately, Chazelle's brilliant screenplay presents a morally ambiguous tale of dedication versus obsession, and concludes the film with just enough opacity to allow for multiple interpretations. This is a scary good indie picture, and one of the best of 2014.

Left me with a very queasy feeling. While technically a superb movie that is full of intense power and raw energy, the characters are not likable (to say the least), the events are highly improbable and unrealistic, and the message the film seems to be giving the audience is rather distasteful and ugly. The actors gave thrilling, admirable performances and all scenes with musical performances were engaging and intense - this is a film about sacrifice, ambition and the power of single-minded, all-consuming passion, and when it came to illustrating these themes, the movie excelled with flying colours. However, I am not sure how the audience is supposed to be left feeling after the movie. Personally, I felt uneasy, dismayed, even somewhat sickened. This was a difficult movie to stomach; in many ways it is ugly and unpleasant. While it was a thrilling and masterfully executed movie, I feel uncomfortable with giving it a strong recommendation.

Outstanding on all fronts, but perfect on none. Although there are certainly things I would change about 'Whiplash' that in no way detracts from the brilliant performances and the audio visual feast it satisfies it's viewers with.

A young drummer endures the abuse of his teacher.
J.K. Simmons's Oscar-winning performance is remarkable. While the majority of his screen time is spent hurling abuses and musical instruments at poor Andrew, there is one vital moment that humanizes Simmons's character, and it is for that moment more than anything else that his performance is Oscar-worthy.  
The film's story is problematic for two reasons, both involving the film's conclusion.  The central conflict is man vs. man, Andrew vs. Fletcher, and while this conflict does resolve in the film's final moments, it still seems unrealistic that Fletcher would accept even the climactic drum solo as proper resolution.  Also, what plagues Andrew throughout the film is not limited to Fletcher.  Andrew's own blind ambition, seen in his relationship with Nicole, is more to blame for his troubles than Fletcher, yet the film's conclusion doesn't encounter the man vs. self conflict in any satisfactory way.
Overall, the performances by Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons are excellent, and there are some very compelling sequences, but the story, while strong, is "not my tempo."

This film has take the inspirational teacher/student formula and absolutely turned it on its goddamn face.  There's no touchy-feely story about a teacher who's tough but lovable who inspires his students to strive to be the best person they can.  Not saying there's anything wrong with that type of movie, but this, from now on and for a long fucking time, will be the benchmark of what an 'inspiring' teacher/student movie should be.  Look, I think Miles Teller is a natural talent.  He's charismatic, he's funny, and he can be charming if he wants to be.  I do not mean to say that he didn't work hard on this film, because he clearly fucking did, he gave it his absolute all to a role that must have been intensely demanding.  Both physically and emotionally, as I'm sure it must not have been pleasant to be verbally berated by JK Simmons all day long.  Miles Teller brings a certain physicality to the role of drummer, once that is essentially needed for a type of drumming that jazz demands, a much more complicated and complex form of drumming than what you normally see.  Thanks to some really damn good editing, particularly the film's excellent third act, it really looks like Miles is playing the drums during the fantastic, and climactic, drum solo.  With that out of the way, it's obvious and expected, that the show absolutely belongs to JK Simmons here with his absolutely incredible performance in this movie.  He perfectly portrays this man whose methods are verging on physical abuse, throwing a chair at Andrew during the first scene Andrew plays the drums.  After this chair throwing, he proceeds to tear Andrew a new asshole with the verbal berating he gives the poor guy.  This scene is like 20 minutes, or so, into the movie and with that scene I decided that the Oscar Simmons got for his performance here was more than deserved.  He added muscle for the role, which gave him a more impressive presence as he does not seem like the kind of guy you would fuck with, at least when it comes to his Jazz band.  The film, as much as it is about Fletcher pushing Andrews past the boundaries of what others would think possible, it's also pretty much a psychological thriller about the effect Fletcher's methods have on Andrew.  He becomes insanely obsessed with drumming, to the point that he pushes away a great woman in order to achieve 'greatness' for fear that she'd hold him back.  He starts getting a little cocky as he improves and starts to begrudgingly earn Fletcher's mistake little by little.  It gets to the point that, during a very important performance, Andrew gets into a car accident with a fucking truck, he proceeds to get out of the car and run to the venue in order to play the drums.  The guy clearly got fucked up in the car accident, with blood dripping from his head and his hands all fucked up.  The performance, as expected, goes to shit as Andrew is unable to play the drums due to the pain.  Fletcher, looking for any excuse to kick Andrew out of the band, uses this as reason to remove him.  So you can see how Fletcher's methods have affected the way Andrew looks at the world and how he views his drumming as more important than anything else in his life.  This is a movie about obsession, and it pretty much plays out like a thriller to be honest.  The music in the film is absolutely excellent and, while I'm not a big jazz aficionado myself, I certainly appreciate the musicianship and complexity of the genre itself.  Jazz is probably one of the most difficult genres of music to play, especially if you're a drummer.  So I'm very appreciative of the talent it takes to perform this type of music.  The music chosen for this film is excellent and it only helps to enhance the story.  I don't think I've given enough praise to JK Simmons, so let's get back to that for a moment.  This guy believes that the worst two words in  our vocabulary are 'good job'.  He believes that this makes people complacent, whereas with his monstrous methods, some would say, he hopes that he push people towards true greatness.  Regardless of whether his methods leave them in an emotionally fragile state, as proven with the subplot of his previous student who killed himself.  This man is pretty much a gargoyle, as described by Damien Chazelle, who brilliantly wrote and directed the film.  JK Simmons is so goddamn convincing that you honestly buy that he's changed when Andrew meets up with him at the jazz club where he invited Andrew to play drums for him for one last time.  It was really just a ruse to get revenge on Andrew as he changed up the sheets and played a different song than what Andrew was expecting.  Andrew, anonymously, testified against Fletcher's methods, which got him fired.  Fletcher, being an intelligent man, clear knew it was Andrew and he set him up.  But, the way the last act plays out, you're unclear as to whether this was one of Fletcher's methods to motivate Andrew to strive for greatness, or whether it truly took him by surprise when Andrew, after being humiliated during the first performance, took over the show and went into Caravan, the song that has the fantastic drum solo at the end.  That's how good JK Simmons is, you're not exactly sure what the motive was behind this.  This movie is incredible, as you've no doubt noticed.  Fabulous acting and writing.  The story is top-notch and the film grabs your attention from the moment it starts and it never lets go.  It would rank very highly among my favorite films of last year and it definitely needs to be seen.  I would highly recommend this.

The moment that J.K. Simmons appears on screen you know that this performance will be unlike anything he has done before. Whiplash is a mile a minute thrill ride that takes you to the center of a prestigious jazz ensemble that is headed by a man with a temper so quick you feel that fire will erupt from his mouth at a moments notice. I dare you to turn off the film because it grabs you right around the throat, continues to squeeze and doesn't let go until the explosive finale. Whiplash is one of those rare mile-a-minute films that deserves to be hailed as one of the best films in the last few years.

I did not know what this movie was about, I just knew it was critically acclaimed. I laughed so hard at some of the things Mr. Fletcher was saying to and about his students. I soon realized I was the only one laughing and this was by no means a comedy! I still found many things to be hilarious but I subdued my laughter so not to disturb the other movie goers. Later I caught on to the scope of this movie and realized that I am a bad person, and I thank God I don't have kids! I was really blown away by the music and the plot hooks were so awesome. It has really opened my mind up to jazz music, I LOVE and admire the drums although my tastes are more or less heavy metal. Jazz drumming blows metal away (accept maybe for Tool and Rush, because they have very jazz sounding drummers). I would totally see this movie again, I'm curious to find out if I would still find Fletcher funny the second time around! Go see it, (it's not FUNNY!) Ok yeah it was. Whiplash is an intense, incredibly well-acted  movie.  It left me feeling edgy and dialed-up once it was over.  I think most viewers will be emotionally drained by the time this sharp, relentless tour de force for JK Simmons is concluded.  Miles Teller seems like a young John Cusack.  Loved it.
if you wanna see a movie about a guy who is passionate only about  drums, go ahead and watch. I felt like I wasted my time on this...
Captures some of the anxieties that musicians face in life and magnifies them in a big way.

Those who are (un)fortunate to have worked alongside me would probably agree that I don't need much encouragement to sound off (dare I say bitch) about most things or indeed everything and anything. This applies more so to some of the management techniques (or lack of) that I have observed. The creation of a bullying culture and the misguided notion that putting someone under pressure brings out the best in them. Although I accept that there are rare instances where this approach works I firmly believe this is a poor, even lazy tactic. Motivating someone with the carrot instead of a stick takes more smarts and guile and will more often than not achieve more. 
For anyone that has seen the trailers or the recent awards coverage for Whiplash its probably clear which method music teacher Fletcher (J K Simmons) prefers. And this is what drives the story. A succession of aspiring music pupils falling over and treading on each other to be the core musician in a reputable college band. Each of them fighting to be a part of an over bearing, oppressively fearful environment. And throughout this, Fletchers justification is that geniuses such as Charlie Parker thrived in such circumstances and that the students would either sink or swim. If they fail, then it just wasn't meant to be and the ends justify the means.
Whiplash is an interesting and intense film. This is mainly down to Simmons who is magnificent throughout. Brash, aggressive and over bearing yet at times, shows enough empathy to suggest that there might be a good guy deep inside fighting to get out. His presence dominates every scene that he is in and even some scenes that he isnt. The music is not bad either and fans of jazz in particular will warm to this element of the film.
I saw this story a little bit like a reflection of our day to day lives. We are encouraged to work hard, to be determined, to be focused and to succeed often at the expense of others. This is not something I like about the world I live in and Whiplash reminded me of this.

A true masterpiece of the year. From cinematography to score to casting to detecting this movie screams OSCAR. Its cohesive directing along with its intense and inspiring story made this film's success inevitable.

One of the best movies that hit theaters in 2014. Brilliant cinematography, beautiful score, and commendable performances by Teller and Simmons. Whiplash earned its Academy Award nominations and win for best supporting actor.

With congruent tenacity as its lead, Whiplash abundantly underlines the magnitude of passion, of drive, of obsession, and the blurred line that separates self-respect from a pyrrhic victory. Teller and Simmons explode with chilling nuance and multi-faceted fixation, giving the performances of their careers. Whiplash serves as a cautionary tale that gives you the freedom to choose what to caution.

Intense, powerful, and raw. The acting is superb from all involved and I have extensive feelings about the characters portrayed. Might have been better suited to a short film. While I enjoyed the journey, I don't feel like I went anywhere. Surely a great film, but "not my tempo."

Whiplash is astounding, tense, tightly written and packed with powerful tension.  It packs brilliance into the pains of perseverance and exudes and overflows with stylistic flair and a true passion for the craft of film and music, or the synthesis of both.  It's just as much a cinematic spectacle as it is a treat to the ears, and the film does something so few movies dare to consider in building each scene and step of the vivacious editing techniques around the music rather than the other way around.  In awards season, Whiplash certainly earned the awards it deserved but sadly flew under the radar although it fits in the ranks of the films most discussed from this past year.  Whiplash is a true gem of masterful crafting, exceptional competence and electrifying structure that earns its own importance and thereby demands to be watched and remembered.

The acting is superb.  The dialog is honed to the finest edge.  You are apt to be a nervous wreck by the end of this movie.  It is an over-charged emotional carnival ride.  Yes, watch this movie!

The one thing I mark this movie down for is that the music seems secondary to the rest of the film.  Is this how "jazz" is really being taught in music conservatories today?  If so, I now know why jazz is dead or dying.

I fear this is exactly the case though.  How many of the jazz greats from the last 100 years came from a music conservatory?  There's a reason for this:  Jazz is only half about technical skill.  The other half is about conveying emotion through music and improvisation.

Perhaps this is what this movie really shows us at the end when Andrew Neyman finally lets loose with a completely improvised and emotional drum solo.

Whatever the actual statement about jazz as an art form,  the tension and energy of this movie makes the plot work.
Amazing!  Blood, sweat, & tears are shed in the pursuit of greatness.  Incredible performances!  A must see!

Intense. Raw. Sublime. The three emotions that will grip and draw and make you flinch while watching this gem. While receiving criticism for the "creative-license" taken in the portrayal of underbelly of Jazz, it is movie that runs in the league of classics for the sheer emotion of the JKSimmons with his wizened-boxer looks and animalistic  fervour of in Tellers scenes will completely dominate your senses. Watch it to experience and remember what terrific acting feels like in modern movie making.

My 16 year old musician son walked out of the theater, looked at me and said, "That was so good, my hands are shaking!" If you've ever wondered how far you'd go to see how good you could become at anything, this movie will strike a chord. And you were ever a stage band kid in high school, you're for certain going to love it.

The film you can't stop thinking about afterwards. It has a multitude of levels of meanings and concealed statements. They are easily overshadowed by the mordbidly sparking 'abusive teacher - obsessed pupil' relationships brilliantly performed by the leading duo, but there's so much more below and beside it, that you can't stop coming back and thinking over and over what you have seen on the screen. There's just a great deal of ambiguity there, and that what it makes the film great, even though the story may appear quite simple at first.

Fletcher. A professor in a prestigious conservatory, seeking for a new Charlie Parker (so far, in vain); his tutelage appears cruel, on the brink of clear sadism, and he governs his orchestra as a bunch of bootcamp rookies, even addressing (nearly) all-male lineup "ladies". Andrew receives all kinds of hazing and humiliation, which he can barely handle. Later on Fletcher confesses that he does what he does in order to push the musicians beyond their self-perceived limits, towards greatness. And he alone seem to know where this greatness starts: apparently being a professor for years and directing countless orchestras aside, he still cannot find his "new Parker".

At a glance, his methods are shown as clearly unacceptable in the modern society: how many lives has he broken beside the poor Sean Casey's one? How many potentially brilliant musicians failed to stand his pressure, threw their instruments away, and turned clerks and repairmen? On the other hand, Fletchers orchestra(s) harvest awards (those he takes as  pretty mundane commodities). And ultimately he has found his new Parker in Andrew, who, despite being set up almost fatally, doesn't give up. Instead he revolts, and prove himself and earns the much-meaningful smile from his brutal tutor. 

In other words, Fletcher ultimately succeeds, and his methods prove to be, despite their exceeding cruelty, efficient. Doesn't it look like the film's central message? A direct attack on widely-accepted today, overly indulging methods of teaching when even the mediocre and even hopelessly bad students may count on hearing "well done", and they know it?

But then again, there's a question of how much these bootcamp practices are applicable in music classes? What does Fletcher do? - He seems to be turning Andrew into an "insensitive technical whiz", as The New Yorker's film critic Richard Brody called the famous Buddy Rich, whom Miles Teller's character in "Whiplash" heavily aspires to. Fletcher pushes Andrew beyond his limits to what? - a petty mastery? Play fast. Then faster. Faster! This part is yours, Andrew. Is it what make a truly great (jazz) musician? I guess, there can't be a versatile answer on how justified, how plain right or wrong is what Fletcher does with his student. The truth is, there are lots of heavy-handed music tutors and orchestra directors who behave like dictators and tyrants, and still their much-thrashed students and orchestras prove to be very successful and professional after all.  

Now, Andrew. It's easy to perceive him to be an innocent victim of Fletcher's 'assembly of evils', and see him as a hero in the end. Is he either? The character Miles Teller plays (and does so brilliantly and captivatingly) is, again, ambiguous, to say the least. Drumming becomes an obsession to him - for a couple of times we hear how the sounds of his drums get blurred into a solid drone, the obvious moments of (at least partial) insanity. Still, Andrew is so persevering that it leaves a viewer almost ashamed: you can't help recalling your own failures and screw-ups that you have allowed to happen simply because you haven't been committed enough to your then-current goal. 

But there's yet another clearly-pronounced obsession Andrew has: the one with his own self. He's so egocentric that just doesn't feel people around him - mr. Teller's character perpetually hazed, inward sight is extremely indicative here. Andrew has no friends and don't feel wrong about it. He is complacent enough to dump his girlfriend on his quest for greatness, while she is probably the only person beside his over-protective father Andrew got along with. No remorse when he "displaces" Carl's sheet music folder, effectively setting him up. Although reluctantly, he does testify against Fletcher. And later when they meet at the bar, Andrew feels awkward (but not remorseful), and proves to be stupid and self-complacent enough to miss the major red flag above the Fletcher's head and trust him. The boy just doesn't feel who is truthworthy, and who is dangerous.  

In a climax scene, upon seeing Andrew's happy smile in return to Fletcher's much-coveted nod of approval, one may think that getting teacher's smile was a more important goal of Andrew's than achieving the ultimate mastery. He achieves both, but what is next? And what is this "mastery" of his, after all? - an art or an insensitive technique?

But then you watch the climax scene again, hear Andrew insanely skillful playing, and feel like every hair on your head goes a-sparking with electricity that emanates from screen. And you go and promote the film to your fellow musicians with '100% recommended' remarks, and tells them upon watching it 'that's what the real drill is', and they nod, even if reluctantly.

A grand movie that deserves more Academy Awards than it received (at least rewarding JK Simmons is a bullseye), the one that leaves you heavily impressed, electrified, and - profoundly puzzled with ambiguity of its characters and messages.
I don't think I'll be able to get those drums out of my head, great flick!!

Review by Jesse Burleson of VIEWS ON FILM


I probably waited too long to see 2014's Whiplash. In fact, I have already comprised my list of top ten picks for said year. Regardless, if I had to revise things (which is something I don't normally do), this small yet loud Sony Pictures release would be right up at the top. I mean what a tantalizing title for a flick and even a cooler title for one about jazz drumming. One minute you're tapping your feet to its infectious groove. The next minute you are wincing and cringing at its mean spiritedness. Ultimately, Whiplash is powerful and heartbreaking. It's a cold sweat of movie, a real rat-a-tat-tat.

The storytelling starts out a little slow only to pick up mega speed. Andrew Neiman (played by Miles Teller) is a 19-year old student at the prestigious Shaffer conservatory (in New York City). He plays the drums and is ambitious as anyone who has ever walked through its doors. He wants to be one of the great musicians of the 21st century with Buddy Rich and Charlie Parker being his full blown idols. He's also fixated on just playing percussion and nothing else. Finally, he doesn't need friends, a girlfriend, or any type of support system in his life to get the job done. In his way however, is conductor Terrence Fletcher (played by J.K. Simmons, who riffs on a sort of bi-polar version of Lee Emery). He has a boot camp approach to getting his orchestra to play the type of perfected tempo he wants. A moody perfectionist, Fletcher berates everyone physically and mentally. He messes with their heads while pounding their fragile psyches into complete submission (there's a scene where he calls someone a worthless pansy ass, that's a new one). Basically, you fear him every time he enters a room. He is the main antagonist but I'd like to think of him more as a bandshell's version of Bill "The Butcher".

That brings me to the ending of Whiplash which is one that I can't quite describe. It's high tail and it's completely exhausting. Just think of the band Led Zeppelin and its late drummer John Bonham doing the solo to "Moby Dick". That might just give you a clue.

Anyway, kudos to the performances featured here. This is a total triumph for actors Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. It's in an arena like you've never seen them before. J.K.'s persona as a loving dad in Juno plus the softy who does those Farmers Insurance commercials, gone! Teller's dopey characterizations from his plethora of forgotten romcoms, gone! J.K.'s Fletcher is a total hard ass, a real Nazi. Teller's Neiman is cut off from the outside world but in the end, he's a mad cymbal junkie incarnate, a real godsend. Together they make beautiful magic as actors and musical czars. Listen, I know this is a vehicle about excelling in an East Coast conservatory, but both of these characters are seen more as sergeants and privates than anything else. This isn't your normal drama, it's Full Metal Drum Kit.

Kudos also goes to the rousing level of film making for "Whip's" one hour and forty-seven minute running time. Director Damien Chazelle deals in a frenzy of close-ups whether it be the actor's faces, their bloodied hands, or just objects in general. He also provides Whiplash with a couple of whip/swish pans accompanied by the constant sounds of Jazz music (one of the oldest forms of popular music known to man). The film has a shadowy look, it's sullen. Watching every scene feels like you're in a wine bar or a darkly lit restaurant. And the editing which won a coveted Academy Award, is designed to put Neiman's character's romantic life and his relationship with his father (Jim Neiman played by Paul Reiser) off to the side. It then becomes strictly a two person character study, a mishmash of nurse Ratched and convict Randle McMurphy or Andy Dufresne and Warden Norton if you will. Whiplash's themed morality: Sometimes you need to go through hell to find success in what you do. It takes sweat and guts, hits and bruises to achieve greatness. The little people who lack ambition, are nice, and coddle you, matter very minimally in the grand scheme of things (yes I'm talking about Andrew's weak-minded father). Dare I say that this is the best movie of 2014. Whiplash has real "whip" appeal.

Whiplash is a cinematic masterpiece.  I don't say this lightly.  I don't even know where to begin.  The acting mainly consists of Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons, and they bring two performances that will be talked about for years to come.  Teller keeps proving he is a rising star and one of the best young actors in the business, with his physical and mental performance here making each scene more stressful than the last.  J.K. Simmons performance is something out of scripture.  He unleashes a performance that rightly won him an Oscar, and is a role that he was clearly born to play.  He reaches a perfect blend of hilarious and terrifying.  Each scene he enters actually has me fearing for my own life, and it made me crave for Teller's character to reach perfection all the more.  Its rare that a performance could actually give me goosebumps, but Simmons accomplished it and then some.  The writing was flawless.  The characters felt real and the dynamic between Teller and Simmons characters was fascinating.  That sort of student-teacher relationship creates a brilliant story, as instead of some inspirational "Karate Kid" similar tale we instead get a dark and brutal look at the lengths someone will go to impress their mentor and become the best at what they do.  The dialogue was exciting and was perfect for Simmons personality.  The film also touches on pushing people beyond what they can do and what it takes to be remembered for your achievements.  Damien Chazelle's second film has proven he has a strong career ahead of him.  He has created a masterpiece of art, enough said.  People will remember Whiplash for J.K. Simmons unforgettable performance, rightfully so, but his performance would be nothing with the perfect script and direction that it took to bring this great story to life.

Simmons who deserves to walk away with the award.

The best part though is how it displays that even the most brutal if people are still people. Fletcher (Simmons) isn't just some asshole, the film displays how his goal is to push his students to reach their potential. This film will be watched by educators everywhere and they will be "inspired" to emulate Terence Fletcher. I don't care about the great direction in this film. I don't care about the magnificent acting JK simmons put out (for which he won an Oscar). I don't care if by God, this film "inspires" a lot of people. Whiplash, as the name suggests, packs a serious punch. There hasn't been a musical movie, or any movie for that matter, that gives such intense human relationship. The film brings a rich drama performed by engaging actors, it is crude in its nature but also possesses classy rhythm. Its mix of true to live cinematography and brilliantly pace musical score is edited so well, audience can't help to be drawn to its excellent tension.

Andrew Nieman (Milles Teller) is a drummer and student in one of the best music schools. He's recruited by Terrence Fletcher (J. K. Simmons), a well-known teacher who's searching for a new musician to join his band. Nieman is a very dedicated young man, he strives to win Fletcher's approval but little did he know that Fletcher's method of teaching is rather unorthodox. The way Fletcher motivates his students is with a lot of profanities, overly honest assessment and borderline abusive behavior. Lots of stick with barely any carrot.

The two are embroiled in an odd relationship, and both leads perform magnificently. Milles Teller represents the youthful ambitious character with hidden aggressive poise. Whereas Simmons as Fletcher is brilliantly antagonistic, he's a mentor but often time he resembles a manipulative enemy. From his body language and yell Simmons is too convincing, it could be unnerving at times, in the best possible way. If he had the opportunity like this in old Spider-Man movies as he portrayed the pushy editor, they would have been truly amazing.

Camerawork captures the flow meticulously and mostly in close-up, it often pans back or slowly approaches the scene, allowing the audience to have a sense of the setting. However, when the music hits, it goes into high gears. Switching back and forth between the plowing of the drum, characters' subtle expressions or winces, down to the blood and sweat. The film's editing is wonderfully fitting, each frame is also accompanied by a spirited explosion of instruments. It's powerful, inevitably engrossingly.

Whiplash is a monster of a movie, never skipping a beat. Rude, brash but stylishly captivating.

Tenacious. Honest. Borderline psychotic. Whiplash starts with the average drummer boy (pun intended) and ends with a more confident, yet arrogant, and equally brilliant drummer, played by Miles Teller (The Spectacular Now). J.K. Simmons (Juno) plays the role of the cutthroat instructor hellbent on being the best (which he won an Oscar for), and he is a force to be reckoned with. His monologue near the end of the film could hold its own, even against the legendary Glengarry Glen Ross "always be closing" speech delivered by Alec Baldwin in '92. All else aside, this film is a glimpse into the life of a student who just wants the be "one of the greats" and a teacher who doesn't settle for anything less than perfect. 4 out of 5 stars.

Ever had a dream of being a great football player? A great dancer? A great singer? A great musician? Our protagonist has a dream of being a great drummer, a drummer that will be remembered forever. Andrew (Miles Teller) is 19-year old student at a music conservatory in Manhattan. Terrence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) is a teacher at the conservatory with a ruthlessly brutal teaching style. After picking Andrew to play in the school band, he pushes Andrew to his limits in order to realize his full potential, at the risk of his humanity.


I had a billiards teacher at one point in my life, who was close to becoming a pro in his craft but a grease fire accident changed all that. His perspective changed, to paraphrase, he realized he was becoming an asshole. He became a teacher of pool instead of becoming a pro player. Through him, I can understand what Terrence Fletcher was trying to instill into Andrew. My teacher would push me a little bit. When he gave me opportunities to show him up, "run the table now," he would tell me, I failed. It's embarrassing when that happens but it's also a learning tool because more work needs to be done. You can't get by on talent alone but it certainly helps. On the other side of it, I saw a little bit of my teacher in Andrew. Losing who you are to perfect something you love. Good thing my teacher realized before it was too late.

I lost myself in the story. It had something to say about not settling and asking more of yourself. Two fantastic performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. 'Whiplash' is a truly nail-biting movie, with one of the best performances of all time (as far as I'm concerned) from J.K. Simmons. The fact that this is Damien Chazelle's directorial debut is both astonishing and a wildly exciting prospect for the future.

Simmons you a good actor and I like ya, but you do not deserve that Oscar for best supporting actor. I would have given it to Edward Norton for Birdman, plus he is overdo for one. D-

I loved this movie. A tight script with two, nasty, duelling main characters. The teacher/student relationship has been explored many times before, but in this movie the twist is that both are unpleasant in their own way.

Both Teller (as Andrew the student) and Simmons (as Fletcher the teacher) were very good and Simmons definitely deserved the Oscar.

For once, I loved that I did not need to pick a side but I could just enjoy the ride and see how these two ambitious, arrogant and toxic personalities were going to hurt (or help?) each other. Also, I do not usually like open endings, but in this case I found it very appropriate.

The music is great, as it was expected. The photography is also good and the story does not drag along for a single minute, as it happens far too often nowadays. Highly recommended.

Bad news for Miles was that the best actor category was so crowed this year, he really didn't have a shot of getting nominated.

On the other hand, J.K. Simmons (Fletcher)  probably delivers one of the greatest acting performances I have ever seen in film. Every time he was on the screen the audience was in the movie. I wanted more of this character since he was so interesting, you really never understand him, not even after the ending. Anytime where it was just Miles and others, the film was strong, but with J.K. Simmons, the film was incredible.

I find it ironic that a movie about drumming would struggle so greatly with consistency, timing and performance. The movie spends a full 3/4 of the time rushing and dragging between conflict fueled classes to movie dates with dad. We do find consistency in J.K. Simmons - unfortunately it's in his monotone performance, cantankerously pounding us over our collective moviegoer heads with his curmudgeonly confrontational verbal beatings. Simmons plays the part of asshole really well. Just look at him as Peter Parker's boss J. Jonah Jameson. This is basically the same character, minus the cartoonish moustache and cigar. Unfortunately, the similarity between those two films doesn't stop there. As our protagonist sits in a cafe telling his girlfriend they need to break up so he can dedicate his life to his calling, did nobody see that they were re-filming Spiderman 2 and Peter Parker breaking up with M.J.? The only thing missing was Doc Ock throwing a sedan through the window. The shining moment of this film is the last 30 minutes when it really finds its timing, as does our protagonist. Unfortunately it's not enough to redeem the first 80 minutes. In the end, a good movie, but one I feel is out of its league as a Best Picture nominee, as is Simmons' nod for Best Supporting Actor.

Intense, brilliant, ambitious and overall magical, Whiplash shines by it's gripping performances from it's two leads and an excellent care from Damien Chazelle, who enters in the cinematographical world with splendor.

I wasn't a fan of the ending but I understood what it meant, that the coach and Andrew will always be together if Andrew wants to be great.  I also didn't really like how Andrew and Stacy ended up, but it's part of the story, and how he ended up drumming again.  I would say Drumline, the movie, has some competition.

The actors were fine, but the writers were lazy.  Charlie Parker didn't have to go to school to play music.  He never had cymbals thrown at his head.  They were thrown at his feet by another musician he didn't undersatnd what he was playing.   The movie wants to promote the idea that with lots of practice you too can be Louis Armstrong or Charlie Parker, who were poor and didn't go to nice music schools at all.  The movie gives no hint at why the young man wants to be a drummer, and the musics in the movie is for the most part insipid.  Much ado about nothing.  Rather unconvincing and unpleasant.

He isn't some guy who voiced Tenzin in The Legend of Korra. In this movie, he is a psychopathic selfish scary douchebag and he owned that role like he was born to play him! Miles Teller is also a great actor in this movie. He manages to pull off the emotions and thoughts of his character very well that he is invested to his own character and ended up being the character in the movie and not some actor in a movie. That goes the same with J.K. Simmons. Both of them are brilliant actors!

Whiplash's plot pace is slow but not dragging at all. Mainly because there is almost no subplot. This movie is straightforward with its main plot. Sure, you can consider the romance between Miles Teller's character and the love interest played by Melissa Benoist (another great actress) a subplot. That's why I said almost earlier in this paragraph.

In the technical work in this movie, it's brilliantly perfect. The screenplay is of course excellent. The camerawork was on cue without any hint of error. The editing elevates the camerawork brilliantly. The cinematography is excellent and of course, the directing is perfect.

The movie that history will remember from the Oscar Class of 2014. Fiercely original in tone, story and direction, Chazelle directs Whiplash with a refreshing flair and panache without losing his audience in a frenzy of style over storytelling. All the plaudits (deservedly) went to Simmons who knocks it out of the park, but it was Teller who took his role to unexpected places and was every inch a match for his co-star.  Whiplash proves you don't need car chases, global catastrophes or rampaging zombies to create a riveting and intense cinema experience. You can achieve it simply with a great story, engaging characters, actors at the top of their game and an eye for originality. Bravo.

Anyway, back to Whiplash, i imagine, storytellers haven't had enough of romanticising pseudo-intense, military-style, mercurial old bats whose penchant for physically hurting and mentally flogging their team members into shape really should qualify them as psychos, or at the very least, sadistic jerks, but oh wait, they have a tiny speck of gold in their hearts and in their genius brains, and that's worth all the pain, right?

And wherever such attempts were made, they were either awkwardly written, poorly staged, or featured some uneasy camera work, or all of the above.
