A super intense and riveting movie that manages to be just exactly long enough. The pacing in this movie is supreme. However it's not so much about jazz or music as it is about egos and abusive relationships. While the last half hour of this film was definitely the most on-the-edge-of-my-seat I've been in a while, I didn't appreciate the last minute. The teacher was too vindictively nasty, he was proven to have been lying when he said he was doing it for his students best interests with the entire last scenario. Even if he got the result out of this one kid, what was the real cost? (I mean really, at least one dead student!) Plus, who's to say he wouldn't have gotten there without being abused? It was a cop out to have the teacher give him that reassurance, the student should have owned his rebellion, spit in the guys face and walked off.

2 things to learn from this movie for me: 1) It literally takes sweat, tears and blood to even get close to greatness in one's profession, not least in art; 2) for the most exceptional of students, the best teacher is not the one urging and supporting softly or encouragingly but the one urging and supporting violently and (seemingly) discouragingly. J.K. Simmons delivers a brilliant performance worthy of an Oscar statuette, while Miles Teller proves (at least to me) that he is capable of acting competently in artistically sound movies, not just some "lead" roles in fun-to-watch-but-ultimately-meaningless comedies or "blockbusters". The music is also outstanding even for a jazz know-nothing like me.

Does the cultivation of talent require constant verbal abuse, threats & brutal mind games? Whiplash flirts with the idea, as young drummer Andrew (Miles Teller) endures much more than long practice hours & a stifled social life to please his loudly abrasive music teacher & conductor, Mr Fletcher. J.K. Simmons' performance as this bullying Pygmalion is no doubt the actor's fiercest. Fletcher's face curls into a mask of vindictive cruelty in the face of fear or suffering. He sweats & shouts vindictive rage. His gym-rat arms fling furniture & instruments. Fletcher tells us that his harsh discipline seeks to find & forge rare talent & devotion. Tellingly, though, he feels he has nothing to apologize for after a hectored former student commits suicide. Still, humiliated, alone, even bleeding, Andrew returns again & again to prove his talent & dedication to his bullying teacher. Andrew makes doubtful life choices to meet Fletcher on his own terms. If this is a case for tough love, I missed the love part.

Intensely absorbing and energetic with two great performances

Whiplash is only the second movie of 2014 that overly exceeded my expectations (first one being Nightcrawler). Being neither a fan of jazz music nor finding a much stellar cast in this one I must say I was highly impressed. Whiplash is a tightly wound experience that puts forth the intense relationship of a student with his literally brutal mentor. Whiplash provides ample scope for deep study of its characters and their psychology.

Miles Tellers plays Andrew Nieman an aspiring Jazz drummer who is confident and talented. One day at his music school the iconic main school band teacher Terrence Fletcher (memorably performed by J.K. Simmons) observers Andrew practicing. He sees some spark in Andrew but isn't fully convinced of what he is capable of. Fortunately for Andrew on another fine day Fletcher storms into their class asking each student to play what he wants and Andrew impresses playing something which he is very good at. Flecther brings in Andrew into the main school band as an alternative drummer. In order to become the main drummer Andrew has to face the seriously exhaustive and physically draining teaching methodology of Fletcher. Fletcher's motive behind all this is to find the next big jazz star in his students for which believes one should defy the limits. While Andrew is highly motivated and inspired climbing the ladder of success slowly but is unknowingly degrading his personal life. He is unable to keep up with his girlfriend and also ends up with family issues. Whiplash tries to portray what we mind end up with trying to achieve perfection in our field. The ultimate successful moment is very rewarding but many of the earlier hardships and sacrifices get overshadowed.

Breaking down the various aspects of the film, the thing that stands out is the performances by the two leads. Miles Teller driving the enthusiasm and energy into the character of highly motivated drummer is really inspiring. While J.K. Simmon's pitch perfect portrayal of the furiously scary mentor was raw and brutal. Even if the character was unforgettable one thing I would like point out is that it would have been better if more light was shed on Flethcer personal life which would have made his character slightly more believable. After the acting, the terrific music and soundtrack absolutely sucked me into the jazz atmosphere.The track 'Whiplash' over which Flecther throws a chair at Miller for not reaching the perfection is mesmerizing. Whiplash has made me a fan of jazz music out of nowhere. The editing and cinematography is splendid which we can see that in the intense and energetic drumming sequences which will keep you glued to the screen. The final drumming sequence in the climax was so exhilarating, it gave me goosebumps. Director Damien Chazelle who wrote the script himself keeps the screenplay focused on the two main characters. The story is quite unpredictable and you can expect some twists here and there. I found it hard to believe when I read somewhere that the whole film was shot in 19 days. Nothing more to say. Excellent.

To sum it up, Whiplash is one movie of 2014 not to be missed. 2014 has been really outstanding with films like 'Boyhood', 'Birdman', 'Nightcrawler', etc. and now another gem called 'Whiplash'. I am thankful for witnessing such quality film-making. Excellent performances with absorbing story and direction plus the jazz music on top of it made Whiplash a memorable experience which stayed with me for hours after finishing it. It is energetically inspiring and heartfelt. Don't miss it.

RATING: [4.5/5]
It was an excellent new story that was so intense you shared the stress with the main actor.

Riveting right from the opening shot till the end credits, the performances by Miles Teller and J K Simmons leave the viewer astounded. Director Damien Chazelle proves a point that he is a wonderful story-teller and has delivered an absolute masterpiece.

Holy shit, just give J.K. Simmons his Oscar. This film. Is about an eager music student played by Miles Teller, who gets the opportunity to play in Schafer university's most revered jazz group under the direction of T. Fletcher played wonderfully by Simmons. The film features some great jazz ensembles, fun drum solos, wonderful cinematography and acting.
One does not have to be a music major in order to appreciate this film. Similar to "Black Swan" where the focus is not on actual art (like ballet) it's more focused on the profile of these characters, how hard they will push to attain their goals, or how tempted will they be to gain approval. I thought I'd never say it but the annoying kid from Projext X also needs a nomination. Teller does a great job of presenting to the audience of a character that is striving really hard to be something. His character eliminates any support from the outside world to perfect his talent. He isolates himself from his family and girlfriend. He outright disrespects others in the jazz ensemble in order to maintain his role in the group. Teller's character is so desperate that he will avoid any physical signs of hurt or pain in order to play in the ensemble. This film depicts a good example of anxiety, depression and obsession. Teller's character becomes a prick to others in order to perfect his craft, however I don't think this would be considered to be a character arc. Why, because I feel that his character has always been like that. Being in a class with a ruthless band leader only enabled him to become so obsessed that he blocks out any outside support. Being part of the best jazz ensemble in New York only fed into his ego. Teller has a borderline personality disorder. From the beginning we can tell that he is somewhat of an introvert, he doesn't socialize with anyone at his old music class and his social network really consist of his father. Besides his girlfriend that he he attained after finally mustering up confidence after being accepted in the band of his dream; Neiman has no friends, however he has an inflated view of self. Friends are in intricate part of anyone's life because they act as a support network for confidence, and it helps us realize how others view us. Which, let's be honest, we view ourselves differently than others view us. It doesn't matter how others perceive you, we will always view ourselves to the highest regard. Neiman has always had an inflated view of himself as a special drummer. Evident in the dinner scene where he shuns his siblings goals. Neiman realizes that he's the black sheep in the family. This role has made him highly competitive with his siblings in order to gain acceptance and respect amongst his family. Also, in the beginning Andrew doesn't seem happy to be with the band he started out with prior to joining Fletcher's ensemble. Probably because he feels as if that band was not on his level of talent. There are so many examples that feed into the disorder of the character. Also teller does a great job on the drums.
Now to the performance that everyone is talking about, J.K. Simmons. Not only is his character a great villain but also what i may consider to be one of the greatest movie villains of all time. If AFI updated there list of villains I would not be surprised to see him on that list. This is the type of villian that makes you (the viewer) cringe when someone in the band screws up. Teller's character is about perfection but it ain't shit compared to how maniacal Simmons character is portrayed. A great quote about "The worst thing to hear is Good job" and his story about Charlie Parker, sums up this character. We can tell that his character wants to get the best potential out of his students but he will go through blood, sweat and tears to get it. J.K. Simmons present this character as unpredictable, you don't know when he will throw a chair or just start yelling. He pulls off a great stoic performance, which is why it creeps us out when he is pissed. We the audience understands that he is angry however we don't know what action he will take next to express it. Simmons character is both physically and emotionally abusive. However he played the character just right, he could've easily went into r. Lee emery territory with Full Metal Jacket. But Simmons plays the role just right, some of the stuff he says is somewhat funny (if you have a dark sense of humor) but is still disturbing. 
The cinematography adds to the disturbing atmosphere of this film. The colors are very warm, it has a nice late-night jazz club look to it. The colors or dark and light is dimmed. The dark atmosphere inside the band room really heightens the intensity of the performances (preferably J.K. Simmons). This is an excellent use of camera work and direction to enhance the film.
Overall, Simmons has done a memorable performance. A role so great that I may be frightened if I see him in another one of those Farmer's insurance commercials. He deserves whatever award  is granted to him. Mr. Fletcher will be one of the best villians in film history.

Totalitarian discipline and chaotic jazz meet in Danmien Chazelle's "Whiplash," the former drummer's second full-length feature based on his 2013 short film of the same name. 

Miles Teller plays dedicated music student Andrew who is determined to be not only a great but legendary drummer. He has already made it into a respected conservatory, but that's not enough. He needs to be noticed by Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), the most notorious and infamous jazz teacher in the school. He is, and soon gets to play second fiddle to Fletcher's main drums student. It becomes immediately apparent that all bets are off within Fletcher's classroom, no method of teaching too brutal.

"Whiplash" can basically be reviewed with one sentence: a largely useless script directed with exceptional vision. The dialogue is weak, the themes unfocused, the plot predictable yet implausible, but it's all told through such a wonderful jazzy cacophony that the film ends up being much more captivating than it earns to be.

There's been a lot of praise for the main acting duo, and they do fortunately make most of their roles. Simmons redoes his Schillinger from prison series "Oz" and Teller portrays an arrogant and ultimately obsessed student with conviction. This is fortunate, as the characters are both scripted in a frustratingly calculating manner; Fletcher an authoritarian despot with underscored moments of softness or what tries very hard to be character depth, Andrew a driven and largely unsympathetic victim slash worshipper of his teacher. 

Both men are engulfed by mania, spiraling into a power dynamic of sadomasochistic dimensions. Fletcher eats at Andrew's humanity and Andrew is willing to let it all be eaten in the altar of success. Family and love become meaningless as a singular goal fills his whole existence.

What "Whiplash" might be at its best is a psychological examination of sinister social phenomena. The dynamic it presents begs to be taken as a human-scale depiction of totalitarian seduction or descent into extremism. Chazelle doesn't force feed the interpretation, though. On the contrary, the film makes a strong case for Fletcher's methods philosophically while condemning them psychologically. Totalitarian regimes sometimes are truly efficient. It's usually a smart move to leave a piece of fiction open to differing interpretations, but here it seems a bit like an incongruous cheat that reduces the overall plausibility even further.

The jazz is amazing. Sharone Meir's cinematography and Tom Cross's editing complement the killer soundtrack perfectly. Every drum solo is almost unbearably dramatic. Watching Fletcher and Andrew and listening to the music makes you feel keenly the way Fletcher's methods are tarnishing the beauty of what is being created with them. The manic drive for perfection seems especially obscene as the music enchants through its freedom of creativity.

Few might expect an indie drama about a dysfunctional mentor-student relationship about jazz-drum can be such a thrilling adrenaline drive, WHIPLASH, which not only proudly joins the elite top 8 in the upcoming Oscar BEST PICTURE nominees, but is also counted as a major contender in for a harvest (with J.K. Simmons undisputedly has BEST SUPPORTING ACTOR in his bag). It is also hard to imagine this is only young director Damien Chazelle's second feature, after his less-seen debut GUY AND MADELINE ON A PARK BENCH (2009), WHIPLASH is such a full-grown piece of gem, with the slithering camera movement, a plethora of intensive close-ups and snappy editing, a buzzy audio surrounding and the irresistible jazzy soundtrack, it engages us with a daunting study of the pursuit of being the greatest and a spellbinding and unblemished mental orgasm in its fierce solo-drum finale.

WHIPLASH is a great film about the drive for artistic excellence and the sacrifices one makes. Set in a NYC music school, it's well told, tautly edited with great performances from Miles Teller and the sinewy JK Simmons, who dominates this film in a way seldom seen. He'll win an Oscar for sure. There' a lot of Johnny Carson era big band and jazz music--but it's well chosen and I never got tired of it. Worth seeing before Oscar night!

The big problem for me is that I didn't believe for a second that any school would allow a teacher to rant and rave and throw chairs at students such as J.K. Simmons' insane take on this music teacher.  And I never saw Simmons' actually teach anything. I know there have been rave reviews for this one, but the only time I found this film to be "exhilarating" or "electrifying " was during the drummer's (Miles Teller) truly astounding drum solo .  And I just don't like profanity for the sake of profanity, and this screenwriter piled it on! I believe this is an adaption of another source, and I guess they edited out any believability .  I'm giving this one two stars, both for Teller's great performance.

For only the second time in my life the audience applauded at the end of a film. Yet this spontaneous gesture didn't seem at all hyperbolic, the reason for that becomes more apparent when you watch the final scene. Whiplash is an energetic film complimented with a great script and an outstanding performance from its star J.K. Simmons. This film is the 'Rocky' of the music genre film in more ways than one and J.K. Simmons has a Rocky story of his own. An actor whose stunning performance is destined to take him from a career of supporting cast obscurity into the limelight at 60. Whiplash though owes its success in a larger part to the great pacing of the film. The film doesn't lag at any moment which is felicitous as it's a film in which the jazz class at the school rehearse the emphatic jazz melody 'Whiplash'. Importantly you don't have to be a fan of Jazz or even music to enjoy this film of sturm und drang.

A movie about pushing people to the brink of breaking or greatness, Whiplash is awe-inspiring in it passion and has a level of intensity in its later moments that is simply unmatched by most films you'll likely see. Teller and Simmons are riveting and pack so much punch in their roles. The direction by Chazelle is compelling and vigorous, yet at times as smooth as the jazz the musicians are playing. This is the best indie film of 2014 and should be experienced.

Above all else, it's a toe-to-toe showcase for Miles Teller and J. K. Simmons, the former finally proving he can be taken seriously as an actor and the latter giving a career, Oscar-level performance that hopefully leads to bigger and better opportunities for him. This is one of the most unforgettable films of 2014.

When I first considered viewing the phenomena that is the 5-time Oscar nominated 'Whiplash' it was with a small amount of trepidation believing that this was a Rudy character study of overcoming tremendous odds in the world of contemporary Jazz.  I was, however, revitalized during the film to learn how wrong my assumptions were, this film was about overcoming odds, but on a much grander scale... at least that's what the film would have you believe.  And it did, the film was successful in it's endeavor to make me believe that the goal of prestigious Jazz instructor (J.K. Simmons) to find and mentor a legend on par with Charlie Parker and the methods he employs to achieve this goal.

     All the performances given in this move were on point with the depth and complexity that was certainly on the page.  Miles Teller is always engaging and keeps the audience on the side of his character Andrew which at times is a difficult gambit with his single minded focus and drive.  Personally I find him representative of a younger set of interesting actors who are more Dustin Hoffman than Brad Pitt, not that he is necessarily an everyman, but you aren't likely to see him on a Calvin Klein billboard anytime soon.  J.K. Simmons is more or less playing the same character as Teller, just from a different point of life, career, and potential; his Oscar nomination is well deserved and if you're familiar with his work dating back to Oz through parts on several Coen Brothers films and of course in the Spiderman franchise, this won't be a total shock.  Watch also for Paul Reiser, who makes hay with the small amount of screen time he does have, especially the understated performance his gives in the closing scene.

     The real surprise of this move for me is how much I enjoyed the music; not being a particular fan of Jazz I found the selections engaging and also exceptionally listenable as this is a real music movie considering the fact that we are mostly following one character and his obsessive practicing of the same pieces.   On that note it's important to notice how claustrophobic the cinematography is and how effective it is in conveying the personal nature of the film but also demonstrating the cramped spaces that I'm certain the best musicians in New York must suffer considering the premium on real estate that they endure.  

	In closing 'Whiplash' has my highest recommendation, it set out to demonstrate how and what costs are involved with developing a legend, but doesn't overstep it's bounds and become fantastical.  Balanced and nuanced, great music and performances, in the age where the zeitgeist seems to be screaming for an original story that doesn't rely on special effects to wow an audience this is one that needs your support to ensure more of its ilk have an opportunity to see the celluloid of day.
Took me back to my days of high school jazz band when we had a conductor that yelled, insulted and threw stuff at us... ahhh, good times!

That was an anxiety attack of a film. It made me miss band despite the insanity going on but I haven't felt that tense in a film in a long time.

Andrew Neilman is a first year drum student and basically wants to be Buddy Rich. He catches the attention of Terence Fletcher, a well respected and feared teacher. What follows is the eternal audition from hell. Fletcher encourages at first but belittles and humiliates more often than not. Nielman continues to try and reach these standards and keep up with Fletcher's ever changing moods and whims. It is really a horror to watch let alone endure. 

Fletcher wants to encourage the next great. Is this a valid strategy? The film seems to suggest yes but at quite a cost.

I can certainly appreciate the Oscar buzz as well as J.K. Simmons' psychotic performance.
The best film I have ever seen
A story of never giving up your greatest dream, regardless of who is shamelessly harassing you, could not be put into anything as convincing and compelling as this one.
A truly gripping exploration of what it takes to be the best of the best. Though none of the characters were likable, they were still believable and excitingly passionate.

Nothing short of five-star performances. Chilling and emotional, repellent and yet sobering, this movie is in perfect harmony with all of its moving parts. The story brilliantly captures one man's struggles to be great, and the lengths he is willing to go to achieve it. If this movie doesn't stir ambition and drive in you, few things likely can.

While Simmons's character is an abrasive and explosively angry character, it is the emotion that is conveyed through the music and the non-verbal tension that is felt.  The rise and fall in tempo of the Jazz music playing in the background perfectly embodies the mood and feeling of each scene.  This movie is easily one of the best of 2014.  Too bad it didn't win Best Picture, but Simmons definitely deserved his Best Supporting Actor win!

Were it not for Boyhood, this movie should have been THE movie of 2014! Highly reccomend it! Go see it!

Stupendously edited and amazingly directed by Damien Chazelle in one truly impressive directorial debut, Whiplash is undoubtedly one of the best US dramas of the 2010s decade as this highly thought-provoking viewing experience. Exploring whether or not the ends justify the means in regards to the abusive teacher-student relationships, Whiplash showcases just how difficult it is to achieve greatness in any art while also making us think about the loss of true greatness these days and whether or not that's connected to the lack of a bigger imitative. Miles Teller is fantastic and J. K. Simmons rightfully won an Oscar thanks to his magnetic turn as Terence Fletcher. The ending is also powerful in its intensity.
really good movie. J K Simmons was really amazing in it.

Interesting movie, but not my favorite. The acting was good especially by the conductor of the band. It was nice to see a movie not at all focused on the love story. The lead actor did well, but he wasn't entirely relatable. I didn't feel myself cheering for him, probably because he was a self-centered jerk. I did love the twist in the last scene when he played on stage. It's a decent movie, but I am surprised that it got nominated for best picture.

"Whiplash" tells the story of the imperious relationship between a hard driving music professor and a very ambitious 19-year-old jazz drummer. Propelled by electrifying performances of both J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller, it is one of the more intense films to come out in 2014.

Simmons plays Terence Fletcher whose personality borders on the psychotic with a very intimidating and tormenting teaching style. His student, Andrew Neiman, on the other hand, is so driven to become one of the great musicians that the badgering and the browbeating become fuel to his passion, dream and to achieve perfection.

Andrew is that student that will take his mentor's intimidations and insults. But he will also fight for a position in a band that he feels is deservedly his. The film is one that will make audiences uncomfortable. "Whiplash" is unlike any other film before it about a student and teacher. It challenges the norm and takes that unconventional path leading to its third and final act. It is a complex study of two minds and Chazelle manages to tell the story in a riveting fashion.

Psychologically and emotionally powerful, it is an uncompromising look and deep study of a descent into madness inasmuch as it is a triumphant journey of an ascent to greatness. It is one of the best films of 2014.

Whiplash has everything you could want from a thriller but placed into the most unlikely setting imaginable needless to say it is tense,thrilling and at times brutal to watch.An incredible first effort from Damien Chazelle.
One of the best edited films I've seen and what a performance by J. K.  Simmons and Miles Teller!

I was really looking forward to this one after all the great reviews. I lost a lot of respect for it after the car crash scene. It disappeared into the realms of nonsense and never really recovered. Not a bad show, but the 95% rating is an insult to some of the greatest films ever made. Reviewers need to catch a grip of themselves, this film will be forgotten about  in two or three years time.

Miles Teller has a lot to do and while he isn't as strong as JK Simmons, he pulls his weight and he's equally compelling. The story is well told and the ending is just superb. It was my favourite ending of 2014, you literally want to stand up and cheer at the end. I remember thinking, "I hope it ends right here it would be so awesome!" And it did! Definitely check this one out when you can!

An intense, unforgettable masterpiece about the troubled relationship between a brilliant music instructor (J.K. Simmons) and a young drumming protégé (Miles Teller), and how the teacher employs harmful mental abuse and torture techniques in order to bring out the best in his students. This is without question one of the best films I have seen, thanks mainly to the riveting turns from both Simmons (who gives a legendary turn that will not be forgotten) and Teller (matching his co-star every step of the way), but also how director Damien Chazelle develops his story and introduces shocking twists and turns along the way. This movie is a masterpiece, and every sequence, especially the grand finale, is masterfully handled.

This movie was really good, but the abusive relationship between Neyman and Fletcher is awful than I can ever imagine. Neyman tries so hard to make himself a good drummer and at first he gets accepted, but then Fletcher makes the other guy, who was in his other band class, try to take his place to make him work harder. I think this is really unfair. He tries to break him down from who he is, to make him work hard. He works so hard that he sweats and bleeds for the position. He makes it, but then everything goes down hill. He gets in a wreck and doesn't play well, making him cut from the position. Afterwards he does a case, but privately so Fletcher won't know it's him. Later when he plays for Fletcher again, he knew it was him and he does the same abuse to him that he did before. Neyman finally gets tired by it and tries to show him how good this is,  but this still gives Fletcher the power to control how long he does.

The movie all and all is good, but the relationship they have makes me resent Fletcher more and makes me happy that Neyman finally proves to him how good he is.

Miles Teller became a great drummer and probably the best drummer in the world base on the movie, and JK Simmons is the one who made him that. That's what I like the best. I was not disappointed. Simmons masterfully dominates the screen with a dazzling performance rarely seen in cinema. He plays the perfection obsessed conductor/teacher of a Jazz school orchestra who accepts nothing less than perfection of his students.  

I liked the movie because of my experience as a 16 year veteran of the San Francisco Opera. The obsession for perfection is real. I see it in every singer, musician, actor, director, conductor, manager, stage hand and everyone else. The truth of this movie is real, anything less than perfection will not be tolerated.

This movie should be liked by anyone who was ever in a band, in the music industry, interested in the music industry or just wants to see amazing acting. It is not for action movie junkies or anyone who cannot tolerate blistering profanity.

A gritty, pulsating, and sharp, [though a bit sophomoric] psycho-drama about how far a person can go by doing more than "their best". My little brother is currently a sophomore in high school and plays the baritone in band. He hasn't seen this movie before, but it would definitely corrupt him!

What a movie! I don't know where to begin. Ok let's start at Miles Teller. He was fantastic in this movie and I wanted to see him succeed more than ever in this movie. JK Simmons... Wow! He plays probably the biggest asshole I've ever seen in a motion picture. When the villain of a movie does his evil deeds and it makes me want to jump into the movie and punch him in the face, that's the sign that the movie has a great antagonist. I've never hated a "bad guy" in a movie since Ivan Drago in Rocky IV. Playing in a jazz band for 5 years, this movie was really relatable (except for having a band teacher throw chairs at your head and making you cry in class) But the ending......One of the best in movie history! Not gonna lie, this movie can be hard to watch at times because of the pain and suffering the main character has to go through but a movie that everyone must see!

A visceral, calculating look into the extreme, pulse-bounding, never ending rush that is Andrew Neyman. A brilliantly shot, realistic film, it is tied together by career-best performances from Miles Teller's powerhouse-of-emotions and determination Andrew to JK Simmons no-holds-bars, maniacal and musical connoisseur Fletcher. Topping the film off is an unbelievable drum solo by Teller/Andrew as he becomes interwoven with the part, sucking Fletcher in with him, proving his worth and thrilling viewers with something never seen before.
Just wow. Kept me edged to the chair and getting such an experience from a music film is great.
Whiplash and Boyhood are the giants of 2014

My mind was just blown away on not only how great the storytelling is, but how stupendous the acting is. You can feel every emotion and it's just intriguing that it pulls you into the story. Truly a great experience.

Whiplash is a very simple story. It is about a young man named Andrew who goes to school at a music conservatory because he dreams of being a great drummer. He is accepted into an exclusive jazz group by an extremely tough (and that's an understatement) director who pushes his students using very extreme measures. The story is literally that simple, there isn't some intricate plot with deep motives and complicated twists and turns, it's simply a battle between one instructor who demands perfection and one student who wants to attain it. Yet I cannot express to you how much I loved this movie. The easy thing for them to do would have been to write J.K. Simmons' character as just a pure evil presence who does nothing but scream and seethe for an hour and a half. Yet Damien Chazelle wrote the character with emotional depth and Simmons pulled off an out-of-this-world performance that nailed everything from rage to sorrow to joy. Miles Teller matches Simmons by showing amazing passion and drive which is essential for this role. What was really remarkable was how Teller still managed to make Andrew a likable character that we were rooting for despite the way he put drumming before the people in his life.

It's hard for me to explain why I'm so passionate about Whiplash. All I know is that my wife and I literally talked about it non-stop for about 2 hours after we left the theater and I was extremely anxious to tell others about the experience. I became so invested in the story of this movie that I tensed up repeatedly, despite the fact that all they were showing was a kid drumming. Not since Gravity have I left a movie theater feeling like I'd been through something so intense and dramatic. I swear I almost wasn't breathing for the last 10 minutes of the movie. The writing is so solid, and they cut together the scenes just right to keep the story moving. So many scenes stuck with me, and I almost wanted to go right back and watch the movie again that same day. The cinematographer used some great camera moves that added something to a number of scenes and just accentuated the emotions the audience was feeling. I even loved the music that they played in the film, and how the ending allows the audience to draw their own conclusions. I was close to holding back my rating for this film because it's hard for me to give a perfect rating to a movie I just saw for the first time but considering how much I have raved about Whiplash, and how I can't get it out of my mind, I honestly can't think of what it could have done better. This is a great film that I cannot recommend more!

With outstanding performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons, along with the clear-cut editing, Whiplash provides an exhilarating movie experience that will leave you smiling. And don't forget the great music that is provided!

Anyone awaiting The Fifty Shades of Grey while wondering what a torture chamber is should go for this instead, in which you'll find no music teacher and pupil but sadist and masochist. Oscar-nominated J.K. Simmons' macho makes Dwayne The Rock Johnson seem like a flower arranger.

Whiplash is about a young musician, Andrew aka Miles Teller, who wants to achieve greatness and he might be able to do that under his mentor, Fletcher aka J. K. Simmons. Fletcher is relentless in his pursuit of pushing his apprentices to do more and more even up to the point of breaking them. Andrew is humiliated, verbally abused at, mentally exhausted, physically threatened, all for the purpose of making him achieve his full potential. To find the next big thing in Jazz music. Fletcher wont stop at anything less than perfect. The final performance is gripping, tension between Andrew and Fletcher at its peak, it can't be justified in a line.
Fletcher: There are no two words in the English language more harmful than 'good job'.
Its no wonder that it got 5 Oscar nominations. And J.K.Simmons chances of getting an Oscar are quite bright!
Wow, what a ride! J K Simmons absolutely deserves Best Supporting Actor for this, hands down.

Trapped from minute 1 to the ending. One of the best cinema achievements I've seen in years. Chazelle drives you all the way, but never tells you what you should think or feel, which makes the journey much more exciting, enjoyable and ritcher.

The Perfect embodiment of what many would call a perfect film. in all its traditional outstanding aspects that makes you believe in the power of cinema. Its the inspiring tale of an ambitious young Jazz Drummer encountering the difficulties and roadblocks with his own career path and a terrifying but well renowned instructor. This film can be summed up as incredibly well acted, fast paced, deeply engaging story, beautifully shot and directed but more importantly a film that delivers a great lasting impression on the audience. I swear if J. K. Simmons doesn't win the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor I will be just as pissed off as his character is on screen. Once you watch this film you will be glad you've seen it and will be eager to tell your friends and family all about it, I guarantee they too will enjoy it just as much if not more.

With very exhilarating and intense sequences, and a remarkable performance from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons, "Whiplash" is an extraordinary film from Damien Chazelle and is one of the best films of the year.

Whiplash is so rich with depth and meaning. An outstanding film with outstanding performances by Miles Teller and JK Simmons. Teller is a determined percussionist that wants to succeed by all means. Simmons is an abusive authoritative music instructor that has no limits. In the end he breaks the young percussionist. The film sheds light on an area of art that many people overlook. It also shows us that success comes with many sacrifices. Sometimes that sacrifice can be your own well being. It also shows the power of an authoritative figure and explores the gray area of abuse to our someone harder. There's just so much greatness in Whiplash. Well worth of its Oscar noms.

Whiplash is an extremely dark movie. It shows us how far we can go in order to be remembered. In order to become famous and be well-known in society. Do we sacrifice everything we are as a human being? Do we forget our family and loved ones? When do we stop creating social and personable bonds with others? What is the price for society's version of "success"?

Like the layers of an onion, this film can be peeled away to reveal many different facets to story arc that is anything but simple. It demands a conversation long after the credits roll as to how far does one go to "perfect" their craft. The relationship between teacher and student is laid out for the viewer to determine on their own whether this is an abuse of power, or a means of achieving greatness in the arts. A fascinating film that still haunts me.
This movie just brought me a huge smile to my face when I finished watching it! That's how good it is.

Whiplash: Sorry to disappoint but there are no thigh-booted ladies in this. Rather the title refers to an intricate jazz piece. Andrew Neyman is prepared to undergo almost any ordeal in his quest to become a drummer-extraordinaire. His biggest obstacle appears to be his tutor and leader of the band he aspires to play with: one Terence Fletcher, superbly played by J.K. Simmons. On more than one occasion we suspect that Fletcher is imbued with a touch of sadism. And it almost feels as if - rather like the son forever trying to please an impervious father -  Neyman, wittingly or unwittingly, becomes the perfect submissive victim. Perhaps there is a clue in the title after all! But, risky as it may have been, I would have preferred it to have been pursued if that was the intention. I certainly feel there was further room for manoeuvre as far as the development of the two central characters was concerned.   
Even so, at times this is as taut as the drum-skin that Neyman pounds. It's original, it's compelling and, although it fails to reach all the high notes, it still hits the spot.

One simple word springs to mind when I think of Whiplash. Just one word... "Oz". 
Those are that familiar with the HBO series that ran from 1997 to 2003 will no doubt remember the brutal intensity of the white supremacist character Vern Schillinger. It was one of my first experiences of actor J.K. Simmons and ever since then I've been a big fan. Now I'm not suggesting that Simmons is the only thing about this film that strikes you but he'll mostly be the thing that leaves you continually thinking about it. 

At a highly prestigious music school, 19 year old Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) is determined to prove his worth as a drumming student. However, in order to prove himself he has to go through the exacting conductor Terrence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons). Fletcher is a man who accepts nothing but the best and to impress him becomes an arduous ordeal for young Neiman.

Inspirational teachers are often depicted in film with great respect and admiration. They often touch the hearts of their pupils and bring out the best in them. In Oscar nominated turns, Richard Dreyfuss' played music teacher Glenn Holland in the little-seen Mr. Holland's Opus and as the passionate English professor John Keating, the late Robin Williams achieved the same in Dead Poets Society. Two thoroughly heartwarming characters that inspired their students to want to learn and grow. Whiplash, however, takes an altogether different path; J.K. Simmons' Terence Fletcher certainly inspires his students but it's not through admiration or respect, it's through spite and a determination to prove his vehement criticism wrong. As a result, the film becomes a highly charged, back and forth, exchange between teacher and pupil. 

The back and forth tension between the two characters almost reflect the instrument at the centre of the film itself; caught in the snare or Fletcher's marching bass, Neiman is like the clashing symbol trying to break out. There's a constant beat between them that director Damien Chazelle captures wonderfully. He has complete control over his scenes and when the moment is called upon to hold tight and build the tension, he does so with the ability of a director with twice his experience. Added to which, he manages to maintain this approach until the very end making Whiplash a great achievement in only his second film (after the Jazz musical Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench in 2009 he originally delivered Whiplash as a short film which won the Short Film Jury prize at Sundance Film Festival before being funded for a feature length film).

In order for Chazelle to realise his vision, though, he must have the actors to pull it off and he does; Young Miles Teller breaks free from his earlier romantic comedy roles to deliver a work of real maturity while Simmons is simply electrifying. As mentioned earlier, though, if you've seen Oz then this will be of no surprise to you. He's an absolutely ferocious and towering presence that dominates every scene he's involved in. Having already won numerous critical and festival awards including the Golden Globe - as well as being hotly tipped to take the Best Supporting Actor Oscar - it finally looks like Simmons has caught people's attention. I can only say... it's about fucking time. Simmons has been doing outstanding work for over 20 years now. No matter how big or small or how dramatic or comedic, he always delivers and no one, at this time, is more deserving of praise for their efforts than this man. Welcome Mr. Simmons! There's certainly no need for introductions. It's always a pleasure having you.

A film about obsessive personalities and how they drive people to incredible highs and lows. It isn't just about drumming or jazz or being a musician. I love jazz. I am a jazz musician. I love all the jazz references in the film. But that is just the surface you could transpose the same motivations to, say, being a footballer, a golfer, a tennis player or a businessman - or whatever! To become brilliant at something you have to be obsessive and driven otherwise it is not going to happen. Yes the characters do not seem to have many dimensions. That is because the single-minded obsession to be a brilliant musician leaves little room for anything else. However, even that is not true as is alluded to by the stilted attempt at dating which is quickly jettisoned if there is a hint it might what is required to become brilliant. This obviously portends the inevitable relationship difficulties a musician will face. I know. Been there. Obsessed myself to death. Practised all night and all day. Chastised myself to death. I know loads of musicians in the same tram lines of thought and behaviour, and indeed artists and sportsmen/women. The really interesting question is why are humans motivated to go through these self-imposed tortures.

A first-year music student out of his depths. A brilliant, yet terrifying music conductor blissfully ignorant to the repercussions of his actions. A battleground of music sheets, slapping, blood, sweat and tears. Damien Chazelle's Whiplash is a simple movie, with a simple premise, a spectrum of colorful language and two of the best performances of 2014. With one of the tightest scripts, and a highly personal, vivid style of cinematography and unforgiving editing in recent years, Chazelle's virtuoso in directing the elements in his movie barely gives his audience any breathing room as he progressively turns the movie into a chaotic and paradoxically symphonic battleground by pitting Neimann and Fletcher against each other.

Going so far as to drop the possibility of a personal life, Neimann's inherent urge to prove his family wrong by being one of the best drummers of the 21st century has him entering the crosshairs of Fletcher, the master of puppets masquerading as a macho conductor that instils fear into the souls of his students in an attempt to push those under him to succeed. As Fletcher's latest target and a greenhorn of the band, Neimann bears the brunt of the torture while his classmates look away in fear. Just when the movie appears to lose steam and turn predictable, Fletcher throws a steel chair at the viewer's head as he violently steers the movie into a different, unexpected direction, as both Neimann and him continue their struggle for dominance and respect over the other.

Whiplash works due to how simple it sounds on paper, but instead reveals a deep, introspective character study of two very different individuals for those who dig deep enough, and how the core story only ever lies on the varying forms of interaction between Neimann and Fletcher, along with their personal, perfectionist obsessions to give them the fuel, fire and that which they desire. As their relationship and characterization were something that Chazelle progressively developed, the script was also aided by the performance of both Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons' outstanding show of manic dedication and gravitas respectively towards bringing their characters to life.

Simmons transforms the very act of verbally berating and physically abusing a music student into a hypnotic, disturbing art form with a physical performance that oozes nothing but grim, pitch black Lovecraftian terror, while Miles Teller puts up an act as a perfectionist turned victim of abuse that finally snaps into one deserving of riotous acclaim. Neither should be praised over the other as their performance and characters are symbiotically reliant on bouncing and leeching off each other, as both deliver an outstanding performance in their own unique and twisted way.

"Whiplash" is an intense look at the competitive nature of conservatory training and the old-school teachers that fuel the fire.  The tone is set from the slow snare accelerando that opens the film over a blank screen.  While the language was brutal, this film tears down the glamorous image of show business and demonstrates what it really takes to be a professional musician.   Any person who plays jazz or loves to listen to it will enjoy the stories, the attitude, and the music.  I don't understand how Justin Hurwitz didn't receive an Oscar nomination for this incredible jazz-based score.  The complexity of the title song that begins in 7/8 and continually changes meters is accompanied by the tamer incidental music that keeps our minds on jazz from start to finish.  But the main reason to see this film is J.K. Simmons, who taps into a dark place that I have never seen from him.  He has forever been known as a character actor (my favorite role being Mr. Pancake in "The Ladykillers"), but this will slingshot his late career and probably win him an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.  The character, based off of the director's real life high school jazz band conductor, is a little overdramatic at times but embodies the old-school mentality of motivating through a demand for perfection.  The story has a few surprises, none of M. Night Shyamalan proportions, but its energy and intensity is enough to drive it from start to finish.  One of the most important aspects of the film is that the music is genuine.  Most of the cast is comprised of professional musicians and Miles Teller is actually playing these charts.  The combination of Teller's own rock drumming experience and two months of "jazz drumming bootcamp" (ironically provided by Nate Lang, his rival in the movie), we see Teller's real drumming chops every time that he is seated at the set.  But what about that incredible Caravan drum solo?  Editor Tom Cross "created" this drum solo by splicing together pieces of drum solos played by Teller over the course of TWO DAYS!  The solo itself gives this film a shot at an Oscar for Best Editing.  Even if Teller cannot play any of these pieces straight through, I am so thankful that director Damien Chazelle chose to cast legitimate musicians and add an extra layer of realism to the film.  The final product is stunning and will keep you on the edge of your seat as much as any action movie or sports drama out there.  It won't win the Oscar for Best Picture, but it actually has a shot at Best Screenplay and Best Sound Mixing, even against "Interstellar."  "Whiplash" tells a gripping story through great acting, intense dialogue, the intimidation that many of us have felt in a heated band rehearsal, and a truly awesome ending - Damien Chazelle has composed a masterpiece.

Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons star in one of the most surprising films in recent years Whiplash; a film that is so powerful and emotionally driven it will literally leave you speechless when the credits roll. This movie has an insane amount of hype following it and it is very rare that a film follows through. Whiplash is this weird exception because it follows through on the hype and the delivers even more. This is a very fast paced, very intense, and exceeding rewarding film that will inspire you as well as leaving a lasting impression. The story here revolves around a young man named Andrew who has a passion for playing drums in a jazz band at his school. When Terrance Fletcher, the most acclaimed maestro on campus, notices him and invites him to play for him; Andrew is pushed to every limit imaginable and thus we have our movie. This film is both written and directed by Damien Chazelle and he delivers one of the most well written films that I have seen in recent years. His script flushes out his characters perfectly, it keeps you on the edge of your seat and it actually leaves a lasting impression on you. His directing skills are also top notch here. This was filmed in 19 days and you would think they spent months on this film. Every shot is masterfully done and the ending scene in particular is nothing short of a masterpiece. The film stars up and coming actor Miles Teller as Andrew and Teller really shines here. His delivery is both charming and heartbreaking and he just proves even more that he is going to be a big name actor very soon. As great as Teller is, the performance of the film however goes to J.K. Simmons as Terrance Fletcher. Simmons is simply mesmerizing here as Fletcher. Simmons brings this air of comedy and fear that really hasn't been seen in a movie of this caliber since R. Lee Ermey in Full Metal Jacket. When Simmons screams you can't help but tremble and the whole time he is on screen there is always a feeling of intimidation that is accomplished by sheer screen presence. Simply, Simmons has delivered a performance to remember here. I honestly have no complaints what so ever about this movie. Everything here fires on all cylinders and never lets up. Whiplash is a intense and deep psychological thriller that will leave you in amazement by the time the credits roll. See Whiplash as soon as you can, this is one you simply shouldn't miss.

If there is any doubt as to the Master Class acting you get from J.K. Simmons, it is unequivocal here.  Just as it is true that the boundless power of Miles Teller's drumming is unquestionable .  It is intense, moving and a bit terrifying.

J.K. Simmons was brilliant, and Miles Teller was as good as I've come to find he usually is, and this was a great story about passion for your life's work, but I'm not sure I think it's as a whole Oscar-worthy.
Growing up in a high school jazz band myself I could totally relate to this! Some great music and a few plot surprises. Nice!

Incredibly difficult to watch at times the student and teacher are over the top great.   Along with acting is the fact this movie is uniquely and beautifully shot. You will never forget this movie.   Every musician should see this movie.

Instense musical drama thanks to two superb lead performances & excellent writing & direction by Damien Chazelle.  Miles Turner continues his streak of great lead performances, this time playing someone so driven to be the best he punishes himself more than anyone, and he knows it.  He also looks quite believable playing the drums.  He is matched brilliantly by J.K. Simmons in a long deserved Oscar winning performance, who straddles the line of both a sadist & a teacher who wants to bring out the best in his students (you're never sure which till the very end), and you will find yourself laughing & cringing at each verbal barb he delivers.  Behind the camera, Chazelle keeps the story lean & focused on the two main characters (the only subplot is a romantic one that is cut short at the right time), while delivering some gorgeous music sequences (you will be wanting the soundtrack after watching this).  Plus, he shows that Andrew is just as hard on himself as Fletcher is, if not harder, and is probably a lot like him (a revealing dinner scene demonstrates).  Overall, one of the best films of 2014 and still Chazell's best film.

Great performances by J. K. Simmons and  Miles Teller.  Simmons deserved the Oscar nomination, but I feel  that performance should have been in the Best ACTOR category, not SUPPORTING.  Miles Teller's performance was even better than J. K. Simmons.

Wow! What an experience. Pushed the boundaries of a student-teacher relationship, ambition and resilience. Teller plays a Shaffer's student who's ultimate goal in life is to become the next Buddy Rich, and he won't let anything distract him, not even a girlfriend, competitors, anyone, not even a car crash! He pours in his sweat and blood, literally, to get where he wants. And pushing him beyond his limits is the unrelenting teacher, played by J K Simmons, who believes it's an absolute necessity to push people beyond what's expected, and he won't accept anything short of perfection. 

Things turn sour and you may think Simmons might end up being nothing but an angry vicious vindictive teacher, but he is a lot more than that, so is Teller who shows you just can't beat him down so easily. It's the journey of these two that keeps you hooked. From the opening "Whiplash" to the final end-game with "Caravan". 

This movie captures more than the art of story-telling. It captures the art of music as well, with brilliant Jazz set pieces and drumming solos. Simmons certainly leads the running for best supporting actor, but Miles Teller is the one underrated here. His best performance till date.

P.S. - Yes he is actually playing those drums, though not in one go, it has been excellently edited and pieced together. Also, this is the director's second film!!!

He gives up his soul when he casts aside that girl so cruelly.  The climax of this film is one of the most pyrrhic victories you can imagine ... at last these two monsters are in sync and actual greatness is achieved.  Observe Paul Reiser's amazing expression in his last shot on camera when he realizes his son has just left him.

This is by far one of the most perfect films I have ever seen. The characters are realistic, dark, complicated and flawed. There is never a point during the film where I say to myself "oh, I know how this will end". 

Rather than films that try so hard to get inside of the heads of every character, Whiplash takes the perfect third person perspective and only lets you observe what is happening to the characters. You never really know everyone's motivations until the absolute last second of the film. 

Teller and Simmons are as perfect an on-screen team as you will ever see in a film. Their portrayals of obsessive, ruthless, and driven people make you root for them even as they continually make what could be perceived as bad decisions. You find yourself in their corner and you don't even know why. That is what a great story does.

Exciting, gripping and incredibly acted, Damien Chazelle's "Whiplash" offers an absolutely encapsulating experience which is a must-see for movie-lovers. Without a single doubt, this is the most intense movie-going experience I've had in a long time. Captivating from start to finish, "Whiplash" is the kind of film that captures your attention and refuses to let go. Perhaps, the best way to describe this film is that it's a 'heart-pounding' roller-coaster ride which moves at the speed of lightning. Not a single moment is wasted, as director Damien Chazelle takes a relatively simple concept of Jazz drumming and by a miracle turns it into a universal story of ambition, determination and the triumph of the human spirit. The direction is highly impressive, the performances are incredible and the writing is insightful. To begin, each and every performer brings their A-game to the table. In the leading role, Miles Teller delivers a career-defining performance which surpasses set expectations. Known for his charm and charisma, he steps out of his usual comfort zone to take on an extremely challenging role. Mentally, physically and emotionally, it's not an easy character to play for any actor particularly a young star whose career is on the line. Yet, Teller rises up to the challenge to prove himself as a talent to be reckoned with. Likewise, J.K. Simmons is equally powerful as one of the most detestable movie-characters in recent history. Owning every scene he is in, the star is completely deserving of the awards-recognition he has earned for the role. It's not an overstatement to say that the film would be nothing without him. The undeniable charisma of these actors, combined with the razor-sharp writing and a beautiful soundtrack, make "Whiplash" one hell of a film. Despite an unrealistic ending, it's a motion picture that will definitely be remembered, talked about and celebrated in years to come.

A tense and gripping thrill ride about the cost of greatness as an artist. Whiplash is one of my favorite films this year, it's a must-see MUST-SEE. A finely crafted film that works well without many layers and yet never gives its audience a chance to breath until the credits are already rolling.

Whiplash, is a very interesting movie. I think there are some opportunities for "Miles Teller" in this hole because he didn't appears a musician; maybe he is a little being cold. But these faults are compensated by "J.K.Simmons", he is perfect, in fact I felt angry of his hole. He deserves win the Oscar for his actuation.
JK Simmons puts on a stunning performance.  I thoroughly enjoyed Whiplash!

It sounds generic, but that's exactly what Whiplash does to suck you in. Once it has you in its grip, it will shove you, push you, gruel you and thrust you into every single drum beat, bead of sweat and drop of blood spilled. The film splays out like a constant sonic sound-wave, increasing in intensity before exploding into a sensational climax like the best drum solo you've ever heard. Miles Teller is superb at the centre of the film, and with it being shot in 19 days, there is every sense that the mass intensity is very much real in his journey. J. K. Simmons is terrific as Terence Fletcher, an instructor whose methods personify as brutal and breathless, but under the granite skin there appears to be a worthy cause of the brutality. You will come out of it reeling after being strained of all your stress and tension - and yet you'll jump right back in demanding an encore. Wow.
Whiplash had my heart pounding for the entire film. Wow... Just wow.

Great movie! One of those movies that will make you think after it's over for hours and not about some deeper meaning but instead the interactions between the characters. J.K. Simmons is phenomenal keeping my on the edge of my seat constantly thinking "what is he going to do now?" Every scene with him in it is a great scene. Miles Teller also does a very good job reflecting the treatment he receives from Simmons in his personal life and even the band showing what stress can do to a person. The dedication Teller portrays in his character Andrew is unlike any of a character I have seen with a complete lack of rationalization. The movie will have you questioning J.K. Simmons' character to figure out if he is a good guy or the asshole as seen in the trailer. Very intense at times, a must-see and an instant classic.

"There are no two words in the English language more harmful than 'Good Job'."
In this day and age of self-esteem and participation trophies, "Whiplash" ferociously asks what is the cost of greatness. How far is too far? Is there a line in the pursuit of perfection?
Led by Oscar-worthy performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons, we witness an electric relationship between a promising drummer and his teacher. A crescendo of relentless drive, personal sacrifice, and torture leads to the most dazzling finale of the year.
10/10 - Must watch. One of the best of the year. An intense and thrilling drama that ends on a perfect note.

Super intense, excellent film about the aspiration for greatness, whether it's Miles Teller's dangerous ambition, or J.K. Simmons abusively pushing the limits of his students to achieve it. Must see! ~ A-

Often people will state that you don't have to be a fan of x to enjoy a film which centres around a particular sport, well you don't have to be a fan of jazz drumming to be completely enthralled by 'Whiplash', a tense edge of your seat watch from start to finish. JK Simmons is correctly winning plaudits for his portrayal of the music instructor who knows no limits, a performance which echo's R Lee Ermey in 'Full Metal Jacket' for pure energy
6 hours after the ending...still in awe. It's THAT good. Worthy of all praise.
An exhilarating, whip-cracking tour de force, Whiplash fires on all cylinders and tells a story of becoming the greatest, in a nail-bitingly grand way.

Exceptional. No wonder this is on the short list to win Best Picture Oscar this year. Not a fan of Miles Teller but he's quite good in this, and though Simmons has a huge body of work and is always pretty good actually, he takes it to another level with this character.

You may not have heard about this. I've still never seen a trailer, just heard some Oscar buzz and then saw great things about it. Basically, you've got a drummer in Teller, who attends a prestigious music school where Simmons' character is the asshole teacher. 

You think your heading for a conclusion and a look into the question at the cost of greatness. Did the teacher cross the line or is that how you make someone great? But it's actually far from over at that point. The final 20 minutes are pretty top-notch movie making in terms of everything. Great visuals, great story, and probably great sound (I didn't get the full surround experience). To top it off, the ending is actually quite excellent.

I don't think I've had a more visceral, real reaction to a movie in a long time. I was watching each scene play out like lives depended on it, and the final sequence between Teller and Simmons is one of the most gut-wrenching, surprising, hilarious, and cheer-inducing scenes I've seen in years. The pacing and planning that went into each sequence is clearly obvious, and the cinematography pulls you in without beating you over the head with style and showiness. The acting, writing, camera work, story, and the music are all wonderful. I loved every minute of it.

Whiplash is very enjoyable with a very interesting story. while the characters are not incredibly likeable they don't have to be and that's where the enjoyment comes from. at times it feels like an 80's sports movie like karate kid or rocky only centring around music instead and trying to tell a more real world story. my only complaint is that i felt i would have enjoyed it more if I didn't know it was up for best picture as i felt like i was unable to just sit back and take it in and it felt like i needed to overanalyse it and probably missed some of the best parts of the film but i would still really recommend it

I was really tense watching this movie in a way that made me both uncomfortable and yet riveted, and I think that speaks largely to the great acting from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons.  The passion their characters had for perfecting their music was palpably overwhelming.  I'm glad an indie film like was nominated for the 2014 Best Picture Oscar, since it contrasts with the historic biopics that encompass half the nominee list.  I know Miles Teller's star is on the rise since he's already been getting a lot of buzz the past couple years, but I hope this film also gets J.K. Simmons the praise and juicier roles he richly deserves.

Whiplash is one of the best movies to come out in 2014, thanks in large part to Damian Chazelle and J.K Simmons. Chazelle does a great job capturing the tension of a serious band practice/audition and the nerves of all of the players. J.K Simmons, however, really steals the show. He is one of those characters that excites the viewer every time he shows up on screen because you just know something interesting is going to happen when he does. His performance is fantastic and his character is even better. Apart from that, the screenplay is decent, as is Miles Teller, but this film really leans on it's director, editor and the stellar performance of Simmons, which proved to be a great decision.

e that he will only continue to grow as time goes by.

Tense, superlative, inspirational-pick an adjective for Damien Chazelle's 2014 film Whiplash and just go with it. A Sundance darling when it was first seen-the story of a jazz drummer prodigy and his enigmatic, larger-than-life teacher-Whiplash is as honest a film you will see. People bleed, they sweat, and they tear in what is one concerto that never lets up. A story about undying ambition, talent and the fine margins that divide the "doers" from the rest, Whiplash is the embodiment of a satisfying, weighty film going experience. It is even more impressive that Chazelle (who also wrote it) has had no prior directing credits to his name for a project of this size. The performances-executed with the swagger of the highest of standards-are exceptional across the band (even the minor characters are great), but it is J.K. Simmons who will be standing in front for all to see. His norm-defying antics as a teacher are scary, brutal and just shocking to witness-keeping you on the edge of your seat, as you don't know if he will snap or laugh. This creates an equally anxious and amusing tone that beats to the drums to the end. Chazelle's directing is complimented by terrific cinematography by Sharone Mier, frenetic and detail-crazed editing by Tom Cross and all tied together by the jazz score from Justin Hurwitz. Like any award-winning band out there, Damien Chazelle conducts his ensemble of filmmakers to create a unified and exemplary experience that will never be forgotten.
Terrific film about success, how to achieve it and the effects of driving people beyond what they believe they can achieve. J.K.Simmons is brilliant.
JK Simmons was amazing. Miles was great too. Thought I wouldn't be into it as much as I was.

Full Metal Jacket meets Rocky as a young talented jazz drummer squares up to his music teacher as they both strive for perfection.  This is a pure adrenaline rush from start to finish, something you wouldn't typically think goes with jazz.  Relaxing this ain't.  JK Simmons and Miles Teller are both electrifying as teacher and student, both wrestling with their obsession to be the best, even if that means going to extreme methods or alienating people in the process. The pacing hits all the right beats (boom boom!) and the script is practically note perfect (boom tish!), this is truly refreshing piece of cinema. It really is like two heavyweights exchanging punches, metaphorically (and literally in some cases). A knockout winner for me, I can't recommend it highly enough.

Jazz hands. Bloody jazz hands! If you subscribe to the theory that being an unapologetic megadick and hurling homophobic insults will inspire someone to be one's best, then you'll find a lot of inspiration here. If your moral compass is calibrated differently, you'll still have fun watching J.K. Simmons be a bigger prick than he ever was as J. Jonah Jameson.
Tense. Hard to watch. Good but disturbing. Unsatisfying ending.
Love Miles Teller, what a great actor! Although the film was good, but lacked nuances.
The most thrilling film of the year blends solid editing, outstanding performances, and thought provoking themes to create a great work of cinema.
The most incredibly intense and explosive ending i have ever watched in the history of cinema. And the rest of the film is excellent too

As a musician in an earlier part of my life, Whiplash--despite the fear it evoked--had me yearning to get back on stage. Every drumbeat was a note building in a suspenseful crescendo. J.K. Simmons is deserving of every award he's been nominated for and every award he's won for his role as the terrifying Terence Fletcher. Whiplash was intense, thrilling, and absolutely one of the year's best.
Too exciting and emotional ride full of twists, killed me almost!

Young would-be big-band drummer goes to jazz boot-camp, where he falls under the cosh of a maniacal perfectionist teacher with a fine command of invective - with bloody but ultimately triumphant results.  Like a cross between 'Fame' and 'Full Metal Jacket', this is a familiar genre piece, centring on two great big-band standards - Hank Levy's 'Whiplash' (the title tune, chosen for metaphorical reasons that become obvious) and the Ellington classic 'Caravan'.  Of course, like any other movie about music - or indeed, any profession whatever - it's full of impossibilities and absurdities and 'that would/could never happens', and people bleed FAR too much.  But for all those excesses it is well performed and well directed - the crash scene is particularly shocking, and the brass instruments, oozing from their gravy-holes onto the stage floor, are lovingly done in atmospheric close-up and slowmo - and the music is pretty well spot-on.  Held my attention!

I would have walked out if I hadn't been there with my family.  Sadistic, foul-mouthed bully of a music coach meets arrogant young jerk of a drummer.  A match made in hell - I honestly can't recall disliking the two main characters in a movie quite so much.  Really sorry I wasted two hours of my life watching it.

With the upcoming 2014 Academy Awards, most of the nominees have finally arrive to my country but when I read the list of Best Picture candidates the one that I hadn't heard a lot from was Damien Chazelle´s "Whiplash".
Andrew Neiman is a 19 year old freshman drummer at the prestigious Shaffer Conservatory music school, Andrew aspires to become one of the best drummers in the history of jazz. Soon he manages to become the youngest member of the school greatest orchestra and student of prestige teacher Terrence Fletcher. With his acceptance, Neiman believes that he´s on the path to greatness but eventually discovers that having Fletcher as a teacher may instead be the path towards madness. 
With a plot revolving around a troublesome musician I expected the cliché inspirational drama where they use every cheap trick to move your heartstrings but "Whiplash" astonished me by being exactly the opposite. "Whiplash" is a film that has almost no flaws whatsoever; it counts with mesmerizing and jaw dropping acting by both Teller and Simons but Simons manages to steal the film with an Academy Award winning performance that reminds me of R.Lee Ermey in "Full Metal Jacket" and is enhanced by the support provided by his costar, memorable characters, the editing is synchronized with the jazz played in the film, the music is of course beautiful,  gorgeous cinematography, an appropriate directing that manages to handle the film´s madness, sound mixing that will blow you away, the writing is at the same level as the performances, hilarious lines in the middle of the intense scenarios, an intense story revolving the protagonist psychology, a perfect pacing, a greatly executed atmosphere where you can smell the characters stress, incredibly intense scenes that just keep escalating until the films conclusion, there is not a single cliché used in this film, a finale that will keep you on the edge of your seat and despite all the intensity this films offers it will still make you feel inspire and cheerful. The only issue that I had thought the film is that despite the intriguing relationship between mentor and student, both characters weren't as complex, I expected some ambiguity to their motives but the writing made this pair pretty straightforward. 
"Whiplash" is a phenomenal and intense film with two splendid performances by both lead actors. I will name it my runner-up for my favorite 2014 film (With "Birdman" remaining in my number one spot).

I MUST have watched the wrong movie. The reviews for this film could in no way apply to the contrived claptrap I've just seen. Perhaps the positive reviews here were intended for that 1974 masterpiece House of Whipcord.  

The movie called Whiplash that I saw stars J.K. Simmons as Terence, a music teacher who can slap a face with such force as to make General Patton wince. The film also stars Miles Teller as Andrew, a student of Terence's who yearns to learn from him how to properly play the drums. Andrew accomplishes this by volunteering to let his teacher play the bongos on his face.

I won't say that Damien Chazelle's direction is heavy-handed, but I would probably prefer to stick my head in Andrew's bass drum during the climactic scene than to endure watching said scene again.

A word of advice to anyone considering seeing this film; go to YouTube instead and do a search for Buddy Rich. You will see the greatest drummer ever, and spare yourself the agony of viewing this over-the-top, trite, clichéd, eye-roll inducing effort. Your eyes and your ears will thank you for it.

Whiplash is an exhilarating movie. It's intense, on the edge of your seat action, even though it's merely about a boy, his drum set, and his teacher. The movie gets it's intensity from the strong, fast-paced direction from Damien Chazelle and absolutely terrific performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons who both bring their all.

Mix Miranda Priestly (The Devils Wears Prada), Sgt Harman (Full Metal Jacket) with some Ty Cobb, Gordon Ramsey and add a pinch of Darth Vader and you begin to approach the sociopathic intensity that is Terence Fletcher played by one JK Simmons. 

I suspect that most of us have had a teacher or mentor who was tough and pushed us to accomplish more than we thought was possible. In this outing Miles Teller plays the role of the student on jazz drums, and Simmons plays the teacher.  The story arc is completely predictable, but I think that the moral conclusions expected of us at the end are a bit nebulous. The production values are OK visually, mostly limited by the abundance of practice room venue material.  The sound as can be expected is flawless.  This one hangs on the performances, and the screenplay. And they are strong. 

Not really relevant, this one rounds out my viewings of 2015 nominees for Academy Awards Best Picture.  As always, I am looking forward to the surprises that this coming year will bring.

An unbelievably intense movie, not just in performances, story, dialogue and filming, but what it does to you for hours after you leave the theater.  The subject matter is based on the real-life experience of director Damien Chazelle, but even though the theme and the behavior of JK Simmons' character, Terence Fletcher, has you gasping much of the movie at how insane his treatment of this poor kid is, one can't help but think, in the end, it was the right thing, as twisted as it is. "Whiplash" is definitely a topic of discussion long after the movie ends, and THAT is what defines a good film.

Brutal, captivating. Every second of this film hums with a kind of elastic energy, and JK Simmons has never been better. I've always liked Miles Teller and I'm glad he found a vehicle to stretch his talents. It's a brilliant film, a rare beast that balances depth and watchability.

This is considerably less hard work than I was expecting. The marketing sells Whiplash as Full Metal Jazz Drumming (or something), and the meat of what we have here is an hour and a half of Some Good Acting. JK Simmons and Miles Teller are both great, and they're in a fairly straightforward 'student wins the approval of a difficult teacher' kind of thing. No twists, no turns; it goes from A to B and it kind of left me wanting a bit more depth - we learn next to nothing about these two characters outside of how they interact with one another. So, for me, this is most definitely a case of performances that are great housed in a story that's merely pretty good. Still an easy recommendation though, even to non-jazzheads.

Low budget, Indie drama written and directed by Damien Chazelle, Whiplash is a gladiatorial joust between Andrew (Miles Teller), an ambitious drummer at an elite New York music academy who wants to become a jazz legend and his blunt, unpredictable teacher Terrence Fletcher (JK Simmons) , who shouts insults and hurls cymbals at every missed beat.

The film is an involving and intense portrayal of obsession. Teller puts in a committed performance of the young man pushing himself to extremes seeking approval. Simmons is brilliant as the terrifyingly ferocious, foul mouthed teacher, who everyone wants to impress but is impossible to please. Chazelle directs the film with a fitting pace and precision, the edits are on beat.

Whiplash says a lot about teacher-pupil relationship and the psychological minds employed in the pursuit of greatness, raising questions of how much you need to bully someone to get the best out of them.

It's Rocky with snare drums. You come out of the movie theatre feeling as if you've just been beaten up for 90 minutes.
