Jazz drumming, bullying teacher, that drippy girl from Glee. This wasn't the most promising setup for seeing this film. I was also the only one in the cinema, but they were really missing out as this was a fantastic film! JK Simmons and Miles Teller as the her and student play out a deeply twisted relationship as Teller's ambitious young drummer takes all kinds of abuse, physical and verbal, from leader of the jazz orchestra at a prestigious NY music school. 
However, the film has some really unusual and subversive things to say about what is acceptable in the pursuit of musical perfection. Simmons pours scorn on encouragement and praise, believing only by refusing to accept anything less than excellence can a musician improve. His methods are intense and brutal - more Joe Pesci in Goodfellas than Robin Williams in Good Will Hunting.
On the other hand, Teller takes it all! Ever ditching drippy girlfriend so she won't distract him and proving himself a pretty obnoxious ass himself when lording it over sports playing relatives,
What I especially liked was the uncompromising lack of syrup. This is no feel good, uplifting tale. It is blackly comic and one of the most tense films I've seen in a while. It really keeps you guessing about whether Simmons actually had a heart or really,is just a mean bastard! 
Great performances, fabulously gripping and involving. Ignore the unpromising premise.  Try to keep up! Definitely my tempo!

By the end of watching this you may well be as breathless as Andrew on the drums. that's because this is one hell of a roller coaster ride featuring two powerhouse level performances from the two leads. JK Simmons won't be doing side character shit after this, he's gonna be leading it up and rightly so. You both admire and fear his reckless perfectionist composer, he may literally rip your heart out but it may just spur you into perfection. As a testament to relentless drive, dedication and focus, it's hard to think of many other films that convey the message. It's not just a montage here and there to show Andrews evolution, no we literally see his blood, sweat, and tears while his soul gets destroyed. 

Elsewhere  I like the way the plot steers away from predictable territory, especially in the final acts and goddam if this isn't a beautifully shot picture that actually makes you think about lighting in a film. Overall it's a must watch and if you disagree, in true JK Simmons style, expect a chair to come flying your way.
5 minutes in and I knew it would be the best film of the year. So good I clapped when it ended.

Not great music and I felt the story never went anywhere!

Okay...well, this movie has an awful lot of flaws (and I mean a LOT), but overall its entertaining and the music is terrific and of course the acting is very good.  JK Simmons is going to win Best Supporting Actor next month for playing the most villainous wretch since Heath Ledger split his lips.  Miles Teller is a compelling young actor who doesn't look much like a movie star, but that's what made him watchable as a gifted but incredibly entitled drummer with dreams of glory and shares in Band-Aid.  The major problem is not so much the cliches in the writing, its mostly how the film is directed.  I can imagine the director talking to his editor about how he shot the film like it was a jazz piece...zig here, zag there, do some of those quick closeup montages that Paul Thomas Anderson is famous for, whip the camera back and forth between the drummer and the conductor (whiplash, get it!), cut away from the emotional finale to show Paul Reiser finally getting it, man!  His son is amazing!  But again, the music is exceptional and fine performances, but a Best Picture nominee?  I don't bloody think so!

Intense to the point of being uncomfortable. That is one of Whiplash's strongest points, and it knows it. The film follows a rising drum student who is taken under the wing of a hellish instructor. This film could have very easily fallen to pieces if it wasn't for the fantastic J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller. We get a side to each of these actors that we haven't seen before, and this is easily Simmons' greatest performance. The film moves pretty briskly, only dragging during the unnecessary relationship drama scenes. And as was previously mentioned, the intensity of the film is certainly a high point for the film. Many scenes that show our actors being tested to their limits tend to test ours, but in a way that pays off. These scenes have slow building tension that creeps over the viewer and starts to make them feel uneasy. All of this comes together for a finale that will keep you on edge. Whiplash is a film that never should have worked, but it does, and it is great.

What a riveting movie. Whiplash has an incredible ending and inspirational message. J.K. Simmons is the obvious choice for Best Supporting Actor in a landslide with his booming voice and spectacular one-liners. Miles Teller also completely rises to the challenge as Andrew Neyman, a somewhat confused and insanely self-motivated young man. The ending will truly blow your mind. This is my pick for Best Picture, and my favorite movie of all time. Yeah, that's how good it is. I not only highly encourage others to see it, it is nearly a necessity.

A movie that lives up to it's name. You go from wanting Andrew to impress his director and in the same breath long for him to walk out of the studio. The performances were spectacular and the intensity dragged you along for the ride. It left me exhausted by the end.
Really enjoyed the movie. Great acting.
I really enjoyed this!
The number 2 movie of the year
Thrilling, disturbing, and satisfying. Incredible performances all around and music that will envelop your soul. Also one of the best endings to a movie I've seen in awhile. Watch this movie.
I loved this film.  never been so tense watching a film before. Absolutely brilliant

Whiplash proceeds to take every cliche we know about about the music prodigy-student teacher storyline, completely destroy it and rebuild from the ashes a tale fueled by mental manipulation, obsession, violence, and the pursuit of a goal no matter the costs. JK Simmons gives the performance of a lifetime as Mr. Fletcher, a jazz band conductor who will never stop at anything short of perfection, even if it means mentally corrupting and hindering the minds of his students to an unsafe degree. Absolutely brilliant from beginning to end.
An intense, no-nonsense thriller that explores   obsession, ambition and the human condition through music. An absolute inferno. 9/10.
A fantastic film about the methods and costs of attaining one's optimum potential, held together by two stunning central performances.

Here me now, J.K. Simmons will walk onstage at the Kodak Theatre next month and collect his Oscar.  Terrance Fletcher is the most menacing character since Ben Kingsley played Don Logan in "Sexy Beast". Also, the music in this film is fantastic!
Sensational. An hour and 50 minutes of exceptional jazz drumming while J.K Simmons makes wise cracks. Dream movie.

Massively intense story of monomania - what would you sacrifice to be the Best. Drummer. Ever? Deserving of all the plaudits it received  with an eye-poppingly intimidating bravura performance from the magnificent JK Simmons.
So perfectly intense that it makes your skin crawl. Simply brilliant!

One of the most compelling films of the last few months. 2015 just ceases to amaze cinematically. 
Andrew (Miles Teller) is a talented drummer at a New York music school driven to perfection by a domineering music teacher Fletcher (J.K. Simmons).
Fletcher's at times unconventional methods of improving his pupils ability can be construed as bullying. 
Andrew ditches his girlfriend and concentrates fully on his drumming in order to satisfy the 'bully' and gain entry into an elite class/jazz band and become one of the main players.
Teller comes across a bit nerdy and boring. I think it is Simmons as the teacher Fletcher who is the star of the film. 
Part psycho? His put downs of some of his failing musical students are classic.
J.K. Simmons is unknown (to me anyway!) but he steals the movie and deserves recognition.
A battle of musical wits that quite literally draws sweat and blood is set between the two central characters.
Not a blockbuster by any means but one if not the best film of recent times for its original screenplay and performances.

A college loner desperately seeking the approval of his mentor - this film certainly introduces the college sports formula to big band jazz. A lot of people have described this movie as 'edge of your seat', gripping drama - I didn't get that vibe, but it was enjoyable, not least because of excellent performances from both JK Simmons and Miles Teller - there aren't really any other characters of significance. The film is light on humour and action: the entire film is the conflict between Simmons and Teller.
The dark and brooding cinematography was both beautiful and atmospheric, but it became overwhelming and a little claustrophobic by the end. I was bored of watching Teller bang the drums until his hands bled and really wanted out of the practice room/darkened theatre/dorm room practice area. It didn't feel as though the characters progressed a great deal although there was some triumph.
The excuses for physical abuse and expletive-ridden homophobic tirades were flimsy at best but are somehow justified within the film's conclusion. It wasn't "the best film of the last 25 years" as some have said, but it is certainly worthy of consideration for an Oscar.

Quite a long film about a man learning the drums and his teacher. Overlong drum solo at the end. 
Overrated
more edge-of-your-seat thrills than most action movies, this is an outstanding two-hander played to perfection and brilliantly directed.
Really amazing editing!!
Extremely intense , i was dripping sensations during the film. :D

Beautiful , lyrical and a poetic sense throughout the picture. J.K. Simmons' brilliant support role basically gives the perspective for the lead. Extremely well paced edition going with the beats of the drum and speed of the sticks. Beautifully shot , one of the few films that uses color to such an effect as to dramatically change the mood of the scenes. A well written and directed piece overall with a beautiful way to portray characters. Cinematography is one of the outstanding features of this picture telling more of the story than the actual exposition of the scenes. The movie has a core narrative thread and that's what drives it. Whiplash is certainly one of the best pictures of the year. Extremely subtle , visually vibrant  and lyrically poised
Wow the last 10 minutes blew me away. JK Simmons, you sir, are a badass.

Holy shit. It's been too long since I loved a movie as much as Whiplash. The last movie I loved this much was Steve Jobs. And I don't know if it's coincidental or indicative of my tastes that both movies are essentially exposes on that kind of toxic white sociopathy that masquerades as authoritarian drive or passion. Maybe I'm repressing something.

Whiplash manages the unthinkable: a mind bogglingly intense masterclass at tension.... about jazz drumming. Sublime editing, screenplay, and pin point perfect performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons; Whiplash is one of the best films you're likely to never see. Phenomenal.

You have to be psyched to see this.  It is intense.  If you do not like swearing and all that goes with it do not see this movie.  Other than that JK Simmons was hard core.  He was the meanest SOB I have ever seen in a movie.  Pity the students who come across a teacher like him.  All in the name of pushing people to excellence.
Not quiet my tempo !! WhipLash is a perfect example of why we love movies , it is a movie we can all relate too even if jazz isn't your thing. This is a movie that won't forgotten  anytime soon.

It's easy to say we're living in an age where music is missing something pivotal. Music, to me, is honest, powerful, sentimental, and brimming with energy. And...well, you can see where I'm going with this.

Whiplash is the story of student, Andrew Neiman, a talented drummer with a goal to become a great. His new Jazz teacher, Terence Fletcher, is volatile and unpredictable, but dedicated to push the boundaries of what his students can achieve. Fletcher sees potential in Neiman, and pushes him to a whole new level. Let the sparks fly.

The narrative is very much a cliche of the same story we've seen many times before. However, this is unique. The relationship between Teller and Simmons is electrifying, dangerous, and in an odd way, full of love. There is a sweet respect for each other underneath the layers of both characters. Explosive drama, which leaves you on the edge of your seat. And there's a reason for that. 

Whiplash is heart pounding, exhilarating and tense enough to rocket you to you out of your seat, shouting with aggressive glee. It takes you over. It's astounding to watch. The stage finale will leave you in jaw dropping awe. Every smash, clash and bang that hits the drum set will send chills through your body. The glistening of sweat and blood pouring over the instrument symbolises the film perfectly. You will not experience something like this for a very long time. 

Whiplash is a rush you'll want to experience again. Never has Jazz music and drumming felt so relevant to discover.

Makes 'Black Swan' look like 'Annie'. Enjoyable but far too OTT for me from the get-go, to the point that I never believed in it for a single second. Also, it only reinforced in my mind the idea that drum solos are fundamentally awful things that should be banned outright. Give me a kazoo solo any day.

Well directed, great acted and beautifully written. Whiplash is without a doubt one of the best if not the best film of 2014. This intense, Oscar-nominated, drama will keep you on the edge of your seat throughout the whole movie and you'll walk out of the theater wanting to be a drummer. 5/5!

Absolutely incredible! J.K. Simmons was intense and gave the performance of his career. I have no clue how a film about playing jazz drums can have me on the edge of my seat and then standing. The best film I've seen in a long time... Highly recommended.

I could go on for pages about how well done this movie is but I'm just going to sum it up in a few sentences. Whiplash was amazing, it's a kind of movie that keeps you grabbing your seat waiting what will happen next. Acting is above standards with a amazing performance from both Miles Teller and J.K Simons. It also amazed me to see that it was a debut for te director who also wrote the script making this a whole of a lot better. The script is snappy as well as the direction. Lots of grit with the shots with close ups and tracking shots leading the way of most of the film. It never looses form and throughout the whole film your always kept on the edge of your seat looking for the next thing that will happen. Overall whiplash is a gritty well performed, award worthy, well written and directed film that turned out to be one of the more better movies of 2014.

A breathtaking, heart-pounding film from new director Damien Chazelle. Mind-blowingly good, a must-see. J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller deliver an intense performance that will leave you shaking in your seat long after the credits. The only weak part of the movie is an under-developed love story, which is all-and-all not important to the plot and could have been excluded. The cinematography in this movie is awe-striking, reflecting the drum beats with unique, unseen close-ups. Miles Teller did 75% of his own drumming for this movie, and the blood dripping from his hands onto the drum set is real. The pain and intensity he shows is real, and both he and the ever-impressive J.K. Simmons have redefined acting. This movie was robbed of a Best Picture nomination, as was Miles Teller for Best Male Lead. Damien Chazelle, a new director bursting into the industry with this film, has not only made a name for himself, but has set the bar for cinematic art.

A wildly visceral film, Whiplash not-so-subtly elaborates the roles that desperation, frustration, and dedication play in everyday life. J.K. Simmons (in a career-defining role) and Miles Teller bounce off each other nicely, with palpable chemistry extending beyond on-screen screaming sessions. Damien Chazelle's direction and screenplay beautifully cap off the smart-as-a-whip storyline that takes drumming cues from the film's wonderful soundtrack to move at a whiplash-inducing pace. This film shows the literal bloodshed going into perfection, and Simmons' character Terence Fletcher revels in it.
Intense,inspiring,heartbreaking,entertaining with a simple real-life story that is like full metal jacket for jazz musicians.

Third week of January, and may well have already witnessed the film of the year. A wonderful piece of work which doesn't allow you to relax for one minute (all the more impressive considering it's based in a music rehearsal room). It builds up upon each scene at a furious pace, the type of film which keeps you on edge with every beat of the drum. Simmons is terrifying and epitomises one who demands 'blood, sweat and tears' from all who follow him.

While this is not a movie for everyone (especially for those turned off by foul language), I think it is an incredible thrill-ride better than any suspense films I have seen recently. Both of the main guys have flaws, but they are painted more like antiheroes when we see the motivations behind them in their grand "battle of wills" throughout the story; it feels really satisfying to have a film highlighting "morally grey" characters and not just making them two-dimensional types. Miles Teller is better in this film than anything else I have seen him in, and J.K. Simmons delivers an incredible performance; he was certainly deserving of his "Best Supporting Actor" Oscar earlier this year. I did not have a chance to see this film earlier, but it has my vote for being the best film coming out in 2014! You should definitely watch it if you had missed it before; I highly recommend it.

(77%)
A film void of death, murder, and violence, yet is as intense as any thriller, horror, or action flick. With parallels to "Foxcatcher", with the student and trainer theme, only here J.K Simmons' character is not a fraud, but in fact is very gifted, and if anything is even more hardcore in his approach. Miles Teller is perfect as the gifted student, you really do believe every step of the way that the guy can achieve something if pushed, but you never truly know for sure if he is being pushed too far. This has all the bases covered in terms of acting, writing, and direction, with J.K Simmons brilliant performance just about nosing it above all else as the best asset. There's also some white-knuckle plot twists, a huge amount of politically incorrect insults thrown around, and a brilliant (and somewhat deafening) ending. A fondness for jazz isn't required to get something from this in the same sense that you don't need to like boxing to really enjoy Rocky, and as such this is deserving of a look for almost anyone looking for something well made, interesting, and memorable.
This is the best movie of 2014.

When Neyman drums in rapture it is riveting.  But at what cost?  The painful bullying of Fletcher, the harshest of superegos, is difficult to watch.  Fletcher is destructive and narcissistic.  He wants to live achieve through Neyman where he himself fell short.  But why has Fletcher chosen Neyman?  Certainly its is raw talent and drive.  A drive born out of the hole left behind from his early years.  Fletcher exploits this and an absorbing power play ensues.  The movie is tight and not a moment feels wasteful.

Having been a jazz musician in college and obtaining a music degree, this is NOT how lab bands are done. I suppose that in Hollywood this type of inaccuracy is acceptable but if have any familiarity to jazz lab bands and jazz competitions you should avoid this film.

Now whip it! Into shape, shape it up, looks great! Whip it real good!!! I just had the Devo inside in that intro for my movie review of the fabulous movie "Whiplash". What a gem!! "Whiplash" stars Miles Teller as first year music student Andrew Neiman. Andrew is a student drummer who is more than just a little drummer boy in his pursuit to excel at his beat craft. However, he has to prove his skills to the extremely rigid music school instructor/conductor Terrence Fletcher. Let's just say that Fletcher is trying to make a newman out of Neiman. As Andrew tries to excel in the battery, Fletcher's own authoritarian battery charge is always on full in pushing Andrew to the edge. Damien Chazzelle orchestrates "Whiplash" with a magnetic flow that hits all the right beats in his direction of the picture; and his screenplay also hit all the write verbal notes. Miles Teller delivers yet another stellar performance in his rising career; here as Neiman. J.K. Simmons was terrible as Fletcher! Wait, wait! I was J.K. (just kidding!) Simmons' work as Fletcher might just be the best delivered by any actor or actress this year. Paul Reiser also delivered an impressive supporting performance as Andrew's supporting dad; but I was not as mad about his performance as I was in Simmons' classic masterpiece thespian conduction. So here is my final drum roll of this picture.......... "Whiplash" is one of the best movies of 2014!

FASCINATING portrait of a bully (borderline sadistic) music professor at a heralded Jazz music conservatory who teaches big band Jazz and his drummer, a 19 year old struggling to be the very best he can be. Who would have thought a film about a Jazz drummer would be this damn exciting and intense. Certain scenes had me on the edge of my seat, quite electrifying , and the music is fantastic.
Never Ending tension building thrilling, glorious!

Whiplash is a tremendous drama that hits every note pitch perfect and has a tempo that neither rushes nor drags. Damien Chazelle's polished modern direction is a sight to see as we delve into the life of music student "Andrew Neiman" as he sheds blood, sweat and tears to become one of the great Jazz drummers of all time. Miles Teller is phenomenal in the central role as Andrew whose determination and grit is a marvel to watch unfold and evolve as the picture progresses. J. K. Simmons similarly is utterly phenomenal as the monster that is "Terrence Fletcher" who pushes Andrew to the limit of his musical ability and psyche through verbal and psychological torment akin to "Sgt. Hartman" from Full Metal Jacket. Both actors have the most remarkable chemistry and play off each other like the finest of musical partnerships. Filled with sequences of unbridled tension that kept me on the edge of my seat, scenes of bittersweet emotional depth between Andrew and his dad or his love interest Nicole; it must be said that the finale of Whiplash is by far one of the best i've seen on screen for some time. It would be a sin for me to not mention how incredible the wall of sound is that is created from the drums at the climax of this feature - the euphoric chills were unreal. Lastly, the attention to detail to the mindset, aesthetic and idiosyncratic nature of music within an educational environment is simply top notch. From the sneaky peaks in practice room windows, the deep seated competition to be the best among fellow peers to the constant practicing over and over again until your technique is just right - Whiplash delivers an authentic look into the life of a student of music. Certainly my favourite of the year so far and quite rightly nominated for Best Picture, Whiplash is a joy from the first hit of the snare to the last crash of the cymbals. I left the cinema in awe.
I hate Jazz but I loved Whiplash,J.K Simmons,J.K Simmons then J.K Simmons.

"Whiplash" Review 
Director Damien Chazelle has made one of the most entertaining, intense, uncomfortable, heartwarming, and inspiring films I have seen in a long time. "Whiplash" is about a 19 year old named Andrew (Miles Teller) who is an inspired jazz drummer at a prestigious school and meets his new instructor Fletcher (JK Simmons) who is one of the most ruthless mentors ever put on film. "Whiplash" is a perfectly written film, perfectly acted, and perfectly structured. I am not big on Jazz music but this film actually made me care about a subject that I have absolutely no knowledge about. What made this film great was the performance by Miles Teller and a superb performance by JK Simmons (he will take the Best Supporting Actor Oscar for sure). Another aspect I loved about the film was how real the situations felt... When Andrew and Fletcher bumped heads I felt like I was in the classroom with them feeling awkward, which to me is the best feeling when watching a film because if you can make the audience feel like they are there for the ride then you have done your job as a filmmaker. Andrew is a character I can relate to because I am only a year older than him and he wants to do something in his life that he will be remembered for forever. He wants to feel important and that is something I believe every young man is hungry for at that age. Not to sound corny but its a movie about pursuing your dreams and conquering them. I believe this will be a strong contender for the Best Adapted Screenplay Oscar as well. This is a true masterpiece and I will be buying it on blue ray in a heartbeat. 

A+

an unusual and original story with J.K. Simmonds playing what could be one of the most evil characters you'll ever see on screen outside of a horror movie. It's about drumming but don't let that put you off. The film is half as good if it wasn't for a single scene at the end.
Wow!! My vote for Best Picture 2015. It masterfully combines the plot , theme, acting ( JK Simmons masterpiece) , cinematography , directing , makeup  ...everything into a very entertaining  movie.

Loved this film...   psychological thriller, drama.  Turns on the increasingly toxic chemistry between two clearly damaged people, to the exclusion of pretty much anyone else.
This is hands down the single greatest movie I have ever seen. I've never been so moved by a film in my life. What are you waiting for?! Go see it!!!

While an interesting foray into a power dynamic, maybe like "Shades of Grey," we watch this debacle unfold. I really didn't like the gloomy nature of both the protagonist and the antagonist. I mean "give me a glimmer of something good!" The acting was good and the cinematography flawless, but at the end, this war of who's got more stamina got old.

There are mentors, and there are monsters. Sometimes, the line between the two becomes blurred. How far does a mentor push before he becomes a monster? One one end, we have Morpheus from The Matrix, and on the other end, we have Miranda Priestly from The Devil Wears Prada. Both push their apprentices past breaking points, but the loyalty those mentors receive comes from different places. The loyalty given to Miranda is borne from a place of fear and abuse, and the same is said for Andrew Neyman's quest for approval from Terence Fletcher. 

This is certainly one of the most intense film experiences that I've ever endured, and I am pretty sure I don't need to see it again. The harshness of the tone of the constant drumming isn't for me, but I can certainly appreciate the reason for it. Miles Teller does a capable job of the young drummer, but it is J.K. Simmons whose intensity brings the film into focus. While Fletcher's reasons for pushing may be admirable, it makes him no less a monster, and I wish that the movie focused more on the futility of searching for the next Buddy Rich or Charlie Parker. The fact of the matter is that there are Buddy Riches and Charlie Parkers everywhere in the world. The reason that no one knows about them is because not only are these people NOT trailblazers, but that fewer people care. People will always remember an athlete who goes above and beyond, because records are meant to be broken; musicians who don't show the world anything new will always be forgotten. It's important to remember that before more people die at a young age of a heroin overdose.

This is a must-see film if you love instrumental jazz, and a superb performance by J.K. Simmons, although Miles Teller was also very good. I wasn't sure how much I'd like this -- how interesting can you make a story about a drummer? -- but this works extremely well, as you learn what drives both men to do what they do; Simmons' Fletcher drive to discover a talent, and Teller's drive to meet those demands.
one of the best films I have seen in a long time. jk Simmons was fantastic in this role.

WHIPLASH!!!!

Whiplash is an independent movie brought to you by writer/director Damien Chazelle. Chazelle entered a short story into the Sundance film festival in 2013. The clip was so high praised he gained funding to adapt it into a full movie. When it was shown in last years Sundance Festival on the 16th of January. It was given such high praise It won the Dramatic Audience Award and has been consistently talked about ever since.

Do not fear greatness: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them. And boy, did this movie achieve it.

Andrew Nieman (Miles Teller - The Spectacular now), is a 19 year old drummer at the fictional Shaffer Music Conservatory in New York City. Plagued by his farther's failure to become a prestigious writer, he will stop at nothing to reach his goal of becoming one of the greatest jazz drummer of all time. One day while he is practicing he catches the eye of the great Terrence Fletcher. (J.K. Simmons - Spider-Man Trilogy) Who leads the top jazz ensemble in the school. After impressing him, he thinks he has got the sweet deal he had always dreamed of. But instead of being the knight in shining armour that Andrew thinks is. He will soon discover Fletcher's frightening and brutal methods that will forever change his life. Andrew's passion to achieve greatness quickly spirals into an obsession. eventually pushing him to the brink of both his ability and sanity.

Editing isn't really something I pay attention to, or even notice while watching movies, but the editing in this movie is fantastic. It is filled with swift transactions between the character to drum set. How it moves perfectly over to each drum or symbol in perfect timing to the music. The back and forth switching from character to character is outstanding, especially in the confronting, and emotional scenes.

The most liberating thing in this movie, for me, is the acting. Oh man, the acting is incredible. J.K.Simmons really does give the performance of his life in this movie. He's so viscous and mean but he plays it to a T. You may say "well, it doesn't take a great actor to be able to scream and shout", but to give the emotion and brutality that he put into his scenes I feel absolutely no one could do better. Picture J. Jonah Jameson mixed with Sergeant Hartman from FMJ, but 10 times worse, and that's Simmons in this movie. Also let us not forget, Miles Teller. He really poured his heart and soul into this movie, a ground breaking performance from him. He catches the emotion of Andrew to perfection, and I couldn't imagine anyone fitting that role more than him.

The most difficult thing while making a story has to be the ending. No matter how good a movie is, it will make or break depending on the quality of the ending. Luckily for us the ending to this movie is PHENOMINAL. So powerful, So unique, so intense it absolutely blew me away. One of the best endings to a movie I've seen since 'Se7en'. You become so emotionally invested in Teller's character while watching the ending. It's just. WOW!!

This movie is near perfection, the only real flaw I have with this movie is Andrew's girlfriend, Nicole (Melissa Benoist - Glee) I don't really thing she was necessary to this movie, maybe if they would have added just a few more scenes, maybe an extra 5 minutes, just so we could get a real feel for her character and care how she ends up. That is the only thing stopping me from giving this a 10/10. A 9.8/10 will suffice. But it is definitely in the run for some Oscar nominations and I believe it definitely deserves a few wins as well.
Brilliant movie.  Mentally brutal in the pursuit of artistic perfection.  Loved it
Simmons' performance is remarkable. And the story is thought provoking. Rather minimalistic, which I liked.

This film is like being yelled at for ninety minutes (I exaggerate - but the tension is palpable). It's essentially a boot camp for Jazz musicians, with Whiplash being one of the Jazz 'standards' that the band play. Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller) wants to be one of the greats, and he's thrilled to get into Terrance Fletcher's (an irrepressible JK Simmons) class - Fletcher is quite used to bullying the best out of his class, and his pithy tirades are a cinematic pleasure. Neyman is so desperate to shine, that he ends up embroiling himself in a situation where he blows it, and Fletcher tosses him out. Neyman takes it badly, but from here on in we get a wonderful game of cat and mouse - can Neyman prove his old teacher wrong, will Fletcher let him - you really feel the tension between the pair in the 'Jazz off' showdown at the end. Stunning performances from the leads - and JK Simmons fully deserves the most probable Oscar glory.

Fear and intimidation as a teaching method will spark a fiery debate.  What is no in doubt is the electrifying performance of Teller and Simmons as student and teacher in this thriller.  Chazelle the director is reverential to original jazz pieces which reverberate literally on the screen and through the viewer.  The audience is left with one question as the student is driven to obsession for perfection....at what cost does does the pursuit of greatness come? In every note and  drum beat, the psychological, verbal and literally blows and jabs are delivered.  Blood, sweat and tears are the spilled in the quest for great jazz.
Electric editing, directing, and performances all throughout - the type of movie that breezes by, though you wish it would keep going. Ends with a BANG (drumming pun, I'm a bad person).

As Mark Kermode said, "It's Full Metal Hi-Hat": but just how paralleled are the two? Probably much more than you might think. For starters, the ironic bond between Terrence Fletcher and Andrew Neyman. The former is an abusive, swearing, angry motherfucker; the latter, an enthusiastic drum student who endures inconceivable amounts of abuse - to the point at which he becomes a masochist, forcing himself, rather than merely submitting himself to, the horrifying mutilation he incurs. Now, another comparison? Take the parallels of suicide. One wonders at the pressing thought of whether Neyman will end up taking his own life in exasperation. But the one whom it is discovered of (i.e. of taking his own life) is revealed to be an ex-student of Fletcher's, Sean Casey. But of course, just as much as Full Metal Jacket appears to parallel this narrative, what one forgets is that R. Lee Ermey's tormenting ends after the first half of the film; in this case, it is ongoing, right through to the end.
Now, FMJ mirroring aside, this is an important film. It can be labeled a drama or a thriller or a "musical drama or thriller" (ew) but the label which I had ascribed after an hour and 3/4 of screentime (rather short in terms of common film screentimes - which can extend to 3hrs+), was "epic". This film is an epic. It doesn't have to be long to be an epic. It doesn't have to be authored by a Milton or a Kubrick to be an epic: this-film-is-epic. There is one single protagonist - and, of course, one single antagonist - who is made to endure, absurdly, horrible abasement and physical abuse. And despite all of this, he constantly rises to the challenge. We think his downfall arrives right at the end (I won't spoil it) when it *appears* that all hope is lost. But this guy doesn't give up!
And now, genre discrepancies aside... man, this is a good film. It's preciously directed, it's taut, it's wonderfully cut and edited, especially during the Jazz sequences, as we get thrown into trombones, as we get pulled directly into coupling closeups of Fletcher's and Neyman's faces. I think it's deserving of an A+. It's a brilliant start to 2015 for us movie-goers, that's for sure.

If i'm going to be honest, I was on my feet for half of this movie. I saw it at home, but I was whisked away into the world of Andrew Neyman. Never before have I seen such a tense movie. J.K. Simmons plays my favorite role of the year, a drill sergeant-esque band teacher that thankfully doesn't try too hard to draw comparisons to Full Metal Jacket. Not only is it a story about their relationship, but it is also one about pure and blind desire to succeed. Two actor plots are hard to execute, but it soars in Whiplash. It could not have been shot more perfectly, with scenes cutting back and forth as fast as his drum solos. Miles Teller's transformation from sheepish first year to aggressive and ravaging is overlooked but cannot be undersold. As an intense music fan, it inspired me, and as an intense movie fan,  it astounded me. Not for the faint of heart with slightly excessive cursing, not to mention the incredible one on one scenes between the two leads, but Andrew has you loving him early on so everyone has him to root for. 5/5 stars, a film that I'll never forget, Whiplash threw me from side to side and somehow managed to leave me smiling.

I haven't watched a film with such tension and gripping performances in some time. I couldn't wait to see what happened next (or more importantly what Simmons would do next!). If you said that you could make a gripping drama about a college band and drumming I'd have laughed but this is so slickly directed, the music so compelling and dramatic and in Simmons you have one of the great movie villains of all time. Like 'Black Swan' this is mostly about our hero trying to strive for perfection and the skill, dedication and commitment that comes with that. I can appreciate that type of story and the type of drama it creates. This film gets it just right and I am looking forward to rewatching it very soon.

This film epitomizes the use of sound and editing in order to convey the message intended for its audiences.  The music shifts from diegetic to non-diegetic so seamlessly that the fluidity of the each scene is uninterrupted.  The shots and cinematography mix filmmaking and symphony in order to show hierarchy and the focal points when it comes to conducting and making music; the camera angled along the conductors arm displays an original and practical focal point at which the characters are looking.
The relationship between Andrew and Fletcher demonstrate the complexity of relationships.  J.K. Simmons's portrayal of Terence Fletcher and Miles Teller's portrayal of Andrew Neyman, along with the direction of Damien Chazelle allows for an open ended conclusion concerning Andrew and Fletcher's relationship.

An amazingly acted, brilliantly directed masterpiece which gives something as unbelievably boring sounding as jazz drumming the urgency and pulse of life and death, it's a thrilling, virtuoso, unique piece of work, with the fantastic Miles Teller's ( a breakout star here) ascension to musical genius filmed like a sports movie (think Rocky on a drum set although Andrew Neyman is a little more Jake Lamotta) The   real standout though is J.K Simons, best known as Spiderman's newspaper boss, he is terrifying and mesmeric here as tyrannical instructor Fletcher, one of the great screen bully's, up there with R Lee Emery in Full Metal Jacket, a nasty, poisonous monster of a man, his vulgar, spiteful verbal barbs are gleefully hilarious and unpleasant. One of the best things about this film is how uncomfortably honest it is, simply, to be the absolute best and achieve true greatness you cant just be a good person, you may have to be an incredibly selfish dick and sacrifice your relationships with all those around you.

One of the most intense films i've ever witnessed this exhilarating rollercoaster ride will leave you breathless until the very last minute of it's one hour and 46 minute run time and still leave you with the feeling of awe and amazement long after the film has run it's course. 

The film stars Miles Teller as Andrew Neyman, a very game and very ambitious young jazz drummer who's drive is to be one of the ''greats''. Enter Terence Fletcher a terrifying and hard-nosed instructor who is known for his teaching prowess as well as his unforgiving methods of teaching. As the two meet, Neyman is treated to the harsh tactics of Fletcher and the film progresses from that point onward. 

Directed and Written by Damien Chazelle, the film is extraordinarily great at pacing itself from lull moments to exciting and breathtaking moments which makes the experience that much more compelling and all the credit for the said effect has to go to the director for the masterful pacing he applied on the film. 

Another thing that made this film one of the best films in 2014 is it's great script and how the actors played along to said script. J.K. Simmons as Terence Fletcher deserves all the awards he has received so far and it's definitely a lock for him to win that Oscar award come February. His brash and devilish performance as Fletcher makes this film all the much more compelling and intense, and from the said performance he might've just stole the whole movie for me. Miles Teller does an amazing job as Neyman, the straight-edge and focused individual who will stop at nothing to become great at his craft, even though he'll have to step on other people to get there, really great drum work from Teller the whole film and his acting is top-notch as well. 

Cinematography in this film is fairly simple and straight-forward, good artistry and effects all throughout(especially close up scenes). Sound Mixing, Sound Editing, and the WHOLE ENTIRE SOUNDTRACK has to be one of the greatest ensemble sound wise i've heard from a film. Edited almost to perfection as well, what else is there to say about this film.. It's a masterpiece and oh before I forget,  the grand finale of the film itself is already worth the price of admission 

Go watch this film

In one of the most intense films I have seen in years, Miles Teller ( Divergent ) stars as Andrew Neyman, a gifted jazz drummer in an elite east coast school, who aspires "to be one of the greats." Andrew's talent is recognized by Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) who inducts him into his studio band & then ruthlessly drives him toward perfection. Loosely based on the author's own experience, Academy Award nominee writer & director Damien Chazelle propels the viewer through an intensely paced orchestration skillfully utilizing the jazz to amplify the tension in the film. The performances from Miles Teller & J.K. Simmons (who actually played their instruments) were spectacular; riveting & terrifying. This film will be in my top five of best films of 2014 list. THIS IS A CANâ(TM)T MISS FILM which is up for five Academy Awards nomination including Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor (Simmons, which he should win), & Best Adapted Screenplay (Chazelle).

Wow.

That's all my inferior lips could whimper after witnessing the magisterial beauty of this awe-inspiringly good movie. Shot in a dizzying 19 days by newbie Damien Chazelle, Whiplash charts the progression of drummer Andrew Neyman through a savage musical conservatoire and his relentless drive to touch the edges of musical greatness.

In his way (or helping him along, depending on how you take this movie), is the savage mentor Terrence Fletcher, played with an unrivalled brutality without ever edging towards a stock character by the impeccable J.K Simmons, the shining star in this galaxy of brilliance.

Whilst striving for greatness is hardly an original general conceit for a movie, Chazelle directs with such dazzling verve that one can view this in all of its unmistakable glory and see an ingenious and truly inventive piece of cinema. Anchored by two extremely strong lead performances, Whiplash whizzes by like visual jazz, leaving you bereft of breath and unable to scrape your jaw from the ground. IÃÂ¢Ã,Ã,(TM)m not speaking hyperbolically here. This movie unflinchingly conveys its message that success requires hard work and encouragement should often be shunned in favour of some good 'ol tough love. As Simmons' chilling mentor says, "There are no two words in the English language more harmful than 'good job'." Whilst some of his Tucker-esque profanities are borderline comedic, such is the fear that Simmons instills in all who dare to witness him that nobody has enough courage to even consider a chuckle; this character is the stuff of nightmares, relentlessly hurling vicious abuse (as well as some furniture) at the unsatisfactory musicians lucky enough to grace the presence of this scathing musical genius.

Chazelle leaves it us to decide how we perceive Fletcher, a character with the obvious persona of a repugnant bully intimidating the poor musicians for the sake of it to allow viewers to latch onto the idea that he is simply an irredeemable villain, yet providing complexity and touches of humanity in the character to leave others to decide whether they believe the explanation of his undeniably atrocious actions he gives in the film's final quarter rings truthful and he is more of an unconventional hero, the kind of aggressor rarely celebrated in a mainstream movie. I tend to fall into the latter category, with the view that Chazelle's ability to perhaps side with this seemingly brutal creature with his beyond acidic tongue and thus side with Fletcher's unpopular ideas.

Most of all, though, this film is edited and packaged with such musical precision that one can only sit in awe and watch the cruel yet ever-compelling story unfold at breakneck speed. This exhilarating experience shows no sign of waning as the film enters its final, glorious sequence. With one seemingly final twist of the knife from Fletcher as both Neyman and the audience realise that he's been set up to be humiliated in front of the industry experts - or did he? Cinematic perfection comes as Teller's Neyman finally ascends to greatness and the ever-terrifying Fletcher, now a more traditional mentor figure, finally gets the classic musician he always wanted to give birth to as Chazelle showcases his superlative directorial talents. This truly electrifying final act is as memorable as they come, topping off this supremely effective masterpiece of a film and blessing every single audience member with its message and its sheer, unabashed brilliance.

Andrew Neyman is an ambitious young jazz drummer, single-minded in his pursuit to rise to the top of his elite east coast music conservatory.When he is not practising, he is listening to drumming by the Jazz Greats. Terence Fletcher, an instructor equally known for his teaching talents as for his terrifying methods, leads the top jazz ensemble in the school. When he is not screaming at and hummiliating pupils, he is wearing a sickly sweet deceitful smile 
So....;  you won't like like Fletcher. He's the foul-mouthed, abusive teacher who uses his authority to  humiliate the pupils. He gets all cosy to start with and finds out sensitive stuff in order to use it against them later....in public. He is a dinosaur, a freak leftover from the Age of Corporal Punishment, before enlightenment washed over the teaching profession like a velvet gloved hand., .....except that they all revere him, and crucially all volunteer and want to be in his 'studio band' . Maybe they all want his methods to drive them to highs they cannot achieve themselves. Maybe they need his discipline, harsh and wincing as it is. But you still feel he's got it wrong, at least you want to feel that, but it's not soooo simple really, is it?
The film gives you subtle nuance amongst the head-banging and this is no mean feat. It also examines the relationship between student and mentor/teacher. It's always been a tricky one, hasn't it?  I mean, to say that this or that is HOW it should be. For all types of pupil? In all situations? In all disciplines?
Crucially, the film has more layers still, not so much the thrown off girlfriend who would " stand in his way" ( for which read " I fancy you something rotten and cannot control myself to remain disciplined AND have a worthwhile relationship with you) ; more so the father. There is a lot of screentime given to Andrew's father, Jim,  and their relationship. 
Jim is the "nice cop" and the film shows  how much a crucial part this is in Andrew's life, enabling  and supporting him, without ever straying into preachy or gushy territory. Maybe that is the point of the film -  that actually we need both voices/ personae in our lives to be effective and to be our "best" selves.

Young director Damien Chazelle's second feature, about a talented and ambitious young jazz drummer, takes us into the cutthroat, struggling and hardworking world of top-notch jazz musicians. The story is linear and simple, but offers so much insight into that world. The two actors selected to portray the main characters, Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons, are perfect; they were meant for the roles. They get into the shoes of the characters with such ease. Even the few scenes with side characters, like Andrew's dad, girlfriend and fellow drummers, are quite interesting.

The story is mainly about passion, ambition, and desperation to achieve one's goal. It also sheds light on the things one decide to sacrifice in order to achieve their goal.

Positive reinforcement vs negative criticism, which is more effective? This is a debate that has been going on for ages. The former might work for some, while the latter might work for others. Ultimately, it depends on the individual and his/her upbringing; everyone responds to different things.

The story is packed with humour and inspiring moments. Simmons' dialogues are just fantastic; it might seem vulgar to some, but they're just hilarious. Other than the actual instruments being played, no background score is used at all; this works quite well for the movie. Nothing seems staged, everything takes place with such natural ease.

And all this leads up to a foottappingly mesmerising climax. The open-ended approach was good. And the film's topics beg to be discussed and debated among groups.

I love when I go into a movie with zero expectations and I come out so happy.  Right up there with writing, swimming and boxing... music is one of my greatest loves.  If I could liken this film to any other, I would describe it as a super intense "Finding Forrester" in the jazz world.  Miles Teller is a revelation and I'm extremely surprised he hasn't been given a little more notoriety for his efforts.  Not surprising is the notoriety JK Simmons has gotten for his.  Anyone who has had an abusive and overbearing teacher/coach with a borderline personality disorder can surely relate.  I was enthralled from the very jump.  I cared about Teller's Andrew Neiman's well-being throughout and I smiled with every winning moment he had.  The music and attention to nuance and detail was top notch.  If you love movies, run don't walk to check out this soon-to-be watched over and over again classic.

Great acting. Awesome script. And a very nice version of "Caravan" at the end. I like the subversive message that the movie offers: Telling everyone that they have done a "good job" just leads to nothing but  mediocrity.

It should be noted that the movie does not have anything important to say about Jazz though. The anecdote they keep mentioning about Charlie Parker is fabricated and more importantly the protagonist, Andrew, takes the wrong lessons about how to achieve artistic greatness. Charlie Parker did not become great by sitting in a room by himself trying to make his hands move as fast as possible. Rather the movie is all about the teacher/student dynamic and about having a singular obsession. It does so very well.

J.K. Simmons' performance is highly enjoyable but his character development is being entirely neglected leaving me unable to comprehend his implied ambuguity. His monologue at the end, clarifying his motives is blatant compensatory exposition dialog which could have been entirely avoided simply by giving him some actual scenes. The focus is on the character of Andrew Neyman and his coming-of-age problems which are appropriate for an upper-middle class boy his age but nothing nearly as hefty as to justify a whole movie.  The chemistry between the two characters seems to have been denied on purpose, which is understandable in context of the plot but makes it hard to connect nevertheless. Now this means Whiplash falls short on it's premise exactly where it matters, trying to be an underdog movie without a real underdog or a real teacher or real stakes. While it's a nice try, unlike it's protagonist, it's just not quite good enough to do what it wants to do.

That being said, this is not a bad movie either and fortunately there is a lot of emphasis on the musical scenes which are nothing short of amazing, making me recommend this movie for fans of complex music after all.

Simmons makes sure that despite being essentially a villain to Miles Teller, he still acts as a human and still conveys his morals and intentions to the audience through the character of Terrence Fletcher. It is, however Simmons ability to switch between personalities that keeps the audience on the edge of their seats in the brilliantly directed drum sequences that help up the anti of an already full-throttle film.

Without Tellers human responses and performance as well as his character growth the film would not of been the same, if the main character didn't have the side and support of the audience.

Whiplash seems to be making a major splash among audiences, and pulling it self forward into a likely best picture winner. Considering director's Damien Chazelles greatest work before this is writing the screenplay for The Last Exorcism Part II, it's rather impressive how well this movie is doing. In all technical aspects this film is great. Credited for film editing, Tom Cross did phenomenal in this department. Cinematography by Sharon Meir, flashy when it needs to be (musical scenes) while elegant during the simpler scenes (Dates, dinners). In all the production departments this film is exactly where it needs to be. My issue really lies with the characters of the movie. While this is strongly against the narrative, I find both the student (Andrew) and professor (Fletcher) predictable and one dimensional. While Chazelle tries to portray them as insane and impulsive, I find everything they do over the course of the film match what I'd expect from the character from the first impression. And I do understand what Chazzelle shows about Andrew and Fletcher in the intense finale scene, I just felt both their motives were always obvious. And this is to no fault of Miles Teller or J.K. Simmons who acted their hearts out. This film makes drumming more intense than I ever imagined, it also has some strong dramatic scenes. But, I see a strong craving for depth in this film, I just don't see the depth.

"Whiplash" is initially a captivating study about what it takes to be great and what is needed to become great, and it ends as a captivating study about what it is to be great. Miles Teller (playing Andrew Neiman) and J.K. Simmons (playing Terence Fletcher) are both absolutely fantastic in their respective roles and their performances are on par with those I loved witnessing in "Birdman" and they fit perfectly, as "Birdman"'s cast did with that films respective themes, with what "Whiplash" is all about. 
Greatness, as I mentioned earlier, is what "Whiplash" is all about. Teller's and Simmons' drive reflect this, and it comes through in their characters. Andrew wants to be "one of the greats" and Fletcher wants to be the man to coach one of them. Yet this is certainly the absolute minimum of what I gathered about this film before I saw it. This kind of drive is in motion about halfway through the film, and "Whiplash" has several twists and turns in it before it finishes. Teller and Simmons develop extremely complex characters and what you come to realise is that what makes them complex is their drive. Andrew for example is an initially very easy character to understand and in some ways, to relate to. We've all wanted to be better and get great at something. But what takes "Whiplash" in a different direction from the one where we see Andrew asking the girl behind the counter at the cinema out is Fletcher. He pushes Andrew beyond "what is expected of him". Watching Teller develop Andrew as a character is a fun ride although Fletcher swearing, slapping and throwing cymbals at him is not so much, but it's all for a reason. 
But is it necessary? Fletcher believes so, calling it "an absolute necessity" in a scene where he seems to reveal himself as the grand villain, right beneath our noses this whole time. "Whiplash" asks these questions and it's almost as if the film sprouted from them, not that they came up and were developed as the film continued to shoot. Andrew and Fletcher's relationship is an attempt at answering them, leaving it up to you whether the answers "Whiplash" puts forward are right or wrong. Are Fletchers methods the way forward? Could Andrew harness his talent and be great without Fletcher? Did Andrew have the talent to do such a thing? Is talent even a realistic construct? "Whiplash" asks all of these questions, and puts forward its answers here.
Of course Teller and Simmons are fantastic too and deserve the nominations they are getting. Simmons character is particularly well developed (and funny too) and again it is a joy to witness Teller's development. Neither character can be described really. Simmons seems describable but there seems to be something beneath him that I couldn't figure out and in one scene we see that he isn't quite as tough as he seems to be. What surprises me though is how Simmons keeps winning awards and Teller does not. For me they are both brilliant and one does not outdo the other because in "Whiplash" you come to think of them as entirely separate individuals, and their relationship is instead an eternal one in regards to how it can be applied to several examples and asked whether it is one required for greatness. 
What's also worth mentioning is the films score. It's brilliant. It really is just a complete appraisal of Jazz.  Drums of course predominantly feature and although the score is not as good as "Birdman"s, again heavily featuring drums, the reason it is not is because the score in "Whiplash" is external and in "Birdman", it's internal, inside the cast's heads. It has meaning and something to do with the film whereas in "Whiplash" it's almost as if Jazz music and the drums in this case are being used as a way by which we can see Andrew become great. It's another eternal concept of sorts. 
"Whiplash" is definitely worth seeing and although I wouldn't quite call it the film of the year, it certainly puts forward a good performance in several categories and has done well considering it was shot in 19 days and adapted from a short film. Most should come out saying "Whiplash" was a good film. It's tense and has some good performances in it and asks questions, and talks about, greatness. It's visually tense as well, helped along by slow-motion shots of sweat bouncing up and down off cymbals and blood dripping from a hand. Because of this, it was an utter relief, and felt hard-earned in some respects, to see the films ending.

Whiplash is the raw, uncut and undeniably intense jazz film I have always waited for.  Helmed by one of the best performances of the year, young actor Miles Teller is mind-blowing as the would-be jazz drumming legend.  JK Simmons also finally nabs that Oscar performance of his life as the abusive mentor Fletcher.  He's psychopathic, but oddly respectable, and overall unforgettable.  The story is excellent throughout the film as we see a dream, that dream being crushed, and then rise from the ashes in the most fantastic of ways.  

The music, editing and sound are all equally top notch.  The script is whip smart and fantastically performed - the film as a whole could have done with half the the amount of strong language for myself personally, and would've been much more effective overall.  I couldn't recommend Whiplash for the faint of heart.

'Whiplash's quality purely comes from its engaging teacher-student dynamic which sets a great intense atmosphere throughout proceedings. The clash between ruthless teacher and tenacious drum student is fun to watch and creates a strong stage for both lead actors to flourish. It may even remind audiences of their school days, specifically relationships with strict teachers, while also inviting us to consider the borders between inspiration and cruelty. The 2014 Sundance Film Festival gem "Whiplash" is a beast that rips you apart. Its flashy editing and particularly Damien Chazelle's ferocious direction bruised, as you witness in pure tension a young man's (played by Miles Teller with such astonishing commitment) striving determination to be a great jazz drummer in America's top music school, but not before extreme suffering from JK Simmon's (acclaimed but somewhat one-note) demanding and abusive maestro from hell. Like Darren Aronofsky's "Black Swan" (2010), this tight film questions the path and expense to achieve perfection: pain and sacrifice are never options. The screenplay was not perfect and at times questionable, but like the steep learning curves in all lessons, you will not forget the blisters on Teller's palms and the blood on his drum sticks.

"If you don't have ability, you wind up playing in a rock band"
Whiplash doesn't miss a beat, Oscar contender! Recommended.

This is what movie making is all about. No-nonsense, high stakes look at breaking into the Jazz circuit. This movie understands why films are different than novels or play: we learn characters, exposition and plot not through their thoughts or dialogue, but how they act and react. Speaking of, all acting in this film is stellar, the cast really bring in the gritty realism of trying to succeed in a craft. Theirs a reason Simmons won so many awards, and it's because the guy's a damn fine actor. Fantastic script really keeps pace with the entire cast. Whiplash really shows what happen when all around talent steps up their game.
one of the few movies that kept my attention to the very end!

 The tension of these willful characters driving themselves and each other to a mythical perfection - almost unimaginable here.

This movie is for the ages. It is tight, tense and taut while being sensitive, subtle and soft. People who have seen this, would ask what I mean by soft. The movie has a unique quality of adding weight to the scene, the music and the emotion by adding time, space or 'wait'. This pause between moments added a lot of weight to prior and upcoming moment. This pause is what added the softness to this otherwise intense film. I loved the subtlety at the end with Nicole. I loved the eyes of the father at the end who loved yet did not understand his son. Those eyes said it all. The intensity and use of blood was fabulous. Their is no criminal in this movie. There is an obvious hero. But it is about an Anti-Hero knowing that by being an Anti-Hero, he can create a Super Hero. 
The music obviously is mind blowing. I couldn't stop tapping to it. I want to listen to Jazz now after this. Any suggestions?
This is one of those few movies that you could feel the 'power' in the shots as well as the pain at the same time. 
Certain close up shots were at perfect moments. It was not over utilized at all.

Fantastic directorial debut by Chazelle who brings grit, style, passion and a surprising amount of heart into this excellentyl made film. Anyone who appreciates the art of film-making will love this film, from slick editing to directorial flare, and from terrific performances (Teller and Simmons are excellent) to a cleverly written script. Just pure cinematic excellence.

There are films that can only dream to reach the levels of tension that this reaches. Whiplash is an outstanding drama with a pair of perfect performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons.

I was drawn into this film moments after it started, the way this film is put together is impeccable and I really had no idea where this film was going next. Damien Chazelle- who clearly looks to have found a type of film he is interested in making- has done an excellent job crafting a very powerful, authentic and intense story about a psychological battle between 2 people. This has to be one of the most intense films that I have ever seen. For his second film this is unbelievably good. 

The acting in this is brilliant and Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons had me glued to the screen, I never checked my watch once, I was so invested in the story and the film really had sucked me in, it was quite incredible. Sure, there were other characters but the film belongs to them. J.K. Simmons has always been a powerful character actor and this is some of his best work, Jason Reitman was one of the many producers for this and Simmons is always in his films somewhere, just a funny little coincidence. Some of the things that J.K. Simmons says, even when he's trying to be nice had me on edge, he starts off by saying, 'just have fun', and that just worried me. He then goes on to get progressively angry and seeing him like that and what he could do to people really just set the mood from that point on. Especially when he starts to insult Miles Teller's character with things that he told him in presumable confidence, this is JJ Jameson x1000, Miles Teller can look at Tobey Maguire and say you didn't have the most intense version of J.K. Simmons, I did! Saying that, some of the things he says are very witty and darkly humorous, and in his quieter moments I found myself agreeing with a lot of what he was saying. Miles Teller put so much effort into this and it really shows, seeing him on the drums and what he could do and just his determination in general was really something to root for. It's also another performance in the awards season that is being ignored, much like in Foxcatcher but that's usually how it goes with a lot of things. Seeing someone that passionate for something they want was inspiring to watch but after awhile it did provide some questions. What's the point in pursuing a hobby if you're not enjoying it anymore and just push yourself to the point of exhaustion? The film has many underlying themes to it and besides having your heart in your mouth whilst you watch it, you'll reflect on the situation and think about something similar in your own life. 

I can relate to the film quite directly to be honest, I play drums and I have been in competitions before but certainly not to the extremity displayed here but seeing some of what Miles Teller's character went through certainly brought back a few memories. Besides that, this film will just remind you of something you went through hell for just because you wanted it so badly, it's a very powerful and exhausting experience. J.K. Simmons' character also talks about pushing people to their limit and beyond what's expected of them and that's how I feel sometimes with writing these, they've just become so involving now.

The cinematography in this is very clever, the longer the film goes on the more frantic it becomes and by the end in the amazing solo act, it is just at really creative angles with quick cuts and it's very well done. The soundtrack is also clever as I think the band actually plays the soundtrack as I can't think of any other use of music outside these moments which is a great decision and a nice touch, for obvious reasons. 

If I have any complaint at all its that I think the family and girlfriend subplot are a bit forced. Miles Teller's character already has enough problems to deal with in his day to day life that the addition of an unsupportive family and girlfriend don't seem necessary, especially because of how little they're on screen. While it does provide more character development and more things to relate to, I felt like it was a little forced, again, it gives more meat to the character and saying that, it does make his struggle all the more compelling which is always good but I just felt like it didn't need to be there, is all. He was already struggling enough and we already rooted for him. I also feel like J.K. Simmons' character got a bit extreme at points, which I know was the idea and maybe I'm missing the point but I don't know about you but if a teacher, no matter how brilliant they are or whatever they are trying to accomplish, threw a chair at a student, I don't think they'd last long or rather, last as long as they had done.

I had a headache after the film finished and I'm not sure if that's just coincidence or if it was because of how intense this was, accompanied with the awesome 9 minute final drum solo, probably just coincidence but it's fun to think it was the film, but after all was said and done I just felt inspired and really good, seeing that final smile from J.K. Simmons really meant a lot and the shocking ending of the film is great as is everything else about it. Whiplash is fantastic, gripping and ultimately rewarding drama with perfect performances from Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. It's excellent and one of the best films of 2014. I'd like the check out the original short that got the funds for this masterpiece, now. It certainly would be interesting to watch.

I like jazz a lot, so fair play to note my bias, but I don't think it matters.  The storytelling here is sharp and fast and invites viewers to think along with the film rather than telling them how to feel.  This opens us up to be surprised at turn after turn.  Just when we think we've got this story pegged, it deflects into an exciting new story-line it's not afraid to explore. 

JK Simmons is getting all the credit so far, and any praise he gets from this performance is deserved, but I think some of that is because this film is shockingly good, and it's easier to lump that on Simmons than a 29-year-old Director (Damien Chazelle) known mostly for winning at Cannes in 2013 with a short film (also called "Whiplash" based on the same Simmons character, Terence Fletcher.) But the magic in this film happens in the editing and writing/adapting rooms, I think.  Zero shots are wasted.  Everything adds up.  The pace is perfect.  Simmons and Teller become their characters, Paul Reiser works great as a dad doing his best, and even the drummers against whom Teller is pitted improve the film with their efforts.
A masterpiece of cinema. Enough said.
