Music is a subject that has been extensively covered by film, almost to the point of diminishing returns. The same way sports movies became a series of dots to join to reach the picture that everyone knew was coming eventually, the way that action movies hit every beat that you just know they're going to hit before you walk in and watch them. But there are exceptions. Raging Bull knocked sports movies on their asses, along with inclusions like The Fighter and Warrior, by looking at the people, not just the sport. Films like Pulp Fiction slammed a shot of adrenaline straight into the heart of action films, blowing up our expectations along the way. This year, the same has been accomplished with music in movies with Whiplash. While I don't necessarily put it in the same rarefied air as Raging Bull or Pulp Fiction (there's not too much that is), in terms of what it does for the subject, it is an absolute gut punch to the medium, and will serve as a standard for films years down the line that attempt to tackle similar topics.

The plot is relatively simple: a young, talented, ambitious musician, in this case jazz drummer Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller), attempts to stand out in one of the most prestigious music schools in the world. His progress is only held up by one teacher, Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), who will accept nothing less than perfection.

Like I said, we've seen this plot before. Newborns have seen this premise. But what we haven't seen is Terence Fletcher. I'm not talking about the bluster and the storm that J.K. Simmons summons as the film's generator of conflict. It's incredible viewing, to be sure, and Simmons absolutely brings the thunder, spitting fury and hellfire at his students if they dare to make a mistake. I'm talking about what this character represents. The core conceit, after all of the quick cuts and insults have worn off, is this idea that Terence Fletcher embodies: that greatness, true greatness, can never be achieved without being beaten down first. That purity is only formed through fire. And he is definitely that fire. In his many, many rants and explosions, he lays down a ferocious gauntlet for his performers; taunting them and roaring at them until they either break or get it right. He goes further than instruction, insulting them, their ability, who they are as a person, belittling them in verbal assault after verbal assault. And if that was all that the film had to bring, it would be a hell of a showcase for Simmons, but the result would be hollow. It's when we see a scene like the one between Andrew and Fletcher in a bar that the movie makes its higher intentions known. "There are no two words in the English language more harmful than 'good job," Fletcher tells Andrew. And in some ways, it's true. Fletcher laments this generation and the idea that parents and teachers don't push their children to be the best, that they don't make them strive for true greatness, because by not doing so, they could be depriving the world of the next great individual. The film references musicians like Buddy Rich, but the sentiment carries through to any context. Without being pushed, without being challenged, people can't improve, they can't discover their true potential. It's a fascinating subject to tackle, and it's handled with such precision and intelligence by writer and director Damien Chazelle. The script explores every aspect of this idea, and it's telling that the finale maintains an ambiguous nature in terms of which side it takes on the issue. There's no simple answer to the question, but the way that it's explored here is bold and smart and completely absorbing.

Chazelle's double duty as writer and director could have meant a certain apathy in one of those fields. But after writing a great script, Chazelle shows off some serious chops as a director as well. A lot of the frantic speed throughout the musical pieces could be attributed to the editing room rather than the shoot, but look at the way Chazelle brings the pace up within the scene, the way each move of the camera elevates the heart rate of the film. It's more than just slick work on Final Cut here, Chazelle shoots these scenes like they're life or death and as a result, we feel like it is. Each scene where Andrew sits down at the drums is a white-knuckle sprint to the finish and it gives the film an energy that I don't think I've seen in a film about musicians before. Chazelle focusses on the details rather than the big picture here, flashing from close-up to close-up as Andrew fights every moment with sweat and blood. On the less frantic end of things, Chazelle shoots the more human sides of the film with a well-balanced restraint, keep the depth of field shallow and the framing tight, insulating us from the world outside. Andrew only sees the drums and the dream, so that's all we see as well. Any distractions or inclusions along the way are brought in as intrusions for the most part.

Andrew is our point of view for the film and Miles Teller brings him to life with yet another outstanding performance. A lot of people are heralding his performance as a breakout role, but those people obviously didn't see The Spectacular Now (shame on them). It's less of a breakout performance and more of a confirmation of the depth of talent he's exhibited in his roles so far. Andrew is a complex individual, at war with himself and those around him in his quest for true greatness, and it's scary to see just how far he pushes himself to get there. Teller plays these moments with absolute commitment, but his restraint is what really sells it. In his normality, his day-to-day existence, he sells us on the fact that this is a person, not a superhero, and what he's going through, putting himself through, is made all the more harrowing for that fact. And then of course there's J.K. Simmons. I've already talked about his role earlier on, and a little about his performance, but it's worth mentioning again. He is drop-dead brilliant in the role, an absolute hurricane of a human who is able to dominate a room just by standing there. He is funny and terrifying and smart and intriguing all at the same time and Simmons completely inhabits him, all the way down to the light in his eyes when he feels those all too infrequent moments of greatness happening nearby. For all the verbal fire he spews, the moments when you can see the excitement in his eyes or the absolute pleasure he finds in revenge, those are the ones that really stayed with me. And as good as they are apart, these two are amazing together. They feed off their individual intensity and you can see each man sizing the other up as they go.

For all the moments of greatness there are a few missteps along the way. A car crash, a lawsuit and a girlfriend are all well-intentioned but they don't land quite as well as they could. Their message is clear and their purposes represent interesting aspects that film explores, but they're less of a breather than a roadblock when Chazelle takes the foot off the gas throughout the film. But when Fletcher and Andrew are in the same room and we get to see them firing on all cylinders, it truly is magic.

Defining Scene:
The final scene of the film is stand-up, jaw-drop, cheer-if-you-want-to level good, so I'll pick that over the possible choice of the conversation in the bar. But not by much.

"I think being the greatest musician of the 20th century is anybody's idea of success."

Have you ever been pushed beyond expected, I mean way way over it? Have you ever felt the pain of loosing your own temper till you loose any common sense of life? Bleed for what you really wanted? So Whiplash, this ode to jazz will have you at the edge of your seat with your heart going a yard a minute. Miles Teller plays a 19-year old drummer Andrew Neyman, who wants to be the best there ever was. The only thing stopping this ambitious student is his equally-ambitious instructor Terence Fletcher, played by J.K. Simmons. 

While watching this movie, your mind, body, and ears will be thrilled by the two main leads, their co-stars, and the spectacular jazz score.
This film builds tension and suspense better than any thriller in my recent memory. The complexity of choices made in shooting the performance scenes were astoundingly good and truly set a visual tone that matched the jazz pieces.

At its core, this is a film about the types of choices necessary to take an honest shot at greatness. It seems that too often in films characters in similar positions make compromises and opt for relationships that are billed as higher values than greatness and mastery. This protagonist makes no such compromises and the payoff is an argument for being driven by such purpose. It has been a long time since I have left a movie theater feeling this emotionally rewarded.

As the performances go Miles Teller is solid in the lead, but J.K Simmons is absolutely riveting. As a side note, I think the film raises some interesting questions for those in the field of performing arts pedagogy. What is the proper role/purpose/tactic of an advanced arts teacher?
Possibly the most intense movie I've ever seen.

Brilliant debut movie by Damien Chazelle. Essentially it's a character study of a pupil and his mentor. The acting from both leads is superb, especially J K Simmons who could quite possibly win an Oscar for his performance.

Damien Chazelle's Whiplash follows the story of a young and talented drummer studying at Schaffer academy in New York. The film expertly observes the pressures and stresses of working under such a manipulative director.

Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller) is a 19 year-old student, gifted with the sticks in his hand. The film opens with him practising his drumming and is a clear indication of how ambitious and determined he is. After impressing Terence Fletcher (JK Simmons), the director of the leading ensemble in the school, Neyman is promoted into the band. Here is where he discovers the strict conditions of working under the perfectionist Fletcher. Insults regarding his mother who ran away when he was young and having chairs thrown at him isn't what Neyman expected.

However, he remains strong and as determined as ever to prove that he can be a great, continuing to practice at every opportunity, literally playing until his hands are blistering and bleeding.

Whiplash ultimately becomes a clash of two musical geniuses striving for perfection, illustrating the pressures and tensions to the extent where the audience are expecting either one to crack at any stage. Chazelle keeps the film strongly in the shadow of Neyman, tracking every single strain and emotion with the camera spending a lot of the time behind the shoulder of Neyman. Tempo is a major theme throughout the film in relation to the jazz numbers on the soundtrack which all make for an enthralling watch.

Teller and Simmons both deliver perfect performances. Teller, who is certainly coming of age, manages to truly reflect the development of Neyman, not only as a drummer, but also as a person. Teller spends the majority of the film in all kinds of pain; either sweating, bleeding or crying and he delivers every possible emotion his character endures.

Simmons standing in the opposite corner also perfects the role of the cynical, terrifying director, constantly pushing his band for perfection in the most intimidating approach possible. His quips and insults leave the audience wondering whether to laugh or sit in a state shock.

Whiplash is a dark and pulsating watch, which deservedly left Sundance with two awards under its arm. With the Oscar nominations just around the corner, it would be no surprise to see a number of honours coming the way of Chazelle's creation.

Whiplash raises a challenging question: how far can you push someone to achieve greatness? Is there a line? Even if you get there, was it worth it? All of these questions are raised in Whiplash, and the amazing part about the film is it makes arguments for either side. Whichever side you'd take personally, Whiplash is undeniably amazing, with one of the best original screenplays I have seen from a second time director, wonderful performances from J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller, and some amazing editing that parallels the feeling of the jazz music that is consistently played throughout the film. Whiplash lives up to the title. It will leave you shaken, stirred, and moved. It's a must see.

Perhaps the most intense film I've ever seen, Whiplash makes you tingle with nerves at any of J.K Simmons' many appearances. You feel psychologically manipulated throughout the whole film, just like the protagonist, which is achieved by the fantastic performances, direct cinematography, intelligent directing and that repetitive sound of the snare. While it features a moment that frustrates many, where more scenes continue to roll in after you thought the film was over, the actual ending (and climax) is, unbelievably, far better than what I thought was actually the ending. It's not a film that leaves you thinking about deeper messages or anything like that, nor does it need to. Whiplash is an example of brilliant storytelling, and isn't that all a film needs to be?

This movie is quite a roller-coaster with plenty of bumps along the way to jostle you senseless. In that regard Whiplash is made well, you buy into the story about a student who wants to be the best and meets his match in tyrannical teacher, Terence Fletcher. This character will stick out in everyone's mind just as we remember the Frankenstein monster. Miles Teller as the student is perfect in his portrayal of the young man and definitely matches the intense performance that J.K.Simmons delivers. Terence Fletcher is beyond John Houseman's Professor Kingsfield in The Paper Chase. Kingsfield was Grandpa Walton compared to Fletcher. I do not want to set off spoilers, but  I felt I had seen this movie before. In many ways this is similar to Black Swan, Gone Girl, and perhaps to some degree Officer and a Gentleman and Fatal Attraction. There were monsters in all these films. Today's horror is the person who goes to far to effect another person and the repercussions. Usually the hero desires the most in life and wishes to attain his ideal goal. How far is too far? American filmmakers seem to latch on to this, because it is what is reflected in the desire of the American dream.Yet to attain the American Dream is a nightmare at times. To say that I was not shaken by this movie would be a lie. It viscerally cut through me and at times I hyperventilated. What disappoints me is that there is not another vision to look forward to in future films. The last positive teacher movie was perhaps Dead Poet's Society or Dangerous Minds. Yet most film makers see these films as part of a cliche'. Does this disappoint me? Yes--in many ways because we do not celebrate the true heroes in our lives any more. We tear them down or look for their demise. Do we need to be hit over the head with this and be bludgeoned until we bleed.

Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) is a 19-year-old drummer in his first year at the best music school in the country. Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), a notorious hard-ass, handpicks him to be in his highly competitive jazz band.  Though Andrew is thrilled about being selected, his joy is short-lived as Fletcher seemingly singles him out for abuse.  There's nothing constructive about this criticism; Fletcher's tactics include berating, face-slapping, and chair-throwing.  

Most normal kids would quit under these circumstances, but Andrew is no normal kid. He's single-mindedly obsessed with becoming the world's next Buddy Rich and is willing to forego everything else - girls, friends, sleep, his dignity - in order to achieve it.  

"Whiplash" is about tense as movies come. It features a surprising amount of blood, gallons of sweat, and even a few tears. Though the title refers to the name of a song the band regularly rehearses, it can also refer to Fletcher's habit of alternating tiny bits of encouragement with lengthy, vein-popping tirades. This isn't a pleasant movie, but it's impossible to look away and Simmons is phenomenal.

As an aside, this show marked my introduction to "reserved seating", something I didn't even know existed until the ticket guy showed me a chart of available seats and told me to pick one. Though I can see this feature being a boon to the Saturday night date crowd who buy their tickets in advance, my primary goal in picking both show times and seats is to avoid being bothered by other people. How on earth am I supposed to gauge the relative obtrusiveness of my potential neighbors - an algorithm I've been refining for years - by seeing only a seating chart? How can I tell if a seat is the proper distance from the screen or the sightlines right or the floor is sticky? What if a pair of Chatty Cathys shows up and I want to move? Are all seats fair game once the movie begins? If you arrive to find someone sitting in your seat, who would you even complain to? It's not like there are ushers. 

Fortunately, the seat I chose for "Whiplash" turned out to be just perfect, though I couldn't actually find any seat numbers so I just sat in the one I liked best and hoped it was mine. Seems like a pretty good strategy to me.
Best movie of 2014 IMO

I teach painting, drawing and workshops in 'public art," and would never treat my students, let alone another human being the way Terence Fletcher, the intensely controlling jazz instructor in a prestigious Music Conservatory in NYC (eerily and wonderfully acted by J.C. Simmons) "hammers" his students to what Fletcher considers "perfection."  WHIPLASH directed by Damien Chazelle is part psychodrama, horror story, case study in manipulation, naked ambition and teaching techniques - do results justify brutal means? OR as I have found to be true does it do the opposite - discourage students to such a degree that they drop out or break down.

We first meet Andrew (Miles Teller) in a movie theater sharing popcorn with a companion - who happens to be his father. Andrew, though socially awkward, is a young  man who single-mindedly knows what he wants from life - to be as great a drummer as the legendary American jazz drummer Buddy Rich and in an almost Faustian bargain willingly succumbs to the spell of an abusive teacher who he believes can deliver him his goal. Fletcher's modus operandi is one of debasement coupled with an occasional affirmation all in the name of precision and superiority; a frighteningly dictatorial approach to the evolution of creativity.

The exchange between student/teacher can be a tender one - growth develops out of sensitive and genuine respect for a pupil's intelligence and capacity, or one that is fraught with anxiety and sadistic motivational techniques. In WHIPLASH - the apt title comes from a Hank Levy (American jazz composer and saxophonist) tune that the school band is rehearsing  over and over again; blood is psychologically and  literally spilled under the "master's" pummeling - the repetitive practice drilling into one's psyche - the audience becomes as tense as the pounding  sounds emanating from the tautly stretched membranes which are struck with sticks know as "beaters."  


Personalities and events are not always anticipated which made the movie compelling. Characterizations are slowly revealed through frenzied musical performances; audacious hunger for success taking precedence over one's personal life and human contact. Between the two lead characters, there are shifts in domination like a wire which coils and uncoils pulling their mentor/disciple relationship together and apart, spawning a tarnished creative union.
Electric, brilliant filmmaking across all of the craft's facets, with some of the best performances of the year to boot.

Whiplash is a story told in broad strokes and is, as implied by the title, a jarring allegory. In the first scene we meet the two main characters, Andrew Neyman; an obsessed young drum student (Miles Teller) at a fictitious prestigious New York music academy, and Terence Fletcher; a brutal drill sergeant of a teacher/band leader (J.K. Simmons). Most of the film focuses on the battle of egos in which these two allegorical figures engage. We find out that drum prodigy Neyman is too obsessed with becoming "one of the greats" to sustain a superficial relationship with girlfriend Nicole (Melissa Benoist) whom he unceremoniously dumps, but we never really get the sense that this is anything more than a plot device. There never seemed to be much passion in the relationship. Andrew Neyman is never able to open up about how he really feels about her or why he wanted to go out with her in the first place. I got the sense that writer/director Damien Chazelle simply decided that the protagonist had to have a girlfriend he could dump just to show how truly obsessed he is. 

Likewise, it's made quite clear that Terence Fletcher is also obsessed. In Fletcher's case the obsession seems to be finding the perfect drummer for his school's jazz band. The attention Fletcher gives to pitting several aspirants against each other while the rest of the band sits and watches in stunned silence becomes somewhat absurd as the story progresses. We never really find out why he has so much trouble with drummers and not other band members. If he was as brutal with everyone in his his band as he is with his drummers, how would he ever get through any rehearsals at all? Maybe if we could hear Fletcher say "It's all about the drums in jazz" or something similar, it would make sense. 

The films most troubling aspect is its rationalization of Fletcher's brutality toward his students. He is on a mission to produce "another Charlie Parker," albeit reincarnated as a drummer. He tells and retells a story about how Parker was driven to be great after having a cymbal thrown at his head. However this story is more fiction than fact - deliberately exaggerated for dramatic effect. So it is with most of Whiplash. The exaggerations are deliberate and calculated to tell a story that is not so much about music than about a certain aspect of male psychology which is wrapped up with success and greatness at any cost. It can't be accidental that are no females in Fletcher's band. There are several scenes of Neyman with his dad, but his mother is a non-entity. Taken this way, Whiplash makes a some sense and rings true enough, but I felt a little disappointed that I wasn't really watching a movie about music at all, in spite of the spectacular musicianship on display throughout.

Certainly a film worth watching, but also a troubling vindication of bullying as the path to greatness.

New director Damien Chazelle does a very fine job in his first feature film, creating such intensity and making each performer truly be at his best. While Miles also is on his A-game getting under our skin with everything he goes through. Moreover, at first when I finished watching the movie I wasn't sure if I had truly understood the movie because I totally felt like I was witnessing human torture, but after reading some more about it, I did understand his "intentions", and even if do not agree 100% with the character Fletcher ideals, because I think there is a limit to everything and more when it involves someone else's life, nonetheless it was still a very fun and terrific ride that not every director and movie is able to portray as powerful and raw.

I'll be honest here - this is one of my favorite movies now. I've probably seen it five times now, but I simply can't get enough. The story is incredibly captivating, with astonishing performances, a near-perfect screenplay and rapid-fire editing. This has to be a modern classic by now, right?

I have been dancing around Whiplash all year. Although it was obvious the movie was excellent, I was afraid it would take a turn for the boring, like so many movies of this genre. Surprisingly, I was completely wrong. Somehow, someway, Chazelle turns a movie that really only has four cast members into a taunt thriller that exist solely as an edge of your seat type of movie. Whiplash has a biting soundtrack that is simply an extension of the movie's events and this serves its purpose perfectly, setting the mood again and again and communicating the anxiety and the desperation of the main character. The acting is superb, with the minimalist set allowing each actor to completely take over the scene. J.K. Simmons really does give the performance of his life here and his brutal scenes repeatedly caused strong reactions from those viewing the movie with me. Teller really is the unsung hero here though, delivering an equally moving performance as the anxious, overfocused and repetitive Neyman. I really am surprised he didn't make it on the Best Actor list at the Oscars. Overall, Whiplash is only the second technically perfect film of the year after Birdman, a lovely blending of blackened sets, fantastic jazz and the gripping interactions between Teller and Simmons, who certainly achieved best on screen combo this year. Excited to see what Chazelle has in mind for his next project.

"I think being the greatest musician of the 20th century is anybody's idea of success."

Damien Chazelle's Whiplash is one of the best films of 2014. It doesn't matter if you aren't much of a music fan (I'm not), because there is much more going on here than the simple premise of a young drummer trying to achieve perfection. I don't know much about jazz or music, but somehow Chazelle managed to make one of the most intense films of the year. Who would've thought that a film focusing on a relationship between a young drummer and his mentor could be so intense and have you at the edge of your seat during the final ten minutes of the film? It was quite a memorable experience. This is Chazelle's sophomore film (his debut film was Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench) and you can already conclude he's a brilliant director and one to look forward to. He's as determined as the main protagonist of the film. When he wasn't able to come up with the funding for this film he decided to make a 20 minute short which debuted at Sundance in 2013 and after garnering attention from critics he was able to finance this film. Perfection comes at a great cost and it requires discipline and practice. Chazelle makes sure we understand that this pursuit of perfection comes at a great cost and he lets the audience decide wether it's worth the price or not. Whiplash is one of those rare films that leaves you with many different things to think about. It raises so many questions: Does the end justify the means? Is the pursuit of perfection possible? Is it really worth all the sacrifice? and the most important question in my opinion; what is our definition of success? The young drummer in this film played brilliantly by Miles Teller (who had a breakout year in 2013) seems to have his mind made up of what success really means, but is he right? The director avoids taking sides and lets the audience come up with their own conclusions. There is a brilliant scene where Teller's character is courting a girl and telling her about his goals in life, and his reaction is brilliant when the girl (played by Melissa Benoist) doesn't really know what she wants to do with her life. He is so determined and focused that he finds it confusing that someone could live without this sort of ambition. These small scenes are what makes this movie so great because it allows us to learn new things about each character through these interactions.  

The core of this film is without a doubt the relationship between this aspiring young drummer and his abusive mentor. It is very different from most other mentor-student relationships explored in movies in the past and it avoids falling into similar formulas and cliches found in other films. This isn't the cool teacher, this is someone whose personal philosophy is about pushing his students to sacrifice everything in their lives to pursue greatness and the only way to do so in his opinion is by pushing and bullying his students to the point of breaking them. It is the opposite of what a mentor like Professor Keating in Dead Poets Society is like towards his students (and most films take a similar approach having an inspirational and caring mentor). But in Whiplash J.K. Simmons' Fletcher is the complete opposite and he psychologically terrorizes his students. You can feel the fear he installs in the students and his presence alone every time he enters a room is felt. Simmons' performance is the best I've seen all year and he delivers in every scene he's in. He is the main reason why the film is as intense as it is because every time Teller's Andrew gets in front of the drums we feel that anxiety and tension. We want him to succeed, but at times the cost seems too high. Simmons' presence is terrifying  and even when he seems to be cooled down we know that he can burst in any moment with a missed note. The way he verbally assaults and demolishes his students is also a troubling part of the film because as an audience we know that it is wrong but we can't help but chuckle at some of the things he's saying. His character is almost cartoonish at times, but it is part of his persona because he thinks it is the only way to push his students to become the best. As good as Simmons is in this film, Miles Teller doesn't allow him to steal the spotlight. Teller is the lead character in this film and even when Simmons isn't on screen we are engaged with the story. The moments he is interacting with Nicole, the girl he is dating, and with his father (played by Paul Reiser) are also incredibly well constructed and they say a lot about who each character is. These relationships give us a glimpse of who Andrew really is and what drives him. Teller's performance is solid and even his drum skills are amazing in this film. The entire cast is fantastic, but of course Simmons receives most of the recognition because his presence on screen is just amazing here. 

Whiplash shows us that fine line between perfection and obsession. Andrew sacrifices so much and is always pushed to the limits by Fletcher and it leaves us wondering if it really is worth it. It's such a powerful film and I'm sure jazz fans will love it even more because the music here is great. The film has a breathtaking ten minute finale as well that will leave your heart pounding. There are so many other aspects of the film that work so well, like the rapid editing that goes along with the jazz beats. The cinematography is also gorgeous. Everything about this film is great and the performances simply elevate it all. The only reason why I'm not calling it a masterpiece is because it does have some issues during the midsection of the film with some rather implausible scenes, but other than that this is a perfect film. I may be demanding too much out of this film like Fletcher is with his students, so it barely misses the perfect note but it is one of the best films of the year. The more you think about it the more you take out of it. I even found an interesting metaphor out of this pursuit for greatness comparing it to with how the American military works trying to build the perfect army because in a way Fletcher's techniques are similar to those that generals use (therefor the comparisons of Simmons performance to that of Lee Ermey in Full Metal Jacket).

When he wasn't able to come up with the funding for this film he decided to make a 20 minute short which debuted at Sundance in 2013 and after garnering attention from critics he was able to finance this film. Perfection comes at a great cost and it requires discipline and practice. Chazelle makes sure we understand that this pursuit of perfection comes at a great cost and he lets the audience decide wether it's worth the price or not. Whiplash is one of those rare films that leaves you with many different things to think about. It raises so many questions: Does the end justify the means? Is the pursuit of perfection possible? Is it really worth all the sacrifice? and the most important question in my opinion; what is our definition of success? The young drummer in this film played brilliantly by Miles Teller (who had a breakout year in 2013) seems to have his mind made up of what success really means, but is he right? The director avoids taking sides and lets the audience come up with their own conclusions. There is a brilliant scene where Teller's character is courting a girl and telling her about his goals in life, and his reaction is brilliant when the girl (played by Melissa Benoist) doesn't really know what she wants to do with her life. He is so determined and focused that he finds it confusing that someone could live without this sort of ambition. These small scenes are what makes this movie so great because it allows us to learn new things about each character through these interactions.  

The core of this film is without a doubt the relationship between this aspiring young drummer and his abusive mentor. It is very different from most other mentor-student relationships explored in movies in the past and it avoids falling into similar formulas and cliches found in other films. This isn't the cool teacher, this is someone whose personal philosophy is about pushing his students to sacrifice everything in their lives to pursue greatness and the only way to do so in his opinion is by pushing and bullying his students to the point of breaking them. It is the opposite of what a mentor like Professor Keating in Dead Poets Society is like towards his students (and most films take a similar approach having an inspirational and caring mentor). But in Whiplash J.K. Simmons' Fletcher is the complete opposite and he psychologically terrorizes his students. You can feel the fear he installs in the students and his presence alone every time he enters a room is felt. Simmons' performance is the best I've seen all year and he delivers in every scene he's in. He is the main reason why the film is as intense as it is because every time Teller's Andrew gets in front of the drums we feel that anxiety and tension. We want him to succeed, but at times the cost seems too high. Simmons' presence is terrifying  and even when he seems to be cooled down we know that he can burst in any moment with a missed note. The way he verbally assaults and demolishes his students is also a troubling part of the film because as an audience we know that it is wrong but we can't help but chuckle at some of the things he's saying. His character is almost cartoonish at times, but it is part of his persona because he thinks it is the only way to push his students to become the best. As good as Simmons is in this film, Miles Teller doesn't allow him to steal the spotlight. Teller is the lead character in this film and even when Simmons isn't on screen we are engaged with the story. The moments he is interacting with Nicole, the girl he is dating, and with his father (played by Paul Reiser) are also incredibly well constructed and they say a lot about who each character is. These relationships give us a glimpse of who Andrew really is and what drives him. Teller's performance is solid and even his drum skills are amazing in this film. The entire cast is fantastic, but of course Simmons receives most of the recognition because his presence on screen is just amazing here. 

Whiplash shows us that fine line between perfection and obsession. Andrew sacrifices so much and is always pushed to the limits by Fletcher and it leaves us wondering if it really is worth it. It's such a powerful film and I'm sure jazz fans will love it even more because the music here is great. The film has a breathtaking ten minute finale as well that will leave your heart pounding. There are so many other aspects of the film that work so well, like the rapid editing that goes along with the jazz beats. The cinematography is also gorgeous. Everything about this film is great and the performances simply elevate it all. The only reason why I'm not calling it a masterpiece is because it does have some issues during the midsection of the film with some rather implausible scenes, but other than that this is a perfect film. I may be demanding too much out of this film like Fletcher is with his students, so it barely misses the perfect note but it is one of the best films of the year. The more you think about it the more you take out of it. I even found an interesting metaphor out of this pursuit for greatness comparing it to with how the American military works trying to build the perfect army because in a way Fletcher's techniques are similar to those that generals use (therefor the comparisons of Simmons performance to that of Lee Ermey in Full Metal Jacket).
-this is the best movie about music ever made . I will not say anything more. this has you on the edge of your seat the whole time. go back watch this one at home. this shows how you can be the best!

Pupil and teacher relationship it's always been covered in films as a very romantic, inspirational and emotional way of seen education.

From "Dead Poets Society", "Dangerous Minds", "Mr. Holland's Opus", "Monsieur Lazhar", "The School of Rock""Half Nelson", "A Single Man" these films presents the classroom as great space for different experiences. Students are encouraged to learn more and achieve greater things, so teachers to will give the most inspiring speeches and take relationships to the next level.

This is not the case in the film Whiplash. David Chazelle directs the story of Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) a 19 year old jazz drummer who is starting as a student in Shaffer Conservatory. This on of the best music school in the USA. He have a great and inspiring life, from love a relationship with Nicole (Melissa Benoist) a college student who works at a movie theater to the support of his dad Mr Neiman (Paul Reiser)

But for Andrew the most important things is becoming the next Buddy Rich considered the world best drummer. The big challenge in Shaffer school is win Terence Fletcher which is the most infamous conductor in school. Andrew put all his efforts to become the best and be for Fletcher his key drummer. 

Andrew will encounter a hard road to reach a higher level, the destructive relationship with Fletcher will turn him into an obsessed person who painfully fight and fight to reach the best place. Fletcher demeanor attitude will focus of destroy Andrew moral, all this with a powerful jazz soundtrack 

Miles Teller is great on the movie, but the show stealer is J.K. Simmons, he deserves an Oscar hands down. 

Whiplash explore human tolerance, human will, the value of artistic careers versus other professional careers but mostly perseverance over an abuser. This film can be also a great piece of study for student been bully by their teachers.

Films about music are usually the last on the list of films I ever feel like watching (Don't hate me for that), but something about the film's trailer caught my eye! I know nothing about drums or musical instruments as such, but always had just sincere admiration for people who dedicate their time to learn & play with such passion. Same goes for the type of music, for example in this movie, where Jazz is the theme, a very under rated & dying form of music. I have been following Milles Teller for quite some time now. Frankly I have become a fan of his peculiar comic timing in silly rom coms like An Awkward moment, Two Night Stand etc & in Divergent, we got see a new dark side to him. But here in this film, Holly!! The story follows Andrew Neyman, a 19-year-old aspiring student jazz drummer at a music conservatory in Manhattan who's pushed and inspired by the abuse and aspirations of his school band leader Terrence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) with a ruthlessly brutal teaching style. After picking Andrew to play in the school band, he pushes Andrew to his limits in order to realize his full potential, at the risk of his humanity. Terence has a reputation for being the best, but mentoring under him comes at a price.  He is ruthless with his verbal abuse & taunts that attempts to push his students towards the greatness he believes they can achieve. Newcomer Andrew is no spared his ire as evidenced in this heated reaction when Andrew can't find Terence's tempo, , "Were you rushing or were you dragging? If you deliberately sabotage my band, I will gut you like a pig. Oh my dear God - are you one of those single tear people? You are a worthless pancy-ass who is now weeping and slobbering all over my drumset like a nine year old girl!" There is no "Wash-on, Wash-off" PG-ness here. Writer/Director Damien Chazelle has turned his Sundance award-winning short film into a fascinatingly brutal message movie that begs for discussion and debate. This film is a journey in the search of your inner spirit, inner creativity, not only will it make it clear that you cannot succeed without effort and hard work, it will also make you realize there are two different kinds of artists - those who make art and those who creat them. Being mean is in Terence's nature. And his assault on his young protégés is sometimes hard to watch. The best part of the film its keeps you so engrossed, you will always be unsure of where it is headed. The technical aspects of the film help it become so stimulating with dizzying closeups tightly edited together and its the stark orange tinted cinematography. It's thoroughly impressive that the Miles Teller knew nothing about drumming before this film & the film was shot in only 19 days & for them to get shots so immaculately timed and performed with all those complicated movements. The concluding act only further exemplifies the events and personalities that took us to the stage and the audience cheered in Andrew's defiance while gasping at his situation. Writer-director Damien Chazelle does a stunning job of keeping us on the edge of our seats wondering when or if a climatic breakdown will occur. We watch in awe as Andrew gets pushed and pushes himself until his hands bleed after hours of relentless play. We feel as uncomfortable for his situation as we feel trapped in finding a solution to Andrew's goal. Miles Teller is on a crazy streak; doing some decent movies and putting in even better performances, but Whiplash definitely taps his greatest effort thus far in his incredibly young career. JK Simmons is as good as they say he is. He's a force of nature, with a terrifying presence. But it's not a one-note performance. Simmons is still subversive with moments of weakness, insecurity, approachability. Even though he's an unlikeable character with nothing nice to say, he's still somewhat endearing and enigmatic! Director Damien Chazelle has given us a cinematic gem! He seems like a filmmaker that knows exactly what type of films he wants to make. He takes inspiration from his own life, his love of film and music, and other places I'm sure we don't know about, and molds them into a gritty, layered experience, conditioned with rich characters, all realized through the writer's story. He has given us one of the best scripts of 2014 & without doubt the BEST climax I have seen in a long while. An ending that will bring tears to your eyes, dual performances that will have you applaud, and an experience that you surely will not forget. Drumming has never felt like such a personality. It acts as a visible tool for the viewer to understand and try. Expect some awards going in the way of "Whiplash" and look out for Simmons in the Oscars shortlist, that's how good he is in it. On the whole Whiplash is not just film or a character study of two people, but an art & an education in itself. Holy Must watch!!

This is the third time this year I have watched such classic character study, first "Locke", next "Nightcrawler", and now "Whiplash". True to their single-word title, these films focuse on developing an in-depth, and intense, look at their protagonists on a framework of simple plot structure (mostly linear, straightforward, almost no twist-and-turn, and short running time - no film among these three is longer than 2 hours, "Nightcrawler" being the longest - 116 min.), minimized and urban setting ("Locke" and "Whiplash" are for the most parts enclosed in the claustrophopic setting of a car/recording studio, while "Nightcrawler" is fixated in LA's urban area), and a small supporting cast of character actors. With such choice, those films, although perfectly executed and often interesting (and entertaining) to watch, have an inherent weakness, which is the unavoidable feeling of artificiality due to the unnaturally squeezed plot and character treatment, which lead to either a sense of over-dramatization (in "Locke"), frustration (in "Nightcrawler"), and unevenness (in "Whiplash"). "Whiplash" has an excellent premise of "how people would react in difficulties to achieve greatness?", which was carried out smoothly through the depiction of the "face-off" between the novice yet passionate Neyman (Miles Teller of "Spectacular Now") against the experienced, brutal and (seemingly) equally passionate Mr. Fletcher (J.K Simmons, who looks exactly like Alan Arkin of "Little Miss Sunshine", and also has a great chance to win an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor with this excellent role). The thing that I love most about this film is the ambiguity of several sequences, which leaves the audience with plenty of space to think, and speculate about what really happened in those sequences, and who the characters really are until the very end, such freedom can hardly happen in big budget Hollywood films, when the producers and directors often presume that the audience is stupid and they need to be stuffed with every details of the story and character. On the other hand, the thing that I was disappointed most about this film is the last part (except for the "final performance", which is astounding by any measure), when it seemed that the director tried (too hard) to "conclude" his story in a satisfactory way, which, in my opinion, actually damages the marvellous inconclusiveness and ambiguity of the fate of the characters, which were already pushed to the climax by the end of the electrifying "second act" (the "car accident" sequence is one of the best shots I have watched this year). Next time, maybe a longer running time or a less ambitious and more focus storyline will help the director to achieve a great film, because this film is already a treat to the audience, especially with the wonderful soundtrack.

Love the performances of J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller. Movie is very dark and intense but realistic in the same time. People who are chasing a career can identify with main protagonist and take notes how to fight with an obstacles in the path for glory.

Between the intensity and the uncertain guilt you feel after laughing at the insults J. K Simmons beautifully hashes out at his mentally torn students, you'll find a movie that not only provides the audience with emotions only a great film can grant us, but a sense that we are there. We're the ones who are being caught for every mistake, we're the accused and only a special film, is able to do that.
   We follow the life of Andrew (Miles Teller), a budding jazz drummer who wants nothing more than to be the best there is and to accomplish such a feet, he has to impress the best there is... Mr. Fletcher (J. K Simmons). Fletcher is the best music teacher around and through perfectionism and guidance he wants, ultimately, to find the perfect student... but not everything is as easy as that. He pushes students to the edge of their mental and physical strength with his calamitous tactics of verbal and physical abuse driven by passion. Simmons' delivery of every insulting line is that of elegance, you don't know whether to laugh or pity.
   There are a couple of moments in the movie where a student has made a mistake. We, the audience, know before Fletcher does and when he finds out, it almost feels like we're in trouble because Simmons' portrayal of a horribly passionate teacher is so incredibly realistic. 
   Miles Teller plays his part perfectly. His journey of finding the path to greatness is something we can all relate to. We've all been beaten down and leant how to pick ourselves back up again. Teller and Simmons bounce off of each other beautifully and the journey has Tellers character grow into a strong young man who can, by the last sequence, hold his own against Simmons which makes for an exceptional final 15 minutes. 
   With amazing aggressive chemistry from Simmons and Teller, a story we can all identify with and great music whether you're a jazz fan or not. This phenomenal piece of cinema will leave you with goose bumps all over, completely blown away and without a doubt wanting so much more.

"There are no two words in the English language more harmful than 'good job'
A brilliant piece of cinematographic art, Whiplash is an intense, gripping and unforgettable drama. A movie in which the strive for perfection is brought to the audience in a hand-to-the-throat storytelling this delivery is a combination of dazzling music score, outstanding performances and flawless directing efforts. 

Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller) is a talented and very ambitious jazz drummer who is in his first year in an elite east coast music conservatory. One day his talent got spotted by the legend of jazz teaching Terrence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) and he gets invited to join as a second drummer the elite jazz band of Fletcher. Driven by his ambition, Andrew is ready to give his best in order to succeed within Mr. Fletcher's band. Unfortunately (for Andrew and many others), Fletcher is not only a multiple-awards winning teacher, but also a terribly ruthless band leader whose methods to reach perfection are highly controversial. Quickly Whiplash becomes a movie in which the characters are pushed way beyond their psychological and physical limits with no hope of reaching Fletcher's desired perfection. 

An intense story, a mind-blowing sound editing and mixing, Whiplash is detailed to the smallest perfection. Listening to the same music segment, over and over and over and over again simply because it is as Fletcher says: "not quite my tempo" will provoke you to a nail-biting level of tension. The ambitiously nerdy Andrew and the restless perfectionist Fletcher are heading for a music and personal clash that is going to blow your mind up. Speaking of Fletcher and J.K.Simmons, could only say that in very rare cases a supporting actor has been such a driving force of a movie. Mesmerizing, scandalizing and ruthlessly sharp, J.K.Simmons delivers the performance that defines his whole acting career. The Oscar that he received for Best Supporting Actor was totally deserved and his performance will long scary you in your music dreams
.
It is hard to mention all the wonderful ingredients that make Whiplash one of the most gripping dramas of recent years. Extremely competitive, dark and at some points furious, Whiplash is not only a cinematographic, but also a music experience that must be seen! Absolutely a must see !

Terence Fletcher: "There are no two words in the English language more harmful than good job".

Whiplash follows are main character Andrew Neyman who is a young jazz drummer, single-minded in his pursuit to rise to the top of his elite east coast music conservatory. Plagued by the failed writing career of his father, Andrew hungers day and night to become one of the greats. Terence Fletcher, an instructor equally known for his teaching talents as for his terrifying methods, leads the top jazz ensemble in the school. Fletcher discovers Andrew and transfers the aspiring drummer into his band, forever changing the young man's life.

Okay let me just start off with this. You had no idea how much I was really looking forward to Whiplash. This was on my movies to check out list, because I heard nothing but positive things from this movie and I heard a lot of people described this film has the Full Metal Jacket but with no war or guns, but with music and well... drums. I think Whiplash and Birdman was the two movies I wanted to see before making my best movies of the year list, because who knows they might make the list. I haven't seen Birdman yet but will do soon, but I finally had the chance to see Whiplash and my god this movie was just so spectacularly flawless in many ways. Whiplash is the best move of 2014.

J.K. Simmons in this movie probably pulls of the best performance in he's career. Every word that came out of his mouth didn't feel like he was reading from the script then act it out, no, I felt every angry punch of words that came out of him, because it was real and not fake. I didn't see J.K. Simmons just playing a movie character in this movie, no he was the freaking Fletcher. 

Now let's talk about Terence Fletcher: The best way to describe Fletcher to those who haven't seen the film yet, well his like Gny. Sgt. Hartman from Full Metal Jacket. He has the best lines, when his on screen your locked on and his also like the kind of person that would be somebody's worse nightmare to have for a boss. This guy doesn't just like music, he breaths music and he wants his band to do perfect. His opinion and his look on music is another thing why I didn't flat out just hated him, I actually understood him. He made a very good point about how people will comment on you act and say "You did a good job", and yes I did use the words "you did a great job", n my past reviews but now I'm never going to use it ever again after this movie.

Miles Teller was another stand out performances in this movie, and just like Foxcatacher where Channing Tatum was so over looked by his performance, Miles Teller has proved himself to be more then a teen in a movie that will be forgotten and so would he, but no Miles Teller played this character so brilliantly he could become the next big thing. Now his character in this movie has the love of the true art of music and you can see that he will wants to tell people his love for music, but when the harsh life of reality comes crashing into him it's truly heartbreaking to see his struggle and effort just not being good enough, and Teller played this character so realistic and so brilliantly flawless.

The directing and the writing in this was just....perfect. Damien Chazelle directed this movie and written it and man did he do it with style and passion to tell a story about two strong music buffs battling out and he freaking nailed it. 

This movie also had probably the best finale that I've seen in years. My nails were digging into the seat. I didn't dare to look away not for one moment, not for one second. I was simply locked on and when it was over... I'm kidding you I actually clapped towards the end of this movie. Now the biggest cliche that I always hear from critics when their talk about a different movies and their use words like "You will clap at the end", but you don't, or "You will feel inspired after the film", and I you don't. But Whiplash actually did make me feel inspirited towards the end and made me clap. It's message of not giving up and the dream that you been chancing for isn't just going to come to you. Movies like Pride, freedom Writers and all that such never ever give me that inspiring feeling inside of me, until I watched this movie.     

For problems: The movie had it slow parts and that's it really.

Whiplash is a movie that everybody should see. This isn't just a popcorn movie where you come and put you legs up and laugh a couple of times, no this movie reaches out to people out there that have the same problems that these character's have, with their passion of what their what to do in life get's over shadowed by something you don't want to do and this movie get's it right. So go and see if you have the chance.

Whiplash was the most intense and exhilarating movie experience that i had throughout all of 2014. This movie did not slow down a single bit as it told the gripping and mesmerising story of a boy striving to be the best jazz drummer in the world with the assistance of one of the most hilarious and memorable characters of the year. J. K. Simmons put in the best performance of his career and the most exciting and exhilarating performance of the year as this very talented and at time frightening jazz instructor. As a supporting actor whenever he was on screen i was in awe at just how compelling his character was, sometimes you are afraid of him and other times you can't take your eyes off how spectacular he is at what he does. Miles Teller also killed it in his performance as the boy who had a single goal in life and blew me away with the level of his talent. The back and forth chemistry between these two fantastic actors made for the best highlights of the movie. There were hilarious moments, scary moments and even emotional moments as the movie explores how their relationship evolves over time in ways that you would not have initially expected. This film does a lot to surprise you and gave some of the most memorable moments of the year. And just as it starts off strong it finishes even stronger with one of the most intense and inspiring finales in recent years. This movie was such a great experience that it is one of the best films of the year, with some of the best performances seen in 2014. - 9.7

Whiplash is a work of technical mastery, in a film about technical mastery.  The editing, music and direction are immaculately done and expertly convey the films themes, often better than the actual dialogue and characters.  Even the acting feels like a masterwork in execution, though neither role demands a ton of range.  It is bleak and unwavering in it's relentless pursuit of excellence, or at least the extremely rigid view of excellence that the film presents.  The film presents the nearly fascist views of perfection and sacrifice that the subject raises in an unglorified, ugly manner; seemingly inviting critique throughout it's running time.  The ending manages to subvert the Black Swan esque character arc, with an "uplifting" finale that reminded me of Zero Dark Thirty in it's "sometimes fascism is necessary" statement.  Ultimately, despite being somewhat shallow, it's hard not to enjoy Whiplash's intensity, incredible editing and music.

Wow! Mesmerizing performances by both Miles Teller and J.K Simmons makes Whiplash the intense spectacle it is.
Brilliant direction and lightning editing only enhance the pace and exuberance.
I particularly loved Simmons portrayal of brutally pedantic music conductor Terence Fletcher and will be surprised if he doesn't finally get the Oscar he has worked hard for for a long career in the shadows as a second fiddle.
There is a line toward the end which resonates with me as a coach and mentor to young men who want to be the best. "The two words that do the most damage these days are GOOD JOB".
Outstanding on every level.
Right up there with Night crawler as the years best film.
Encouraging, emotionally-moving, nail-biting, and musically superb. 'Whiplash' might seem to be a conventional talent-development film but actually creates a one-of-a-kind musical drama.

Amazing, Astounding, Incredible, Wonderful, Masterpiece are some of the words tossed around after viewing this sure fire Oscar nominee. It was bound to happen and it surely did, I saw the best movie of 2014 and it wasn't Birdman. The film Whiplash (2014 film) rocked my world. I saw masterful performances and have now became an instant fan of Miles Teller. He was nothing short of phenomenal! This movie brings an intensity I have rarely if ever felt in a film. All leading up to a crescendo of an ending so intense and so powerful that I felt like I needed a cigarette and I have not smoked for 10 years. Not only do I find this movie the best movie of 2014 this movie earned a spot in my overall top best made and most favorite movies have ever seen. Music has always had the power to move me and when I see real legit, incredible musical talent performing right in front of me and that is not even counting the acting of a character whilst playing said instrument it is an incredible and overwhelming feeling. This movie is truly astounding. When you watch this movie you are literally witnessing greatness, and I haven't even got to J.K. Simmons yet who turns in one of the most intense and memorable onscreen performances I have seen in years. 

I am still a champion for Michael Keaton for his work in Birdman but these performances were right up there. This movie felt real to me, my emotions were raised and connected with the main character more so than any movie I have seen in a long, long time. Perhaps it's because I played the drums for so long that it connected with me like it did, and if you're a drummer this movie is an absolute must watch, but for lots of reasons this movie just hit with me, hard. IT blew me away and left me with my jaw on the floor and it took me a couple minutes to collect myself at its end. It is seriously one of the most exhilarating movie endings I have ever experienced and it hammers home the point of the film itself like few I have ever seen in my entire lengthy history of watching movies. This is a movie that is not a blockbuster, it's not meant to break monetary and attendance records, it is just a film allowed to portray its art and its love for Jazz music and the intensity of trying to make it perfect or to become one of the all-time greats at what we do. It takes intensity and ratchets it up to 11. I was hooked within 35 seconds and watched with bated breath the entire last act of the film. 
 There is a reason that this one is certified fresh at 95% with a 96% audience approval rate. Expect to see many award nominations handed out for this film and for the first time in years it's going to be a really hard thing to figure out which is really worthy of holding best picture, I can make a case for Birdman and I have, I can make a case for Boyhood in which the most recent podcast episode has, but for me and my money I can make a case for this being not only my favorite movie I saw in 2014, replacing the longstanding Guardians of the Galaxy, but it also replaces Birdman for what I believe to be the best made picture of the year. I cannot say if you will feel the same way about being better than your choice for best picture of the year but what I can guarantee is that you will certainly have to think about this in the same way once you see it. You cannot watch this movie and not feel something, it is impossible. What you feel is powerful too. I could gush for days on this so I am just going to rate it, champion it as my pick for the best picture of 2014 and I am going to recommend the shit out of this to anyone and everyone because it is a movie that serves to have everyone's attention. Teller's and Simmons performances deserve to be talked about and this movie deserves to be seen by everyone who likes movies to turn things up a bit. Especially if you are a musician or if you love Jazz music or if you are a performer in any way but its not just limited to that, this is a film all can love. This movie, hot damn, I rate it an unrealistic 6 out of 5 stars, and I give it 110 percent and give it just about the highest recommendation I can possibly give as this is one of the best movies of the past decade and a new entry in an damn near impenetrable wall of my top 10 favorite films I have ever seen and also the most impactful due to my emotional investment to the characters. Wow just wow.......Bravo to all involved, Bravo.

One of 2014's most passionate and vibrant films, WHIPLASH is an extraordinary portrait of a fascinating relationship.  The movie works beautifully on multiple levels: on one, it's a spiritual heir to the PAPER CHASE throne, a story about young people working very hard under the guidance (and/or abuse) of a mentor figure; on another level, it's a love letter to jazz music itself (which I maintain is an under-represented art form in cinema); and on yet another level, it's an examination of the dedication required when chasing excellence, feeding on universal feelings (the desire to be great, the fear of humiliation, the fear of not being good enough, etc.) to create a compelling, captivating ride.  Writer/director Damien Chazelle displays an incredibly strong vision, with dynamic camerawork and whip-fast editing, both of which highlight the intense dramatic moments and musical performances (though those tend to be one-and-the-same in this movie); indeed, the film is - at times - as tense as any of 2014's best proper thrillers (including one, GRAND PIANO, which was written by none other than Chazelle himself!).  While Miles Teller is great in the movie (he nails the very difficult physical requirements necessary to convince the audience he's a talented drummer, and he also captures a kind of introverted vulnerability which gradually changes over the course of the story), it really is J.K. Simmons' performance that people will leave the film thinking about; "career best" is a phrase that doesn't really capture the kind of work Simmons pulls off here.  He's enormously imposing, towering, terrifying, and many more "ing"s, but he's never one-dimensional, which is a huge feat when playing what could have so easily been an ultra-arch taskmaster.  The entire movie is terrific, but it's the final 20 minutes - which I dare not even hint at - that truly push the film up to another level.  I feel like I've somehow undersold how good a film this really is; it satisfies on so many levels (narratively, emotionally, and even thematically) that it's hard to do full justice to it.  But let it be known that WHIPLASH is thrilling, energetic, exhilarating cinema, pure and simple, and it is among the very best films of 2014.

The Interview
The Innocent Interview: A Film That Cause An Overly-exaggerated Reaction 
Young Critic
12/30/2014
Who didn't want to watch this movie after the whole chaotic scandal ensued with North Korea and the United States almost commencing a cyber war? I have to say that the excitement made my expectations elevate, which wasn't necessarily a good thing.
 
If you don't know the plot of The Interview you should be ashamed for your lack of keeping up with current events. Just to refresh your minds, The Interview tells the story of a talk show host Dave Skylark (James Franco) who along with his producer Aaron Rapaport (Seth Rogen) are able to get an interview with North Korea's supreme leader Kim Jung-un (Randall Park). The CIA however tasks Dave and Aaron with the mission to kill Kim Jung-un. As you can expect, not everything goes according to plan.
 
The film actually was surprisingly light for my expectations. I found that they portrayed Kim Jung-un in a surprisingly humane way. I came off it actually feeling bad for the guy. The actions taken by North Korea against this film were extremely exaggerated, I can predict most of you will come off watching the movie saying: "That's it?" The fact that it's also a Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg directed comedy is another reason to think that North Korea's actions were ridiculous. Rogen and Goldberg were the people that "killed off" Rihanna, Kevin Hart, Emma Watson, and thousands of other celebrities in This Is The End. Hell, even in the Spanish comedy Torrente 3, they 'accidently' kill President George W. Bush when he was in office. With North Korea's actions we can learn the difference between an educated country and an enslaved country. I think that the real Kim Jung-un has been flattering so much that when a slight pebble is pegged at him he declares war.  
 
As for the film, it was alright; it was the typical Rogen-Franco film. The jokes are mostly about sex and drugs, and the humor is extremely repetitive. I was expecting to laugh out loud in a couple of moments, but the actual trailer for the film showed every joke that the film had. I'm serious, there wasn't a single other type of joke. I was disappointed. On the other hand, James Franco surprised me again with his passionate acting. He deals with the subject in the properly exaggerated way so that we all know he's joking; something that North Korea clearly didn't see.
 
In the end we are left wanting a little more. The lack of a diversity of jokes and the cyber explosion that the film caused has led for the whole world to expect more from the film, but sadly it didn't deliver. 
C
Whiplash
Whipped Up Genius: An Incredible Film that Looks into the Tough World of an Artist
Young Critic
12/30/2014
It's hard to make a movie about art. It's even harder to make a movie about an artist's struggle. However, Whiplash goes to face the ultimate challenge of showing the formation of an artist. It would have been easy to make a biopic of a famous musician or painter, but director Damien Chazelle chooses to form his own fictional character in a fictional school. The artistry in the movie is in how immersed and knowledgeable one is of the music world when watching it, and of course the much praised J.K. Simmons is even better than expected in his abusive teacher role.
 
Whiplash is the story of a young drummer, Andrew (Miles Teller) who attends the most elite school of music of New York and of the world. Andrew struggles at an amateur music class as the second drummer. However, during one practice session the conductor of the rigorous and elite music class, Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) walks into Andrew's rehearsal. Fletcher only sees Andrew play for mere seconds before he picks him up to be his second drummer. During his first rehearsal Andrew learns that Fletcher abuses his students until they play with hair-thin precision, either that or they are kicked out. Andrew, nervous and young, suffers from Fletcher's abuse to the point that Fletcher throws a chair at Andrew. However, the abuse is much more psychological and scarring than physical, and therein lies the genius of the movie.
 
Just like Begin Again earlier this year, Whiplash looks at the music world with realistic and raw eyes. However, unlike Begin Again, Whiplash doesn't filter the cruelty of an artist's world to its audience, it throws at you with shocking and appalling honesty. The film isn't sweetened in any way, Andrew's love interest is handled in a realistic way, the outcome of decisive scenes is believable, and best of all, the final scene is intense and explosive.
 
Whiplash's intensity builds up from the moment one sits down. This tesnion is built into staggering heights so that when Chazelle wants to wrap it up one fears that all his hard work could come tumbling down. In fact Whiplash's last quarter seems to be completely lost, one begins to shiver a cheesy ending is set up, where all loose ends are tied. But thankfully an incredible last scene is able to it wrap up expertly. It was the cherry on top that this film's beginning sequence deserved.
 
The acting is very demanding. Miles Teller is pushed to the limits of his acting capabilities. We had seen him bursting from the screen in The Spectacular Now and now he has been given a role that challenges him a lot more. Mr. Simmons, on the other hand, is indomitable. He plays his character with such an angry passion that you barely breathe in fear that he'll snap at you from the screen.
 
An incredibly powerful film, whose mounting tension is perfectly concluded with its final scene. J.K. Simmons' charisma is worth every penny.. 
A
The most interesting aspect of this film is how you can be at the top of your field, yet the people outside of it could not give a damn. So well done.

An intense look at jazz ensembles with electrifying performances from Miles Teller and J.K Simmons.  Walking out of the cinema made me want to run a marathon I was so shaken up and adrenalised.

Some of the best editing you'll ever see at the movies, and some of the best performances too. Captures the spirit of jazz and makes you think about teaching methods and how "greats" are made. Whether or not you agree with Simmons' character is against the point; this is a movie about taking one ideology as far as humanly imaginable and sticking with it until it explodes. Constantly surprising and the music will have you tapping your feet throughout, and wanting to go and play an instrument right away after it's done.

An absolute masterpiece. Teller is fantastic, and Simmons is phenomenal. Every second of this movie is masterful and intense. The editing, the music, the cinematography. It's all flawless. A very original film with great characters and a great acting. Both the protagonist and the teacher are slightly insane. The protagonist wants to be famous so badly he will do almost anything and the teacher thinks that being a massive Dick to everyone is a good thing even if it does improve the musicians skills. That is what makes the movie so entertaining and intense. The ending is quiet different to the rest of the movie but it is a pleasing conclusion.

At this point we all know good art takes sweat, but in WHIPLASH we learn it may take blood as well. A lot of blood, and even some tears before your soul is revealed. This movie showcases a compelling dynamic between two mesmerizing characters. The lively music goes from gut wrenching to heart soaring in a few bars as the film asks, how far it is too far to push someone when creating the next artistic genius? 

Far beyond what most are willing to do, according to band instructor Fletcher, who yells screams and throws things, sending his students into depressions laced with anxiety to draw out the inner brilliance he believes is there. Positive reinforcement to him is the anathema to effective teaching, and In order to get at the genius he knows his students are selfishly harboring, he will sacrifice much. Not only the mental stability of his students, but his entire career to be able to take credit for creating the next great jazz musician. 

See this movie for the music, or see it if you're an artist who's ever wanted to give up, or see it because you had a teacher you didn't understand, or because you're a teacher filled with frustration, or see it because you're a parent who's afraid their child will become lost in a force you can barely understand, or see it because at one point you've lost your way and are too prideful to look at a map - but do see this film. 

97% wakefulness - Yeah, I have no idea why you'd close your eyes during this one either (Maybe it was those three slices of pizza he'd had for lunch?). Just remember, movies are expensive, take a nap before it starts.
An instant classic. An exhilarating fictional look into a genre of music known for usually relaxing people. This is as close to perfect as a film can get. Run, don't walk to see this.

Whiplash is mesmerizing in its intensity. It's all about the characters, and the acting is tremendous. J. K. Simmons' Oscar is well deserved, and this is a disturbing character study that leaves you breathless.

Completely lives up to the hype.  Simmons and Teller are mesmerizing in their performances. For a plain fiction drama from an independent filmmaker, "Whiplash" has one of the most tension-inducing antagonists I've ever seen. Terence Fletcher is abhorrently vicious and vile to his students, spouting hateful verbal abuses with every breath he can muster -- not to mention lying to his pupils, yelling at them, and even physically abusing them in order to get whatever desired reaction he wants. He remains an enigma throughout the film and even til it's end, but despite this, he's not at all an underdeveloped character. His raging verbal taunts directed towards the the lead immediately remind one of Gunnery Sergeant Hartman -- the character from "Full Metal Jacket".

Simmons can act but he had me believing so much in his character that I was stunned to see his character "Terrance Flethcher" had a soft side. Miles Teller did an outstanding job and I found out after seeing the film that he was the one who actually played the drums in the movie. He really nailed the character. He showed that his character had passion, desire and talent. There were times in the theater where I wanted to say "Come on man, you can do it". Most films can not get me to move my mouth to form those words inside the theater. The highly intense jazz music that makes up the soundtrack drove this movie home. It is about time I finally got a chance to watch this film and the hype behind it made me want to see the movie so bad. This really is one of those times where the hype really pays off and where a film impresses the hell out of me and meets and transcends all of my expectations. Every quote that you see on the main poster for this film all perfectly describe the movie in every way. The acting, directing, and editing are all masterful in this film and this one of the most intense movies I have seen in recent memory. Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons both give the best performances of their careers and they did flawless jobs playing their characters. J.K. Simmons is an absolute revelation in this film. He has played one of the best antagonists I have ever seen in this century. He plays a music teacher who strives to get the very best out of his students and to do that he will use lots of verbal abuse. J.K. Simmons manages to be scary, charismatic, and funny all at the same time when playing Terence Fletcher. Some of the things that he said had me laughing out loud and feeling frightened by him and he also presented a soft side of him which I didn't see coming and it only made the film even better. There is nothing else I can say about his performance other than that it was brilliant and J.K. Simmons is a lock to win Best Supporting Actor at the Academy Awards this year. Another fantastic performance in this movie comes from Miles Teller. He truly impresses here and this is a big step forward from every other character he has ever played. With this and The Spectacular Now, he shows he can actually act and not just play disposable characters like he did before starring in The Spectacular Now. His character's obsession to be the best at jazz drumming drives the motion picture and shows the road to succeed can be a really hard one. The editing in certain scenes really impressed me and the camera movements and quick cuts were used really well. The soundtrack in the movie is full of great jazz music and it also felt like a character on its own. The ending of this film had me gripping my hands and had me on the edge of my seat and it was one of the most tension-filled endings I have seen in a long time. Damien Chazelle who wrote and directed this film did a masterful job in both fields and he has a bright future ahead of him in Hollywood. The dialogue he wrote was fantastic and it is one of the best scripts of 2014 in my opinion. Overall, this is one hell of a must see for anybody who works hard in their field of work, who loves great acting, and who loves movies in general. Whiplash and Birdman make my top favorite films of 2014.
