Whiplash is easliy the best movie of 2014. A statement that I don't think would change if the date were January 2015, rather than December 2014. This movie is phenomenal. The cinematography, the performances, the story telling, the soundtrack, are all done perfectly. Everything is in synch here, running like a well oiled machine.

For those of you unfamiliar with the Premise, Whiplash is the story of a young man, played by Miles Teller, who is enrolled in school at Shaffer Conservatory, the best music performing college in the United States. He quickly finds himself being the alternative drummer for the Shaffer jazz band, where the director, played by J.K Simmons, is the mentor from hell. His insults and degradation are in a league few antagonists have ever achieved on screen. This is Simmons best performance, and I would be shocked if he were not nominated for an Oscar.

The performances are not the only thing in this film worth drooling over. Director Damien Chazelle is also fantastic, and he knows how to make a small idea feel big. Some of the most exciting shots are of the band members setting up their equipment or emptying their spit catchers. That's not because the other scenes are boring-there aren't any boring scenes in this movie-it's because Chazelle knows how to capture interest with quick cuts, and he knows when to hold a shot and when to do a slow pan.

If you have a theater in your town that's playing Whiplash, you are doing yourself a diservice if you're not seeing it. The movie is funny, it's moving, and it's ultimately inspiring. It's the best movie of 2014. Do not miss it.

Fast, dynamic, exciting, brilliant and intense is this well written and intimate depiction into the world of Jazz music. J.K Simmons delivers an absolute knockout performance as the oppressive yet dedicated teacher who we learn to enjoy and resent concurrently. The chemistry between Simmons and lead Miles Teller is authentic and electrifying. While the film focuses on the pursuit of perfection it rightfully translates it pitch perfectly to the audience.

A syncopated rhythm, a fervent tempo; a war of egos and a thirst for greatness. Whiplash - directed by Damien Chazelle - is a film centering on young jazz drummer Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller), as he tries to win over ruthless studio band teacher Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) in the most prestigious music conservatory in the country, Shaffer University.
Fletcher puts his entire jazz ensemble on strings, playing the role of a sadistic puppet master. Fletcher especially abuses Neyman and his two alternate drummers by humiliating, jabbing, dismantling their confidence, giving them mixed messages, and toying with their emotions. In pursuit of crafting the next "Charlie Parker," Fletcher slowly deteriorates Neyman's sanity and replaces it with an unrelenting perfectionism. Fletcher digs and gnaws into his student's mind; Neyman soon becomes solely obsessed with becoming the best drummer ever and neglects his other hobbies, his family, and even his girlfriend. From a brutal yet compelling car crash to the motif of bleeding hands, Whiplash arcs a story of perseverance and obsession laced with aggression, entitlement, and the absolute refusal to be just "good enough."
While the plot, directing, and cinematography are all dynamic, what truly brings this story to life is the remarkable acting of J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller. Simmons grows from a jack-ass, hard-nosed, manipulative character to a more subtle, down-to-earth, but equally manipulative version of himself. Simmons is electrifying in both presence and tone. Meanwhile, Teller convincingly plays a young teen whose passion for Jazz becomes an addiction when Simmons pushes him past the brink of possibility. Having to wrestle with his dad's failed writing career to pressures from his underachieving family to trying to impress his teacher in vain, Miles Teller's inability to cope leads him to breaking down and getting expelled from Shaffer. Teller plays a good-natured kid who becomes increasingly entitled, snarky, and arrogant throughout the film; however, the negative progression of his personality does not overshadow his radical transformation into one of the world's most tenacious musicians.
Whiplash is not without flaws. Fletcher's freedom to physically torture any student at will and use obscene insults without getting fired is definitely hard to believe. The constant blood you would normally associate with an action film is unnaturally used here as a tool to dramatize more than provide a sense of reality. The main - if only - actual issue with the film is the seemingly important but flat characters who only exist to provide perspective into Neyman's life and show the audience everything he had to sacrifice to achieve his dream; for instance, Neyman's girlfriend doesn't possess enough qualities to even be considered a fully functioning character and exists merely to serve a purpose.
One of the main compositions played in the movie, "Whiplash" by Hank Levy, perfectly mirrors the groove of the film and the meaning of the word itself: this funk-infused, driving, big-band song sets the mood while the lashing of a whip exemplifies the pain Fletcher inflicted upon Neyman and the unbelievable circumstances his student had to endure. Whiplash is one of the most riveting movies of recent years and a definite must see - you'll be gripping onto your seat until the very last clang.

These two men are put together on an path due to their ambition and passion for music, and we, the audience, are simply lucky to witness this cinematic musical extravaganza.

I loved this exploration of the struggle and lengths that we must go to to achieve greatness. In fact, it was one of my favorite films this year, but only because I looked at it through a specific lens. If viewed as a literal story, it's a pretty disturbing, abusive relationship that could be seen to glorify negative reinforcement. However, I think this film presents a powerful metaphor for the immense, seemingly insurmountable challenges that stand in the way of realizing full potential and greatness, in music/art or any other endeavor. Instead of viewing the professor as an abhorrent, offensive, unsympathetic jerk, look at him as the devil figure in Crossroads (biopic of Robert Johnson) or as that force inside each of us that tells us we're not good enough. For me, this was a highly successful film, inspiring and motivating me to keep pursuing greatness in my life and career. That wasn't true for everyone in the room, so I'm interested to hear what you think. If nothing else, the jazz is superb.

This film builds tension and suspense better than any thriller in my recent memory.  The complexity of choices made in shooting the performance scenes were astoundingly good and truly set a visual tone that matched the jazz pieces.

At its core, this is a film about the types of choices necessary to take an honest shot at greatness.  It seems that too often in films characters in similar positions make compromises and opt for relationships that are billed as higher values than greatness and mastery.  This protagonist makes no such compromises and the payoff is an argument for being driven by such purpose.  It has been a long time since I have left a movie theater feeling this emotionally rewarded.

As the performances go Miles Teller is solid in the lead, but J.K Simmons is absolutely riveting.

As a side note, I think the film raises some interesting questions for those in the field of performing arts pedagogy.  What is the proper role/purpose/tactic of an advanced arts teacher?

I'm just going to start out the review with that statement. Though the movie was universally praised, and managed to get a nomination for JK Simmons for Best Supporting Actor, this movie deserves so much more. It has Oscar Material written all over it.

It tells the story of a young jazz student (Miles Teller), with dreams of becoming the next great drummer. He gets into the best music school in the country, but finds out that his instructor (Simmons) is incredibly strict (read:the biggest d**k in the world.) He's a perfectionist, verbally abusive, and yells often. So the drummer sacrifices a lot to please him, and the film highlights the highs and lows of their relationship.

This movie was pretty intense. You start to feel for the drummer, as he struggles to become the best, practicing until his hands bleed, and being constantly rejected. You start to care whether he fails or succeeds.  The story is very moving and even disturbing at times. The movies plot is unpredictable, and it even got the audience to gasp at one point near the climax.

The movie's also worth seeing for it's acting. JK Simmons' nominated performance as the instructor was very good. Having previously played J Jonah Jameson in the original Spider-man trilogy, he does a good job of playing an unpleasant person, spraying vulgar insults and criticisms at his students. But he also seems human at times when you can see his motives. There's also some great acting from Miles Teller as the drummer. He is a very sympathetic and believable character.

In summary, Whiplash is an amazing movie. Even though it hasn't gotten the attention from audience that it deserves, it is worth your time. If you like intense drama, emotionally charged performances, or jazz music, I would recommend this movie. I don't want to over-hype this movie, but I think it is actually worth 5 stars.
Very gripping and intense.  The tension comes at you full-force and rarely ever lets up.
FINALLY saw this. Damn good movie.

I've been a drummer for over ten years so I found immediate relation within Whiplash; an extremely ambitious and impressive film held tightly together by its main characters who force the question of morality, and how far one is willing to go and how much pain they they are willing to endure all for the sake of being the absolute best at what you love the most. After all the ingredients of a solid plot, the talent alone behind Whiplash is just mesmerizing; nonstop entertainment.

Amazing performances, especially by JK Simmons, and outstanding drum playing by Miles Teller. Whiplash shows in great detail what a drummer goes through to become one of the greats and it's very emotionally engaging.

If ever there was a film to successfully visualize music, Whiplash would be it. The rhythms and beats drive the film forward giving us a look into the world of music they rarely show on screen. Whiplash focuses on the blood, sweat and tears that it takes to become one of the best. It's brilliantly edited, building tension out of nothing but the playing of the drums until you're wound so tight tou reach a breaking point. It is more exciting and enthralling than most blockbuster action flicks, but it gives the same rush. The performances from leads Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons are electric pulling the film through in the couple instances when the script falters.
Best movie of the year!  Both leading men were phenominal.  Very intense and emotional.  Can't give this movie enough praise!!

It's an experience.... More uplifting than black swan and felt winded when the credits rolled... Loved it the same night...But after much thought that rolled into the work week didn't like it as much... Why? Didn't know if the need to glorify bullies is really something that's needed... But if the bully does it out of love ... Does it serve a higher purpose? Is there a better way to forge steel? Iron sharpens iron blah blah.... But is there a better way for intense training if you want to be the best in the world? Don't know.... But the fact that this film made me think intensely about it makes it worth it alone. How many movies are intense and make you think?

We've moved the story form of a sports movie with all of its inherent problems into the world of competitive jazz drumming. Mean coach, brilliant but troubled player, screw-up at the big game, redemption made possible by raw talent, and a little twist at the end. I wasn't as enchanted as my peers with this formulaic and manipulative drama, but I concede that it was well made, kept me on the edge of my seat, and had some pretty amazing performances, certainly Simmons, who is bound to get showered with awards for this and a lifetime of great performances.

A chilling, modern retelling of the classic moral of being carefull what you wish for. We follow Andrew played by Miles Teller as he persues his dream of becoming a famous drummer under the teacher  playee by J K Simmons. He uses pain and humiliation as a teaching method and the powerful dialogue and Simmons electrifying performance makes every scene hes in a tense rollercoaster. The scenes are beautifully paced and the way the director uses music to emphasise the maon emotions of a scene.
Holy shit this is good.

Intense!  Well acted with the bonus of a great story line.  I rarely see a movie twice but I had to go back with a family member so they could experience this fantastic movie.  It is so refreshing to see a movie without CG!

Simmons. As cut-throat and white knuckle as most action movies, Director Chazelle expertly examines talent, greatness, and how far one might go to get there.  Is anything too far?  You decide.  Superbly acted, written and performed; this is triumphant, visceral film-making.

As cut-throat and white knuckle as most action movies, Director Chazelle expertly examines talent, greatness, and how far one might go to get there.  Is anything too far?  You decide.  Superbly acted, written and performed; this is triumphant, visceral film-making.

"Whiplash" is such a layered film. It is an examination of the self-esteem movement generation. It contains one great performance and one career defining one. For a small film about a genre of music that isn't popular amongst the young, it packs one hell of a punch. It is fast, fun, thrilling, daring, and a masterpiece. Not many directors can say that for their first film. Congratulations, Mr. Chazelle!

What might be the best film of 2014, Whiplash succeeds on every level, whether it's the script, the acting, the editing, the directing and the music. It also marks a long overdue career performance from J.K. Simmons.

Basically a standard new recruit meets brutal drill sergeant/coach movie. But set in a music school.

The movie focuses on two characters; everything else is superfluous and underdeveloped. We get a few scenes representative of the character deepening scenes we see in other movies and we're apparently expected to fill in the character details based on our experiences with other stories that actually pursued and filled in those details. This movie gets away with skipping over that material because:

1) we're so familiar with the tropes that most of the audience will fill in those parts of the story automatically
2) The performances and the editing are so intensely driving that we don't get a chance to catch our breath and contemplate the movie

One of the best things about January in the UK is that we get a lot of the movies that came out in December or November of the previous years. Whiplash was one of them and now having seen the film I can honestly say I get the hype. This film is one of the most intense movies of the year I would even go and say this is one of the best of the decade. Whiplash is a film that does brilliantly on just about everything. The performances are just amazing. Miles Teller is so good, he's so like able and just really sells his character. He's a fantastic actor who's great in everything but this is his stand out role. However even though Miles Teller is brilliant he's outshined by J.K. Simmons. Except for Spider-Man I honestly haven't seen him in much, he was so brilliant in this movie. He was scary, funny and felt more like an angry drill instructor than a teacher. He plays the character of fletcher so well and he 100% deserves his Oscar. The character of Fletcher is one of the best characters ever put to film. We really see how seriously this guy takes his job by the way he berates and then kicks out one of his students for thinking he is out of tune. Or the way he walks into the classroom and we see the looks of fear on the students faces. The character of Terrence Fletcher is one of the most intense and down right terrifying characters put to film and so much of that comes from Simmons outstanding performance. Whiplash is also amazingly directed, I don't think I have seen anything else from Damian Chazelle but he's directed this film fantastically and I can't wait to see what he does next. One of Whiplash's strongest aspects is the amazing writing. The script for this film is brilliant, all of the lines feel very natural and some of the lines Simmons has are so creative. The editing is amazing. Every transition or cut feels flawless. The way the drumming scenes are edited are too amazing to describe. The cinematography is also fantastic there is this one dizzying shot when Miles Teller is drumming that is just brilliant. This film is also ridiculously tense, whenever we get scenes of Teller drumming with the band and Simmons watching it's very intense as you get the feeling he could snap at any minute. The scenes where Teller practices on his own are so intense as we see that he is pushing himself so much, covering the drum in blood and sweat it can be very hard to watch but I couldn't stop watching. This film also has an amazing ending, it is ridiculously intense and Teller shines in this portion. If I had any complaints there was a 5-10 minute but in the film where it's just Teller and there is no Simmons or drumming. It slows down what is a very fast paced film. However the scenes are good they just aren't as great as the rest of the film. Whiplash is a ridiculously tense movie that will have you on the edge of your seat. It has amazing acting, directing, editing, cinematography, sound mixing, music it's just a fantastic film and I'm so glad that I saw it. It's one of the best movies of 2015 and a film we will still be talking about years later. A

This could be the best movie of the year. I see what all the hype is about with 'Whiplash' among my musician friends, who have raved about this rare gem of a film. Every musician should watch this film at least once in there lifetime. Brilliant movie!!!

An interesting and well crafted story is told here, and while it may not be based on a true story, there are many details of this story that are surely true in various arts schools throughout the world.  Andrew is a full-of-himself young percussionist looking to be the next Buddy Rich. He thinks he can make it, and his new teacher Fletcher (Simmons) thinks he has some potential too, their interesting roller coaster of a relationship makes the journey to find out if he has what it takes quite interesting.  False confidence, ridicule, verbal abuse, physical abuse are all tools Fletcher uses to try and instill greatness in his students. Some students donâ??t handle this well. Most it seems. Andrewâ??s talent and willingness to fight back make him different. Performances from Teller and Simmons, along with some innately crafted musical scenes and some sharp dialogue make this drama intriguing. As a fan of drumming, but not so much a fan of jazz, I still found the acting and performances here to be legit and a ride worth taking.

Arguably Teller's and Simmon's best work to date. This intense thriller depicting the inspiring tale of jazz in the modern world will have you begging to see more from young director Chazelle. It may also leave you with an intense desire to pick up your old instrument and change your life. But you'll probably want to rethink that last decision and leave the jazz to the professionals. At least you'll want to get back into listening to jazz.

Intense. There is really no better word to describe Whiplash. Writer-director Damien Chazelle's fast-paced musical drama about the complex relationship between an aspiring first-year jazz student and a sadistic conductor is intense for numerous reasons: firstly, drums are the most physically demanding of all instruments, and the film discloses this by having the main character, Andrew Neimann, hammering his hands bloody and sweating like a pig. Secondly, J.K. Simmons delivers one of the most frantic, vociferous performances of the year as the abusive Terence Fletcher, and is on par with R. Lee Ermey's iconic performance in Full Metal Jacket. And thirdly, the film is looks incredibly alive through Tom Cross' fierce editing. Whiplash has the audience primarily exhausted, but in a good way, yet there is too much nuance and ambiguity in it to call it merely an emotional experience. It challenges us to question what it takes to be truly great at something; Fletcher takes pleasure in embarrassing his students and hurting them both mentally and physically, but his formidable methods also inspire them to excel. He never encourages them with cheap praises, and even when Andrew thinks he has earned his respect, Fletcher tantalizes him again. Andrew could obviously go from where the fence is lowest, let his affectionate father tell him he did a "good job" (two words which Fletcher considers as the most dangerous in the English language), live an unambitious life and be just another run-of-the-mill slacker, but his persistence and ambition ultimately triumph. There are a couple problems with the film; Miles Teller's drumming is very authentic, but as an actor he should be more expressive, and cinematographer Sharone Meir's constant use of extreme close-ups gets often irritating. But thanks to Chazelle's potent direction, smart screenplay and Simmons' unforgettable performance, Whiplash lives up to its title.

Amazing is an understatement. The drums never sounded better. While watching scene after scene, the feeling of intensity kept growing all the way to the finale. J.K. Simmons was strong, a dickhead, yet perfect.

This is one movie I will never forget, and it's the best movie I've seen all year. Whiplash gets 5/5 stars (A+).

Think back to your days in school or college. Did you have that one teacher that stood out above all the rest, the one that realized potential in you and gave you the push that you needed to do something great? Maybe that teacher or professor was beloved by many, and other students always only had the greatest things to say about that instructor. 

On the other hand, maybe they were notorious. Maybe there were widely referred to as the "hard ass" teacher that nobody liked, except for a small, devoted group of disciples that hung on their every word, where the smallest hint of approval was gobbled up like mana from heaven, and if you ever got that approval, by god, you EARNED it. I had a teacher sort of like that. He wasn't universally hated, but he wasn't necessarily loved by everyone either. He was the best teacher I have ever had, and he pushed me to succeed. He didn't dole out hugs and candy canes. When I did well on an assignment, he said things like "it's an improvement. Keep pushing." I have nothing but the utmost respect for that man.

In Whiplash, a young man named Andrew (Miles Teller) is enrolled at a prestigious music conservatory to pursue a career as a drummer. An infamous instructor, Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), takes notice of the freshman drummer, and invites him to his exclusive jazz band, where Andrew will be put to the test and his limits pushed beyond his bounds in a quest for glory.

Fletcher is the instructor from hell. He's like a swearing, screaming Mr. Holland from "Mr. Holland's Opus." His goal is absolute perfection, and anything less than that means utter failure. This is a movie about a battle of wits and wills. If you're not bleeding on your instrument, you don't have a right to play it. Andrew does not want to stop until he becomes the thing of legends, and Fletcher will settle for nothing less than absolute greatness.

When folks watch the trailer for this movie, they might think "Oh look, a jazz movie! Neato." I assure you, this is as much a suspenseful thriller as it is an exploration of the intricacies of jazz music. It is very intense, and I didn't think that could be possible in a movie about a jazz ensemble. 

If you're a musician, it's easy to appreciate that aspect of this film. Its rhythmic and propulsive, explosive and exhilarating. If you've ever sat down and practiced your craft for hours, trying to get that ONE THING right that just escapes your grasp, you'll understand this movie. 

J.K. Simmons as Fletcher is the most outstanding part of this film, and I hope he gets some award recognition. He is monolithic and intimidating, and delivers some of the most creative put-downs I've ever heard. Some of his insults are so intense that they made me laugh out of shock. It's often crass, yes, but wowzers is it effective. 

Also impressive is Miles Teller's ability on the drums, which was not performed by a double. He's been playing the instrument since his teens, and he is pretty fantastic at it. 

This is a simple movie, but incredibly satisfying. It didn't have a large budget, it went largely unnoticed by the majority of movie-goers, and was filmed in like, three weeks. But this is absolutely one of the best films of 2014, and I enjoyed every single minute of it. The last 15 minutes are absolutely explosive, and you'll want to stand up and cheer. I always love it when your first reaction to the end of a film is simply "...wow."
Whiplash devours you, drains you, and makes sure you'll never forget what you just experienced.
Propelled by the electrifying performances of its central duo, "Whiplash" is a captivating, fiery study of the perils and positives of ambition.

I went for what I hoped was good Jazz and was mildly disappointed, but the acting did hold me and the other Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone (all two of them) for the entire movie. The Jazz is the sort of large ensemble Lincoln Center thing that I don't care for all that much. At one point  J.K. Simmons (who is wonderful) laments that Jazz is dying in America and I sort of blame the Lincoln Center folks and the emphasis on exactitude for that. Jazz should, in my opinion, retain the loose mixing of talent that were it's origins. But there I go giving a Jazz lecture instead of a movie review. All the movie is the interaction of Miles Teller as a young Jazz drummer and J.K. Simmons as the nearly psychotic music teacher. The young man's desire to be a great drummer becomes an obsession and the teacher takes advantage of that for his own twisted purposes. This is  well interspersed with great drum solos albeit in the style of Buddy Rich and that school of machine gun drumming. The supporting cast have very small roles, but Paul Reiser and Milissa Benoist hold up their ends nicely. All in all a good movie if you like music or just good acting.

As a lifelong musician who went on to receive his bachelor's degree in music, this film hit home with me. Not only was it a really well done movie, but I found myself laughing at every little nuance of our world that was, for the first time, revealed on screen. It acts as a long-deserved glorification of the musician and the hours of practice that we spend at home practicing our craft. It also touches upon so many ideas and struggles that we have to constantly deal with. The belittling comparison to athletics in this film is one that I have always had an issue with. So much attention and money is shelled towards sports--something that people are less likely to become successful through than music. When music is a tool that is more useful, people scoff at it and give it no attention. Those of us in that world know its importance, but getting the "normal people" to understand that is almost useless. If someone gets to be starting quarterback they are worshipped and bragged about, but when someone earns first chair saxophone it usually just warrants us a simple pat on the back as if we were just getting an A- on an algebra test. Luckily I had parents that were extremely enthusiastic and supportive of my music endeavors--always bragging about what I have accomplished. That's why the only thing in this movie that I can criticize is Andrew's dad's negativity towards his son's music career. It doesn't make sense that his dad would pay for and support Andrew in music academy, but then go on to tell him that he would never play at the Lincoln Center. It was the only thing random and out of place in this film. It caused unnecessary tension between the two characters. But that scene doesn't warrant dismissal altogether. It may also be one of the most true and honest parts of this movie. People are praised when they are said to be going to college to play football, but when I tell others that I am a music major, most people's response is "Why?" or "So, what are you going to do with that?" When in reality, I am unbelievably more likely to get a job in my industry than an athlete is in his or hers. But because sports are deemed as cooler, nobody cares. Whiplash touches upon and pokes fun at these typical ideals, which makes the film all the more great. But perhaps the one thing in this movie that I can relate to the most is having an instructor eerily similar to that of J.K. Simmons' character, Terence Fletcher.

In high school I was in jazz band that started every morning at 7am. And if I wasn't tuned up and ready to go by 7:00 exactly, my teacher would start the rest of the band while glaring at me the entire time as I was frantically trying to get everything setup. This was me almost everyday. I felt like he hated me because he thought that I didn't care enough to get there on time and that I was ruining his valued rehearsal time. Little did he know, I did everything to make it to rehearsals and performances on time. I sped through lights, rolled through stop signs, and probably almost hit several pedestrians at times. But honestly, it had nothing to do with caring about not wasting his time--I just didn't want to get yelled at. Honestly, I didn't care as much as everyone else. I should have, but I didn't. That's where Miles Teller's character and I differ. I had other things on my mind--girlfriends, my social life, sleeping. Throughout high school we had a weird relationship. He would always scold me about things while the rest of the band would sit there in an awkward silence thanking the Lord that it was me and not them. Much like when we, much like in this movie, would sit there for 10 minutes while our teacher would yell at the drummer for not being at his tempo. The scenes in this film almost exactly replicated what happened in our rehearsals. It was almost funny, but you wouldn't dare laugh. There was a genuine fear that he placed in all of us. He and Fletcher shared the philosophy that belittling and humiliation helped to motivate. In a way, they're right. It's just not for everybody.

I practiced my parts at home for bare minimum--an hour every couple of days. I was 2nd chair tenor saxophone the entire time. One time we had a jazz competition and I forgot all of my music. To this day it was the most nervous I have ever been. There I am, in the front row, 6 feet from my teacher, and I was pretending to play an entire folder of music. Some I could bare through off the top of my head, but most I had to improvise. It was a real test of how well I knew the music. A test that I failed. I'm not sure if he knew what was up with me. To this day I'm convinced that he did, but just let me suffer through the agony rather than saving me the humiliation by making me sit backstage. If I had practiced, I wouldn't have needed the music to begin with.

He had lost his voice a few years before I got there, but I'm not sure how. We always speculated it was because of his yelling, but we never really knew. He was a stickler for everything and none of us understood it. We feared him, but also respected him at a high rate because he did what no other teacher had, or will, ever do--go to extremes to make sure that we never satisfied for mediocre. Doing music in college was the last thing I ever thought that I would do. I have him to thank. He put me one step ahead of the game and taught me that music was just as meaningful as sports--if not more. He hated playing at the football games because he thought that such a beautiful thing as music shouldn't pander to a silly thing such as high school football. He had his ideals set. We didn't understand at the time, but his passion for the art transcend to me all these years later.

My teacher wasn't as extreme as Terence Fletcher in Whiplash, but he was definitely on my mind the entire time I watched this movie.

As for the film, it was fantastic. It features great jazz, and equally as good acting, and the story never drags. It's a must watch for anyone who was ever in an ensemble.

The ferocious lead performances (Teller and Simmons) in "Whiplash" impute a mesmerizing power on the viewer, who witnesses a psychological struggle between teacher and pupil that is both unsettling and riveting. Good, perhaps overhyped,  yet tells the perfect story of the unconventional way to lead.  This story needs to be told no matter the subject matter.   The need for man to overpower one another is abundant in society today.   I personally have struggled with those who take to the harsher side of mentoring others.   
This is the story of a young college student whom has aspirations of becoming one of the greatest drummers of all time.   He is enlisted into a prestigious jazz orchestra and has to endure the unethical teachings of the one who put him in position to become all he can be. 
The story would like to conclude that people will not give something there very best and work until their hands bleed unless they are driven by someone else to get there.   This could be true,  but the drive is where they lose me.  Too many people believe in order to get the best out of someone,  you have to put them in a place that makes them feel they cannot do anything right.   Most people react to this approach by giving up.   The point is made that this teacher will accept that as someone who doesn't have the will to be great. 
I couldn't disagree more. I believe that people can be mentored without these ridiculous methods.  Holding someone accountable without making them want to commit suicide should not be so difficult to comprehend. 
So,  did I enjoy the movie?   Yes,  I did.   In that the story shows the reality of who we think we are.   And how we think we need to treat one another. Yet,  I also hated the movie at the same time because it conveyed this mistreatment as something that eventually turns into greatness. As if the best leaders can only see greatness through destroying one's soul. 
This movie will have a hold on me for a while and I hope that many can see it as a representation of how this way of life destroys lives.  
Some of the best acting I have seen for a 2014 movie.   I really hated J. K. Simmons' character in this movie,  so credit goes to him for that.   I will never look at him the same way.   
3.5 out of 5 stars.

"They are no two words more harmful in the English language than good job." -Terrance Fletcher 
	Damien Chazelle has not done a good job with Whiplash. He has done an OUTSTANDING job with this film. With a watertight screenplay, amazing performances from the leads, and a keen eye for direction Chazelle created a visceral experience centered around a drum set. Whiplash is the story of Andew Neiman, a jazz drummer who finds himself in a award winning studio jazz band that is run by a man named Terrance Fletcher, a brilliant and ruthless instructor who only cares about getting the best performance from his students. Chazelle, has crafted a film so fine tuned that nothing fell flat. I'll start with the talent in front of the camera for Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons are perfect. Teller, who actually plays the drums in real life, captured the hardship of a young musician. That strive to become better than you were the day before was always present in Andrew's character. I am a musician myself and I know this look very well. Teller really shows his acting talents and I hope to see more of his work in the future. On the other side of this coin is Simmons who plays the most intimidating characters I have seen in 2014. Seeing the no holds bar Fletcher just grill Andrew was intense and cruel. Yet, Fletcher's intentions are not in spite but in for the favor of his students so it is hard to totally hate the man, especially since Simmons brings a strong likability to the character in brief moments. (Simmons will probably take home the Oscar this year) The screenplay provides some of the best dialogue i have seen in 2014. Conversations fill honest and are never just filler. I could never tell where the film was going, which is good in this case as I was always engaged in the story hoping that Neiman would succeed. The soundtrack is amazing, especially if you love jazz like me. The direction is superb as I felt apart of the band in Whiplash. The way Chazelle showed the sheer brutality of being a jazz drummer though Neiman's excessive practicing was very unnerving. This film also has the best finale I have seen in 2014. I could think of a million other reasons why I loved Whiplash but I rather give you the opportunity to see it. If Whiplash is playing anywhere near you in a 50 mile radius than I encourage you to see it for it is definitely my favorite film of 2014.
Awesome movie !!! I loved it !!!
amazing thriller with no bullets

This movie was horrible. Here's why. Cliches, cliches, cliches. Why is it that films about revered genres get a pass on the cliches that are constantly deemed unacceptable in other movies on more generic themes? The best example of the most egregiously horrific cliches in this movie is the scene when the main character, while frantically playing the drums, literally emits......wait for it....blood, sweat and tears. I've no idea what purpose most characters were meant to serve, except that of the band leader and he obviously was present just to harass the main character, even going so far as to invite him at the end of the movie to play in the heralded jvc jazz competition, only to try to trip him up by opening up with a tune that had just been written and the drummer didn't .....know? Really? A band leader who wants so badly to trash an unknown drummers non career, that he's willing to trash his own on the first song in a well known jazz competition? Who does that? Each character had their own roll of insignificance. Daddy figure was droll and uninspired, mommy figure walked out of the family years earlier (as in the way I longed to walk out of this movie) the love interest who was sacrificed for the sake of art was had the emotional attachment of a paid escort, the dinner table scene was a pointless attempt to obviously portray how nobody liked the main character, even his own relatives, and why didn't this " musician" didn't even have a fellow band mate for a friend? No banter? No humor at all? Musicians are introspective, funny people. But not in this movie. If you liked "Top Gun", " The Hurt Locker", "Rambo", and any of the other omnipresent cinematic examples of the implausible, then you'll love this crapfest. But don't see it because you already have.

Whiplash is a downright dazzling piece of work from newcomer writer/director Damien Chazelle about the price one is willing to pay for greatness. Miles Teller is fantastic as Andrew, an aspiring jazz drummer at a prestigious music conservatory under the tuteledge of Professor Fletcher; an absolutely domineering and fiery J.K. Simmons. Are Fletcher's means to realize his student's full potential justifiable abuse? What sacrifices are worthy in the pursuit of success? Is it better to be remembered, or loved? Whiplash is the Full Metal Jacket of jazz films, and it's also one of the best films of the year, with a finale so intense it left me utterly breathless.
I have PTSD after seeing this sadistic movie. I regret seeing it and I urge people not to go.

Whiplash is an exhilarating psychological battle of wits that is a riveting vehicle for stars J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller. The concluding segment of the film is phenomenal. Whiplash showcases bravura film-making.

I'll spare you the hammy music metaphors that so many other reviewers have already--and will in the future--employ. I'll simply state that Whiplash is an absolutely engrossing film, superbly acted by the two leads. It is taut and assured; no wasted scenes slow the movie's brisk pace, the plot twists are at times over-the-top but compelling, and the characters smartly written and well-defined. 

Many people will characterize this movie as a study of great talent and the extreme lengths one must go to tap into it. But for me the movie's true brilliance lies in the questions it raises, not the answers it provides. By the end of the movie I found myself wondering if Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons) was really a demanding hard-ass who just yearned to maximize the talent of his promising young student, or a bully who merely took satisfaction from grinding him down. The fact that the movie left me wondering about this is the key to its genius. It is a movie about talent. But more than that, it is a movie about obsession. Obsession for music, obsession for greatness, obsession for towering above the rest--by any means necessary. A movie that acknowledges we must take risks and make great sacrifices to reach great heights would be at best a pedestrian film. Whiplash poses the better question: by taking great risks, by making great sacrifices, are we paying the price of greatness, or are we selling our souls?

I don't care for jazz but I LOVED this movie so much that I even found myself digging the music. Anyone who had a coach of any kind that really pushed him/her will relate. Be prepared to hear lots of gasps from the little old ladies in the audience. Does Simmons push too far? You make the call. Teller and Simmons should both get Oscar nominations. This is the best movie I have seen in 2014 so far.
A very deserving Best Picture nominated film that gets credit for being unconventional, even if it isn't on the same level as the absolute best films that were nominated for Oscar's top prize.

This movie is ridiculously over the top. The plot, the drama, the acting would have been better suited to a boxing or martial arts movie.  There is nothing redeeming or likable about Fletcher and even Andrew Neyman drifts from 'innocent kid' into a barely tolerable, angry young man consumed by his obsession to succeed. The music is great but the drama is so overdone and negative that it throws a wet blanket over the feel, spontaneity and creative vitality of the jazz - so much so, that I no longer cared what happened to Neyman, Fletcher or the music. When the credits rolled, I breathed a sigh of relief and perhaps felt a little sorry for the music, which took more of a beating than Andrew Neyman.

In high school I was in jazz band that started every morning at 7am. And if I wasn't tuned up and ready to go by 7:00 exactly, my teacher would start the rest of the band while glaring at me the entire time as I was frantically trying to get everything setup. This was me almost everyday. I felt like he hated me because he thought that I didn't care enough to get there on time and that I was ruining his valued rehearsal time. Little did he know, I did everything to make it to rehearsals and performances on time. I sped through lights, rolled through stop signs, and probably almost hit several pedestrians at times. But honestly, it had nothing to do with caring about not wasting his time--I just didn't want to get yelled at. Honestly, I didn't care as much as everyone else. I should have, but I didn't. That's where Miles Teller's character and I differ. I had other things on my mind--girlfriends, my social life, sleeping. Throughout high school we had a weird relationship. He would always scold me about things while the rest of the band would sit there in an awkward silence thanking the Lord that it was me and not them. Much like when we, much like in this movie, would sit there for 10 minutes while our teacher would yell at the drummer for not being at his tempo. The scenes in this film almost exactly replicated what happened in our rehearsals. It was almost funny, but you wouldn't dare laugh. There was a genuine fear that he placed in all of us. He and Fletcher shared the philosophy that belittling and humiliation helped to motivate. In a way, they're right. It's just not for everybody.

I practiced my parts at home for bare minimum--an hour every couple of days. I was 2nd chair tenor saxophone the entire time. One time we had a jazz competition and I forgot all of my music. To this day it was the most nervous I have ever been. There I am, in the front row, 6 feet from my teacher, and I was pretending to play an entire folder of music. Some I could bare through off the top of my head, but most I had to improvise. It was a real test of how well I knew the music. A test that I failed. I'm not sure if he knew what was up with me. To this day I'm convinced that he did, but just let me suffer through the agony rather than saving me the humiliation by making me sit backstage. If I had practiced, I wouldn't have needed the music to begin with.

He had lost his voice a few years before I got there, but I'm not sure how. We always speculated it was because of his yelling, but we never really knew. He was a stickler for everything and none of us understood it. We feared him, but also respected him at a high rate because he did what no other teacher had, or will, ever do--go to extremes to make sure that we never satisfied for mediocre. Doing music in college was the last thing I ever thought that I would do. I have him to thank. He put me one step ahead of the game and taught me that music was just as meaningful as sports--if not more. He hated playing at the football games because he thought that such a beautiful thing as music shouldn't pander to a silly thing such as high school football. He had his ideals set. We didn't understand at the time, but his passion for the art transcend to me all these years later. 

My teacher wasn't as extreme as Terence Fletcher in Whiplash, but he was definitely on my mind the entire time I watched this movie. 

As for the film, it was fantastic. It features great jazz, and equally as good acting, and the story never drags. It's a must watch for anyone who was ever in an ensemble.

Dynamite film from relative newcomer Damien Chazelle is an intense, visceral experience from beginning to end. Its plot is relatively slight, telling the story of ambitious young jazz drummer Andrew Neyman (Miles Teller) and his single-minded quest for greatness. But Chazelle's execution is absolutely thrilling, drawing forth remarkable performances from both Teller and J.K. Simmons (having the time of his life as the ruthless instructor/conductor Terence Fletcher) and creating a raw, kinetic energy that gives the film the same swing as the music. There isn't much depth to these two, and opportunities to find other colors in these characters is often eschewed for pace and style, but this is more than made up for by the film's radiant love for the art forms of both jazz and movies - evident in every frame... blood, sweat, and all. If this is any indication of what Chazelle has to offer in the years to come, we should be very, very excited.

If I have one bit of advice to offer about 'Whiplash,' it's this: don't forget to breathe. On paper, the premise sounds a bit cliched - an aspiring young jazz drummer is pushed to the brink by an unorthodox instructor. On film, it's a search for greatness by way of brutal assaults on the limits of compassion, capacity, and control.  

JK Simmons has a career best performance - and that means a lot for an actor of his caliber - as the abusive mad scientist of a teacher who is convinced that excellence lies slightly beyond the edge of reason, and that it takes violent coaxing for one to break the plane. Miles Teller is perfect as his pupil whose atypical coming of age puts at risk either lifelong success or absolute failure.

'Whiplash' has the intensity of a horror-thriller and the adrenaline of a war movie. Considering that it primarily consists of its two leads playing off each other, that's an incredible accomplishment. If your heart isn't racing when the credits roll, you're probably dead.

Whiplash is a wild, rambunctious, at times tortuous roller coaster. Its a music drama that isn't about the music. It's about life, and the blurred line between humane and inhumane. By far the most intense 100 minutes of cinema to play this year.

There's really only one word to describe "Whiplash": Intense. That's not a word I'd expect to use when describing a film about a 19 year old jazz drummer who dreams of becoming the next Charlie Parker. Actually, to be more specific, he dreams of being better than the next Charlie Parker. Folks, this is one of the great films of 2014.
Miles Teller stars as Andrew Neyman. His only focus in life is the drums. In fact, he sacrifices the chance to be in a relationship with a girl he really likes because he knows he'll neglect her in the future in favor of the drums. (It's curious to wonder why he even asked her out in the first place.) Note how often directer Damien Chazelle frames Andrew and the drums together - they're one in the same. 
At the start of the movie, we find ourselves in a deserted corridor; the only thing filling the hallways is the sound of someone drumming. The camera slowly tracks down the hallway and approaches where the drumming is coming from. There we see Andrew. He looks as if he's just finished training for a marathon. He notices he's not alone, and we then meet Terrence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), a highly respected instructor at the
fictional Schaefer Conservatory (the best jazz school in the country). This is Andrew's big shot to impress Fletcher. He doesn't. And this sets up the rest of the film, really: Andrew will continue to do whatever it takes - whatever it takes! - to win the adulation of Fletcher. For Andrew, receiving praise from his supportive father (Paul Reiser - in an incredibly sweet role) isn't enough. Even his father questions why it's so important
for Andrew to win praise from Fletcher. I'm not sure Andrew understands himself. He teeters between insecurity and confidence - he never quite finds a common ground. Hearing the words, "Good job" isn't enough for Andrew. He wants to be the best - even if he dies young and penniless, as long as people remember him for his drumming he regards that as success. But how far can you push yourself to get to that level? And how far will you allow someone else to push you to that level? "Whiplash" posits this,
and the intensity I mentioned earlier comes from Andrew's actions and Fletcher's teaching "methods." Does Fletcher cross the line when pushing Andrew? (Had his intense - or insane? - teaching methods pushed another student to suicide?) Fletcher raises an interesting point of view: If he fills each student with praise, will they ever
push themselves to achieve their greatest potential, or will they just coast through life believing they've already achieved greatness?
The film, directed by first-timer Damien Chazelle, was directed in an astounding 19 days. The whole rhythm of the film feels like a jazz performance - jazz is all about the ensemble and improvisation, and that's exactly what makes "Whiplash" feel so fresh. The film never follows the conventional route.
J.K. Simmons will certainly score an Oscar nomination and, to be honest, I think he's the one to beat. (I also learned that he holds a degree in music, and knew how to conduct prior to filming.) Even when he's not speaking, we can see how intimidating he is.
There are, however, a few moments that feel a bit unbelievable in the movie. At one point, Andrew is in a pretty bad car accident, yet in the scenes that follow he has no apparent cuts/scars/bruises... was this an oversight in post-production? It's a tiny piece of criticism that certainly doesn't harm the film's power. This is a movie carried by its performers. And Simmons and Miles Teller are electric.
Brought back thoughts of Black Swan- Any movie that can do that deserves the highest ratings... An especially appropriate movie for a college students. To what extend to we need something to die for?
The final 10 minutes minutes are the best concluding 10 minutes in a film this year. Miles teller and J.K Simmojs deserves an Oscar nod for sure.

Are you willing to push yourself beyond expectations to become the best? That's the question Andrew (Miles Teller) must answer in this spare, well-crafted drama. A bit like "Officer and a Gentleman" for the Jazz set, it's a worthy picture, but it doesn't exactly break new ground. The characters are functional, if not fully realized. Andrew is conveniently anti-social, leaving little room for us to see his character in contexts other than the practice room. As with its main character, the film rarely complicates itself with entanglements of life outside the conservatory, which I think prevents this movie from reaching greater emotional depths and (ironically, unlike Andrew) solidifying itself as truly great.
Epic, leaves you vibrating for an hour afterward.

Whiplash (2014) - Sometimes we must suffer for art. "Whiplash" stars Myles Teller and J.K Simmons in a harrowing musical drama revolving around the dynamic between Andrew (Teller) and his hard-knocks instructor Fletcher (Simmons). In order to succeed in one of the most prestigious jazz music Academies, Andrew must not only tackle the abuse of Fletcher but the hardships and lengths involved in becoming truly great. 

This was probably one of the least surprising results I've received from a film this year but in no stretch whatsoever is that a critique. I knew ever since I saw the remarkable trailer earlier this year for the film that it was something to keep an eye on and it did not disappoint. This is a fine example of a film that is just utterly perfect at what it sets out to do and your gauge of likeability is centralized around the movies core theme and message. In the cases of "Whiplash", it sets out to tell a tale of artistic sacrifice, abuse and reaching the very limits of the human condition; all wrapped up neatly in the trappings of a drama with jazz at the centre. The best part is, you don't have to be a fan of jazz to enjoy this movie because it's just so damn entertaining, tense and clear-cut that you'd be hard pressed to find anyone who wouldn't leave the theatre with a big smile on their face.

A lot of thanks to the films execution is in large part delegated to the immaculate direction by Damien Chazelle. No single frame, edit or lingering shot was wasted in the picture; it just flows so viscerally and naturally that you lose yourself in your seat. I never once checked my watch, in fact, I could have kept watching this movie. Well, now let's talk about the elephant in the room... Or in this case, two elephants. As I said, the direction was vital in this movie's success but I think it's crowning achievement is in the two lead performances at its central core. Both Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons are OSCAR worthy in this movie... There's really nothing else that needs to be said. They're just incredible! So much so that despite the solid direction, I don't think this movie would have worked as well as it did without them. There's a veracity and determination in Teller's eyes that from the opening shot make you immediately route for him. This is only amplified when you learn that Teller translated his rock drummer background to the film's more technical jazz drumming which makes a fire light-up inside you every time he picks up the sticks. On the opposing end, you have yourself a tour-de force performance from Simmons. He's filled with pent up rage, manipulation and yet he's so passionate about the art of jazz that you just can't help but find him endearing. The two characters and their "locked-horn" relationship is what truly makes this film knock it out of the park and will have everyone on the edge of their seats.

I cannot recommend you see this movie enough. It's a fine example of acting, film-making and art. It's inspiring, engaging, thrilling and might have the best ending/cut to black of any film of 2014. If you appreciate movies and want more quality entertainment from this near limitless art-form, you should make an honest effort in seeing one of the year's very best films.

GRADE: A

Just because Whiplash is centered on a drum student (Miles Teller) trying to become one of the jazz greats at an elite music conservatory doesn't mean you should thumb your nose and pass on it. Whiplash is a whoosh of a film, dazzlingly entertaining, bolstered by two amazing performances. Written and directed by Damien Chazelle (Guy and Madeline On a Park Bench), from his own experience as a drum student, Whiplash is a heady battle to the death, and a potent provocation: just how much of ourselves should we sacrifice to be excellent.

When Andrew Neyman (Teller) goes head to head with bullying instructor Terence Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), there's blood on the drums, on the walls, on Andrew's very psyche. Terence runs his band like a drill sargeant, with barbs that would make R. Lee Ermey biush. Heaven help you if you're not on his tempo. Chazelle, 29, stages these drum duels with startling skill, and the two lead actors are more than outstanding. Teller (The Spectacular Now), a drummer himself, is a young actor of brilliant nuance and grit. And Simmons, who can play pure evil (see him in HBO's Oz), sweet (Juno), hilarious (the Spider-Man trilogy) and everything in between, is superb. Simmons is an acting beast, here's hoping there's finally some award recognition in his future. Together, he and Teller make Whiplash the electrifying music that it is.
Complete package. A treat to watch teller and Simmons. Direction, editing and screenplay probably makes this one the best movies of 2014.

This is the best movie about music and the relentless teacher who almost pushes his gifted student too far. Not for everyone, certainly. Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons are brilliant throughout. A must for people in the performing arts. This is a little movie that was shot in 20 days. DON'T MISS IT!

I know diddly squat about music. I know less about drumming. However, I do know that this film is a blinder!

You're unlikely to see a more intense film in 2015 - a weird statement considering we're talking about a film about an ensemble jazz group. The focus on drummer  Andrew (Miles Teller) gives some indication to the ferocious energy that is about to come your way; this is made abundantly clear within the opening minutes. When it really strikes home that this film is going to pin you to the wall and not let go is the introduction of Fletcher, played by J.K. Simmons in a career high performance. 

The frightening, disarming and at times outright evil of Fletcher is wonderfully brought to life by Simmons in a way that you'll be unlikely to forget him for a long while. Scene after standout scene we're provoked by this character, loving to hate him throughout.

Damien Chazelle's direction is just as furious, barely allowing us to catch our breath between shouting, drum solos, bleeding hands and grown men brought to tears.  His screenplay is a gift to both Simmons and Teller, their powerful performances coming naturally from the snappy screenplay.

It does have it's flaws. Neither central characters are particularly likeable, one of which we can understand but the other stops us from every fully investing in the protagonist's plight. This also leads to Simmon's character in particular to seem veer a little into caricature and over the top at times - like a cartoon bad guy.

The film lacks any clear resolution, in my opinion, and seems to stop at the climax. I can, in some respects, understand why it ended where it did - I just wanted five more minutes to clear everything up.

All in all, this comes highly recommended. A film unlike any other you'll see this year, or any year to be honest. Sit down, strap in, grab your sticks and prepare for a white-knuckle ride!

Whiplash, starring Miles Teller and Jk Simmons, is the story of a drummer attending one of the greatest music institutions in America and how his life changes when he is noticed by the conductor of the institution's studio band, their top ensemble. The movie is certainly carried by the performances of its cast and by the score, which is very well done. It is also cut together very, very well, especially in the scenes when Teller's character, Andrew Neyman, is drumming. JK Simmons is the star of this movie, however, and his performance NEEDS to be discussed. His was one of the best performances by an actor, not just in a supporting role, but even in a lead role, that I have EVER seen. It would be a pure travesty if he doesn't win the Oscar for best supporting actor. I loved Ethan Hawke and Ed Norton in Boyhood and Birdman, but JK Simmons was FLAWLESS in this performance, and he should be recognized as such.

An intense experience if there ever was one. Whiplash is about the combative relationship between student and teacher at an exclusive New York music school. Miles Teller is a rising star on the acting scene and he does a phenomenal job as the tightly focused young student trying to achieve his life goals as a jazz drummer. This robustly directed film ebbs and flows through the emotions and experiences of achievement and success. It is a great insight into characters striving for greatness. If a little overplayed at times it is nonetheless an intense and sometimes scary experience.
Miles Teller & J.K. Simmons are phenomenal. This movie is INTENSE and quite wonderful! Can't stop thinking about it!

With a rush of adrenaline and a wave of support for the young protagonist, Andrew, Whiplash ends with one of the best climaxes of film in recent years. This is not the typical "rising-star drama" of an underdog who transgresses from zero to hero and spend hours of screen time practicing and struggling through physical and mental barriers in order to culminate in a final moment of greatness. One, because  Andrew is already a great drummer but with the aspiration of becoming THE GREATEST drummer. There are many moments within the film to prove of his present talent. It further refuses to fall on the cliché of giving Andrew everything he wants in the end beyond his moment of validation.  On his path, he has left his romantic and personal life behind, and although he leaves us with a high note, this may or may not be the be the best for him in the end.

Opposing Andrew, J.K Simmons arrives as his instructor, Fletcher, with a blend of menace and a natural comedic flare, familiar to his roles in Juno, Spiderman, and the brief cameo in Burn After Reading. From the very opening shot, he is seen as a snake spying on Andrew down the hall and tempting him with greatness and prestige. When he is in a scene, he is the only character in the scene. 

On an artistic level, the cinematography strikes impressions of Wes Anderson to develop ideas of uniformity both in the practice and theory of Jazz. It also confirms that this is a story about Andrew rather than a love letter to Jazz or the drums. In close-ups, Andrew is the focus. Not once does a shot includes the drum kit without the presence of the performer. The blood that drips onto the snare and the sweat that shatters off the cymbal belong to our protagonist and remind us what this film is truly expressing. 

As a character piece, expect strong nominations for Miles Teller and J.K Simmons. Considering the Academy's track record of Best Pictures, I wouldn't expect it to find its way to the stage, although it may prove worthy for a Golden Globe.
Tremendous acting and film. J.K. Simmons has always been a favorite of mine. Now he may be up for an Oscar now...at least he should be.

OH!  MY!  GOD!!  THIS IS MY NUMBER ONE MOVIE OF THE YEAR!!!  This film better be a killer at the OSCARS this year!!

Drumming up an exhilarating and emotional rollercoaster of a drama, writer-director Damien Chazelle's blistering music-story plays so fast and furiously with the audiences sympathies that whiplash nearly occurs. If the Great Santini taught at Fame, it might look a lot like this. What price, greatness? That's a question that Whiplash nails down violently and profanely. On one hand, the teacher goes too far. On the other hand, the student gives a better performance. Anybody pushed by a mentor or who strives under their own worst critic  themselves - surely relates. Its the authenticity of the acting and, by proxy to the performance, instrument playing that really makes you consider this price, however.

In this R-rated musical drama, a promising young drummer (Teller) enrolls at a cutthroat music conservatory where a driven instructor (Simmons) stops at nothing to realize the student's potential. 

In an intentionally polarizing role that makes Sgt. Hartman from Full Metal Jacket come off like Pooh Bear, J.K. Simmons gives the greatest performance of his already great career and one of the best dramatic turns of the year. As a filmgoer, you bristle at his maniacal slave-driving. When hot-headed, blister-handed Miles Teller drums himself into a seemingly possessed absolute frenzy at the climax, however, you practically sweat and bleed along with him. Due every bit of recognition surely coming his way this awards season, this actor plays every note of Tim Simonec's amazing, original jazz songbook. Yes, what results from their hard work truly makes you think, but you'll be tapping your knee to keep time while the brain toils all the same. With such frenetic performances and an improvisational jazz influence, filmgoers might suspect that writer-director Damien Chazelle would mostly take a handheld approach. They'd be wrong. Smartly using stead-cam to capture the on-screen madness only keeps the explosive goings-on that much MORE in focus.

Bottom line: Ringo of Fire

After several days of seeing this it still seems impossible to put into words all the emotions this film brought up in me. Disbelief, pity, rage, elation, excitement, awe and everything in between! Whiplash is a thrilling story of gifted student and his sadistic teacher who feed each other's obsessions. How much ambition is too much? Does the means justify the end? The final climactic scene might offer you an answer. One of the best movies of 2014!

Whoa!! Intense. Literally was glued to the edge of my seat in the theatre the whole film. Towards the end I had chills running up my spine. Incredible acting by the main characters. Simmons is mind blowing and we should definitely see him nominated for a few awards for his portrayal of a tough music conservatory teacher. Excellent editing throughout. High anxiety. Great performances from Simmons and Teller. I usually don't like Teller but he was great in this. I think of this movie as the first half of Full Metal Jacket but with Jazz Music instead of the war. Ending was as good as it gets. Hopefully it takes a couple awards this year.

Whiplash is both one of the best, and most terrifying movies I have ever seen, which is based solely on J.K Simmons performance as a music teacher that will stop at nothing to see a musicians potential be fulfilled. The film kept me at the edge of my seat the whole time with relenting force, playing out like a thriller or, dare I even say, a horror film. Fantastic performances all around and definitely one of the best films this year.

Easily one of the best films of 2014, Whiplash keeps you tense, horrified, and glued to the screen as you witness the psychology behind ambition and perfection. The director fine tunes the actors and brings out their best, much like the relationship between mentor and student. Just go ahead and give J.K. Simmons his Best Supporting Actor award already. Was he too abusive? Does the end justify the means? All I know is that the film certainly feels as a catalyst for its viewers, not unlike the impact Breaking Bad brought to the world.
This is a movie that had me on the edge of my seat and breathing heavily the entire time, and for that I will say that Whiplash is truly a CINEMATIC EXPERIENCE.

The cinematography is top rate and the script is pitch perfect. Every adjective they use to describe this in the trailer is accurate.  So this is about an ambitious young drummer (Miles Teller), wanting to be the next great musician.  To get there, you need to get the appropriate training, and at Shaffer Conservatory, there is an instructor (J.K. Simmons), who is renowned for pushing students to realize their full potential.  I don't even want to pussyfoot around this: if there is a movie from this year that thoroughly exceeded my already high expectations, this is the one.  I walked out of the theater floored, and I did not realize how much I was holding my breath until the end credits were rolling.  My interest for this first sparked when Korey Coleman of doubletoasted.com gave this the honorary rating of "your movie is so good, it made my life look like shit."  I have to say that I share the same sentiment.  This is tightly written, emotionally charged and scary good at every single turn.  This is roughly 100 minutes, but it only feels like 60 because it is so incredibly engaging.  All the credit in the world goes to the two actors, Teller and Simmons; the performances that the director was able to get out of them are nothing short of astonishing.  They play off each other so well that they deserve accolades on top of accolades.  Before I gush about Simmons like everybody else, let me first send some praise Miles Teller's way.  Simmons wouldn't be as good as he is if he didn't have somebody to reciprocate; acting is reacting, and Teller dishes it right back to him.  You can tell how much of himself he put into this, and you can feel every ounce of this character's frustration behind all the literal blood, sweat and tears.  In addition, there is a love subplot that makes total sense, given the direction this goes, and it perfectly highlights just how obsessive you have to be if you want to reach for greatness.  Because of the commitment of his performance, you realize just how competitive this field is, and just how high the stakes are.  Now on to what everybody is talking about: J.K. Goddamn Simmons.  I am not exaggerating when I compare this to Full Metal Jacket; remember how every line R. Lee Ermey barked at the recruits is so offensively off kilter that you have no choice but to awkwardly laugh?  Yeah, it's the same effect here.  He is so fierce, harsh and severe, you get chills every time he opens his mouth, and you genuinely pity anybody who is foolhardy enough to get in his way.  His performance is mesmerizing, and you can only describe it by using lofty words like commanding and dominating.  If he doesn't win an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor, it would be criminal.  On top of all that, the music in this is foot-tappingly infectious, and I have never wanted to listen to jazz music more than I did when I was walking to the car after watching this.  And I know this is just music, but there is palpable tension through every single plot development.  Because I was so engaged by this, I did not realize the passage of time, so when it gets to the pitch-perfect moment at the sublime crescendo to end the story, right when I thought, "they should end it here, but there's still 30 minutes left," it cut to black.  I cannot praise this movie enough, and there should be a picture of the poster of this movie in the dictionary, right next to the word "exhilarating."
Whiplash will give you chills throughout the entire film, whether it's the introduction to the main characters or the mesmerizing finale. Definitely a must-see movie.

Best Actor of the year J.K. Simmons. Best Picture of the year. This is a must-see. Exhilarating. Painful. Brilliant. You don't watch this film, you inhale it and hold it in as you would listening to the music behind its inspiration.

This is a role of a lifetime for Simmons  and he kills it.  From his vein popping  bald head to his uber-bully persona his Fletcher is scarier than any horror show this year or any year.  Miles Teller matches him beat for beat as the obsessed drum student. Both are serious Oscar contenders.  The script is taut as a drum snare and the music is as powerful as its characters. As a graduate of the Juilliard School, I can attest that this abusive relationship is implausible anywhere. Such a teacher would have been fired immediately for slapping a student hard in the face while demonstrating tempo. This film is a travesty and a bad message to young people in the arts. The film itself has excellent technical highlights, but the story is utter evil bullshit. Anyone endorsing it cannot be a serious musician, as this absurd garbage cannot be taken seriously. Amazing how many audience members love this. It means they know nothing about real music and art. Never in my entire life have I known or heard of any teacher behaving this way. Another damaging aspect of this garbage is that not ONCE did it speak of the MUSIC as being paramount. It was just about becoming "a legend." Newsflash: it's 2014. There are no legends in jazz anymore. You're lucky if you simply make a decent living performing, at best.  Worst story in a long time. I did find it entertaining though, in as much as I laughed a lot over the absurdity of it all.

Now for a more serious comment. The most disturbing part of this film is that NOWHERE does it even remotely illustrate the fact that music is much more than playing fast and loud until your hands bleed. Any real musician knows that technical proficiency can only come about through relaxation and control, not FORCE. Where was the essence of art in this film? Where was the beauty of music? Where was the joy of learning how to honor the composers instead of one's ego. THIS FILM IS A ANTI-ART FILM. IT IS EVIL AND MUST BE AVOIDED BY ALL SERIOUS MUSICIANS. I'd like to end by saying to Mr Damien Chazelle or whatever his name is: Go fuck yourself. Seriously. Shame on your sorry ass, selling your soul like this. But I'm not even sure you have a soul. You certainly have not one once of musicianship if this is the best you could up with as a film about music. And a double fuck you for the homophobic insults in the film. How long do you think a professor of a NYC arts school would keep his or her job while slinging anti-gay insults to students? THIS WAS THE MOST ATROCIOUSLY UNREALISTIC FILM OF ALL TIME.
